Title: Jennifer Aston
Comment:
My husband and I starting flying out of Muscle Shoals when Delta came in and offered service through Atlanta.  The convenience factor was wonderful and the pricing, compared to Huntsville, was close enough that it was justifiable to fly from here.  When we had to fly through Memphis, prior to that, we could never get any good connections, so we wouldn't do it.

When SeaPort airlines was at the Muscle Shoals Airport, we went and took a look at what they had to offer and were quite impressed.  Yes, the plane was smaller, however, they were offering several flights daily at a very reasonable rate of $98/round trip to Atlanta.

If you award the contract to GulfStream, you will be losing a lot of business, as the bookings over the past couple of years show.  The connections through Atlanta are so much better than through Memphis.  I just checked on airfare to New York (LGA)..we have  a trip planned in April, and, to get there from Memphis....I will have to fly from Memphis...to Atlanta...to New York and it will cost me $266.  Then, add the $150 to get from Muscle Shoals to Memphis....the fare is $416.  I checked the fares from Huntsville and I can fly Huntsville to Atlanta to New York for less than $300 on the same dates.

I think it would be a huge mistake for you to award a contract to GulfStream, a company that has recently filed for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy (http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/news/2010/11/05/gulfstream-airlines-files-chapter-11.html) and has recently been fined by the FAA for improper practices (http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2131185820090521), when you have the opportunity to work with a smaller company who offers much more personal service and is willing to work with the citizens of the area they will be serving.

It took us YEARS to get out of having to fly through Memphis....and have decent air service....and, now you're going to put us right back into the same mess we were in.  With this decision, you will be going backwards.

In the days of a strained economy...it is necessary for an inexpensive mode of transportation to allow people to go from one place to another. Title: MPC Visionary Concepts
Comment:
See attached file(s)

An engineering solution now exists that permits every rail carrier in the U.S. during the boarding and alighting process to provide, as presently required by applicable provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and implementing regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), nonsegregated full train length level entry boarding at every train car doorway with its corresponding platform edge on every train within a trainset stopping at any location in a train station along the train’s route regardless of track configuration thereby providing nondiscriminatory service to individuals with disabilities.

Therefore, there is absolutely no need to modify existing ADA regulations as proposed in the 2/27/06 NPRM.

Title: MPC Visionary Concepts
Comment:
See attached file(s)

Michael P. Chisena, as sole inventor, has been awarded by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office two (2) separate and distinct U.S. patents both entitled “Train-To-Platform Gap Mitigator.”

The first patent - Patent #7,784,406; Serial #12/116,078 was awarded on August 31, 2010.

The second patent - Patent #7,913,628; Serial #12/837,185 was awarded on March 29, 2011.

The device of said patented invention mitigates the gap width between the train car and its corresponding rail station platform edge. 

Said patented device simultaneously accomplishes the dual goal of permitting all rail line systems to achieve and/or maintain gap width clearance mandates set in law, by industry standards or recommendations and/or by the rail line system itself ensuring the safe passage of all trains through each of its stations within its system while providing gap mitigation as may be required by law or otherwise necessary to facilitate passenger safety in boarding and alighting trains regardless of size of any existing gap along its route resulting from any cause. 

By utilization of said patented device, all rail carriers can now achieve compliance with existing Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) gap width mandates and the U.S. Department of Transportation implementing regulations without the necessity of any modification to said regulations as presently proposed in February 27, 2006 Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (Docket # OST-2006-23985 / RIN 2105-AD54).

Title: Vicki Moreno
Comment:
I am a flight attendant for American Airlines. I'm writing because there has been two times on my flights in the last two months where a single passenger has brought on two "emotional support" animals on my flights. The animals (both small dogs) sat on the passengers lap during the entire flight, at times, moving to the neighboring passengers lap.

The emotional support animals are becoming very popular. It is the best way to have your pet outside of the carrier during flight as well as avoid any fee for transporting them. Plus, there is no limit, so you can bring all of your animals with you on the full flights. In fact, everyone can bring all their animals. There is no limit.

This needs to change. There is no reason why one passenger needs more than one animal to provide emotional support...and if there would be...in that extremely rare case, then that passenger could go through the proper channels at the particular airline to discuss their unique issue (or travel with a second person).

My airline says their hands are tied. The DOT should address this. While I understand the reason you passed this rule re: ESA, what was a well-intentioned idea has hurt more than it's helping...bc many people don't want to sit next to two animals on a full flight (and they are all full these days).

Please change this rule to limit ESA's to one per person. Not a "service animal" limitation in general, just an "emotional support animal" limitation, since those animals are basically just your pet, traveling outside of their cage, on your lap during the flight.

Title: Peggy Marie Alexander
Comment: Besides the obvious stress and loss of income...you do realize to pick up the slack there will be MORE trucks out here and MORE inexperienced drivers out here. Sounds counterproductive to me..Why would the experienced drivers stay out here and work 10hrs an day when we can go home and work 8hrs a day and save $600 a mth on the cost of living out here..With all the down time we have with no regulations at the shipper and reciever where we sit sometime 8hrs NOT GETTING PAID...we would actually make more then being so conmtrolled and under a microscope 24/7 out here!!!!...DOT itself states over 50% of truck vs car accidents is the cars fault..Maybe you should utilize some of your resources and time to educate the motoring public and regulate wait times at shippers/recievers..I SEE THIS BEING A BAD AND "DANGEROUS" thing!!!!

Title: Mary Barhydt
Comment: These regulations are reasonable and fair to both the flier and the airlines.  More importantly, however, is holding the airline accountable for what they do not provide.  For example, I understand that there are minimum penalties to be paid to bumped passengers. Bumped passengers who arrive at their destination less than two hours later than planned should get the value of their one-way ticket back, up to about $400 in cash. However the airlines are masterful about avoiding this penalty as they fill a plane with standbys, even knowing that there are passengers arriving on their own planes with connecting tickets, then leave the gate early so that connecting passengers 'miss' their flight. As they are not 'bumped', they are not compensated. Any new laws should address this type of practice.

Title: Anonuymous
Comment:
It is my opinion the existing tarmac delay rules and compensation for weather delays are adequate.  

The compensation for airline passengers delayed due to maintenance issues does need to be enhanced.  It is ignored by the carriers in an attempt to keep costs down.  But the net impact is a major disruption for passengers.  For the first two weeks in January, Delta airlines managed to have serious maintenance delays for every single plane I attempted to take either booked or on standby because of missed connections due to maintenance issues.

Airlines cannot control the weather, just how they handle it.  But the airlines are in control of their maintenance and have been failing miserably.  The impact to the passengers is just as bad as when delayed due to weather but is unforgivable because it can be controlled by the airlines.  I propose any aircraft delay due to maintenance greater than 1 hour should require $100 refund per passenger.  Maintenance delays due to maintenance in excess of 2 hours is a refund of $200 per passenger.  Maintenance delays in excess of 4 hours is a full refund to the passengers.  Flight cancellations due to maintenance are full refund for passengers plus hotel expenses until the airline can get the impacted passengers to the target destination and an addition $60 per day for meals during the delay.

Title: M. A. S.
Comment:
I am in support of banning all peanuts from planes.  Before you chalk me up as an alarmist, let me explain...
As a mother of children with multiple food allergies (boy-shellfish; boy-peanut, treenut, egg) I am of the opinion that kids with allergies need to learn to manage them and live within the world as it exists.  I do not promote living in a bubble and our family does eat out.  However, I also teach my boys to use extreme caution when eating foods I have not prepared for them by reading labels EVERY TIME, or if we are out, telling the wait staff of their allergies.  I tell them that they should also ask to speak to the the chef or manager if they feel wait staff seems to lack specific understanding of food allergies or if they feel uncomfortable for any reason.  They carry Benadryl and epi-pens with them, in case of an emergency - and my older son, because he is not always with an adult, also carries a cell phone.  Finally, they know that in the event of a reaction, they can LEAVE immediately and someone will get them help immediately - at the nearest hospital if necessary.  
THE ABILITY TO LEAVE AND GET HELP DOES NOT EXIST ON A PLANE, which is the primary reason I am in support of banning peanuts on all airplanes.  Those allergic to peanuts tend to have the most severe and life threatening of all allergic responses and the fact that they are on every plane, (thus traces are on every seat, armrest, etc.)  is terribly dangerous for those who are allergic.  A peanut free zone or peanut free flight does NOT eliminate those traces and therefore is not protective.  PEANUTS SHOULD BE BANNED FROM FLIGHTS.

Title: Karen
Comment: I like peanuts.  I want to eat them on airplanes.  Let airlines make peanut free zones if they have to.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am highly allergic to cats and dogs.  If peanuts are going to be banned from airlines than I demand that all cats and dogs be either banned from aircrafts or at minimum, flown below the aircrafts.

Comment: I recently flew for the first time since developing peanut/nut allergies four years ago. I flew regularly before developing the allergy but have avoid flight since. It seems it would be in the airlines/passengers best interest not to have to divert an aircraft because a passenger became anaphylactic.  There are reasonable options out there. I'm baffled as to how accomodations can be made for other disablilities but this one is so blantenly disregarded.  I'm sure if the head of the organization had a peanut/nut allergic child, the rules would be different as one does nut understand the seriousness unless they have a personal experience with it.

Title: Andrew Phillips
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

We appreciate this opportunity to submit comments on this notice and strongly support setting up this on-line complaint form for the public to electronically submit aviation service-related complaints against air carriers. Deaf and hard of hearing people struggle every day accessing information in airports and on air carriers as critical information is often relayed auditorily and is not available in visual formats. This includes but is not limited to information about: flight delays and cancellations, baggage claim numbers, gate changes, and emergency information.  To enhance the quality, utility and clarity of the information collected, we suggest the following:

1. We urge the DOT to make this complaint webpage fully accessible to all deaf and hard of hearing individuals by providing all written instructions for filling out this complaint form in American Sign Language (an online video of someone signing the written information.) Agencies like the FCC and IRS have led the way in providing online information online in ASL as many deaf and hard of hearing individuals are not fluent in English and need information translated into ASL.

2. We urge the DOT to accept complaints in ASL as many deaf and hard of hearing individuals are not fluent in English and are best able to communicate through ASL. This would mean allowing deaf and hard of hearing individuals to submit video complaints in ASL. The FCC accepts certain comments in alternative formats (see 47 CFR § 1.1803.)

By allowing deaf and hard of hearing members of the public the ability to comprehend complaint information and file complaints in ASL, this complaint form will allow one of the most marginalized groups the ability to effectively file complaints. Section 504 requires that federal agencies provide information made available to the public accessible and ensure equal access for people with disabilities.     


Sincerely,

Andrew S. Phillips, J.D.
National Association of the Deaf

Title: Art D. Unger
Comment:
Re: Docket DOT–OST–2011–0025

Since climate change threatens our planets survival, environmental protection and energy conservation are critical.
A few Americans may already have died due to climate change; I refer to the fact that West Nile Virus did not occur here until 1999 and could be a result of global warming.

Mass transportation tends to require less fossil fuel and hence produces less carbon dioxide than private automobiles. Therefore rail roads are preferable to highways and to air transport. For trips over 2,000 miles, air transport may be the most efficient mode.

Thanks, Art

This would not change the rules, just make it more understandable, and  benefit the inspectors and operators. Plus if the inspectors are training from liquids to gas the rule numbers decimal are identical. I have spoken with many inspectors in different states and they ALL agree.

Title: Duane E. McKee
Comment: The CDL drive times were intended for over the road truck drivers.  The drive times hinder snow removal in several ways.  Cranberry Township simply does not have enough employess to complete snow removal operations when a storm last more than 20 hours. TheTownship's residents expect to have safe and passable roads and the drive time rules make us use non-CDL drivers with less experience and lighter equipment.  This adds additional time to clear the roads, additional cost on materials and overttime.  The residents are getting a lesser service.  Snow removal operations should be exempt from the Policy.  thank you.

Title: Chris Metka
Comment:
For locally sponsored projects (such as Transportation Enhancements and Safe Routes to School) the cumbersome, time-consuming requirement that accompany federal projects need to be removed or at least streamlined. These processes are foreign to local sponsors, such as borough managers, township supervisors, or local school staff. 

Programs of this nature are typically small and have very minimal environmental consequences, but even attaining appropriate right of way, utility clearances, and other clearances are very cumbersome. 

Also, the consultant selection procedure is very time consuming and expensive relative to the project. A small, locally sponsored sidewalk project worth $200,000 may take 2-3 years to implement due to all these burdensome requirements. 

These time-consuming and inefficient regulations are a poor use of federal funding. States need some flexibility in how they implement projects, especially for these smaller, community-based projects.

Title: Deborah Stange
Comment:
I would like to submit a comment for consideration that the size standards for DBE regular dealers be changed.  

The current revenue cap is based on a company's gross receipts, which can be significantly dependent on material costs. West Fuels is a DBE fuel distributor and is greatly affected by the dramatic increase in fuel prices.  At today’s prices, annual revenues for current contracted business will be approximately 30% higher than expected, and will likely exceed the cap. 

I propose that the DOT follow the SBA size standards which are determined by revenues and number of employees per industry classification.

It is not logical for us to lose our DBE certification status due to increased costs, rather than a true increase in business.

Title: Emil August Biendara
Comment:
HAZARD ELIMINATION SAFETY
PROJ. CRITERIA REVISION
WORK TYPE WITH NO ACCIDENTS Work Type proposals with no accidents is against the guidelines of FHWA.
SAFETY INDEX The Safety Index Calc. undervalues the cost of accidents, & has fatalities & injuries as a single category. The Accident Reduction needs definition.
MIN, QUALIFICATIONS With no minimum requirement, much is wasted on unrealistic applications. Proposals have values of 0.05 when the cutoff was 300. As many as 90% of the projects do not qualify.
LOW $ LIMITS It is a political decision to limit project funds to a pointlessly low amount.
REVISING ESTIMATES Low-Ball estimates are selected, only to return requesting additional funding or a reduction in project scope.
PROJECT DELIVERY Awarding a project to an Agency behind schedule on an existing project is poor stewardship.
Improvements to Selection Criteria
Select proposals based on a revised SI ranking, the cost of the project & the history of accidents with the potential for safety improvements.
An Agency with an existing project behind schedule is disqualified from submitting new requests.
Revise the Safety Index Calculation to reflect real accident costs.
Revise the cost of accidents to segregate minor injuries from major ones & set fatalities as a separate cost.
Revise the SI with the Expected Accident Rates for the types of work.
Define the Accident Reduction to the Expected Accident Rate.
Rank all proposals in one continuous SI priority list.
A minimum qualifying SI rank will allow no proposal to be accepted with a score of less than one half of that SI score.
Raise the grant maximum to (10% - 15%) of the total funds available to the State for that year.
Fix grant cost in the application and no adjustments can be made until the project is completed as scoped at the Agency’s expense.
On completion, the Agency may request extra funds with a revised SI calculation.  If the Project qualifies for funding in the year it was selected, extra funds will be OK'd.

Title: Brent Hugh
Comment:
The Missouri Bicycle and Pedestrian Federation appreciates the opportunity to comment on existing rules and regulations impacting implementation of the federal Safe Routes to School program.

We are a coalition of bicycle, pedestrian, and trails groups in Missouri with an affiliated membership of over 30,000 across the state.  Most of those organizations are involved in grants involving bicycle, pedestrian, and Safe Routes to School projects either as advocates, citizens supporting these projects, or as direct grant recipients.

In addition, we organize and operate the Missouri Safe Routes to School Network, with over 100 agencies, individuals, and organizations working to support Safe Routes to School programs.  Many of these agencies and organizations have applied for and/or received Safe Routes to School grants and one of the primary purposes of the Network is to work to improve the implementation of the federal Safe Routes to School program and grants.

We heartily endorse the comments about this program and solutions offered by the Safe Routes to School National Partnership, particularly these sentences:

"Unfortunately, there is a key challenge hindering construction of these projects—delaying the installation of safety improvements, increasing costs, and reducing efficiency. The challenge is that Safe Routes to School projects are governed by Title 23 regulations, which are primarily targeted to large-scale, complex, federally-funded highway projects. Both local award recipients and state coordinators have indicated that the time and effort needed to comply with these regulations is high given the small size and scope of the typical SRTS award (the average size is approximately $150,000).

"As a result, obligation rates have lagged. As of December 31, 2010, states have awarded approximately 71% of available funds and have obligated 43% of available funds."

We have heard this same comment and sentiment from SRTS grant applicants from across Missouri.

Title: Michael H. Graef
Comment:
Deficiencies of NOAA & NMFS 
Thank you for this opportunity to express my views on this issue. I have been a for-hire charter boat fisherman since 1989 in Destin, Fl. In 2004 I bought my own 6 pack charter boat (I have Federal Reef and Pelagic permits. With that said and done I have a vested interest in the rule making by NOAA & NMFS. In fact here are a list of Rule changes since 2044:

1.Red Snapper Season shortened from 189 days (April 15-October 31) 
to 54 days (June 1st -July 23rd). Hmm that's a reduction of 325%
  a. Bag limit decreased from 4 per person (including Captain & Mate 32 total) to 2 per person (excluding Captain & Mate  12 total) Another reduction of over 70% Yet every year since 2004, except 2010 (Deepwater Horizon) recreational fishermen exceeded their TAC!
  b. 2010 Dr. Crabtree stated "Red Snapper are no longer being overfished" 
  c. 2011 will have a TAC increase but wait a minute the average size of Red Snapper is 5.3# and the increase in days will be taken away to reflect bigger fish!
  d. Why are we using pounds for recreational TAC? Makes more sense to me use numbers of fish to get an accurate and not best guess available to really know how many fish are being caught.
2. Trigger fish went from 11" overall length to 12" to the fork,  less than a year later 14" to the fork length.
3. Red Grouper was declared undergoing overfishing then a year later using the same DATA was  not  being overfished. Same crystal ball (DATA) was used for King Mackerel and Vermilion Snapper.
4. Greater Amberjack went from 28" fork length 1 per person bag limit (including Capt. & Mate) to 30" 1 per person (excluding Capt. & Mate) that's a reduction of 30%. Then why is it we met our Quota (recreational) for the first time in October 2009 at which time NMFS closed down Amberjack.

Title: David B. Forster
Comment:
Currently the FRA, FHWA, and FTA each have their own regulations regarding NEPA, and
-currently, for ARRA projects, FRA does not accept the NEPA documents completed for the other agencies, as in if a state DOT has a completed NEPA document for a train station done under FTA or FHWA, the FRA requires that the document be redone as a FRA document
-it would be prudent and timely for FRA to be able to accept these other documents as fulfilling NEPA requirements with just the addition of an addendum covering any specifics that FRA would additionally like to see ....this would greatly expedite the review/approval process for some of the ARRA projects which have already cleared NEPA under either FHWA or FTA

-Also, currently FHWA environmental regulations allow CEs from a list of specific project types, and they also allow CEs for projects not listed specifically, but with a minimal amount of documentation can be shown appropriate for the CE status (often called "documented CEs").
FRA regs do not currently allow this type of CE....it again would be very prudent to modify FRA environmental regs to all "documented CEs"

Title: Orange County Transportation Authority
Comment:
Mr. Neil R. Eisner
Assistant General Counsel for Regulation and Enforcement
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Dear Mr. Eisner:

Thank-you again for the opportunity to present remarks regarding the Orange County Transportation Authority’s (OCTA) Breaking Down Barriers initiative at the Department of Transportation’s (DOT)  March 14, 2011 public meeting regarding Regulatory Review of Existing DOT Regulations (Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0025).  During my remarks at that meeting, I made reference to a report being prepared for OCTA by Ms. Susan Binder and the firm of Cambridge Systematics.  This report compiles information from over forty interviews with highway and transit project implementers, as well as several national trade associations which represent these entities.  As I said at the public meeting, this report contains the details regarding  proposals which OCTA believes will greatly assist in expediting project delivery. Although the report is still being finalized, the Draft Final Report is complete and was reviewed by our Board on March 28, 2011 with unanimous positive reaction. 

Therefore, in order to meet the comment deadline for this docket, I am submitting the Draft Final Report for your consideration.  Appendix D to the report provides a table of the recommended changes to expedite project delivery, noting where regulatory changes may be needed. 
OCTA expects that the report will be finalized within the next few days, at which time we will make a copy of the Final Report available to DOT, separately, and as a further submission to this docket if it remains open for comments.

Sincerely,

Darrell Johnson
Deputy Chief Executive Officer
Orange County Transportation Authority

Title: Welltec, Inc.
Comment:
The current FMCSA regulations divide commercial motor vehicles into two groups:  GVWR 10,001 to 26,000 (no CDL required) and GVWR over 26,000 pounds (CDL required).  With the exception of the CDL, those drivers operating the first group (10,001 to 26,000 GVWR) must follow the same rules as operators driving heavy truck-tractors.

Usually, the first group of vehicles are operated by private motor carriers of property.  Those companies do not transport goods and services for hire.  Their primary function is not trucking, but (in the case of Welltec) to provide oil/gas well down-hole services with CMV operation as a function of going from the shop to the well site with people and equipment.

It is illogical to equate oil/gas well service field engineers with for-hire over the road truckers driving heavy trucks.

I suggest that the FMCSA create a department that would regulate that small goup of drivers (10,001 - 26,000 GVWR CMVs) with less stringent HOS rules and RODS requirements.  Our drivers may only drive 3 -4 hours/day, but may work at the well site for 2 - 3 (or more) days.  It seems unnecessary to regulate non-truckers the same way as the 18-wheeler drivers.

Title: National Conference of State Legislatures
Comment:
The National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL) is writing in response to the Department of Transportation’s request to comment on development of a plan for periodically analyzing existing significant rules that may be outmoded, ineffective, insufficient, or excessively burdensome.

In reviewing existing significant rules during this process, NCSL urges the department to incorporate into the review process a comparative analysis of the costs estimates for state and local governments developed during the rulemaking and the actual cost of implementing the final rule.  The analysis should include a review of what went into the estimates as well as how accurately they reflect the real world costs associated with implementation. For instance, did the cost estimates for the regulation include both the cost of implementation as well as on-going costs?  What federal funds were provided for state and local implementation?  Did they cover the costs?  Were there under-funded or unfunded mandates?   Could the regulation be modified to minimize the fiscal impact on state and local governments?

NCSL also recommends that the department review the level of consultation that occurred in the development of any significant regulation. Consultation with state and local governments should be conducted early in the process, prior to a document being sent to the Office of Management and Budget. As part of the department’s plan to review existing significant rules, NCSL encourages the department to reach out to organizations like NCSL to determine if meaningful consultation occurred during the development phase.

The attached rail routing rule (Hazardous Materials: Enhancing Transportation Safety for Hazardous Materials Shipments--PHMSA-RSPA-2004-18730; RIN 2137-AE02) is an example of where “meaningful” consultation was not conducted.

NCSL looks forward to working with the department as this process moves forward.

(See attached file.)

Title: Missouri Department of Transportation
Comment:
Section 407.105 includes Street and Highway Functional Classification. The guidelines currently in use have not substantially been reviewed or revised in over 40 years.  HPMS Field Manual has been recently revised and new implementation is beginning.  Functional classification is related and should also be reviewed.  Urban Area boundaries might have more utility for transportation planning as an "urbanness" index assigned to US Census geography, or to features inside the US Census features.
Since 1991, Functional classification has been used in some cases solely as a funding tool, and objective trip length data for classification is difficult to obtain and measure.  The Functional classification system needs to be more robust to accommodate more classes to provide better utility at the local and regional levels to perform sound planning.  Normalization of classes and better objective criteria would help unify data used by RITA and by the Bureau of Transportation Statistics.
Section 500.101 should include a component for GIS for definitions and scope.
Section 656 Carpools and Vanpools currently have a gap in coverage of incentives for not-for-profit, non-profit, and government agencies.  The Commuter Benefit Program provides good incentive for these activities with reimbursements and tax credits for taxable organizations, but there is no provision to provide reimbursement or incentive for untaxed entities.  Some sort of program should be added to provide incentive for these organizations to participate.

Title: John C. Keppel and Michael L. Miozza
North Central Texas Council of Governments
Organization Name: North Central Texas Council of Governments
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Heath Maddox
Comment:
I write in support of FHWA Guidance for Bicycle and Pedestrian Provisions of Federal Transportation Legislation, updated on April 4, 2007, which states the following:

"Due consideration" of bicycle and pedestrian needs should include, at a minimum, a presumption that bicyclists and pedestrians will be accommodated in the design of new and improved transportation facilities. In the planning, design, and operation of transportation facilities, bicyclists and pedestrians should be included as a matter of routine, and the decision to not accommodate them should be the exception rather than the rule. There must be exceptional circumstances for denying bicycle and pedestrian access either by prohibition or by designing highways that are incompatible with safe, convenient walking and bicycling.

I have seen comments submitted by AASHTO recommending that FHWA should rescind their guidance on the meaning of “due consideration” on the grounds that it places 
 undue burden on states to justify exceptional circumstances when not including provisions for bicyclists and pedestrians in a project.  

As a transportation planner who has worked on local bicycle and pedestrian projects for over ten years, I strenuously object to AASHTO’s proposal to roll back federal regulations directing state DOTs to ensure that their projects include provisions for pedestrians and bicyclists.  The existing regulations are consistent with my own state DOT’s policies and directives, but this should not be taken for granted.  Many state DOT’s lack similar regulations, so federal rules are crucial to providing incentives to accommodate walking and biking as a routine part of all transportation projects.

Title: Jerry Foster
Organization Name: West Windsor Bicycle and Pedestrian Alliance
Comment: I'm writing to support the FHWA's guidance regarding the presumption of bicycle and pedestrian facilities in federal projects, not just consideration. We must have a sustained commitment to build out a complete multi-modal transportation network, and the weaker interpretation will result in serious gaps in our walking and biking infrastructure.

Title: Elizabeth M. Gaines
Comment: Mr. Babaian,  as a common citizen and frequent traveler of the struggling airline industry, I submit to you that a proposed ban on utilizing vapor technology on flights or any other public transportation is absurd.  I have been using the vapor technology for several years now with any adverse affects.  There is no smoke therefore there is no danger to any other person near me of inhaling anything much less any dangerous chemicals.  Public safety is important.  That was the reason for the ban on public smoking and there can be no confusion between vapor delivery and the smoke produced by a cigarette.

Title: Jeffrey D. Blackburn
Comment: I smoke. I support the ban on cigarettes in aircraft due to the limited ventilation. I do NOT support the proposed ban on electronic cigarettes. As far as I know there have been no studies regarding the chemical properties of the vapor from these devices. To simply ban them because they look like cigarettes is silly. If there is science to indicate a health problem, use it. I have used these devices and can attest to the fact that they put off no odor. If we are going down the road of banning things that others merely do not understand, then may I suggest banning excess perfume on passengers instead, since that actually IS offensive to other passengers and has been linked to triggering migraine headaches and allergy attacks when sensitive individuals are exposed in unventilated areas. In my opinion this is rule making for the sake of rule making.

Title: David A. Camras
Comment: In regards to the outlawing of electronic cigarettes: I think such a ban is ridiculous. It is not a cigarette but an electronic device. Might as well put game boy in the same category. (I am not a smoker, just think this is overreach.)

Title: Niki Rose
Comment: The U.S. Government seriously need to rethink its policies on electronic cigarettes. They have been through numerous testing and there are no negative passive smoking affects. You are supposed to be one of the world's leading countries, you have been given a device which could save thousands of lives a year, promote it, not ban it! Start ldirecting the world again...

Title: Daniel Scott Camper
Comment:
It is entirely illogical to ban electronic cigarettes from airplanes without an *cause* for alarm.  Actual scientific evidence of harm needs to be supplied before a ban is put in place.  One test of one type of cigarette does not make "scientific evidence."  In addition, be aware that electronic cigarettes are not all the same, and it is entirely possible that a single brand can deliver different elements to the user.  A broad ban against all electronic cigarettes, regardless of the actual chemicals used in their cartridges, would be illogical as well.

If a ban is created, everyone will understand that DOT is taking this action at the behest of the tobacco companies.  As mom always said, when an action appears to make no sense, follow the money.  In this case, it's perfectly obvious what is happening here.  I urge you to take the high road and use common sense, instead.

Title: Charles Jackson
Comment: I have been an Airline Station Manager for over 15 years.  Banning electronic cigarettes on aircraft seems absolutely ridiculous to me.  No argument proposed holds any water.  If you are worried about air quality, then go on board any aircraft and take a deep breath next to the lavatory.  If you are worried about other passengers "feeling" like they might be getting toxins blown at them then you should worry about the passenger whos perfume can be smelled from 10 rows away or the guy next to you that didnt shower.  If America still represents a "free" country with our tens of thousands of Laws and regulations then I'd hate to see a country that isn't free.  To each their own.  But enough wasting your time trying to appease the squeaky wheel group just because they dont have jobs and have time to lobby for new laws.  I cant imagine anyone truely cares if someone is breathing in and exhaling water vapor next to them.  This just distracts policymakers and wastes their time when there is real work to be done.  Make a good decision on a new lap child policy.  Holding a 15 day old baby on your lap is legal during take offs and landings.  They should be in a car seat as they cant even hold their head up.  Fix real problems.  Take this proposed rule and trash it. Thank you for your time.

Title: A. Ko
Comment: Traditional tobacco cigarettes were baned due to second hand smoke.  Electronic cigarettes do not emit 2nd hand smoke.  Stop this new rule.  Instead educate flight attendants on how to tell the difference between tobacco and electronic cigarettes.  Will there be a future ban on chewing tobacco and chewing nicotine gum?

Title: S. K. Ying
Comment: This is NOT a well thought out rule.  Electronic cigarettes do not harm other people.  There is no second hand smoke. DO NOT PASS THIS STUPID RULE

Title: Lisa Ann Johnson
Comment: I agree that electronic cigarettes should be banned on aircraft. While the makers of such devices say they are safe, the devices are not regulated, so who knows what will be found to be true once studies are completed? The vapor may contain chemicals that harm others, similar to second-hand smoke -- nobody knows. Also, allowing anything that heats up onto an airplane is cause for concern. If smokers really can't go a few hours without nicotine during travel, the most unintrusive way to obtain it is to use a nicotine patch. I know I wouldn't want their water vapor blowing in my face on an airplane.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Until the vapor emitted from electronic cigarettes can be proven to be hazardous, there should be no Federal rules barring them from aircraft. Airlines are free to restrict the devices as they please. This should suffice until there is evidence that more action is needed to protect public safety. 

Since this rule will likely go into effect despite public opposition, I would suggest that, at the very least, the language be made clear that the devices themselves are not banned from aircraft. As a user, I would like to keep the device in my possession (as I am currently allowed to do with cigarettes) so that I may use it upon exiting the aircraft.

The use of an electronic cigarette has allowed me to completely stop smoking. I am convinced that it is much less harmful than cigarettes. By restricting their use on flights, you are making it more difficult for those of us who are trying to be healthier.

As for complaints by the public, I am not convinced that they are as widespread as this rule suggests. Which is more offensive: an odorless vapor that has not been proven to harm anyone or a stinking smoker who has just smoked 3 in a row before boarding the plane so that he can go the entire flight without smoking?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes use nicotine, a drug said to be more addictive than heroin and known to cause cancer.  i do not want my body to be subjected to the second-hand effects of this dangerous drug, either by smoke or vapor.  Usage of electronic cigarettes should not be allowed on airplanes.

Title: Brian L. Davis
Comment: Banning Electronic Cigarettes on airplanes is obscene. The devices do not cause the alleged second hand smoke dangers of traditional cigarettes and do not produce an offensive odor to those around the user if a non tobacco flavored cartridge is used. If you are going to ban e-cigarettes then perfume, cologne, bad breath, gum, food, drink, farting and burping should also be banned. Stop unfairly targetiing people who use legal nicotine. When is it going to be enough? There are far larger problems in this country than this.

Title: Renee Denice Bidstrup
Comment: There is no reason to ban electronic cigarettes from airplanes. You're not smoking tobacco. There is no smell, there is no smoke (only water vapor that quickly disapates, there is no refuse. Electronic cigarettes are a way for a person to "smoke" without bothering other people, which is why cigaratte smoking has been banned from almost anywhere. If this passes, what you're saying is that it's not the tobacco you are banning, you are banning anything that may look like a cigarettes. Ridiculous. I've heard people say if they see someone smoking an electronic cigarette then they'll think they can smoke the real thing. Ridiculous! When you announce no smoking, you say only electronic cigarettes can be used. People know the difference. Electronic cigarettes are a way for people to eliminate tobacco use, in some cases even quitting altogether. Smokers have been limited in where they can smoke to the point where there's almost no place left. So the electronic cigarette comes along for smokers, and it eliminates all the problems of regular cigarettes and now you're going to ban those. It's unbelievable that the government thinks that regulating an electronic alternative to tobacco is a bad thing. I know they've got much more important work to do.

Title: William W. Lange
Comment:
Hello-I am a frequent flyer who has logged over 4 million passenger miles during my business career. I can't believe that electronic cigarettes weren't banned years ago on all flights. The process involves heating up liquid nicotine which creates a vapor that is then inhaled. I am not concerned about this part of the process as I believe every person has the right to commit suicide. The problem for me and my fellow travelers is the exhale part. The tobacco lobby would have us believe that users only inhale. Just because the exhaled vapor doesn't have a foul smell doesn't mean it OK to breath it. Please pass the proposed legislation for the sake of the majority of Americans who fortunately aren't hooked on this very dangerous drug. thanks you. 

Bill Lange

Title: Carl McBee
Comment: I feel that the ban on electronic cigarettes to be unnecessary. Other than people who are unfamiliar with them treating them like regular tobacco products, what is the downside to having them? They release water vapor. As they pose no known health risk to the public and cause no known damage to flight equipment, I see this as an issue for airline policy and not for the government. Bans of products like this that cause no harm are no different than banning red shoes on flights or certain perfumes because they might offend someone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
They are not cigarettes and produce no smoke.
Why on earth would you do this, and per what rationale?

These stop people from smoking cigarettes and should be encouraged. This regulation is not a good idea, and I strongly oppose it on the basis of sound reasoning.

Title: Mark Amans
Comment:
The reason for this change is "...because of the increased promotion of electronic cigarettes and the potential health and passenger comfort concerns that they pose in an aircraft."

Have e-cigarettes been shown to have a potential health impact?  If not, then this reasoning makes no sense.

This sounds to me like a knee-jerk reaction and not very well thought out at all.

Title: Robert Craig Smith
Comment:
This seems a little silly.  I'm not a smoker, but I wonder if next we can ban Asthma inhalers, eye drops and perfume.  Surely perfume is just as dangerous, if not more-so, than the vapor that is produced and inhaled by an e-cigarette smoker.

I am against this ban.

Title: Mary Bankston
Comment: An airplane is a closed environment. Passengers should not be allowed to make others uncomfortable whether that is talking on cell phones or horrible body odor. The emissions of electronic cigarettes may be only water vapor, but the device is a delivery mechanism for a deadly drug. I don't want any part of it. Let's just all be polite and respectful for the next few hours until we get out of this tin can, okay?

Title: James E.
Comment: i think that banning cigarettes on flights is unconstitutional. if there is no proven harm from the vapors these cigarettes emit, what would be the point of banning them? just to trample our freedom??? for fun? i mean really, if there is no harm in it, then what is the issue. if another passenger doesnt like the smell, too bad. we live in a free country and if i dont like the smell of their cologne of perfume i can do nothing about it so why should they be able to stop others from using items they like.

Title: Hunter Weiss
Comment:
Why is this necessary?  Why must we impinge further on the civil liberties of Americans.
The second-hand smoke from electronic cigarettes is neither carcinogenic nor otherwise harmful and there is no actual flame that might potential ignite an on-board fire.
Why is the TSA so ignobly ensuring that Americans lose yet another liberty aboard airlines?
Should it not suffice that passengers are nearly strip-searched ere we board a flight to provide a morning full of fun for the woefully under-educated and under-trained TSA agents?
I would far prefer if the head of the TSA would focus on important elements for safety, such as conducting a proper background check on all agents or finding methodologies for ensuring that test bombs don't continue to pass through security checkpoints.
Why is there such an abhorrently significant focus on electronic cigarettes?
Yours truly,
Hunter

Title: Eric Thomas Munn
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,


I object strongly to the proposed rule that would ban the use of 'electronic cigarettes' on flights. 

The term cigarette is misleading as no smoke is produced by the said device - it is therefore not harmful to other passengers.

This proposed ban sounds like a knee-jerk reaction that is absolutely not in the best interests of passengers or airlines.

Yours Sincerely.

Eric Munn

Title: Nicholas Charles Casler
Comment: Primarily due to the fact that the vapor produced by the electronic cigarette is largely composed of water vapor, and is not actively aromatic, this ban should not be passed.

Title: Jessica
Comment:
I do not agree with this rule at all. Electronic cigarettes do not pose any health risk to airplane staff or other passengers. It is extremely stressful to fly these days, and many airports do not have smoking lounges at all. 

If electronic cigarettes are banned, smokers will have a very hard time on planes. They may sneak them in and use them in the bathroom, which would lead to increased work for security staff. Their use is not detectable by smoke alarm, so the bathroom is probably where this would happen. Other people need to use the bathroom for its intended purpose.

Please do not waste staff time by making them enforce this silly rule. I am sure airport and airplane employees have better things to do than search out and stop e-cigarette use. 

Let this be handled on a case by case basis. If a passenger's behavior is disruptive, he or she can be asked to stop. There is no need for a general ban. All it will do is cause extra bother for passengers, flight attendants, and security staff.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is simply idiotic. E-cigarettes are the same as traditional cigarettes in name only; they contain none of the harmful secondhand side-effects.  Anyone even halfway educated about them would know this.  But this measure is not meant towards them; it is meant to appease the ignorant masses that store their brain in their ass.  Quit trying to regulate peoples' lives and quit trying to pass laws to appease ignorant morons.

Title: Patrick
Comment: The only reason I see given for this is to "enhance passenger comfort and reduce any confusion".  To me, the only comfort being enhanced is that of busybodies who are annoyed with e-smokers enjoying themselves.  As for the confusion, you can reduce confusion with information, rather than curtailing individual liberties.  This is just lazy and un-American.  We don't ban activities just to reduce annoying complaints about the practice.

Title: James Arron Tecumseh Sinclair
Comment: The banning of electronic cigarettes on commercial aircraft is unnecessary and meaningless.  The device poses no risk to health of passengers in the form of any second hand substance, it does not burn, contains no tobacco, and has no noxious odor.  The release from this device isn't smoke, like an actual cigarette, but a water vapor.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Smoking of tobacco on US flights has been banned. These passengers are using miniature humidifiers. They are not "smoking." The title of this document is inaccurate. 

Banning harmless water vapor would be add to the discomfort  nicotine addicts -- and won't enhance the comfort of the rest of us one bit.

Find something less ridiculous to regulate.

Title: Stephen Little
Comment: I have been a smoker for over 10 years now. I do not deny the medically harmful effects it has on myself, nor the effects of second hand smoking. That said, I do not agree with the proposal to ban the electronic cigarette. I have attempted inumerable times to stop smoking, and for the FIRST time, I feel that I may be able to succeeed. This is a very appropriate and necessary alternative to traditional smoking. I get to continue the same physical habits that smoking creates but all the while reducing the harm to my body and harm to others. I do believe that more research is warranted for both sides. In my observation with family, friends and co workers who do not smoke; they appluad and encourage this use as they see it as the means to an end. Also, they claim that the "vapor" creates no odor, smell or uncomfortable feeling for them.

Title: Brian Richard Demers
Comment: This is absolutely ridiculous.  Stop trying to regulate and ban items that have no proven negative health effects.  So much for freedom in America, huh?

Title: Ralph J. Andrews
Comment: Absolute NOT!  Do not allow "electronic smoking" devices to be used on planes.  This is ridiculous as everyone has "survived" just fine without smoking ANYTHING on planes for years.  Also, wouldn't that be just one more delay in passing through security as well?

Title: Gene Birkholz
Comment:
I'm strongly anti-smoking, but this just seems like it's going too far.  After all, the whole point of a smoking ban in an enclosed space is to protect ME (the non-smoker) from the harmful effects of someone else's cigarette.  I haven't looked into e-cigarettes closely (for obvious reasons) but it seems that the nicotine delivery system effects only the person sucking on the stick.  Why NOT allow them on aircraft?

If having the ability to get their fix (without harming my lungs or generally bothering me) makes smokers less irritable or agitated when they fly, then I'm all for it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This proposed ban on electronic cigarettes on airplanes is without merit as it not based scientific evidence but on public opinion. If there are no harmful effects of these types of cigarettes to passengers or to aircraft then there is absolutely no reason to ban them from the craft. The ban proposed here seems to be to ensure the comfort of passengers and that is simply not a plausible reason to ban a product. Also, the department of transportation is a bit hypocritical regarding this ban, since there is no proposed ban on alcohol products. Indeed, if we are so concerned with passenger comfort, we should seek an alcohol ban as well. There have been many documented instances were alcohol has affected the behavior of passengers to the point where flights had to be diverted. Yet we continue to offer these products in aircraft. This move to ban electronic cigarettes by the DOT is without merit and should be suspended.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should NOT be pernitted on aircraft.  They should be confiscated at the security check point.  I've recently had the distinct displeasure of having dinner in a restaurant with a diner many tables away smoking an electronic cigarette.  The vapor produced after the inhale is very obnoxious, can be smelled from quite a distance and questionable from a health risk.  I think that electronic cigarettes should be treated just like regular cigarettes. Please ban electronics cigarettes from aircraft.

Title: Andrea L. Anderson
Comment: The purpose of an e-cigarette is to deliver nicotine into the body... It is a vehicle for nicotine delivery, much like nicotine gum or a nicotine patch is.  Water vapor is inhaled and exhaled, not smoke, not tobacco, not harmful byproducts... WATER VAPOR - which then evaporates.  There is no odor, it is not smoke - to ban the use of e-cigs because they LOOK like cigarettes, APPEAR like it's real smoke etc is ridiculous.  An e-cig is essentially an inhaler, delivering a product into the lungs which is absorbed into the blood stream.  To ban e-cigs on aircraft you would have to ban all types of inhalers.  What is needed here is not a ban on e-cigs but education on how these are NOT an actual cigarette, and that there is no harmful "second-hand" smoke that others will be exposed to.

Title: Rachel V. Betta
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0044]
RIN 2105-AE06

Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft

I am in full support of this regulation to ban the use of Electronic Cigarettes on airplanes.

No one should be exposed to the chemicals in the vapor created by these devices without consent.  There is not sufficient evidence that the problems associated with second-hand smoke are not associated with the e-cigarettes.

In addition, designs that mimic actual cigarettes can lead to confusion and could cause significant disruption on a flight.

Thank you for your consideration and I urge you to enact this ban of electronic cigarettes on aircraft.

Title: Jason L. Snowden
Comment: I'm a non-smoker, and pro-tobacco bans, and even I think this is unreasonable. The Federal Government should be *encouraging* alternative healthy choices to reduce the number of people smoking tobacco. I can think of no justification for this whatsoever. If anything, it should be allowed and encouraged, and then frequent fliers who smoke tobacco would be more likely to try them, and once they found them equivalent, they'll stop smoking the carcinogens. Please rethink this regulation.

Title: Katie Dwyer
Comment: Banning electronic cigarettes on flights is the stupidest thing I've ever heard. It affects no one but the smoker. What's next? Banning nicotine lozenges? How about if someone is using the patch to quit smoking?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
You have got to be kidding me.  A safe, totally non-harmful to others method for smokers to get some relief on a long flight and it's going to be banned to "avoid confusion?!?"

As a former smoker I can sympathize with the discomfort of air travel.  These "cigarettes" are a huge plus for everyone.  Smokers can get their fix, and non-smokers suffer no ill effects what-so-ever!  

Leave people alone.

Title: Joshua Swift - Comment
Comment:
I can understand a lot of the concerns about people "vaping" electronic cigarettes during a flight. But it doesn't exactly make sense to ban them on all planes. I always thought the original reasoning behind banning original cigarettes was because of the dangers from second smoke. There are no second hand dangers related to electronic cigarettes. There's no smell, and no fire hazard.
As an individual who has switched from traditional cigarettes to electronic cigarettes I have to say I never really planned on using one during a flight. This is mainly because most of my flights are less than two hours. My main concern is that this may give electronic cigarettes the same kind of stigma that traditional cigarettes have.
If you are going to end up banning electronic smokes during on planes, can it be met "half-way" and make sure that electronic cigarettes can be used in the airport and terminals? I think many e-smokers out there would be fine with that arrangement. Not "vaping" on a plane is one thing, but still having to go outside and then back through security again during a stop over/flight change to use it is what would anger me the most.

Title: Patrick C. Hughes
Comment: There is no evidence that E-Cigarettes pose a harm or danger to anyone other than the user.  It is very offensive that the government would even consider banning these devices on aircraft.  There is no rational for this ban.  Please leave the citizens of this country alone.  If you really lack anything useful to do then quit your jobs.  The country need the money.

Title: Dave May
Comment: I have yet to see any evidence that "electronic cigarettes" have any negative effect, or indeed any effect at all, on people in their vicinity while they are being used. Vaporized nicotine travels from the device directly to the user's lungs, with no residual vapor in the air and none of the harmful byproducts that led to tobacco burning being banned. Disallowing the use of "electronic cigarettes" in no way benefits public health or safety. The devices should be studied impartially; if they are found to cause harm to people in their vicinity then they should be banned from flights, and if they are found to not cause harm then they should be explicitly allowed on flights.

Title: J. Beach
Comment:
In my opinion this is a complete waste of time and tax dollars.  The electronic cigarette is a smoking cessation devise.  The user gets a dose of nicotine and exhales what is essentially water vapor.  There is no smell and no harm to the people around the person using the inhaler.  

The government and other regulatory bodies need to stop over-regulating to make themselves feel useful.  Unless you are preventing harm to other people then you have no need to waste my tax dollars putting into place frivolous regulations.  Show that these devices cause some form of harm that must be prevented or let it go.  I am beginning to believe that the USA is a Nanny state.

Title: Tim Smith
Comment:
This proposed rule is grounded in ignorance, fear, and disbelief.  There are no studies that conclusively show electronic cigarettes are harmful, either through first-hand use or second-hand inhalation of vapor.  In fact, the primary ingredients of the "smoke" juice are the same ingredients that have been used in fog/smoke machines for years. If you ever had a Halloween display that used a fog machine, you have inhaled the "smoke" from an electronic cigarette.  All three liquid bases are common food additives used in a variety of pharmaceutical formulations. Propylene glycol, the current dominating liquid base, has been utilized in asthma inhalers and nebulizers since the 1950s, and because of its water-retaining properties, is the compound of choice for delivering atomized medication.
Don't place a ban on relatively new technology before taking an honest look at it.  A child puffing a novelty cigarette filled with talcum powder releases more particles into the air than someone using an electronic cigarette.  The proposed rule judges the book entirely by its cover and is a fine example of how lawmaking should not work.

Title: Chris J. Dopuch
Comment: The proposed ban on electronic cigarettes is ridiculous.  The items in question pose no danger or inconvenience to other passengers.  The only issue is that other passengers might be confused by the e-cigarette..."Is someone smoking next to me?"  Are we really going to outlaw something b/c some people just aren't technologically savvy and might confuse this with a "real" cigarette?  We might as well outlaw the patch itself on planes, since it does pretty much the same thing as an e-cigarette, deliver nicotine to one person with no impact on anyone else around.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The proposal to ban electronic cigarettes on flights is the absolutely most idiotic political garbage I've heard all week, second only to the moronic lies and "ideas" spewed by the republicans at their little debate. 

Electronic cigarettes do not produce carcinogens, unlike aircraft, and the water vapor produced from them is no more harmful than that produced by a hot shower or a fresh cup of coffee, which is to say, it is not harmful at all. 

Banning e-cigarettes on air travel would demonstrate a wild disregard for the health of the citizens of this country, encourage smokers who have quit to return to using harmful tobacco products, increase the national debt because of associated health care costs resulting from use of those tobacco products and decrease ticket sales. Great plan! 

That "confusion" about what electronic cigarettes are is mentioned as a reason to ban them is totally pathetic. The simple answer to that is to educate people. It's really not that complicated. The LA Times laid out what an e-cigarette is and does in a single sentence: "....electronic cigarettes do not burn tobacco but use a lithium battery to heat up a liquid nicotine solution, creating a vapor that can be inhaled to deliver the chemical directly into the lungs....."

Title: Andrew Varnes
Comment:
Are you serious?

I oppose this vehemently. There is no positive gain from this ban whatsoever. All it does is create a resentful environment, because at this point air travel regulations are bad enough.

Electronic cigarettes cannot harm or cause discomfort to other passengers. 

You would be taking a method of making a group of people happier while flying away for no legitimate reason whatsoever.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: If it HONESTLY poses no risk then who really minds? Just individuals who have some misplaced sense of self importance that feel a need to ban smoking everywhere.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: There is no reason to pander to those wanting to ban these harmless devices. You've already beat down on smokers beyond what the government should be doing. Citizens already have to submit to police state powers in the TSA. Banning ecigs is just another way to make the citizens of this country bow down. Good bye freedom.

Title: Paul Menard
Comment: The banning of electronic cigarettes on airplanes is wrong. These devices provide those addicted to Nicotine a safe alternative to cigarettes. Additionally, these devices are smoke free, do not emit any odor, and do not inhibit the quality of life for people sitting or standing in close proximity to someone using an electronic cigarette. Please strike down this law. Protect the rights of people that are seeking to find a safe alternative to smoking cigarettes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The e-cigarettes absolutely need to be banned.  I don't want to smoke, never have, and never will.  And I particularly do not want to "smoke" someone else's exhaled waste products.

Title: Peter Gareth Walker
Comment:
This is idiotic in the extreme. The vapors from electronic cigarettes are about as harmful as a lungful of the vapor from a fog machine, or steam from a pot of boiling water.

There are more important things than people using electronic cigarettes on airplanes to worry about. File this proposal where it belongs: File 86, for idiotic shit that should never have been proposed to begin with.

Title: Troy Lee Mauldin
Comment:
The intent to control and regulate every moment of a person flies in the face of the freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States. In every case the courts and government entities should minimize the intrusiveness of our lives. The use of an e-cigarette is no more dangerous to the average traveler than an inhaler for asthma. Probably less dangerous since it is not a pressurized container. If you intend to implement this regulation then you should also ban the use of asthma inhalers, insulin inhalers, or any other device that delivers any substance via vaporization or ingestion by breathing including the very air we breathe. Think and use common sense and do not overreact to every fear that one person may have. we are still a land of majority rule and not minority reaction. Over regulation plagues us and harms each and every citizen. 

Thank you.

Title: Haley Parker Chivers
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

The notion of banning electronic cigarettes for the sake of public health in regard to aircraft passengers by method of enforcing their regulation as identical to traditional tobacco smokers is both unfair and cruel. Those who choose to imbibe nicotine by electronic cigarette do not represent the same crowd of individuals that are commonly found to smoke cigarettes. They are frequently former traditional smokers who are seeking a healthier alternatives but are plagued by an addiction that has clearly demonstrated neurological effects.

The merit of this effort is ideological at best and serves no genuine benefit to public health. These are individuals already aspiring to help themselves and others who are being targeted to accommodate enforcement. It is understandable that confusion among those who are poorly informed is undoubtedly an issue but that is not justification for this treatment.

I myself AM NOT A SMOKER and I have a father who has smoked ALL of MY life. I understand the good intentions of this effort and support the idea of discouraging smoking. At the same time I understand that the HABIT OF SMOKING is a neurological need for long time users. The emotional duress caused by those like my father who have been unfortunate enough to succumb to the HABIT AS A NEUROLOGICAL NECESSITY for emotional stability is not only unfair to him but to family which endure this stress.

Quite frankly even if there WAS any form of measurable impact to health comparable to a traditional cigarette, I would much rather lose five minutes of MY LIFE than endure a five hour flight with someone struggling the neurological withdrawal symptoms. Yet, as I presently informed by the sciences, the vapor imbibed it and expelled from an electronic cigarette user to be no more toxic to myself than the air of any busy American city.

I would not wish undue stress on my lawmaker in session. I should hope you would not wish it on a well-meaning citizen in transit.

Title: Sebastian Smith
Comment: As a non-smoker, I am absolutely comfortable with allowing Electronic Cigarettes on airplanes, in restaurants, etc.

Title: Joe Rella
Comment:
This proposal is ridiculous. It smacks of non-smokers pushing their political agenda, rather than a means to enhance public safety. If the FDA can find something toxic about the vapor from electronic cigarettes, then maybe this is a discussion that should be held at that time. However, to my knowledge, there has not been a single scientific study showing that these devices are harmful to those around a user.

Without proof that these devices can harm others, banning them is simply a political move, and has no place masquerading as a public safety issue.

Title: Thomas J. DePaul
Comment: This rule is not needed. The e-cigarette can be banned by the individual airlines if they determine that their customers would be bothered by it's use. This is just another example of government overreach into a problem that doesn't exist.

Title: Michael Hernandez
Comment: This is absolutely ridiculous. It appears as though your department has started banning items just for the sake of having more regulations. Does this actually make people feel safer when traveling? I don't even smoke electronic cigarettes, but this stuff is *water vapor*. Exactly what type of threat does this pose to either nearby passengers or our national security? Perhaps we should spend more time fine-tuning the regulations that are already in place (and overwhelmingly abused) rather than sensationalizing another non-issue.

Title: Tim Lamour
Comment:
Electronic Cigarettes should NOT be allowed on any commercial flight.  

When an electronic cigarette is activated and inhaled by the addict, and then the smoke (vapor) is exhaled, it leaves a plume of chemical vapor waste that is then passed on to those seated next to the "smoker".  I see no difference between tobacco cigarettes and electronic cigarettes – neither should be permitted on aircraft. 

Please ban electronic cigarettes from being carried onto aircraft.  They should be confiscated at the security check point.

Title: Christopher J. Esser
Comment:
These products cause no harm to any bystanders at all.  None.


There is plenty of medical evidence that they do little to no harm to even the consumer of the product.  The use of nicotine in this manner is no more harmful than consuming caffeine in your coffee or tea.


This ban will do nothing aside from increasing tensions on flights for those who are nicotine users, causing further tensions with the flight crews.


This is the least harmful alternative to smoking that is available on the market today.


There is no rational foundation to this ban whatsoever and it would only further the growing negative mythology surrounding these products.


My only interest is that I am a user of electronic cigarettes and they have permitted me to completely quit smoking after 27 years of trying other methods.

Title: Elizabeth Lucille Gibson
Comment: There is no good reason to ban Electronic Cigarettes on flights within the United States.  These devices cause no harm to those adjacent to their use.  Furthermore, this ban could be used as a precedent to encourage other federal agencies and private entities to also prohibit their use.  This is a public health issue, and you have an obligation to support the option that does the least harm to those using nicotine and those around them.

Title: Paul Scott
Comment: As someone who got bladder cancer because of second hand smoke from my parents, I don't tolerate tobacco products of any kind being used in my presence. If someone smoked anything anywhere near me on a plane I would forcibly remove the offender's smoking device in order to make him stop.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is something amazing to me. As a user of an electronic Cigarette, restricting the use of it at any point seems to be a punishment for improving not only my health, but improving the air space of those around me. From Smokers, to Non-Smokers, everyone who has seen me use this device has commented that it must be nice to be able to use it where ever i like and not have to worry about it bothering people. The issue is that some people are determined to make an issue of everything to the point where i have had people start coughing as they walk by from the "smoke" only to be made to look foolish when i point out that its an electronic cigarette. For the people who think its going to be bad for them, perhaps they should look into the device more, and for the Smokers who want to ban it, perhaps they should instead just get one for themselves so they dont have to be angry that we who have made the choice get to have something where/when they can't. Point being, is that the liquid is roughly the same as the stuff that they use to produce fog out of fog machines. Never hear much complaints about those... isn't there somewhere else perhaps we could be focusing the time and effort on instead of this?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Unless it is shown that the vapor's produced by Electronic Cigarettes contain harmful chemicals that affect those nearby this should not be implemented.

Title: Matthew H. Dawdy
Comment:
Lack of evidence disproving a negative impact does not lead to the need for a ban.

"We are unaware of sufficient studies on the health 
impact on third parties from these vapors to conclude that they would 
not negatively impact the air quality within the aircraft and/or 
increase the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and 
crewmembers."

Have there been studies on every brand of perfume available on the market?  Hairspray?  Fumes from all types of food that can be carried on?

You should not ban every substance in existence merely because of a lack of a study.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I don't see how you can legally consider adding electronic cigarettes to the smoking ban.  Electronic cigarettes, which people associate with tobacco products due to the name, don't produce smoke.  They produce an odorless vapor.

How is this improving customer comfort?  If anything, it does the opposite.  Growing up as a military dependent I spent a lot of time flying.  The most common problem I saw, other than screaming children, was smokers trying to smoke in the bathroom and being overly irritable.

Banning a product that has no health risk for bystanders is asinine.  You are not solving a problem by doing this.  You are creating a problem.  Considering our legislative track record, I expect this to pass, but hopefully, somebody out there will get their head out of that dark, stinky place and stop this proposal.

On a side note, dismantle the TSA and start profiling.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a bad idea.  How can you possibly prohibit something that isn't harmful in anyway?

Title: Gregory Daglis
Comment:
As electronic cigarettes have not been prove to be of any danger to the general public.  The ferederal government should NOT ban them from any flights domestic or international.
Federal resources should be put to more vital issues like unemployment and improving the economy and stop wasting their time on random issues such as this.  
The airlines should be left to make these decisions on their own.

Title: Kenneth Edward Welch
Comment: This rule should not be passed. I use a electronic cigarette, but would not use it on a plane out of fear. I do not use it in resturants out of fear. It causes no harm, yet I have fear. My fear is some over zealous person approaching, and imposing their will upon me. This rule is a back door attempt to justify a attack of a new industry. Tell the law makers to give the industry some time to make more money, then they can hire some lobbyists. That way congress can get their rightfully earned money, and create panic. Then the crazy over zealous people of the world can be happy to have fear back. I honestly think a rational person does not have a problem with the eletronic cigs. If the law makers pass this rule, then it will create bureaucratic monster that will crush a new business. The reason? Because a flight attendant can not tell the difference. That makes no sense. The reason? Passengers have rights. Tell me how a little steam is infridging on a passengers rights? The reason? Because probably one idiot wants to impose their will on the world, and received the support of some politician who is getting leaned on by their tobacco lobby.  Stop this rule!

Title: Bob Fisher
Comment:
I have quit smoking cigarettes after 57 years.  I now "vap" smoke electronic cigarettes ad there is a noticeable improvement to my smelling, breathing and overall well being.  I have used my electronic cigarette in many restaurants, bars ad a multitude of public places and have never had a complaint or even a negative response to them.  I have had many inquiries as to what they are
and interest shown by smokers and non smokers alike.  I have referred numerous people to the company where I purchase mine and they too have given up regular tobacco products including cigars.
I believe this really helps the public environment from invasion of 2nd hand smoke.
Please don't take all of our rights away from us.

Title: Chris Bower
Comment: This is ludicrous. I use electronic cigarettes on flights every time I fly to cope with how awful flying economy is now days. Its not harming any body for me to slip off to the lavoratory and take a nicotine break. I rarely, if ever use it in my seat, and if I do I hold the vapor in my lungs until it dissipates so that nobody even knows I'm using it. There is no discomfort to other passengers, even if vapor was being released. E-cig vapor certainly doesn't stink the way cigarette smoke does, and in the majority of cases smells pleasant.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
E-cigarettes release nothing but water vapor. If you're going to ban e-cigarettes because some people feel like they're inconvenienced, then I would much prefer that you ban alcohol.

Far more problems are caused by drunk and unruly fliers than will EVER be caused by someone emitting additional water vapor.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: what will be regulated next? the food

Title: Michael Steinberg
Comment: As a physician, my concern is that we have no idea what chemicals are found in e-cigarette vapor.  These products are entirely unregulated and untested.  Until we can determine that the vapor from these products will not harm others in the enclosed and recirculated environment of an aircraft, it is the duty of the US government to protect the safety of its citizens.  This duty demands that e-cigarettes NOT be allowed to be used on aircraft.

Title: Shawn Gamble
Comment: Why ? you already ban cell phones that do nothing ? are you actualy looking out for the public safty of trying to be the nanny to every one in America. This is without a doubt the dumbest use of federal time and money I have ever seen. there is no reason for this.

Title: James Scott Jones
Comment:
I think it is badly thought out to ban the electronic cigarettes. This product will save the lives of millions of people and save governments billions of dollars in health care. To treat a user of this product the same as smoker is absurd.

There is no second hand smoke, there are no toxins (nicotine by itself is not a toxin), there is no smell, and there is no harm done. 

 To ban this product because some lazy flight attendant, waiter, whatever, does not want to take to the time to explain to ignorant, self righteous ignoramuses, that this is a sage product, it really going beyond the pale.

Title: Nathan Scott Sinclair
Comment:
While standing at the security checkpoint in Houston for the third time since arriving, it occurred to me that I was surely not alone. Having to cross out of security in order to smoke outside only to turn around and reenter security is absurd.  I couldn't help think that a smoking lounge in the airport would reduce the line at security, speeding up check-in. 

While sitting on a plane watching a fellow passanger become more and more agitated over nothing, it occured to me that banning water vapor from a plane is absurd.  Banning it from a train is even more absurd.  Allowing a harmless device onto planes and trains that cuts down on passenger anxiety would be a godsend.  

It would speed up the security checkpoints, and ridership among smokers would also rise.  As it is, I am more likely to drive somewhere than take the train because I can smoke an e-cigarette all I want without harrassment. If this country wants to encourage train ridership, if it wants to curb tobacco SMOKE related illness, if it was sedate peaceful airline passengers; we will end this nonsense.

Title: Anonymous
