Comment: This proposed ruling would put people that are trying to stay away from the harmful chemicals of regular tobacco cigs and put them in that area where they would have to breathe in second hand smoke. Thils ruling would esentially be like taking a normal non smoker and telling them if they want to chew gum they must do so in the designated smoking area and live with the fact that they must breathe in second hand smoke in order to chew gum. It is a joke and I for one think it is ridiculous that people that are trying to do something much healthier than smoking regular cigarettes are being punished for doing so. Please do not allow this to pass into law.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I will mention that I do not smoke, and I also do not like the smell of secondhand smoke. The rule seeks to prohibit something that is, arguably, a manifest goal of anti-smoking groups, presuming that goal is to eliminate tobacco smoking. If the reasoning behind a ban on smoking tobacco products on a plane is to prevent secondhand smoke injuries & complaints, and also to prevent creating an uncomfortable environment for fellow passengers, this rule does not achieve those ends. However, electronic cigarettes were designed to assist smokers in smoking cessation, and also to allow smokers who do not wish to quit to have the ability to facilitate a personal choice without disturbing those in their vicinity. The byproduct of electronic cigarettes is water vapor, which is literally no worse than the combined exhalations of a full passenger jet. Further, this rule seeks to prohibit one harmless byproduct, with no consideration of any other, actually harmful byproduct; an individual with a minor upper respiratory tract infection, who spends the flight coughing, is sending vast quantities of particulates into the air, possibly infecting and sickening others - yet there is no rule against flying when sick. An individual with a child who refuses to quiet down, and cries incessantly throughout the flight could be damaging to fellow passengers ears and mental health - but there is no rule against flying with children under age 6. Similarly, this rule does not actually serve any purpose, and only serves to appease those individuals who would ignorantly claim that it bothers them. It is justifiable only when rules are implemented that regulate personal hygiene, parenting behaviors, and like. Meanwhile, it deprives those individuals who did the homework, and made the switch to electronic cigarettes, knowing that there are ZERO effects to persons not consuming the electronic cigarette.

Title: Brian Michael Sweatt
Comment: I would be against banning electronic cigarettes on air planes.  Their contents are propylene glycol, some small amount of nicotine that dissipates quickly, and an electrochemical cell to vaporize the two items.  It seems pointless to ban them.  What will we ban next?  Items with garlic in them?  Stinky cheeses?  Thank you for your time.

Title: Danial Gene Woodford
Comment:
This is not needed and is only another grab for power over other people.  Electronic cigarettes are no more offensive or harmful than the steam off the cup of coffee from the guy wearing too much after shave sitting next to you.  We can't take away everything just because someone doesn't like it.  There are no studies showing harm from electronic cigarettes and in fact the studies I have seen show no detrimental effects to other people.
Rephrase this ban to include all items that produce steam, then see how many of the supporters of this rule change their tune.

Title: Laurie Jill Laidley
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should not be banned on airplanes. There is no harm to others, as would be from second-hand smoke from a traditional cigarette. The problem is the people that see the electronic unit and think of it as a regular cigarette. This is just ignorance by uneducated people. As a user of electronic cigarettes, I think that they should be permitted. Or other air travel annoyances should be eliminated, such as perpetually crying babies, people who sit next to you and talk loudly on their cell phone, and other annoyances. If someone chooses not to smoke, that's their choice. If you choose to smoke, that's also a choice. Electronic cigs don't put out anything besides water vapor. The nicotine has already been absorbed by the user. These people trying to ban them need a check up from the neck up!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I can understand banning regular cigarettes as they produce smoke that others in the vicinity would inhale. However, it makes absolutely no sense to ban e-cigarettes as they do not produce any smoke and would have no effect on the surrounding air.

Why ban e-cigarettes, which effect no person except the user of the e-cigarette?

Would you ban chewing tobacco? The same principle applies. Chewing tobacco is a smoke-less nicotine delivery system, just like an e-cigarette.

Hopefully you reconsider your position on banning e-cigarettes, not just on aircraft, but anywhere.

Title: Rob Guerrero
Comment: I think people should not be allowed to use electronic cigarettes on an airplane. It eliminates the problem of people not wanting other passengers to use them. What about security risks? Are we going to have to wait an extra half an hour at bag checks?

Title: Donna Lee Benevides
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes (even though I do not use them) can save lives for those who cannot give up nicotine. Many people have quit smoking by using them. Please see this article: http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/2011/sep/14/smokeless-nicotine-cigarettes-government

There will always be those who cannot quit using nicotine and banning a safer alternative is telling them to "quit or die". Some people can not quit, so banning safer alternatives is equivalent to giving them a death sentence for not quitting. 

If we truly want people to stop smoking, they need affordable, workable alternatives.

Title: Richard M. Isbell
Comment: Since there is NO observed threat to ANYONE on the Aircraft, why should this device be banned? As a Airline pilot I can see NO benefit to this proposed regulation other than make some folks feel good. I would go as far to say that the use of these devices are of benefit to Aircrew in that they relieve the anxiety of the smoking public.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Banning electronic cigarettes on airplane flight or anywhere is
ridiculous.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a new ex-smoker who was able to quit thanks to e-cigarettes, I find this proposed regulation ridiculous. The only byproduct of electronic cigarettes is harmless water vapor. It would be the equivalent of banning asthma inhalers. 

I understand that it may be difficult to police different models of e-cigarettes and that the public perception of smoking may lead to conflicts on airplanes. But the more sensible route is to address these on a case-by-case basis, rather than banning these completely non-harmful products outright.

Title: C. Drake
Comment:
I agree that electronic cigarettes should be banned from all locations in which regular tobacco products are banned (including smokeless chewing tobacco), in airports and on the air carrier.   It should be considered consistent with the current policy prohibiting cigarette smoking, regardless of the form in which it takes.  
         Aside from the obvious health reasons which electronic cigarettes still contribute with the nicotine delivery, it would present an issue for the flight attendants to have to differentiate between tobacco and electronic delivery devices and constantly have to monitor it (and other passengers' complaints) while trying to perform their regular responsibilities.   I would be concerned that they might be distracted, and this distraction will cause more stress on the staff and passengers, which we cannot afford when there are other security issues needing constant monitoring.

Title: David A. Saunders
Comment:
There has been no evidence suggesting that second-hand "vape" is in any way detrimental to the health of any nearby. The water vapor that is expelled from a "vaper's" lungs is only slightly more potent than the water vapor expelled from every other humans' lungs who has ever drawn breath. There is no smell, and the vapor dissipates almost immediately. 
I can't stand the smell of traditional cigarettes, but find absolutely no reason to infringe upon the rights of another person to use a personal vaporizer in close proximity. They are inoffensive and, thus far, are not proven to be the slightest concern for bystanders. This is fueled by ridiculous paranoia. Don't shun the possibility of an advancement that could help smokers and the people around them. It is not sober, sane, or prudent to begin illegalizing things due to unfounded, untested suppositions.
This is a shame.

Title: Norman Briggs
Comment: This proposal is absurd. The "smoke" exhaled is nothing more than water vapor posing no threat to anyone. What the user of the product chooses to do is not the business of anyone else.

Title: Amber Van Hoosen
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes are not tobacco products and should not fall under the smoking ban.

Electronic cigarettes are an electronic device that produce an inhalable vapor via heating, rather than producing smoke via burning.  The vapor may or may not contain nicotine.  There is no fire risk and no combustion byproducts exhaled by the user of an electronic cigarette.  The vapor that is exhaled by an electronic cigarette user is mostly water vapor, and thus i no more dangerous to other passengers than normal exhaled breath.

Other non-tobacco nicotine delivery devices include gums and patches.  The form of the electronic cigarette mimics that of a tobacco cigarette for ease of use to tobacco cigarette users, but the form does not dictate the function.

Key points: 
~ Electronic cigarettes burn nothing and produce no smoke.
~ Electronic cigarettes contain no tobacco.
~ Electronic cigarettes are not hazardous to non users.

Therefore, the proposed change to the existing airline smoking rule should not be implemented.

I am not a smoker, but this proposed change is ridiculous.

Title: Raymond David Davis
Comment: As a former smoker I am against any attempt to allow the use of any type of "cigarette" in any enclosed public space including aircraft. why should the person seated next to someone using one of these electronic cigarettes be subjected to a dangerous chemical (nicotine).

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
electronic cigarettes should not be allowed on aircraft any more than regular cigarettes. It is promoting the use of regular cigarettes as well as being a security problem for the TSA. Another device to be checked through security scans that could hide unknown threats.

RL
Los Angeles, CA

Title: Patricia Renee Falk
Comment:
This is ridiculous. To not put too fine a point on it, a solution was found to give smoker's their addictive fixes (oral and nicotine) without harming themselves or people around them, and immediately the idea is to ban them in public places as though they were exactly the same? The only potential issue I could see is that some of the flavored cartridges have a smell to them like mint or strawberry, but seeing how many people wear too much or far too little in the way of personal toiletries, this wouldn't be any different.

Just leave e-cigs alone, doing otherwise is just needlessly tormenting people for no good reason.

Title: Danielle Sally Berggren
Comment:
Until it is proven that electric cigarettes are harmful to passengers, they should not be banned from aircrafts simply because other passengers find them "confusing".

I am more than willing to put down my electronic cigarette if there are children nearby or someone says that the vapor gives them a headache, but it is better than my addiction is sated and I'm not a raging pain the in butt.  I love these as a safe alternative to the hazardous chemicals in tobacco products.

Listen to your people, not the tobacco lobbyists that are hurting from their profits going down in lieu of this wonderful new product.

Thank you.

Title: Lisa N.
Comment:
Banning electronic cigarettes because they look like cigarettes & cause confusion is unacceptable. Please explore the evidence found through multiple scientific studies - which clearly shows that the vapor emitted is not a threat to anyone.

Creating a law/ or a ban based on what people perceive to be harmful (but actually is not) shouldn't even be up for debate. 

There needs to be proof that it is harmful through scientific fact & evidence before banning something based on prejudice alone.

Title: David Samuel Manley
Comment:
Stop it! Stop it! Stop it! Stop passing legislation that takes RIGHTS away! STOP DOING THIS!!! This is not NOT your job. 

Protect rights!

This product does not cause any harm. It releases water vapor. WATER VAPOR!

If the airlines want to ban it, that is their choice. Not yours, not governments. This is not how it works.

It is in the choice of the business. NOT GOVERNMENT!!!

Once again, THIS IS NOT YOUR JOB!! STOP DOING IT!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This rule would only make sense if it were being put in place temporarily while the effects of secondhand electronic cigarette vapor were examined. Since this is not the case, I must say I find this rule stupid; the reason cigarettes aren't allowed on planes is because they're harmful, not because they smell bad. Or would you guys like to ban farting on planes too?

Title: Jonas Michael Wood
Comment: Honestly it seems the only reason ciggerettes had any real right being banned on airplanes were due safety concerns related to fires starting on airplanes.  I find the arguement of minor annoyance of other passanengers to be unconvincing, at worst non-smoking flights could be instigated.

Title: Gabor Laufer, M.D.
Comment:
Cigarettes were banned on airplanes because of the alleged health hazards, irritation by the exhaled smoke emitted by burning tobacco products and the smell which irritated some people.

E-cigarettes are cigarettes only by name. Those are not really cigarettes, nor they are burning tobacco products by any stretch of imagination. They have no smell, no burning tobacco products, no proven health hazards by the exhaled, mostly water vapor. The inhaled nicotine (much smaller quantity than normal cigarettes contain) are absorbed by the users lung, and the exhaled water vapor, if it contains any nicotine at all, must be negligible amount of trace chemical. 

Banning those on airplanes would be equivalent banning airplanes altogether, because of the increased amount of cosmic radiation. It other words, ridiculous. 

Dr. Laufer

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Don't we have enough regulations in this "Free" country. 
And just because you don't have enough information on something it does not give the government the power to ban it.

Title: David Roth
Comment: I am against banning electronic cigarettes on airplanes

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
GET OVER IT!    PEOPLE ARE TRYING TO COMPLY WITH YOUR STUPID RULES, AND EVEN THAT IS BEING SHOT DOWN BY SOME IDIOT THAT DOES NOT AND NEVER WILL UNDERSTAND AN ADDICTION!
THE FINAL TRUTH IS THIS:
PEOPLE WILL CONTINUE TO SMOKE NO MATTER WHAT OR WHO PUTS THEM DOWN!!!
JUST LIKE ALCOHOLICS!!!!!   GO AFTER THEM FOR A CHANGE!

WE ARE SICK AND TIRED OF THE MEDIA AND ALL GOVERNMENT PEOPLE GOING AFTER US SMOKERS!!!!

THE MORE YOU DO SO, THE MORE WE WILL SMOKE!!!!!

SHUT UP AND LEAVE US ALONE AND THERE WILL BE A PERCENTAGE OF US THAT WILL QUIT OUR OWN WAY!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I do not smoke cigarettes, or electronic cigarettes, nor do I know anyone who does.

I would fully support this ban if you could convince me that other passengers smoking electronic cigarettes causes me harm in some way.

Until you have proved the danger of second-hand "smoke" from electronic cigarettes, there should be no federally mandated rule against smoking them on an aircraft.

Title: Michael Bennett
Comment: Ban them!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While I understand the urge to ban Electronic Cigarette usage on planes, I feel the issue is more education to non users. Why not, rather than ban them, support initiatives to research and understand Electronic Cigarette advancements and then make an informed decision.

The banning of E-Cigarette's is a knee jerk reaction to a new product that looks a lot like a product we all know a lot about: regular cigarettes. However, they are so different that it warrants it's own classification. 

It makes sense that the public would be worried about E-Cigarettes as they misunderstand what they really are. I am an E-Cigarette user and it has been a life changing/saving experience. For once a smoking alternative is available that works this well and is not filled with cancer causing carcinogens. They need to be explored, studied and understood so that sound decisions can be made in terms of their regulation, instead of sudden overreactions.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The nanny state that you have/are creating is out of control. how does this product harm anyone on the flight? Don't you have anything else better to do? This is insane. Please ban chewing gum, because it makes me uncomfortable! While you're at it, please prohibit all screaming children from flights. Now that's a hazard!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I do not support this rule.

This ban is based on ZERO scientific evidence that there is a problem with E-cigarettes.  My wife used E-cigarettes to quit smoking.  Note - I am a non-smoker.

Title: Samuel
Comment: Would there be any plan in place to lift the electronic cigarette ban if science were to conclusively prove that they do not put anyone else at risk, that there is no 2nd hand effects like those of traditional cigarettes?

Title: Omar Lyle
Comment:
I believe this rule to be absolutely preposterous. Electronic Cigarettes ("eCigs") do not fit under the definition of tobacco products as they do not contain tobacco.

The name "cigarette" is only added to this device for marketing purposes.

The purpose of the 2000 Rule prohibiting smoking on air carriers was mainly due to the health issues associated with second-hand smoking. There is no data showing similar health issues associated with eCigs. 

The function of an eCig is that of vaporization of water and additives (which may or may not include nicotine - the effective chemical in tobacco cigarettes). Smoke is not a byproduct of eCigs as with conventional cigarettes, but rather a fine water vapor. The effects of this vapor on the consumer and/or surrounding persons has not been deemed 'harmful' which adds additional doubt to the purpose of the proposed rule change. 

As it currently stands, no evidence that these devices harm anyone exists. To ban their use on air carriers is equivalent (in my opinion) to banning soft drinks on flights. Both are items which are used/consumed by passengers that have no direct effect on surrounding parties. 

The excuse of "confusion" is not justification for such a rule change. If the device is not affecting the passengers or the aircraft, then attempting to regulate it becomes a waste of both time and money.

Title: Arthur Joseph Hawley
Comment: These devices do not contain the tars that are the cancer causing agent of cigarette smoke. Until some study can be done to prove that these are a danger to other passengers, there is no good reason to force a nicotine addict to go through withdrawal symptoms for the length of a commercial flight. Have there been legitimate complaints, or is this just some power play by individual control freaks who hate the idea that someone is doing something they don't approve of? Is it just the odor people find offensive? Will you outlaw perfumes, or require mandatory showers for people with unpleasant body odors? Is it not enough that we have to have our bodies and our privacy violated in the name of safety just to travel about the world? Must you exercise control over every one of our actions and the state our of comfort? Leave these people alone. You have made them pariahs in almost every public place. Let them have this one last personal freedom.  The fumes from the car ride to the airport and the jet exhaust do more harm to the health of everyone in the world in one flight, than all the electronic smokers in the world combined. Stop being so hypocritical and put this in it's proper perspective. Doesn't anyone in this country remember how to mind their own business and grant people their freedom of choice? Do we have to legislate every human behavioral choice just because we can?

Title: Jamie McLaughlin
Comment:
Please reconsider banning e cigarettes on airplanes.  By the way, the rule is mistitled:  One does not "smoke" an electronic cigarette. There is no issue with second-hand smoke, since nothing burns. If you are concerned about the possible harmful effects of inhaling propylene glycol in the vapor, then you will logically have to ban asthma inhalants on flights too.  Why should a non-asthmatic passenger be put at risk by the propellent in the inhaler?

Please avoid the knee-jerk reaction of banning something just because it looks like a cigarette.  Air travel is miserable enough already.  If flight attendants are being hassled by passengers who can't tell the difference between a real, burning cigarette and a nicotine inhaler, maybe they should distribute an educational leaflet.

The only other valid complaint a passenger may have is that the vapor is perfumed.  I don't see you banning passengers from wearing scent, so please toss that complaint out too.

Thank you.

Title: Joshua Berliner
Comment:
"Airline passengers have rights, and this new rule would enhance passenger comfort and reduce any confusion surrounding the use of electronic cigarettes in flight," U.S. Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood said in a statement Wednesday.

Ray LaHood speaks for Transportation Security, not comfort. If he really wanted to involve himself in passengers' comfort, he would mandate meals at mealtime and complementary pillows/blankets in passenger airplanes.  

E-cig bans are a comfort issue and not a security issue by Secretary LaHood's own admission.  They should not be subject to a TSA ban.  This would be a complete abuse of power, possibly illegal, and open the door to banning other perfectly reasonable items on aircraft.  

Please DO NOT submit this ban!  Please reconsider, for the rights of ALL passengers!

Title: David Harris
Comment:
I'm against this proposed rule.

The opposite legislation should be enacted. Electronic cigarettes emit no smoke and don't use tobacco. They also don't have any emissions that would negatively impact other passengers.

On the opposite side, banning them would mean users of electronic cigarettes would be required to use a "smoking area" forcing them to be exposed to dangerous smoke and other chemicals. This proposed rule actually endangers people.

I'm against this proposed rule.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should be allowed to be used in airplanes. They produce only water vapor and do not emit any foul odors.

Title: John L. Cudin
Comment:
no need to ban electronic cigarettes ion planes.  solves the issue on people wanting to smoke.  no smell, no danger to other passengers.

spend your time on something worthwhile.

Title: J. Cantu
Comment: Why don't you guys ban breathing while you're at it. That contains water vapor too, which is what the e-cigs produce. Why don't you try educating people as to what e-cigs actually are, instead of caving in to the demands of the ignorant?

Title: John Robert Martin
Comment: I will use an eCigarette as a form a protest on all flights.  Since it causes no harm to anyone around there is no crime.  You do not have a right to not be annoyed.  Yet I have the right to annoy you.  See you in the Supreme Court suckers.

Title: Scott Allen Craver
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes do not produce smoke, do not produce second-hand smoke, do not burn or produce flame, and do not otherwise pose any health or safety hazard.  These products are not actual cigarettes, but inhalers that are made to resemble them.

To ban these products on airplanes is as absurd as banning candy cigarettes, or banning mimes who mime the act of smoking.   This does not achieve any health, safety or security goal.

Title: K. C. Sweat
Comment:
I'm a life long non smoker. I have no love of smoking or being confined in any small inclosed are with a smoker, but I feel
enough is enough. The banning of electronic cigarettes is an example passing new regulator laws for no other reason
than just to pass new laws. The electronic cigarettes have none of the hazards of second hand smoke or fire danger.
The regulation of these items would be pointless. I feel our governing bodies can better find ways to spend their time
and my money than this.

Title: Esther Schiller
Comment:
I have asthma. I was at a trade show staffing a booth and a man came up to me and blew the mist from an e cigarette in my face. I suppose he was trying to show me that they are not harmful.

However, I was immediately affected by the mist. I became hoarse. I would not like to be on an air plane with people using e cigarettes. What ever is in that mist would be circulated throughout the plane.

The FDA is planning to regulate e cigarettes. Once that is accomplished and we know more about them, this might be considered again. Right now, we really don't know what is being emitted.

Title: Christopher Michael Tipton
Comment:
It is absolutely ridiculous to ban the use of electronic cigarettes on flights. There has been no proof of any sort of second-hand effects from these devices.

There are several things that we could make illegal which would make flying more comfortable. For example, let's make bad breath illegal. How about body odor? How about having a cold? After all, I don't want to be the guy that gets stuck next to the passenger with a cold or the flu.

As you can see, this line of reasoning is absurd. We can't make everything that MIGHT be uncomfortable to someone illegal.

Electronic cigarettes are a great alternative to smoking. The government should be encouraging the use of them to get people away from smoking tobacco, which does negatively affect the user and everyone in the vicinity.

Instead, the line of thinking seems to be 'it looks like smoking, therefore it must be just as bad.' This is very sad to see from a government which is supposed to be informed and looking after the interests of ALL of its people.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Hello,

Electronic cigarettes should only be banned because of their health risks if there actually are proven health risks of electronic cigarettes.

If e-cigarettes are tobacco-free nicotine delivery systems for users who exhale a safe water vapor, they could provide an outlet for habitual smokers prohibited from smoking on flights.  I've heard of cases where smokers tried to sneak a regular cigarette, and the plane had to make an emergency landing because of security concerns.  

Since many people are addicted, allowing them a means of getting nicotine is clearly preferable, if there are no chances of doing harm to others.

Considering how stressful flying can be, allowing smokers a safe outlet that does not harm others is erring on the side of freedom.  On the other hand ,if e-cigarettes can be proven hurt or bother others, ban them and you'll get no complains from me.  Science > Prejudice.

Thank you for your time.
Have a good one!

Title: Delilah Harden
Comment: Banning e-cigarettes is completely senseless. There is no flame, no tobacco, and no risk. What it does do is provide people with a nicotine addiction an option to get through long flights. If we actually want to help Americans quite smoking then e-cigarettes should be allowed EVERYWHERE. After 15 years of pack a day smoking using an e-cigarette helped me quit where patches, gum, prescriptions meds, and going cold turkey failed. I use mine everywhere and have asked everyone whether the vaping bothers them and every single person has assured me it didn't, even those who can't stand cigarette smoke. I suggest that perhaps some research should be done before anyone even considers banning them anywhere. I thank god for my ecig as I do believe it's saved my life.

Title: Skyler C. Walker
Comment:
This is a foolish ban and a waste of taxpayer money. To ban something that is harmless due to a few ignorant passengers flies in the face of reason. 
These Electronic Cigarettes exist SOLELY because they aren't harmful!

Title: Lori Ann Pignatelli
Comment:
I believe that this proposed bill is completely unconstitutional.  The use of electronic cigarettes have not been shown to cause harm to the user or to people around the user.  It simply delivers nicotine to the system which is what a nicotine patch does.  Will nicotine patches be banned as well?  There is no smell at all with an electronic cigarette.  However people are allowed on planes every day with very strong perfume.  Where is the fairness is this? 
Please reconsider this law and help protect our freedoms on things that cause no harm to others.

Title: H. Rivera
Comment: I applaud the DOT for taking a stand on a device that has not proven that it is safe.  Think about the ramifications of an ignited device in a flying tube.  The possibilities of a negative health effect on those around the person "vaping" can be grave.

Title: Brian Richard Morrison
Comment: I am writing in opposition to the proposed ban on E-Cigarettes aboard aircraft. This is a ridiculous proposition. To ban the E-cigarette, ostensibly, for merely looking like a regular cigarette, and confusing some passengers is a further intrusion on our rights that is unwarranted. There is no danger to those around you, nor any offending smell. This is supposed to be the land of the free. the only caveat should be, that freedom, as long as there is no negative effect to your neighbor. Give it a break, already. The US criminalizes everything it can, it seems. We don't need or want more restrictive laws that serve no purpose, but to make someone more likely to be a criminal. Shame on the TSA for proposing such nonsense.

Title: Donald Buer
Comment:
This law would be an outrageous abuse of authority and a dangerous precedent that puts political whining ahead of public health.  Electronic Cigarettes are an important tool in helping people to quit smoking.  It provides harmless nicotine while eliminating the tars and poisons found in tobacco.  

Ever since Boeing and others decided to build planes with unhealthy systems that no longer exchanged stale and infected internal cabin air with clean external air, smokers have been forced to rely on patches, pills, and will power.  Now, there is a safe healthy effective tool that helps people to quit smoking and also helps to eliminate CPOD, Emphysema, and Cancer and many other diseases.  Instead of promoting its use. liberals mindlessly complain that it "confuses" them, confuses them???!!!

Question:  Is is proper to encourage smoking and other unhealthy behaviors in order to avoid "confusing" a few scatterbrained flight attendants?  Is their "comfort" more important than human lives?

Electronic cigarettes have been proven to be both effective and safe.  They produce no objectionable odors nor do they release any unsafe chemicals into the air.  Users breath in a combination of water vapor and nicotine (harmless by itself) and exhale simple water vapor (if anything).

This is a product whose use should be promoted and encouraged.  Critics do nothing but promote increased rates of Cancer and other diseases and should be sharply rebuked.

Title: Jacquelyn Romanish
Comment: There are no flames or devices that produce flames. No butts. No tobacco. No second hand smoke. No odor. Sales tax is collected when the item is sold. E-cigarrettes should be allowed everywhere. (If you want to ban something on an airplane , please ban perfumes and any food item that has onions.)

Title: Leslie Annette Powers
Comment: I smoked for over 30 years and have quit for over a year, using the e-cigarette as my crutch. My famiily and friends have made it VERY CLEAR the e-cigarette does not bother them one bit!! I believe if you are going to ban them, you should also ban people who wear too much cologne or perfurme, people who don't bathe, women who wear too much hair spray and so on. Please allow e-smokers to politely use their e-cigarettes where they want. Thank you.

Title: John Noriaki Seto
Comment: I totally agree with the ban of electronic cigarettes on flights.  I have few friends who smoke electronic cigarettes and there is a distinct odor omitted by them which made me very uncomfortable.  The nicotine level may be low, but the smell is still there and the smoke itself is not something that everyone should have to put up with.

Title: Michael Jason Osten
Comment: This is really going too far.  These devices are a safe alternative to tobacco and pose no risk to the comfort or safety of airline passengers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is dumb.  They pose no harm to others.  This seems very ignorant and typical of government these days.

Title: Tony Abate
Comment: The primary attraction of e-cigarettes is their ability to allow you to use them in places you were unable to smoke before. More and more people, like myself, have quit smoking using these devices and the benefits are better for everybody. Forcing them to obey the same rules as actual smokers for no justifiable reason not only makes no sense, but is harmful to the attraction of e-cigarettes and would make many wonder why they should give up smoking, leading to continued cigarette related illnesses and death, driving up medical costs, and just more of the same. Don't punish those taking a step in the right direction, reward them and allow them to continue their habit, one that has no effect on others and no harmful effects on themselves, whereever. An e-cigarette is not a cigarette, period. Alarmist studies such as the ones referenced in the rule just show that they have no better idea than anyone else. There has been no hazards shown in any testing, yet they always end with 'But there could be'. That's ridiculous and unprofessional. There are real hazards on airplanes that should continue to be addressed, so there's no need to simply make one up.

Title: Eric
Comment:
This is the most ridiculous idea for a ban that I have heard of in years.  It sounds like people want e-cigs banned from planes just because they philosophically disagree with smoking.  There is no evidence that second-hand nicotine vapor from an e-cigarette is harmful to people nearby, as a matter of fact there is evidence to the contrary.  If people want to indulge in a habit that does no harm to others and does not infringe on anyone else's rights then it is not other people's business to try to have the habit banned.

Thank you,

Eric

Title: James Hunter Goodwin
Comment:
"We are unaware of sufficient studies on the health 
impact on third parties from these vapors to conclude that they would 
not negatively impact the air quality within the aircraft and/or 
increase the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and 
crewmembers."

Then why are you banning it? There are plenty of unknowns in life. Stop trying to fix what's not broken. Aside from that, nicotine would be medically beneficial if used as an anti-smoking aid. Are you going tp ban those prescribed products as well?

Title: Christopher Payne
Comment: Seriously, banning electronic cigarettes!? The first EFFECTIVE device to help cessation for smoking and the government is going to try to ban it in public places? For a free country it seems to me that over the last 30 years we have lost more and more and more rights as a "free people". No wonder the rest of my family moved to Europe...

Title: Kathelene Joyce
Comment: This is just another pathetic attempt to "control" the people!! E-Cigs are harmless! Nothing burning, no second hand smoke to worry about, or anything else. There is NO good reason why a passenger can't use one. But this is just why I will never fly again!! Not ever. When you're in that plane, you are literally a prisoner of the airline's. You will do what they say when they say so... But when I drive down the road, I'll smoke and e-cig without anyone telling me NO!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I believe that banning electronic cigarettes on domestic and international airlines is absurd. 
This is a device that offers nicotine to the individual (user) without any harmful or negative effects to any surrounding persons. 
The nicotine delivered to the user helps to calm the nerves and is able to eleviate symptoms (irritability etc) during these long periods of airline travel; especially with the long security lines and stressful situations that have been imposed on passengers.

Title: Douglas Ryan Welch
Comment:
This proposed legislation is ridiculous.  I can fully understand the protections provided to other passengers from the effects of in the cabin tobacco smoke, but the byproduct of an e-cigarette doesn’t even come close to the same issue.
I do not smoke, however my wife does.  She has since her early teens to now in her fifties.  Quitting seems like the logical thing to do and is the mantra bashed into our heads every day, but it’s not that easy for most.  It’s an addiction equivalent to heroin, and even heroin addicts are allowed to use transition devices to quit.

My wife uses the e-cigarette in her attempt to stop in the inhalation of so many chemicals, while at the same time providing the relief she needs for her addiction. Most importantly, it is a god send on long flights, ALL of which to get out of Alaska are long; we really have little choice in this regard.  Banning this device will return her to her fear of traveling; affect her mental wellbeing while on trips, and cause a great amount of anxiety at layovers as we try to get outside for her to smoke and then fight the security lines to get back in.

It’s bad enough that as a society we allowed her to become a victim of the smoking habit as a teenager, that now as an adult just trying to keep her sanity flying, we’re going to punish her yet again.  With the lack of any scientific data on the second effects of these e-cigarettes, which I believe are negligible to non-existent, this really borders on a law that singles out one segment of the population, and that is unconstitutional.

Title: Stephanie Scoye
Comment: Rather then banning the electronic cig. I think they should be encouraged. I've used them for almost 3 years. The public should be educated about them instead of saying well they might look like a regular cig. so we must get rid of them. You shouldn't give credence to unfounded hysteria by banning them from flights. They will make the flight much more pleasant. They do not smell like regular cigs at all and most of what is exhaled is water vapor. There is probably more nicotine in a tomato or potato then in the exhaled water vapor.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please enact this law!  As a majority of Americans are non-smokers, this law will help increase public health.

Title: Leonard Keith Henson
Comment: I am tired of being ostracized for my choice to smoke. I spent eight years in the US Marine Corps and fought in the first gulf war for this country and I feel I have a right to smoke. Now, I understand the rules prohibiting smoking on an aircraft but when I finally have a device which allows me to be comfortable on an airplane as well as my non smoking fellow americans I consider that a win-win - at least with reasonable thinking folks. The vapor produced by an e-cig are the same as you'd find at a concert (the fake smoke on stage) and we aren't worried about health concerns there, are we? No - this is simply a specious attack on a class of people that other people dislike - and one class is yelling louder and getting undeserved political preference. You took the smoke out of the workplace, out of bars and restaurants and out of airplanes as well as many other places. Keep pushing, eventually we'll be pushed too far and we'll push back.

Title: Glenn A. Koeppel
Comment:
It's very true that E- cigarettes have no secondhand smoke to offend and harm those around them, however there is the matter of lingering nicotine. We should all know by now the highly addictive nature of nicotine. It's always the last vice people are willing to struggle through getting over. 
   What most people don't realize is that when a person using an E-cigarette inhales the heated liquid nicotine into their lungs, like every other breath they take, only 15% remains in the lungs. The other 85% is exhaled into the air.  
   So if I'm a former smoker, having recently quit, and my body is free of nicotine, I'm now forced to be exposed to the airborn chemical in an enclosed environment such as the fusealage of an airplane. 
   If you think about it, the only source of nicotine is from a tobacco palnt, therefore the E-cigarette utilizes a tobacco product and should therfore fall under the tobacco free policy of all flights departing from or heading to the United States of America.

Title: Mark Allen Evans
Comment: In the absence of any evidence that they do harm, the decision to allow or dissallow any particular behavior should reside with the individual carriers.  It may be that one carrier or another would seek to cater to passengers who favor these devices, and the free market will establish the viability.  Creating unncessary legislation is wasteful and very irresponsible.

Title: Margaret McDowell
Comment:
Why don't y'all just work on our debt instead of stuff like this?  The last thing we need is another stupid law like this.

GET TO WORK!!!

Title: Quinn R. Allen
Comment:
I'm of two minds about this, but also have a solution that I have never seen in any new bill regarding the attempted ban on e-cigarettes. On one hand, as a former pack-a-day smoker, e-cigarettes have most likely saved my life. After 14 years of smoking a pack a day I have not had a single cigarette or the desire for one in the past 6 months, and as e-cigs allow for their users to step down their nicotine level I have also reduced the amount of nicotine I take in. In this sense I dislike seeing any bans on ecigs.

On the other hand, I recall being a non-smoker and not appreciating being around someone who is smoking. I can empathize with the concerns of those who don't use e-cigs and are concerned for their health and well being.

I have seen lots of statements pointing to a lack of information on the products themselves and the potential health risks to the users and to bystanders. What I have never seen stipulated in any bill is a clause stating that this ban would be removed if evidence came to light that, as has been claimed by the e-cig community and MANY health professionals and laboratories, e-cigs are in fact benign to users and bystanders. The chemical composition is known. The batteries used are known. Extensive research has been done on the chemicals used in the liquid in their other uses outside of being a delivery system for nicotine. 

Not once have I seen this research cited. 

The research is being done. Rather than cost more tax dollars to be spent to overturn a ban once e-cigs are proven to be safer to users and completely safe to bystanders add provisions to these bans that they would be lifted once proof was given.

Title: Lloyd Katz
Comment:
I support the proposed regulation banning the use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft.

I believe, however, that the proposed regulation needs to be modified to ensure that individuals who are using products that are similar in appearance to an electronic cigarette, but that do not present the potential of similar risks to other passengers, are not inconvenienced or otherwise affected by the proposed regulation.

Notably, the Nicotrol Inhaler is a prescription drug that is very similar in appearance to an electronic cigarette.  The Nicotrol Inhaler consists of an inhaler, or puffer, that looks much like a cigarette and contains a nicotine impregnated cartridge on which the user inhales, or puffs.  Statistics show that use of this inhaler doubles an individual’s chances of quitting smoking (http://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/archives/fdaDrugInfo.cfm?archiveid=1502)

The proposed regulation should explicitly PERMIT the use of all products such as the Nicotrol Inhaler that have been approved by the FDA for use in smoking cessation.  It should also permit the use of placebo products that mimic the appearance of a cigarette, but do not emit vapor, as a matter of right.

Further, the regulation should require the explicit education of aircraft personnel as to which devices are permitted and which are not.  It is otherwise certain that well-intentioned, but ill-informed airline employees will from simple confusion attempt to bar individuals from using devices which they are entitled to use, simply because they look like an electronic cigarette.  This is particularly important in the current environment, in which simple acts of disagreement with cabin crew can quickly escalate into something far more serious.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: John Taylor
Comment: Big pharma and big tobacco corporations are the largest purveyors of nicotine in America.  It is undoubtedly their wish to stamp out any competitors that satisfy the addicts they have created with a more healthful alternative to smoking.  The tobacco and pharmaceutical lobbies have most likely concocted this ludicrous rule to protect their dying market share.  Government by the corporations, of the corporations and for the corporations.  U.S.A. Inc. (a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer, Reynolds, Altria, Lorillard,)

Title: Jeffrey William Hall
Comment:
I believe these e-cigarettes should be explicitly banned on all commercial flights to and from the USA. There is likely small levels of nicotine in the vapor that is then inhaled second hand by other passengers. Nobody should have to inhale nicotine in unless they want to. Additionally, it's a matter of respect for other people around you. Even if it is 100% safe, I don't want to breath in water vapor that has been blown out by someone else and in an airplane the air is constantly being recirculated. From a microbiologists view point, many pathogenic viruses and bacteria could hitch a ride on these water vapor droplets and have an easy route of transmission to their next host. The recirculated air already increases a person risk for infection. 

Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I find it ridiculous that electronic cigarettes would even be considered to be banned on flights. They pose no threat to the health of other passengers, are not potentially dangerous items, and allow people who use them to feel comfortable and at ease during travel. 

I think that electronic cigarettes are a wonderful alternative to tobacco products, as they are not known to pose the health risks associated with tobacco. To ban their use on flights is blatant discrimination against those who use electronic cigarettes.

Why has alcohol not been banned on flights?

Title: Charles Curtis Bledsoe
Comment: e-cigarettes should be handled the same as traditional cigarettes.

Title: Sonja Anderson
Comment: I am absolutely opposed to banning e-cigarettes on aircraft.  These produce no smoke, and no tar.  This seems more like a witch-hunt than anything else.

Title: Harlan Kanoa N. Sheppard
Comment:
Salutations,

I have reviewed the argument laid forth by the government for the proposed rule making and find that there is indeed a stark lack of data regarding the effects of propylene glycol from e-cigarettes.

While the opinions of such figures as the USAF Surgeon General and USN are noteworthy and demanding of respect, the requirements of the military are distinct and separate from the needs of a free civilian populace. 

Given the already egregious impositions on the people by the government in the name of security, the proposed rule making seeks to remove one of the remaining vices by which the average American may cope with the inconveniences and burdens placed upon them by their government.

The FDA still lists propylene glycol as GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe). OSHA has not defined a PEL (Permissible Exposure Limit) for the aforementioned chemical. The opinions of the FDA and OSHA should be construed as more relevant and concise to this particular issue than the supplied sources of the government.

While I do concur that additional testing and regulation would be necessary within the field of e-cigarettes, that fact-finding should occur at a minimum before the restriction of e-cigarettes from aircraft.

Sincerely,
Harlan Kanoa N Sheppard
Honolulu, Hawaii

Title: Steven Paul Bailey
Comment:
I have been an Oncology Nurse for many years. Many people claim that e-cigarettes should be considered harmless because they have not been proven to cause damage. I would be inclined to approach the situation from a different viewpoint. Many of my patients are suffering from the devastation caused by tobacco use, either their own or another’s. Some of these patients began using tobacco prior to the Surgeon General’s explicit warnings. Cigarette smoking was seen as a harmless pleasure until rigorous studies indicated otherwise. I have a fear that the same will hold true for e-cigarettes. Innocent airline passengers should not be subjected to those dangers in the meantime. 
Since tobacco users continue to engage in an activity that has uncontested evidence of obvious serious harm, studies showing the very real dangers of e-cigarettes will probably also be dismissed. One such study was published by Anna Trtchounian and Prue Talbot in December of 2010. That study illuminated several concerns about e-cigarettes, including the inconsistencies in manufacture, fallacies in marketing, and health issues in disposal.
The main consideration is that when it comes to the absorption of chemicals into our bodies, we should be very concerned with what we do not know. A tobacco user may not be the appropriate person to ask about whether non-smokers should be exposed to these products.
The only viable argument against the ban on in-flight use of e-cigarettes is that we should not be so ignorant as to need one.

Title: Kendall Wright
Comment: As a member of FlyersRights.org, I strongly support this rule.  I share the concerns of the U.S. Air Force, U.S. Navy, AMTRAK, and many of our states, and believe that those concerns must be answered before these noxious devices are allowed in the cabin of my next airline flight.

Title: Edward Roberson
Comment: I want this rule struck down. There is no valid proof of harm from electronic cigarettes and no valid reason to ban their use.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This ban is utterly ridiculous. I, as all rational Americans, am tired of laws being made that serve no purpose whatsoever except to appease fanatics who have nothing better to do than make others miserable by forcing their own narrow code of conduct onto the rest of society. Electronic cigarettes are a great alternative for people who want to smoke (and have the right to do so, regardless of how bad it is for their health) without harming anyone around them. What good reason do you have for even proposing this law? Who do you think you are? The people are supposed to run this country, not the fear-mongering media, not the 5% minority fanatics. I just hope that the sane majority speak out against things like this, instead of just the few crazies who think it's a great idea.

Title: Deborah L. Ameion
Comment: Please do not allow e-cigarettes on airlines. The liquid has been proven to leak. They emit toxic ingredients into the air which will be breathed into the lungs of other passengers. The FDA states they contain diethylene glycol, a poisonous ingredient in antifreeze, and tetramethlypyrazine, known to cause brain damage. It also contains propylene glycol which is the same substance used in smoke machines in dance clubs and concerts. Most people do not choose to go into dance clubs to breath in smoke machines and should not be forced to breath it in the closed area of an airplane. The elderly, children, and people with asthma are especially vulnerable. E-cigarettes are no better than real cigarettes. It is just a device to keep feeding an addiction. People who have this addiction who cannot handle the length of plane ride should not be traveling on planes or they should learn to control themselves until they get off the plane and can feed their addiction in the privacy of their own home.  Thank you for this chance to comment.

Title: Kevin C. Adkisson
Comment: Banning e-cigs makes no sense whatsoever. Since when do we ban things before there is some form of proof that they are harmful? Banning e-cigs would be like banning colognes and perfums. All of these put off odors. All of these mix chemicals with the air. None of these should be banned because doing so is just flat out silly.

Title: Thomas Richard Bolin
Comment: The electronic cigarette presents no harm to anyone your attempts to regulate it is based on ignorance and fear mongering. I also believe that it is based on money from tobacco lobbies and big tobacco. if you had to good of the people in mind you would back the users of e-cigarettes as in the long run it will save billions in health cost. Which is more important the good of the people or the good of big business.

Title: Alma Wu
Comment:
Ray LaHood is the same guy who spoke about the Toyota acceleration problem without all the facts.  He is doing it again with electronic cigarettes.  Drivers of Toyotas can just put the car into NEUTRAL (transmission) to disengage the engine and get it to slow down.
Mr. La Hood, you are a not-so-well thought out political appointee.  Please don't enact not-so-well thought out regulations.

Title: Ramsey Garland Kropp
Comment:
I strongly feel that the proposed regulations prohibiting the use of electronic cigarettes violate the freedom of nicotine users without just cause. These devices are not combusting any material and have not been shown to have any harmful effects on the user or those in close proximity. From a personal freedom standpoint this action represents the worst excesses of prohibitionary zeal and further supports the populist perception of the federal apparatus as a "nanny state". Although there are many valid reasons for preventing the use of certain materials (including smoked tobacco and electronic devices) they all seek to minimize some harm. Until such time as these devices have been shown to cause any detriment to the aircraft, crew, or passengers they should not be regulated at the federal level. If the individual airline chooses to ban their use that is their prerogative, but the regulatory actions proposed will create a whole new class of felons, who stand to lose a great deal of personal liberty.

Save regulatory power for harm reduction and not knee-jerk reactionary grandstanding. I am asking this even though I am a non-user of nicotine and have no stake in the outcome other than the fear of creeping criminalization of non-harmful behaviors.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes in no way have a negative health impact on others, and the water vapor exhaled is nearly odorless.  It is ridiculous to ban them as all the reasons that make banning combustion-based cigarettes do not apply.  I cannot stand regular cigarette smoke and understand the health risks to non-smokers.  However, electronic nicotine delivery devices, while superficially resembling cigarettes to assist in acceptance by smokers as an alternative to smoking, are not cigarettes.

Title: Noah
Comment: This is absolutely ridiculous. What the hell is wrong with you people? We already have enough B**LSH*T regulations, you can't smoke cigarettes anywhere but your own house, so the people who are trying to comply (albeit hard enough as is) can't even use their harmless crutch? Seriously, leave the American public alone already. Let us maintain at least some of our basic freedoms and choices. I am appalled at the state of the nation, and the bureaucratic A55H*les that seem to think they know what's best for everyone. Do something about some REAL problems before you impose any more limits on the last few HARMLESS  freedoms we the people still have.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
There's no reason to ban electronic cigarettes on airplanes as there is no second hand smoke from them.  The entire problem over this is flight attendants who don't know what they are and how they work.  Being that there's no combustion, there is no second hand smoke.

If anything, we should encourage smokers to switch over to electronic cigarettes, and we'll see cancer rates likely go down if a good number of them do.

Title: Stella Davila
Comment: The vapors of an electronic cigarette are not harmful to people in the vicinity. Please do not take away our civil rights to smoke these immitation cigarettes anywhere.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is the stupidest thing to come out of our government yet. Small amounts of water vapor  WATER VAPOR are released no smell nothing. If you want to ban something stop people who were tons of noxious perfume!

Title: Jeremy Micah Rivera
Comment: The purpose behind the ban on smoking tobacco products is because of the health hazards to other passengers. E-cigarettes have no detrimental effects on other passengers. Therefore, without the health argument, there is no reason why these devises, which have no negative impact on flight attendants, personelle or passengers should be banned.

Title: Joel R. Cederholm
Comment:
This is not smoke, this is mostly water vapor. Let's ban all variations of 'vapor'.  Have all passengers hold their breath while on board.
Ban the overuse of perfumes first.
While we're banning things, let's not serve alcohol on flights. That seems to cause more problems than anything else.

Title: L. W.
Comment:
I feel that electronic cigarettes should be treated, and therefore regulated, as are other tobacco-based products. 

Something generating vapors--vapors that potentially include propylene glycol--in a closed air enviroment has health ramifications for everyone on board the aircraft. 

I suspect, further, that someone will find a way to transport or ingest illiegal substances via the cartridges, which could jeopardize the safety of the flight.

Title: Denise
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION

Office of the Secretary

14 CFR Part 252

[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0044]
RIN 2105-AE06


I am against the implementation and enforcement of this rule.

Legal activities should not be controlled by the government. 

If this rule is enacted and enforced, I recommend also introducing a rule that no alcoholic beverages be served on a plane. Someone who has had too much to drink is a significant danger to himself, other passengers, and airline personnel.

Title: Anita Alice Koser
Comment:
I work as a bartender on an Indian reservation where smoking is allowed in bars and restaurants.  I'm 58 years old and have a history of asthma and emphysema.  Whenever a customer would smoke one of those vapor-producing electronic cigarettes, the vapor produced would cause me to have an asthma attack.  I'm also an EMT-Basic, and I believe allowing these vapor-producing cigarettes to be used in an enclosed space like an airplane would adversely affect the health and well-being of other passengers.

Thank you for allowing me to comment.



Anita A. Koser

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree that electronic cigarettes should not be used on aircraft, but not because of health concerns, since it's been proven time and again that electronic cigarettes are not dangerous. My reasons for saying they should not be used on aircraft are:

1) Because if someone vapes, another person might believe they're smoking, and may light up an actual cigarette.

2) Because some flavors of e-liquid can smell bad to others.

Title: R. J.
Comment: E-cigarettes are technically called Personal Vaporizers (PV). While nicotine is one possible additive, not all PV cartridges have nicotine. The smoke is not smoke, it is merely water vapor from the users lungs, which is exhaled in any case, PV used or not, and is ONLY visible due to the particles of Propylene Glycol (PG) and/or Vegetable Glycerin (VG) which is what PV users are really vaporizing. PG is labeled as GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe) and is a core part of most cosmetics. VG is edible glycerine, and is used in baking. Additionally the nicotine level is typically 1/100th that of a burning cigarette, with zero carcinogens. The vapor technology is identical to the fog machines used at parties and dance clubs, they have been used for decades are there are zero health risks to those around the vapor. This legislation is idiotic and intrudes into citizen lives needlessly.

Title: Cynthia Welch
Comment: Electronic cigarettes are not SMOKED. There is no smoke created, inhaled or exhaled so an electronic cigarette cannot be classified in the same category as a tobacco cigarette. If you are not going to allow vapor to be expelled from a persons mouth or nose, then you need to ban all breathing entities from flying in an airplane.

Title: Brent M. Teal
Comment: Why would they create a law banning a legal product that helps people quit smoking.  This is absolute government intrusion in to something they do not need to regulate.  If an actual person reads this answer this question: Why are you punishing and individual that may really need nicotine on a 5 hour flight.  Who does this help?

Title: Sara Gramcko
Comment: The intent of the ban on smoking on aircraft is to protect the rights of all passengers to contaminant free air in a situation in which they do not have the option of leaving the area.  As electronic cigarettes introduce contaminants into the air they should be banned just like traditional cigarettes.

Title: Lee Whitaker
Comment: I am a smoker who uses the e-cigarette when traveling and in non-smoking areas.  I SINCERELY doubt that there is any objectionable vapor emitted from these devices that would be harmful or irritating in any way to those non-smokers who might possibly come into contact with it.  There is nothing in the research from the government agencies that shows this to be a dangerous device and once again, if this legislation/regulation is allowed to be enacted, indicates yet another FREEDOM OF CHOICE which is being taken from the individual BY the government.  THIS IS NOT A REGULATORY OR LEGISLATIVE ISSUE.  IT IS PURELY A POLITICAL PLOY SO THAT 'THE GOVERNMENT' CAN CLAIM TO BE PROTECTING the citizens of the country and "working together", in a political climate that is so devisive and unable to compromise on important political policy.  Surely our representatives should notice by now the absolute comtempt with which the general public views them.

Title: Ruth E. Malone
Comment: I am a Professor at UCSF and chair of the Department of Social and Behavioral Sciences. In addition to teaching health policy in the UCSF School of Nursing and conducting NIH-funded research on tobacco issues, I am editor-in-chief of the international journal, Tobacco Control, published by the British Medical Association and the leading policy journal in the tobacco control field. Tobacco Control is a respected, peer reviewed publication, and in that capacity we have published some of the initial studies on these new products. Work published in Tobacco Control has shown that these products vary greatly in their composition, ingredients, use profiles, nicotine content, nicotine delivery, packaging, and many other aspects. They are an unregulated chemical product that is currently exposing users and those around them to unknown substances, since there is no oversight of their ingredients. Regardless of whether they may be eventually shown to be helpful to tobacco smokers seeking to quit, or to be shown to have minimal harm to users, it would be unconscionable to force passengers in the enclosed space of an aircraft cabin to be exposed to aerosolized ingredients from these products, which could precipitate anaphylactic reactions in sensitive passengers or affect the health of others in as-yet unknown ways. To allow e-cigarette use aboard aircraft would be to engage all passengers unwittingly in an experiment in which they were not given the opportunity to provide informed consent for participation. We ended that social experimentation long ago on airlines, but only after many people, especially flight attendants, died or contracted disease from it. I urge you to pass this rule. There are many other non-airborne routes for nicotine administration for those who cannot tolerate long flights without it.

Title: Nelson Charles Bisphop
Comment:
Please ALLOW use of electronic cigarettes on airplanes. 

These devices do not burn tobacco.  They vaporize nicotine and flavorings.  The vapor disipates quickly, more like steam from coffee or tea than cigarette smoke.  

While someone very close to the user may faintly detect the flavorings in the vapor, it is far below the level of the average perfume/cologne or a soiled diaper.

Respectfully,
Nelson Bishop

Title: Anthony William Cangelosi
Comment: this is bullshit. my name is anthony i was a smoker for 9 years and e cigarettes saved me from smoking any longer. i will not have to worry about getting cancer or dying of lung failure if you ban this you will be killing 1000s of people this devise saves lives everyday its more healthy smells beter and taste beter and is alot cheaper then cigarettes please dont do this

Title: Timothy J. Chasteen
Comment: The ecig does not produce harmful second hand smoke. It in fact isn't smoke. These devices are valuable health saving devices. It's helping me. And others.

Title: Eric Roger Apple
Comment:
The proposal states repeatedly that little to nothing is known with regard to possible negative health effects of e-ciggarettes but none the less presses forward with yet another ban that further marginalizes a significant sector of American citizens for using what is in fact a legal product.
Proceeding in ignorance "just in case" there might be a problem in the complete absence of data supporting such an action may be Politically Correct but is not logical or warranted.
I oppose the extension of no smoking regulations on air carriers to include E-Ciggarettes.  It's an issue of personal freedom and logic over knee jerk regulation.

Title: Roberta Farrell
Comment: Agree 100% that "e-cigarettes" shoudl be banned on airplanes.  There is not enough information on them to convince us there is no impact to others in enclosed areas.

Title: Ayesha Haran
Comment: I am of the opinion that vaping an electronic cigarette on an airplane SHOULD be allowed.

Title: Shannon C. Dann
Comment: As we know e ciggerette is just vapor it has no known Heath effects and it is just vapor I can understand how some of the. Many flavors can be a nuisance. however it is usually close to odorless. I do feel that since it poses no threat to others as health goes it should be allowed.

Title: David Byron Gordy
Comment: E Cigarettes saved my life! I was dying of COPD and now I am much better thanks to them and an HONEST DOCTOR! Please do not regulate them in any way!

Title: Eric Westbrook
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes are not harmful to anyone, and they assist many people in avoiding tobacco cigarettes, which of course are themselves actually harmful.

"Eliminating confusion" is not a sufficient reason to prohibit a helpful and harmless product from being used in any public place, including an airplane, where they arguably provide benefit to the user at a time he or she might benefit from it more than others.

If Electronic Cigarettes had been found to be harmful to anyone, that would be one thing.  But since they have not, it would be just as wrong to prohibit them as it would be to prohibit the SkyMall, which, while it annoys a great many people, is also not harmful to bystanders.

Title: Alexandra C. Romanov
Comment:
Leave the E-cigarettes alone. Quit trying to parent the American people. There is nothing wrong with it, no danger to others and should be left alone.


If you decide to ban THAT, please ban perfume on flights as well. I've been on planes with both and the perfume bothered my asthma, the vaping didn't.

Title: Michael Frances Phipps
Comment: The electronic cigarette is clearly not a tobacco product. It is a form of delivery of nicotine only. It should not be concidered to be anything than what it is. When a person is breathing out of their mouths and chewing gum it is the very same thing. I think this is going too far. Why not ban perfume which makes me sick. how about the corbon dioxide when opening a coke? Don't you understand that this form of delivering nictoine is the cloest experience one can have to smoking tobacco. What harm has been done? You are going crazy with regulations because smomeone made a complaint. What will be next on your stupid adgenda? How about not breathing because you could spread a virus? Why not take vital signs?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: E-cigarettes should be classified as smoking materials.... banned where regular cigarettes are banned

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Bann it.

Title: Joseph Ward
Comment:
I'm extremely against this proposed regulation.  

There's no indication that these devices cause any harm or damage or even annoyance, and banning them without strong evidence of harm is irrational.   

I do not smoke, but I've been around those utilizing these devices and there was not even an odor, let alone anything harmful that I was able to detect.

Title: Michael A. Blischke
Comment: If you are planning on banning electronic cigarettes based on the tiny amount of fumes they give off, you should first ban applying perfume and cologne, and also applying nail polish.  These are much worse in a closed environment like an airplane than the e-cigarette emissions.

Title: Brian J. Roland
Comment:
Please get you science straight.
Personal Vaporizers are NOT SMOKING.

1.  There is no SMOKE.  It is misleading to the public to categorize these devices as 'SMOKING'.

2.  The presence of any tobacco product is only an assumption.  If a Personal Vaporizer has nothing in it derived of any kind of tobacco product, then how is this a 'tobacco product'?  Will you do a chemical analysis of every single personal vaporizer to see if it contains nicotine?

If the DOT finds significant risk in operating a small battery and heating element in aircraft by individual passengers is unsafe to the general public in any way, then so be it, but make the ban in a separate and distinctive code of its own.  Saying it is 'SMOKING' and including it in the smoking portions of the code is going to lead to many problems in the future, some of them possibly even Constitutional in nature.

Finally, before banning something it would be nice to have evidence that it is harmful to any person or property at all!.

Passing unconstitutional rules, codes, and bans "Just Because You Can" is one sure fire way to witness the public backlash against the Patriot Act.  For every inch the department takes with harmless things like personal vaporizers, it looses a MILE in public opinion on serious matters like scanning for weapons and preventing sabotage or terrorist attacks.

If the personal vaporizer is dangerous, by all means remove it, but do it properly.  It is NOT SMOKING!

Title: Edwin James Geels
Comment: I am in favor of banning the use of electronic smoking devices on all commercial airline flights.

Title: Andrew J
Comment: This is ridiculous, it sounds to me like the flight attendant who brought this to attention was just upset that she couldn't smoke on the plane and that this passenger found a loop hole and told him to stop.  As a smoker I understand why traditional cigarettes aren't allowed on planes, first and foremost to maintain the comfort of other passengers.  I do, however, know people who use electronic cigarettes and have used them in the past.  I don't like them cause they just don't do it for me, however, even as a smoker I can tell if someone nearby is smoking, but electronic cigarettes create no noticable byproduct that should affect or bother any neighboring person, there is no smell and no harmful second hand residue.  This should not be banned, this product was designed partially for this purpose.  I don't understand why everyone is always so up in arms all the time about every single little health issue.  We're creating a society that harbors a bunch of wimps.  Shut up and let them smoke their crappy sudo-cigarettes.

Title: Barbara J. Wathen
Comment:
The only cure for tobacco use that has worked for me
and which my pulmonlogist applauds, is the e-cigarette.
I have used all other measures to get rid of the habit and
none have worked for me.

I would not smoke my e-cigarette in public anyway; but i might
go to the bathroom and get my nicotine through vapor on a very long flight.  Some of the eliquids do produce an odor.
If I use a cherry eliquid, it smells of cherries, orange flavor
the same, smells of oranges.

I think this is nothing but big money and ridiculous rules
to stop a device that is the very best alternative to smoking.
Smokers do not want to stay smokers; but some of us started so many years ago with the fancy TV, billboard, movies and magazine ads that made it glamorous.  Cigarettes contain some
2,000 or more additives, some quite harmful; whereas e-cigarettes do not.

I am a considerate vapor person, and will not expose to others
the vapor smells it might omit.  Public mandating is ridiculous.

Title: Judith Tillson
Comment:
I am writing regarding the banning of smoking electronic cigarettes on board aircraft.  I support the Dept. of Transportation (DOT) in this excellent idea.  I frequently fly, as do my family members and do not want them (nor anyone else) exposed to the e-cigarettes “smoke”

The e-cigarettes are highly controversial in my mind, they are not regulated and little is known about what is used in them.  In some cases, I’ve read that there are carcinogenous compounds being used.  Any of this can be recirculated in the airlines air systems.  

Work recently published in the “Tobacco Control” peer-reviewed publication (British Medical Association) shows that these products do vary greatly in their composition, ingredients, nicotine content & delivery (just to name a few).   Please keep in mind that these are UNREGULATED CHEMICAL PRODUCTS, and there is no data at this point showing that they are helpful to tobacco smokers who wish to quit (in spite of what the companies say that manufacture the products).  

To allow e-cigarettes on board any aircraft would be exposing all passengers and crew members to the ingredients used in these products.   It’s hard enough today to travel, let along being exposed to this during an entire flight.  

For the person who can’t stand to be on a long flight without a cigarette, there are other ways to control the nicotine desire that don’t affect the entire plane of passengers (chewing gum for one comes to mind).

Please go forward banning these e-cigarettes on board all aircraft.

Thank you.

Title: April C. Wilhelm
Comment:
First I want to say I am completely against this ban. 

Second, I would like to explain why.
I've been using electronic cigarettes(e-cigs) for a number of months now. Not only has my personal health improved, but the health of my husband, who is a nonsmoker, has improved as well. Whenever I am forced to go stand with smokers in order to vape, I start to cough almost to the point of vomiting from the cigarette smoke. It's just that awful since I quit them. 

Third, I would like to show you something, assuming anyone actually reads this.

There is a compilation of reports made by various places on the effects of electronic cigarettes, including all the separate ingredients, exhaled vapor, and inhaled vapor. That website is; http://www.electroniccigaretteban.org/electroniccigaretteban.org/reports-electronic-cigarettes.htm 
Unlike what you would expect, they give -all- information, including the short, fairly slapdash, report that the FDA did in 2009. Funny though, that the FDA fails to mention the fact that the carcinogens that were found in e-cigs are also in the gum and the patch that they currently think are the best thing ever for quitting smoking. And in a lesser amount. Interesting how that works out, huh?

Anyway, that's my two cents. I'm happily using e-cigs, and I have no want to ever smoke a traditional cigarette again. These things have been a godsend for me, and many others, who have tried quitting with the patch or the gum, and couldn't.

Title: Vance
Comment: I think you should worry about more important things such as the condition of roads and bridges in the country rather then this subject. I do use the electronic devices and it should be up to the carrier rather then the government. Most airlines already do not allow these and government intervention is not needed or wanted. I have been using these for 2 years now and have had an increase in health rather then the decrease that is being used by some entities as a scare tactic to increase there own profit margins.

Title: Louise DeCarlo
Comment: This is ridiculouis.  Why don't you just ban smokers from flying.  The airline industry is in enough financial trouble without making an almost perfect alternative to smoking real cigarettes unavailable for smokers who still wish to fly.  Smoking was banned because of the supposedly dangerous secondhand smoke (even though at least 95% of scientific tests show there is no significant risk).  Air quality on airplanes is worse than when smoking was allowed because the airlines cut down the ventilation/air filtration.  This is supposed to make passengers more comfortable?  ha  Electronic cigarettes are being banned because of WATER VAPOR emissions?  Is that secondhand water dangerous?

Title: Von R. Spence
Comment: BULLSHIT      you guys are nuts    first we have to stop smokeing on flights    and then in order to take the easy way out you want to ban electronic cigarettes on flights     really what or who do i harm with one of thease units      i get the nicotine   and the overweight slob next to me gets vapor    i have a great idea   ban fat folks from airplanes   as well as handicaped as they would impead my right to escape an airplane emergency situation      yall waake up and get real

Title: Benjamin Andrew Story
Comment:
The vaporization of nicotine should be entirely banned on commercial flights. Just because you can't see the nicotine doesn't mean that it is not there. After vaporization and inhalation of the nicotine, the user exhales a minute amount of volatile nicotine into the surrounding air. 

With circulating air flow inside commercial airplanes this nicotine could be potentially passed to other passengers including but not limited to children and potential mothers.

The NFPA rates nicotine as a 4 for the health section of the "fire diamond," this means that for nicotine : "Very short exposure could cause death or major residual injury"

Some may argue that it is "necessary" so that tobacco users suffering from nicotine withdrawal can get their "fix." I disagree entirely, the user can simply use chewing tobacco as an alternative that does not physically disturb nearby passengers.

People that choose to voluntarily poison their bodies should not be allowed to do so to others.

Title: Craig A. Dawkins
