Comment: I'm a Nurse and Certified Health Educator. When humans breath in the lungs absorb approximately 20% of the available oxygen. The other 80% is exhaled. Following this 80/20 pattern, users of e-cigarettes exhale 80% of the vaporized nicotine and whatever chemicals involved in e-cigarettes. That exhaled breath is now environmental tobacco smoke (ETS) because it contains chemicals known to case harm to others. It may not have all the 4000 chemical and particulates that a cigarette, pipe or cigar has but it has at least one, nicotine, that has been proven in studies after studies to harm others. Therefore it should be banned as a measure to protect the Public's heatlh. I urge you to move forward with this proposal and strengthen the protection it will provide to all. Thank you, Cynthia

Title: Teresa M. Henning
Comment:
Ban Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft now

Teresa

Title: Marietta Turner
Comment: I think electronic cigarettes should be allowed. There is no known hazard to people or aircraft.

Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: James Michael McKnight
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: John McDonald
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: James L. Repace
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Beth Miller and Brenda Roman
Comment: Please see the attached file submitted by Beth Miller & Brenda Roman

Title: Association of Professional Flight Attendants
Comment:
Association of Professional Flight Attendants' Comments 
RE: DOT-OST-2011-0044 - E-Cigarettes on board aircraft and 
its affect on Flight Attendants' working environment.  See attached letter.

Title: James R. Rothenberger
Comment:
Banning a product such as Electronic Cigarette because it might look like a cigarette or have cigarette in its name is not a logical approach to the situation.  It is not smoking, no tobacco is burned and there is no second hand smoke.

The product has been on the market for several years now an no tests have been performed to indicate that there is any danger to other people by the vapor that is created.  There are no more carcinogens than there are in FDA approved products such as Nicotine gum, lozenges or a Nicotine Inhaler.

If you are going to ban usage of something, there needs to be some solid evidence that harm can come from a products use.  In this case, the only thing you're regulating is the level of discomfort you give to a passenger that may use the product.

I personally don't fly much anymore and for me it's not major issue.  However, any regulation that ties use of a product that appears to be 98-99% safer than smoking to a smoking ban is ridiculous.

Title: Alexander Kim
Comment: As has been mentioned several times already, there is no evidence, anecdotal or otherwise, that second hand vapor from electronic cigarettes has any negative effect. The ones who claim otherwise have no evidence to back up their ridiculous claims. This discrimination against smokers, who are trying to make a conscious decision to make things more comfortable for others, is out of hand and frankly ridiculous. If the other passengers don't want to sit next to a nicotine inhaler, they shouldn't be flying, should they? This is just needless legislation that specifically targets a group of people who really aren't doing anything bad. If this rule is passed, make sure you ban people wearing too much perfume or people using asthma inhalers. Both those things make me quite uncomfortable to have to see.

Title: Ben W. Walker
Comment:
The sheer fact that there has been no independent research clearly shows that this issue has no weight.  I am sensitive to perfumes (parfum is a KNOWN carcinogen) yet there is no ban on that.  Touching a nicotine patch or gum is poisonous as well.  There is NO EVIDENCE that the vapor emitted by electronic nicotine delivery systems is harmful in any way.  The residue left behind is minimal to none and is far less than the parabens used and spread all over every surface of the interior of every internal space - INCLUDING airlines. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12387298  
I could say much more about what I am forced to endure but I guess I just don't have a right to complain.

Title: Philip Jaquith Carpenter
Comment:
I support a ban on the use of electronic cigarettes for all airline passengers on all national and international flights originating from or flying into the USA. I do feel nebulizers should be allowed for people that have asthma, etc.

Thank You,
Philip Carpenter
Exec. Director
Arizonans Concerned About Smoking
www.acasinc.org

Title: Marcia Anne Matthies
Comment:
Thank you for proposing the ban of electronic smoking devices, such as cigarettes and cigars, on airplanes.  This is truly a good health issue.

I congratulate you and truly hope and pray this becomes a rule quickly and is well enforced.

Marcia Matthies

Title: Kay Lysse
Comment: I cannot believe that MY goverment is going to, yet again, make choices FOR ME without any scientific evidence showing that there is ANY danger to anyone from "secondhand vapor".  This is laughable.  When I use my inhaler and I then exhale..the person next to me is breathing in my asthma medicine???  NO!  I read that using electronic cigarettes caused non-smokers to have "psychological stress" when they SEE a person smoking an electronic cigarette.  WHAT?  You are going to base a gov. regulation on this??  So, I CAN wear a patch of nictotine (which mya just rub-off onto the material of the seat I am sitting in and the next passenger may pick-up some of the nicotine that was left on the seat I was sitting iin (previously)???  WHAT?  This is nuts.  I dont like that I have to LISTEN WITH MY EARS to people who have crying babies.  I dont want to ruin my appetite because the guy next to me on the plane has poor hygiene.  I may be psychologically affected in an adverse manner.  I have to breath the fumes from someone's bowel;s each time I need to use the restroom on a plane.  This cant be as healthy as CLEAN air.  For Gods Sakes..in an airplane we are ALL breathing dirty air (despite what we ar led to believe..that the air is "filtered").  Please do not make a decision for me based on speculation and rumor and the fear of God that has been put into folks from the likes of lobbyists protecting a zillion dollar business that is killing people (Phillip Morris)!!!  Put all of the elctronic cigarette passengers in the back (like you use to do with smokers).  That way..the non-smokers wont be "psychologically affected" unless they turn around and LOOK AT THE SMOKERS! (same people who dont know how to turn a channel on the TV when something is offensive).  Wait on this.  MAke no move on this until you have 100% proof..just like you had to do with real cigarettes (whcih are still legal and killing people, thank you).  DO something right.  CONSTITUTION.  PLEASE.  FOLLOW it.

Title: Stuart Macdonald
Comment:
I support the ban on electronic cigarettes. I also believe this language is too weak: "It does not include the use of a device such as a nebulizer that delivers a medically beneficial substance to a user in the form of a vapor."

There must be an accepted term such as "prescription drug" instead of "medically beneficial," which could include any kind of recreational drug.

Title: Corinna Kay Jones
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: My opinion on the proposed rule is that it’s something that should be in place anyway, the facts of the matter are as I see them that we exist on this earth with the objective to remain alive by not having water in our lungs. Facts of the matter are that the vapor of the electronic cigarette is nothing more than water vapor and it is as dangerous to the person smoking it as it would be to those exposed to it. Just as dangerous in all reality as it is to expose people to second hand smoke. And to have such a thing contained in an area like an airplane is really no matter what the chemical is that is being implemented into the air it’s hazardous. Carbon monoxide or water vapor it’s still exposing people to something that they should not be exposed to. And to think of the potential impact that it could have on others it’s something that should be banned without a doubt.

Title: Jeff Wood
Comment:
Until the vapor of an electronic cigarette is proven to be any more harmful than the air freshener used in an airplane, the DOT has no real or good reason to ban the usage of e-cigs.  

Banning their use because it "looks" like smoking is not justified. As they become more common, people will learn to tell the difference.  Until then, simply explaining the difference generally is enough to calm folks excited by the "smoke" exhaled by an e-cig user.

Title: Shelly D. Reimer
Comment: I am currently a student at the Minnesota School of Business in the Paralegal program. We are researching proposed regulations within a federal agency that interests us. I choose this particular regulation due to the fact that the banning of smoking in public places is becoming an overwhelming issue for many people. I myself agree with the proposed regulation. If individuals cannot smoke in public places, why would they be able to smoke a type of cigarette in a more confined space? There is no scientific facts that states that these types of cigarettes are not harmful to non-smokers. With that being said, if people choose to smoke they do so in the privacy of their own home or in desginated areas only not in the presence of non-smokers.

Title: Kristie L. Wegner
Comment:
I do not think that there should be a ban on the use of "e-cigarettes". I think that there should be better regulations on the making of the e-cigarettes since they are supposedly safe. I think that the regulation of no smoking of tobacco products would not include the electronic cigarettes since they do not use any form of tobacco. 
I think that there should be some more research done to really know what kind of affects the electronic cigarettes has on the people using them and the people around them.

Title: William Donald Andrews
Comment:
Agency: Department of Transportation, Office of the Secretary
Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-044
This comment is in support of the Department of Transportation’s proposal to ban the use of electronic cigarettes on all passenger aircraft. The safety and comfort of all passengers traveling in a confined space is more important than the addiction of a minority of passengers. The psychological effect of sitting next to a person who is smoking an e-cigarette is significant enough to cause other passengers discomfort when traveling. According to a recent article in Web MD, less than 20% of Americans smoke. This large difference between smokers and non-smokers should influence the DOT and airline carriers to support the interests of the majority.

The lack of scientific data concerning e-cigarettes is another concern to be taken into consideration. The e-cigarette provides nicotine to a person without the burning of a cigarette and releasing carcinogens. One of the concerns with e-cigarettes is the vapor released. The vapor released contains nicotine that can be harmful to third party individuals. The unwanted exposure to nicotine by non-smokers and children is a valid concern. There are companies that provide other products to satisfy the nicotine addiction of smokers, nicotine gum and nicotine patches are meant to provide nicotine as a substitute to smoking. 
The financial argument for banning e-cigarettes, support the idea of a ban on smoking completely. Currently, e-cigarettes bring in profits of $400,000 annually. Another concern of not banning e-cigarettes is that it will provide less of an incentive for people to quite smoking. In 2007 Americans had 96.8 billion in productivity losses due to health related problems associated with smoking. The financial numbers alone show that allowing smoking e-cigarettes and not providing an incentive to quit smoking is bad for the United States economy. 
Every effort must be made to ensure that this regulation is passed and is made clea

Title: Samantha Jo Kurilla
Comment: While reading the summary as well as the information about this regulation, I would have to agree about banning the electronic cigarettes on airline carriers.  I understand that the electronic cigarettes do not have the threat of smoke like real cigarettes do, but the other individuals on the flight may become irritated or feel unsafe.  Not everyone may know the difference of electronic cigarettes to real ones, which sometimes is hard to tell the difference between.  To me it's a reasonable regulation because the electronic cigarette gives the freedom of smoker's to smoke wherever they want, and this will help regulate that.  Everyone has their rights but when it comes to smoking, it should stay out of the public, even if it's just an electronic cigarette.  I personally smoke, but I never smoke around the public, especially small children.  I believe that children should never see that, I would rather have people look up to me in a positive way rather than for them to see me smoke and feel like it is okay.  I have tried electronic cigarettes and they have the same look as real cigarettes, so it is very hard for others to see the difference.  If they were able to be brought onto airline carriers the others around them would feel like they were being put into an unsafe condition and may possibly never use that carrier again.  Overall, I feel this to be a good regulation and I would hope that it would pass to put that ban on the use of electronic cigarettes on airline carriers.

Title: Addison
Comment: Please DO NOT allow smoking of electronic cigarettes on aircraft

Title: Ania
Comment: I am not a smoker, nor do I have a respiratory problem. I would think that these e-cigarettes should be regulated under the “Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act of 2009.” Since the effects and chemicals used in these e-cigarettes are unknown this is a problem especially for people in confined areas with respiratory problems such as asthma. Although proposed regulation does state that if products are marketed as therapeutic they would fall under the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, which could be a violation of the power allowed to the “Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act of 2009.”

Title: Timothy Lloyd
Comment: I am writing to argue against the proposed document to ban Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft. With all the known pollutants contained in tobacco cigarettes that cause harm to the smoker, second hand individual non-smokers, and the environment has empowered business to find reasonable alternatives to cigarettes for individuals to chose as a means for nicotine. The e-cigarette is a idea that was created for these individuals. This idea has allowed business to expand their business model and create jobs for US citizens a down economy. I understand the need to regulate e-cigarettes as a drug, however, to begin to regulate where and when people could use this product is taking away from our individual freedom of choice. E-cigarettes unlike tobacco cigarettes do not cause harm to individuals. DR. Anthony Panariello, M.D – Pulmonologist states: "Electronic Cigarette contains zero cancer causing elements in other words no carcinogens. Secondhand smoke in cigarettes have been known to cause cancer to non-smokers. Electronic Cigarette does not produce any secondhand smoke in the traditional sense – it only produces harmless vapor which according to lab reports contains 99% of water and 1% of nicotine and other trace elements which have deemed non-harmful by the FDA." I would have to argue that if you remove e-cigarettes from aircraft, because it is classified as a drug, you would have to regulate the sale of alcoholic beverages on aircraft for the same reason. For the record I am not a smoker and agree with many of the state regulations on banning smoking from public places do to the risk on other individuals, all of which e-cigarettes do not cause on others. Also, please remember the impact this is going to have on the business of e-cigarettes and the move people will make to go back to tobacco products (known to cause cancer) which according to the newly passed Affordable Health Care Act would make the price of insurance rise for both individuals and business.

Title: Nathaniel Robert Keller
Comment: I am writing in response the proposed ban on electronic cigarettes on U.S. flights.  I believe that electronic cigarettes should be allowed on flights, and in some instances, their use could be beneficial.  In your docket, DOT-OST-2011-0044, you state that “We see no reason to treat electronic cigarettes any differently than traditional cigarettes. The purpose behind the statutory ban on smoking aboard aircraft and the regulatory ban in part 252 on smoking tobacco products was to improve air quality within the aircraft, reduce the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers, and enhance aviation safety and passenger comfort”(Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, para. 4).  Many smokers that are trying to quit switch to e-cigarettes to try and ease the transition.  An electronic cigarette satisfies a smoker’s cravings in two ways.  First, it supplies the needed nicotine to calm the smoker’s nerves.  Second, many smokers have a physical fixation with the act of smoking the cigarette (having it in their mouth, holding it in their hand) and an electronic cigarette helps them deal with this.  Air in commercial passenger aircraft is continually refreshed.  A Boeing 707 for example, has a complete air change refresh time of 5-7 minutes.  While traditional cigarettes contain tar and other additives that make the stench of cigarettes linger, new electronic cigarettes do not.  Also, electronic cigarettes usually contain a battery powered heater; no open flame is required, or sustained inside.  This alleviates another large safety concern concern.   I also believe being able to use electronic cigarettes on a plane might actually increase flight safety.  Fewer people will try to smoke in the lavatories, the act of which requires disabling or permanently breaking the lavatory fire alarm.  These reasons are why smoking electronic cigarettes should be allowed on commercial aircraft flights.

Title: Melissa Harmon
Comment: I support the proposed rule. I do not feel that electronic cigarettes should be allowed on any flight. I do not know a lot of information regarding electronic cigarettes, however I am pretty sure that there is an odor, and ingredients that could irritate passenger eyes and and throats. The possible risks of this product are unproven, however it would be irritant in a pretty confined area. Amtrak has banned the use of e-cigarettes anywhere that smoking is banned and the airlines should as well.

Title: Staci Marie Schurhamer
Comment: I think that they should be allowed to use electronic cigarettes on an aircraft. It does not produce anything harmful or bad vapors it only has a water vapor that comes out of it. It might be uncomfortable to some people but it is harmless to the human being. There should be bigger concerns happening in todays world other than a water vapor cigarette.

Title: Jeff Ransom
Comment:
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0044]
RIN 2105-AE06
Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft

I would like to submit a comment for consideration of the current policy prohibiting the smoking of Electronic Cigarettes or E-Cigarettes on aircraft.  I support the current ban, and I hope the Food and Drug Administration makes it clear to include all cigarettes banned from aircraft public or private.  Currently, the majority of electronic cigarette smokers try to work a gray area of legality.  They feel that electronic cigarettes are not actual cigarettes, but even the makers of electronic cigarettes agree that more testing needs to be done to find out the true effects from smoking electronic cigarettes.  According to an article in the Huffington Post dated 
February 11, 2011, Jason Healy the president of Blu Cigs, he understands the current ban on the product.  He says, "It's not the actual product, it's the disruption and explaining to everyone else that it's not smoke."  According to the same article, users and distributors both claim electronic cigarettes address both the nicotine addiction and the behavioral aspects of smoking.  It addresses holding of the cigarette, the puffing, seeing the smoke come out, and the hand motion.  It falls in the category of a cigarette, and therefore should fall under the ban.  I hope that more testing is done to prove such.  There should not be any gray area that the users can claim it is ok for them to smoke in flight.  The vapors produced from electronic cigarettes are manufactured from nicotine products which makes it a cigarette.  I hope you take these comments in consideration for your final decision.

Title: Samuel Anderson
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Ravien Evans
Comment:
I am in favor of this proposed rule. Electronic cigarettes may be less harmful than traditional cigarettes but it does not mean they are not harmful at all. Aircrafts even the largest of them are constrained spaces and being forced to sit next to or in close proximity to someone submitting vapor into the air could be harmful and may cause discomfort. Personally I would not want to sit next to someone smoking an electronic cigarette on a plane.
	After reviewing the proposed policy I think that “smoking” may unintentionally include medical devises. To stir away from this issue I find it important to specifically state that the smoking of medically produced vapor devices are not apart of this ban and are allowed on aircraft. It is important to allow those who need to be medically treated by vapor devices can do such while traveling. 
	I believe the purposed rule will only have benefits. If an individual does not get the opportunity to smoke on the aircraft nothing bad could happen to them or their neighbors. But if an individual does get the opportunity to smoke on an aircraft there could be a lot of costly consequences that we do not know about. More testing and regulations should be required, and until then they absolutely should not be allowed on aircraft.

Title: Eric R. Haynes
Comment:
I have reservations about the reasoning behind making this explicit ban.

Removing cigarettes from airplanes was a fantastic change. They smell, leave ashes, are a fire hazard, and give off second hand smoke. Being locked in a confined space with a bunch of smokers even makes a smoker feel that he smells gross. I'm completely with you on that decision.

However, on the flip side, being locked in non-smoking areas for hours at a time causes a certain amount of discomfort for smokers. I would think that electronic cigarettes would be the solution, not a problem.

I never smoked in my home or my car, but I do use an e-cig in these places because there is no lasting odor. It can be smelled slightly, but the flavoring used resembles that found in chewing gum. Much as, yes, there is some slightly noticeable odor of a passenger chewing gum, an e-cig might have a slight scent. But it is not smoke, does not contain tar, and thus doesn't saturate clothing and cause the discoloration on the surfaces of the seating area. The scent is rarely an offensive one, and in fact non-users have often noted that they like it

There is no evidence that the vapor exhaled is dangerous to other passengers. Second hand smoke risks from cigarettes are due to their carcinogenic ingredients. The trace amounts of nicotine (the only exhaled chemical from a e-cig) exhaled was never one of the second hand smoke risks, and is comparable to that found in a tomato.

There is a stigma associated with electronic cigarettes that it's "like smoking". It does resemble it visually and in how it is used. That's part of its allure to smokers. However, they were designed specifically to allow something *like* smoking without all of the negative impact caused by traditional cigarettes.

Contrary to this proposal, I would think that the DOT would encourage a large sign saying, "May be used on airplanes:" attached to the top of a vending machine dispensing simple e-cig devices, and everyone would be content.

Title: Paula
Comment: This is beyond ridiculous. Vaping is at least 99% safer than cigarette smoking according to research conducted in the UK. 2 or 3 non-carcinogenic compounds plus flavoring compared to 4,000 known chemicals in cigarettes - sounds like this agency has way too much time on their hands, or are being pressured by pharmacuetical companies who manufacture smoking cessation drugs that not only don't work, but can be dangerous and deadly. Shame on you for attacking people who have found a way to quit smoking forever.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes are not the same as cigarette smoking and produce no smoke at all.This regulation would be extremely unfair.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.

Title: Matthew Zukowski
Comment:
The DOT is proposing $2300-3000 fines if someone is caught using an e-cigarette on an air plane.  Please keep in mind that European airliners actually sell e-cigarettes for use on flights.  This is excessive and unjustified.  

The DOT has failed to present any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a risk to bystanders, and in fact approves the use of propylene glycol for deicing. 

The DOT only regulates smoking, which has a ton of scientific evidence on it's objective impact on air quality.  

The DOT like the FDA has no evidence of a single person being harmed, user or bystander, from the use of e-cigarettes, and have been in use by US air travelers for 5 years.

Provide the evidence there is an objective impact to the health of bystanders, then you can regulate it.  Until this time, this is beyond your scope.  

I personally use e-cigarettes with friends with asthma, and one person who lost a lung from cancer.  All objective evidence indicates it's statistically equal to not smoking.

Title: Mark Daniel Walsh
Comment:
M. Daniel Walsh
CEO Akston Hughes International

As CEO of Akston Hughes International, it has been my duty to oversee and Directr the Research and Technology associated with Electronic Cigarettes and Personal Vaporizes usage within confined, closed, and / or 'shared air' spaces.

Whether the concern be psychological or physiological, as policy makers we must seek to err on the side of caution regarding public welfare while maintaining public comfort and liberty as uncompromised priorities.

To these ends, Akston Hughes is preparing the eminent release of a device which completely eliminates exhaled vapor BEFORE it is released into the shared airspace.

This device - 'The Exhaler' allows users of Electronic Cigarettes and Portable Vaporizers to exhale into a small HEPA styled tube which completely filters all particulates from the exhaled breath.

Visibly, this creates 'NO VISIBLE' vapor, and upon testing these 'Exhaler Tubes' provide HEPA quality filtration down to the .3micron level assuring that absolutely no Nicotine enters the shared air space.

It is a solution which offers the best of all worlds: 

1. Protects the Shared Airspace from Contaminants and Irritants
2. Removes the visible disturbance of vapor
3. Preserves the Liberty and Comfort of the 45million Americans who currently smoke and may use Portable Vaporizes during confined travel.

Be aware that "1/5 of our American Population" are tobacco users.  Refering to this constituency as a 'tiny fraction' is a misnomer, when in fact 45 million Americans constitute a huge segment of the airline commerce - the comfort of these passengers must be closely considered in the regulation of these new devices.

In closing, may I suggest, legislation be written in such a way as to afford:

1. Voluntary compliance from Airlines (preserve liberty by leaving an option open)

2. Include wording to accommodate the use of Approved HEPA styled 'Exhalers' for use in these confined shared spaces.

Sincerely,
M. Daniel Walsh

Title: Deborah Lee Guardino
Comment:
Hello,
     I am writing to comment on your proposed regulation concerning electronic cigarettes.
 #1. I feel that the fines that would be imposed are both unreasonable and excessive.
 #2. There is no evidence that electronic cigarettes pose any health threat to bystanders. In fact my husband is allerigic to cigarette smoke and suffers no ill effect from my electronic cigarettes use both in our home and in in vehicle with the windows closed.
 #3. I feel that this regulaltion is contrary to federal law in that the use of an electronic cigarette is not the same as smoking.
 
Thank you

Title: Alex Ching
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes are a great alternative for those with the initiative to quit smoking.

I as a someone who uses electronic cigarettes understand the implications of Smoking in an enclosed area let along smoking on a plane,

I work in a call centre where I am allowed to use my electronic cigarette.
Managers have seen it, have asked questions and once I actually take a "puff" they smell it and they always comment on how pleasant it smells.

We electronic cigarette users do not produce harmful chemicals, we do not wreak of dirty cigarette smells.

As an ex-smoker, I feel bad for those that sat beside me when i did smoke, thats my honest opinion.

All seriousness aside, if someone was to # 2 in the washroom, but used a fruity pleaseant smelling electronic cigarette, im sure the next person to use the washroom would be happier about that.

We understand the government regulations but our voices should also be heard.

We are choosing a healthier alternative.
we are no longer burning and releasing toxins into the air.
We care about our heath & of those around us, therefore we do not smoke.

Quitting smoking is an ongoing battle no matter where in the world.  Tobacco companies profit at the expense of people's health, and Government intervention with healthcare always mention the harmful effects of smoking.  So why are we preventing people from choosing a healthier lifestyle.

Whoever reads this, if you do happen to smoke or know someone who does, persuade them to change to electronic cigarettes.  It's the best thing you can do for that person if you do truly care about them and their well being.

thanks

Title: Tomislav Vujec
Comment: I don't see any reference on why this would be a reasonable course of action. There is no scientific or even incidentary evidence showing any health impact on bystanders. E-cigarette vapor is more comparable to vapor from a hot beverage as opposed to any kind of smoke, including e.g. smoke generated by electronic devices that include motor, like laptops or DVD players.

Title: Christopher Dale Johanson
Comment: I believe that things should not be banned without some evidence of harm, and in the case of the use of electronic cigarettes there is no proof or even evidence that they do harm to the user, let alone bystanders.  Studies show parts per billion of nicotine in the vapor itself, and test after test confirms this, both from our government and others.  In fact, calling it "Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft (Document ID DOT-OST-2011-0044-0003)" is, in itself, a misnomer as there is no smoking involved.  Air travel is painful enough these days, and a device that has less evidence of harm than a cell phone should be allowed to be used to keep people happy.

Title: Matt Frye
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Scott B.
Comment:
Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use should not be (and I believe IS not) an issue within DOT purview.

The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking.  Since there is no fire or smoke, the use of an e-cigarette is not the equivalent of smoking & should not be treated as such.

Further research on the part of DOT, along with valid analysis of same, would seem to be in order prior to taking any action regarding this issue.

Title: Nik Rusimovic
Comment:
I feel this proposal is unfair and unnecessary and is being done without proper research being done first. I haven't smoked a real cigarette for almost three years now. My health has improved drastically because of this. I also use e-liquid that does not contain nicotine now. I know many people who have stepped down to "zero nic" liquids, but the habit itself of the hand to mouth action, satisfies them. Why put a rule in place for people that aren't even really smoking, let alone people that aren't even using a device that contains nicotine?

Regardless of the name "ecig" it really has nothing to do with being a cigarette at all for some. It's not real smoke. It's not something combusting. These devices are vaporizers. They are heating a liquid and people are inhaling steam essentially. Yes there are flavorings, but they aren't being combusted. They aren't harmful to people around them and these juices contain PG or VG which are GRAS (Generally recognized as safe) by the FDA.

The fact of the matter is, there HAVE been studies done on the inhalation of PG and it's not harming anyone. PG is used in inhalers and even injected intravenously in medications. It's in food, soaps, shampoo, body washes, and other bathroom products... and guess what... when you use those things on your skin, you absorb it right into your blood stream. If PG was so bad, it wouldn't be so widely used in various applications and approved as safe by the FDA.

I fail to see any evidence provided by the DOT that they have found vaporizing to be unsafe to other people around users. Also, my understanding is that DOT only has authority to regulate smoking, and vaporizing is not smoking. I also fail to see how this is going to be enforced. Vaping does not leave ash, litter, smoke, or smell left behind. So how is someone going to be accused when you can't even prove what they were doing. People should have the freedom to vape. The United States was based on freedom, not tyranny.

Title: Jacqueline Stallings
Comment:
It would be my strong hope that DOT will not pursue this proposed rule.  Vaping, or the use of e-cigarettes, contains no dangers to others like second hand smoke does. There is no fire, flame, combustion or any detected carcinogens to make this product a hazard to either the user or others. I believe the non-vaping community mistakenly feels that cigarette smoking and the use of e-cigarettes are similar ... they are not. The liquid in an e-cigarette contains only vegetable or propylene glycol base, nicotine and flavoring.  The "vape" exhaled is produced from the body's own moisture.  

Before you make your ruling, I would respectfully request that you educate yourselves first on the electronic cigarette.

Title: John M. Sabla
Comment:
" We are unaware of sufficient studies on the health 
impact on third parties from these vapors to conclude that they would not negatively impact the air quality"

Given the already, much derided, overcomplicated and overreaching nature of government regulations, it seems irresponsible to create even more regulation, regulation which would be unenforceable as there is no way to prove an act of "vaping" has occurred as no evidence is left and no smell produce, based on a lack of sufficient studies that conclude that they would not negatively impact air quality. 

 There are literally countless things which we lack a study concluding they would not negatively impact air quality. If such a regulation is needed then before it should be passed the government has a responsibility to
a) Prove that it would have a negative impact on air quality
b) Have an effective means of actually proving such action occurs.

Without either of the two above criteria being met we are left with an unenforceable bit of regulation, regulating something based on an unverified alteration of air quality that may or may not be occurring.

Title: Amanda J. Patricks
Comment:
I feel that making vaping illegal is unneccesary in addition to the rules already established by the airlines that wish to regulate their passengers' activities. 
Furthermore, the proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

Title: Nick Rusimovic
Comment:
I find it interesting that you put this quote in the proposal "Contrary to the claims of the manufacturers and marketers of e-cigarettes being `safe,' in fact nothing is known about the toxicity of the vapors generated by these e-cigarettes."

Yet here is a study, on a government website, talking about the affects of PG which is used as a carrier for a prescription drug which is inhaled.

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18158714

Here is another site that did actual testing of PG inhalation.

http://jpet.aspetjournals.org/content/91/1/52.abstract

So in my opinion, the article from Science Daily is not true. To state nothing is known about the inhalation of vapors when there clearly is data on this, and then to include such an example in this proposal seems a bit hasty and neither Science Daily or DOT seems to have done their research.

Furthermore, Science Daily says the group that tested this had these main observations: 

1. The e-cig hardware doesn't have proper information and warnings. (Obviously this can be easily remedied by including that information, but this has nothing to do with the vapors harming other people)

2. E-cig cartridges could leak which exposes users to nicotine. (Well, aren't they kind of being exposed to nicotine by using the product in the first place?)

3. Currently there are no methods of proper disposal for cartridges, which could lead to contamination of water and soil. (And currently there are no methods of disposal for a lot of things. Making this claim is a bit ridiculous though. Garbage and litter of all kinds, ends up everywhere, including soil and water... that would also include the litter from regular tobacco cigarette butts and wrappers/packaging from cigarettes. E-cigs aren't something that people buy every day like cigarettes and don't create nearly the same amount of waste"

4. The manufacturing, quality control, and advertising is unregulated. (Again, this has nothing to do with harming other people by vaping)

Title: Alan
Comment:
This regulation is really rather silly. I have nothing at stake in this as I do not use e-cigs but I have researched them a bit as I know a few people who use them. 

From all the evidence I have seen there is no danger to any non-users of e-cigs from second had vapor. This regulation appears to be nothing more then a mean-spirited approach to the issue of tobacco/nicotine use. There is in fact a growing amount of evidence that it is completely harmless to non-users. Vape away folks as it doesn't bother me one bit.

Title: Ted Edward McCune
Comment:
Good Day,

As an ex-smoker I would like to take this opportunity to point out some flaws in legislative proposals to ban e-cigarette use in public. 

Since the vapor from e-cigarettes does not produce harmful chemicals the way cigarettes do they cannot be compared in any meaningful manner. The burning of tobacco leaves produce over 4000 chemicals whereas vaporizing glycerin or propylene glycol has shown to produce absolutely no chemicals whatsoever. 

There are also some sticky legal issues with your proposal as well, to wit:

1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. There exists, however, plenty of evidence that e-cigarette vapor produces no toxic substances whatsoever.

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking".  E-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught “vaping” are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5. Millions of anecdotal stories, including mine, support the scientific evidence that e-cigarette usage is not only a safe alternative to tobacco use, it helps smokers quit as well, unlike the ineffective methods promoted by the pharmaceutical industry.

Please be sure to check the science as well as all the stories of healthier ex-smokers whose lives have been saved by e-cigarettes. Ask doctors who are overjoyed that their patients have stopped their use of tobacco. Make a sensible and informed decision. Once you have seen the science and the results in actual human lives, you can only conclude that e-cigarette use poses no threat public health or safety and in fact will improve health and safety for ex-smokers and the general public as well.

Thank you.

Title: Patricia Kay Clewell
Comment:
There's no scientific- or health-based reason to prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on flights--much less to attach such an exorbitant fine to it, for heaven's sake. E-cigarettes do not produce smoke, and the vapor is virtually odorless. There's no flame, no ash, and no butts, either, so I'm not sure how this would even be enforceable. 

There are far more important issues calling for our tax dollars. This is unnecessary--a waste of time, effort, and money. I urge the DOT to reconsider.

Title: Shawn Ward Pettit
Comment: The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. There is not heat, ash, or chemical byproduct produced by these products. There is no threat that can be isolated to the use of these products and since at this time e-cigarette use is not considered "smoking" by any part of the government the DOT has no authority to actually regulate the use of them.

Title: John Alexander Connell
Comment: The proposal to ban electronic cigarettes on aircraft is in my opinion not necessary and initself problematic.  This is a vapor that is not combusted and thus produces no smoke.  The argument that it may irritate others or have detrimental effects toward others is not valid.  If this is indeed the primary concern addressed then the wearing of cologne, perfume or other chemical agents should be thoroughly addressed as well.  These are smokeless products that are in no need of regulation.

Title: Mark Hoogendoom
Comment: This decision should be left up to the airlines and the passengers.

Title: David Anthony Borrero
Comment:
This rule should not be imposed because electronic users are not smoking anything. Unlike smoking this device does not burn anything, leave any ash or foul odors. There is no second hand smoke because there is no smoke at all!!!
There is no evidence that this vapor adversely effects the air quality. Also like any other electronic device if asked to stop using it they must stop just like anyone using an i pad or cell phone so an additional rule is not needed.
Please do not group electronic vaporizers under the same rules as smoking because this is not a tobacco product and users of this device have made the long hard struggle to quit smoking by using this. This device is saving lives everyday and though I don't want you to promote using these devices on your airline, I would only hope you would not treat this device as a tobacco product  It is not smoking and should not be treated as such.
Thank you for your time and I would hope you are listening to the very same people who ride the airlines everyday.

Title: Troop Wol
Comment: Please educate yourselves on the difference between e-cigs and smoking. It's not up to we the people to do so. E-cigs have succeeded where all of the other smoking alternatives have failed for me. I beat a 20 year smoking habit with the use of a non-combustible device that is the e-cig. It produces NO smoke, and is not burning anything. Furthermore, the DOT has no authority to create its own definitions of smoking. E-cigs produce no smoke.

Title: Michael Wheway
Comment:
This ban is nothing more then an uninformed, knee-jerk reaction to the public's misinformed bias against anything that remotely resembles smoking.

1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

6. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

Over the past 10 years, I have tried numerous times to stop smoking.  I have tried every type of stop-smoking alternative I could find, and the only thing that has worked is an electronic cigarette.  Since I started using it, my sense of taste and smell have returned, I can breath easily, and I don't smell like an ashtray all the time.
I vape in my home, around my pets and my family.  The "smoke" (Which isn't smoke at all) doesn't leave a funky residue or smell, it doesn't bother the pets, and it doesn't bother our family or friends that strongly dislike the smell of cigarettes.
There have been studies showing that the exhaled vapor contains nothing more then water vapor and trace amounts of flavoring.
Will we ban glasses of water next?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
To whom it concerns:

As an ex-smoker I would like to take this opportunity to point out some flaws in legislative proposals to ban e-cigarette use in public. 

Since the vapor from e-cigarettes does not produce harmful chemicals the way cigarettes do they cannot be compared realistically. The burning of tobacco leaves produce over 4000 chemicals whereas vaporizing glycerin or propylene glycol has shown to produce absolutely no chemicals whatsoever. 

There are also some sticky legal issues with your proposal as well, to wit:

1..The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders..There exists, however, plenty of evidence that e-cigarette vapor produces no toxic substances whatsoever.

2..The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking". E-cigarette use is not smoking.

3..The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught “vaping” are unreasonable and excessive.

4..The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5..Millions of anecdotal stories, including mine, support the scientific evidence that e-cigarette usage is not only a safe alternative to tobacco use, it helps smokers quit as well, unlike the ineffective methods promoted by the pharmaceutical industry.

Please be sure to check the science as well as all the stories of healthier ex-smokers whose lives have been saved by e-cigarettes. Many healthcare professionals are overjoyed that their patients have stopped smoking. Make a sensible and informed decision. Once you have seen the science and the results in actual human lives, you can only conclude that e-cigarette use poses no threat to public health or safety and in fact will improve health and safety for ex-smokers and the general public

Title: Stephanie R. Murphey
Comment: I can say that I understand a non-smokers view, as I am a former smoker and my fiance' still smokes.  Well he now smokes electronic cigarettes and I do allow them in the home.  The scent is not obnoxious and sometimes it actually smells fruity or sweet depending on what flavor he is using.  It would certainly be nice if the government would allow the airlines to make good common sense decisions and stay out of the private lives of citizens.  There is no fire, flame, or smoke.  It is all vapor and the vapor does not contain the carbon monoxide that cigarette smoking does.  Ken Cuccinelli our State Attorney General is very supportive of electronic cigarettes and has voiced that he supports them being allowed in restaurants.

Title: Pam Briggs
Comment:
I am very distressed to see this. I fully quit smoking. The vaporizers I use do sooo much less harm to myself, and certainly there is no evidence that any harm is done to others. I would also like to make the following points:


1 The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

2 The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

I realize the FDA is having a temper tantrum over the US Justice System unanimous ruling that they have no right to regulate these products- after all, we also use them in larger sizes in our childrens bedrooms when they have chest cold- Therefore, doctors individually support them. 

So why must we ban products for personal use on airplanes? 

Thank you.

Title: Ethan Edward Becker
Comment: Regarding to the proposed rule change to ban electronic cigarettes on commercial flights and most charter flights, I have a few issues with the proposed regulation.  First, I do not think the language involved in the previous ruling is strong enough to in fact cover electronic cigarettes with other tobacco products.  Since the electronic cigarettes have a different chemical make-up, a slightly different function, and a different product produced, despite meaning to imitate regular cigarettes or as stated “derived from cigarettes”, the electronic cigarettes are thus different from regular tobacco products.  Being derived from a cigarette doesn’t mean a necessary health risk to the person using the product or someone else.  If banning electronic cigarettes is the goal of the department, explicit banning of the product may be necessary.  Second, admitted within the proposed rule is the fact that there was not a fair amount of research done on the harmful effects of the vapor produced by the electronic cigarettes, and how they affect others.  I agree that the safety of the passengers is a top priority, but making such a drastic move without credible sufficient evidence is a mistake.  I would suggest postponing the proposed rule until more evidence showing the harmful effects of the vapor has been produced.  I understand the department’s view on smoking related matters, and the health effects of them, but having a product that is, while similar, not of the same content of regular cigarettes, does not mean that it has the same effects of the imitated product.  When talking about the benefits of such a rule, if the product is found to not be harmful, then the cost of implementing the rule would be more than the benefit gained.  That is why I would suggest postponing the proposed rule.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic Cigarettes are no different from Asthma Inhalers. This is ridiculous to fine someone. They can use a nicotine gum and use an asthma inhaler, but if they use an inhaler designed to deliver nicotine they get fined several thousand dollars. Get a grip people.

Title: Vicki Woods
Comment: This just seems ridiculous to ban electronic cigarettes on airplanes! There's nothing harmful in the vapor emitted by e-cigs. I'm much more bothered by some of the perfumes and colognes that fellow passengers wear than by e-cig vapor. I admit the public will need to be educated about the devices, but that seems easy enough. I do know they are allowed on many other countries--even encouraged. I'm getting awfully weary of living in a nanny state.

Title: Colin McQuillan
Comment: Regarding the making of using e-cigarettes on airplanes illegal, I believe that your proposition is unreasonable and unfair to the users of these devices that are only trying to live a healthier life, and are in no way harming those around them.  There is no smoke, merely water vapor that is emitted from these devices and although it may look like smoke, which understandably can be alarming to someone on an airplane, rather than demonize these devices people need to know more about them.  Attorney generals from, i believe, 2 states have already shown that there is no harm done to those around e-cigarette users.  To impose such a harsh penalty with no reason other than a likeness to a well known dangerous activity (smoking tobacco cigarettes), hurts both the people who are trying to live a healthier life and those that may benefit from this safer activity if they are made aware of the truth of the safety of these devices.  In addition, I would like to add that when I smoked tobacco cigarettes it would give my girlfriend allergies, merely when I walked into the same room as her.  Since I have stopped smoking and started "vaping," I have constantly done so in her presence and it has never once caused her the slightest discomfort.  If more people were exposed to e-cigarettes there is a great chance that we would all benefit from the harmless vapor that is produced.  Think of all the people who could live a longer healthier life if e-cigarettes are recognized as a much healthier alternative to smoking rather than being demonized.  Please reconsider what you have proposed, as it is unreasonable, unfounded, and not based on any real danger to anyone involved.

Title: Alan Michael Mullen
Comment:
I was a cigarette smoker for over 25+ years. I have been cigarette free for over 1 month because of electronic cigs. I have tried everything to quit, and ecigs allowed me to quit in one night! My health has sky rocketed, I don't smell like smoke anymore, my house smells wonderful, no more ashes, smoke stains. No more tar, carcinogens... It's just water vapor... Most of the vapors have wonderful scents that are pleasing to smell. It's considered vaping NOT Smoking. Ecigs should be allowed on airplanes, and everywhere where smoking is not allowed! Because it is not considered "Smoking"
Ecigs have saved my life! And I wish all smokers would attempt to try this life saving method. It's basically just wearing a nicotine patch, or chewing on a piece of nicorette gum. (Even though those didn't work for me) It's the same principal. 

Alan Mullen - Concerned Vaper!

Title: John Schonfeld
Comment:
Sirs, this ban seems unreasonable and harsh. Ecigarettes are a known, safe, alternative to tobacco cigarettes. There is no dangerous second hand "smoke" since there is no combustion. Individual airlines already have sufficient rules and authority to deal with any specific questions dealing with Eciagrettes...no new ban, specifically regarding Ecigarettes  should be made and could only be viewed in a prejudicial manner....
Thank You
John Schonfeld

Title: Cheryl Lucille Richter
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern,
I am disheartened that the DOT is so grossly misinformed as to believe that there are "potential health and passenger comfort concerns" that electronic cigarettes pose in an aircraft. This is simply not true and if it were, asthma inhalers and nebulizers would need to be banned as well, as the exhaled vapor from e-cigarettes is the same. Please do not ban them. I truly believe they have saved my life. After more than 30 years of smoking, I never picked up another cigarette and I know first hand the benefits to my health I've enjoyed. The more the government does to impede their use, the more it becomes impossible to believe that the government actually cares whether people live or die.

Title: B. Peterson
Comment:
The DOT should NOT include 'electronic cigarettes' in it's airline smoking ban.  The simple reason for not including 'electronic cigarettes' in the airline smoking ban is that 'electronic cigarettes' do not produce smoke.  There is NO combustion involved in the operation of an 'electronic cigarette', therefore no smoke is produced.  
A VERY SMALL heating coil is utilized to VAPORIZE a solution consisting of one or more of the following: propylene glycol (often abbreviated as PG), vegetable glycerin (often abbreviated as VG), water, flavorings and nicotine.  All components, except nicotine, are classified as GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe) by the FDA.  The solution contained in an 'electronic cigarette' DOES NOT necessarily contain ALL of these components.  If the solution in an 'electronic cigarette' does not contain nicotine, then all components in the solution are considered GRAS.  Even if there is nicotine in the 'electronic cigarette' solution, there has been NO EVIDENCE that the VAPOR produced by an 'electronic cigarette' is harmful to bystanders.

Title: Lorain Mendleson
Comment: Since e-cigarettes produce no smoke, no ash, are virtually, odorless, and cause no harm to others, there is no need to regulate their use on aircraft. There is no smoke produced by an electronic cigarette; users are not smoking. There is no combustion at all. There is no need for this proposed rule.

Title: Charles Aaron Frazier
Comment:
As an ex-smoker I would like to take this opportunity to point out some flaws in legislative proposals to ban e-cigarette use in public.

Since the vapor from e-cigarettes does not produce harmful chemicals the way cigarettes do they cannot be compared in any meaningful manner. The burning of tobacco leaves produce over 4000 chemicals whereas vaporizing glycerin or propylene glycol has shown to produce absolutely no chemicals whatsoever.

There are also some legal issues with your proposal as well, to wit:

1..The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders..There exists, however, plenty of evidence that e-cigarette vapor produces no toxic substances whatsoever.

2..The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking". E-cigarette use is not smoking.

3..The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught “vaping” are unreasonable and excessive.

4..The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5..Millions of anecdotal stories, including mine, support the scientific evidence that e-cigarette usage is not only a safe alternative to tobacco use, it helps smokers quit as well, unlike the ineffective methods promoted by the pharmaceutical industry.

Please be sure to check the science as well as all the stories of healthier ex-smokers whose lives have been saved by e-cigarettes. Ask doctors who are overjoyed that their patients have stopped their use of tobacco. Make a sensible and informed decision. Once you have seen the science and the results in actual human lives, you can only conclude that e-cigarette use poses no threat public health or safety and in fact will improve health and safety for ex-smokers and the general public as well.

Thank you.

Title: Jordan D. Marsengill
Comment: The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

Title: Lynn Repko
Comment:
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

6. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

7. Adult are more and more being harassed over their legal and unharmful activity by out of control government agencies. It has to stop.

Title: Dawn M. Noren
Comment: I'm writing request that the DOT NOT ban personal vaporizers (e-cigarettes) on airplanes.  This safe device has easily saved my life after smoking for 18 years, and also the lives of numerous other people that I know.  I tried patches, nicotine gum, cold turkey, self-help....nothing worked.  I'm now smoke-free because of e-cigarettes and feel better than ever.  Nicotine is known to be nearly as safe as caffeine and even has health benefits.  Banning a device with nicotine mixed with PV and/or VG, both found in food and common household items, would make no sense whatsoever.  There is zero evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.  This is not smoking.  There is no 'smoke'!  Banning an e-cigarette would be like banning an asthma inhaler.  Furthermore, the proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.  Please do not ban e-cigarettes.

Title: Ruth Anna Stenske
Comment: I am very much opposed to this rule. As a former smoker, electronic cigarettes have greatly improved my health. Everything from my sense of taste, smell, and lung function has improved due to this marvelous technology. I live in a home with 6 other people, and none of them have experienced ANY side effects from "second hand vaping" Propelyne Glycol is FDA approved, and is in many products we use today. I would like to note as well, that MANY things in the air can cause minor irritations in the nose/throat and cause a slight cough. I see absolutely no reason why electronic cigarettes should be banned on flights, as they have not been proven to cause any risk to the public. It seems to be just another way to appease the public who disapprove of the "appearance of smoking" If there were scientific evidence that showed it was harmful I would stand behind the rule. As things stand, there simply is none. It's a amazing technology, that should be accepted, and even promoted, to deture people from traditional cigarettes which are harmful, and inevitably may cause death.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: You should not attempt to forbid vaping on airplanes. There is no proof that electronic cigarettes cause any harm to anyone. The fines suggested are outrageous.

Title: Reverend Gerard G. Repko
Comment:
This proposed ban is ridiculous and should be left up to the airlines to police themselves. As an ex smoker who's lungs and life have been saved by e cigarettes I strongly oppose all of the beuracracy that they are trying to put in place just so politicians can line their pockets, and big tobacco companies continue to  get rich from the millions of deaths their products cause yearly.
My own pulmonolgist has praised the ecigarette as she has seen first hand the damage that thirty five years of smoking has done to my lungs, and then the incredible change in that damage with the switch to the e cigarette. 

There is no proof that second hand vapor has ever received a valid complaint or endangered anyone else's  health. Unlike big tobacco companies products that hid their findings for many years .

Title: Drew Gliem
Comment:
Im appalled that you would consider this. It really does not serve to protect anyone and feeds the rumor and bad science that casts a negative lite on Electronic Cigarettes and other harm reduction products. 
The Electronic Cigarette stands to save milions of lives in the upcoming years...If it saves ONE, it would negate this rule.
Please consider this and take a stand to do the right thing here.

Title: Stuard E. Wiggen
Comment:
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5. The e-cigarette changed my life, and my family, friends, and acquaintances have zero problem with being around e-cigarette users. I have been smoke-free for more than 1 year and 300 days.

6. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

7. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

Title: Scott Jeffrey Pullar
Comment:
After a close examination of both the proposed rule by the Department of Transportation, that being the attempt to ban electronic cigarettes on passenger aircraft, along with the studies performed on the health risks of said item, I feel informed and inclined to comment on the issue. I feel that the current statutory ban on smoking on aircraft was intended to include all types of smoking and not just tobacco products, which would place electronic cigarettes in the prohibited category. Language used in section 708 “Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights” only includes the term smoking and lacks to explicitly list the items that comprise this vague definition. It is for this reason that I commend the Department of Transportation in their attempt to amend the ban to eliminate questions. 
	I am in agreement with the Department of Transportation's proposed rule to ban electronic cigarettes for reasons geared more towards public satisfaction than potential health risks. The studies that were conducted by researchers at the University of California do not present a very convincing argument as to the negative health effects of electronic cigarettes, so the argument is a weak one at this time to use as a point of persuasion. However, I am arguing in favor of the proposed rule on the basis that any act of smoking, whether tobacco or an artificial product, that occurs on a plan can and most likely would induce anxiety among other passengers, and potentially lead to negative confrontation between the user and either crew-members or other passengers. The last thing anybody wants in this day and age is any sort of panic or bickering on a plane, and I feel that an electronic cigarette could cause just this, or at the least raise constant surveillance by crew-members to insure order, which would result in the potential neglect of more important matters. Deprivation of an electronic cigarette for a few hour flight will not kill the user, and will instead satisfy all.

Title: Ian Chandos Gallagher
Comment:
After a careful examination of the proposed ban on the use of electronic cigarettes and the authority of the Department of Transportation concerning the regulation of tobacco products, I have come to the conclusion that the amendment to ban the use of these devices is a necessary action to ensure the air quality and safety of aircraft cabins. 
	The effects of the vapor that is released from these devices is not studied well enough to officially state that it is either safe or dangerous, and the inability to state that it is clearly not a health risk is adequate enough to at least temporarily ban the use of these products on passenger flights. In the future when more research can be done on how the vapor affects those around the smoker I believe this amendment should be revisited. If there is significant proof that there are no ill effects on the health of others from the products, the ban should be lifted. 
	At the present there is some research stating these vapors can irritate the throat of some third-party passengers, and there have been design flaws found in some of these devices that can expose surrounding passengers to the liquid nicotine within the cartridge of the device. As long as these dangers are present, these devices should not be allowed on flights. They are a risk to the health of others and can disrupt the comfort of other passengers on the flight. 
	I do agree with the idea proposed by the Department of Transportation, but I do hope that it can be revisited in the future once more adequate research can be done on the safety and health risks of electronic cigarettes.

Title: Chelsey Carothers
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Stephen R. Bowen
Comment:
After reading this rule and some separate information on e-cigarettes I think that this is a wise policy at least in the intermediate period, but there are a few issues that must be raised with the administration of this rule.  First there were numerous justifications for the banning electronic cigarettes on airplanes including possible health concerns, enhancing aviation safety, and passenger comfort.  Considering the health issue this rule noted the use of propylene glycol in these products might cause adverse reactions from people who have asthma, and the FDA has noted that some of these products contain diethylene glycol which is a toxic substance found in antifreeze.  Because of the presence of diethylene glycol in some of the e-cigarettes this does seem to have sufficient reason to worry.  The other issue is one of comfort for passengers which should likely carry less weight.  Admittedly I am fairly ignorant about the any smell or other issues that might cause issues for the non-smoking passengers.  If it is true though that it is basically odorless and the main defining characteristic is the visual of the vapor than this issue seems to be one that ought to be ruled in favor of the e-cigarette user since there would be very little effect on the other passengers.
While it is currently unknown the effect of the second hand smoke further research seems to be necessary from the FDA as they begin to look closer at this emerging trend.  While we wait because of the unknown composition of the vapor and knowledge of what is contained in some of the toxins e-cigarette cartridges in the intermediate future it is likely best to take a safe strategy and ban the use of e-cigarettes.   Previous smoking bans on tobacco products occurred because of the hazardous effects that the second hand smoke had on bystanders if e-cigarettes are benign and have no effect on bystanders then this rule should be considered for repeal or amendment.

Title: Shane Allan Welch
Comment:
Dear DOT, 
The recent proposal is fundamentally flawed for the following reasons.
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act. 

ecigarettes have been a lifesaver for countless numbers of people to take back our health and hygiene. they leave behind a very faint smell at best and the associated risks are very little in comparison. to regulate the use of such a device would be akin to regulating the steam coming off of a brewing coffee pot within an aircraft or the spray of non-aerosol perfume which in comparison would be quite bothersome to fellow occupants within an airplane. i sincerely hope this regulation does not pass.

Title: Don Grimme
Comment:
I beg you not to pass this proposed rule (Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft)!

I smoked tobacco cigarettes for over 40 years, quitting twice for about a year each time ... but resumed smoking because I missed it so much. I quit forever two and a half years ago, on the first day of my use of personal vaporizers (the more accurate name for "electronic cigarettes"). I'll never smoke again, because "vaping" e-cigs is much healthier and more pleasurable.

I am still addicted to nicotine and the hand-to-mouth, inhaling experience ... but now I don't ingest the tar and all the other harmful chemicals in tobacco smoke. There is no tobacco or any form of smoke in e-cigarettes. Also nothing is burned (so no fire hazard).

What looks like smoke is merely the vapor of atomized flavored USP-grade propylene glycol (used, for example, in asthma inhalers and foods) and/or USP-grade vegetative glycerin (used, for example, in foods, beverages, and pharmaceuticals). Since I am not exhaling smoke, there is, of course, no second-hand smoke.

Please do not deny me (and hundreds of thousands of others) this simple pleasure while flying. And certainly do not impose the proposed, excessive fines of $2,300 and $3,200, if I give into my cravings (hurting no one) while in an aircraft.

Thank you for your consideration!

Don Grimme, a former smoker and now a committed vaper

Title: Ronald W. Harris
Comment:
I have seen no evidence that proves that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. In fact, even though I’m a non smoker, I’ve been around e-cigs and have no ill effects from it. 
And since the e-cig is not smoking it’s plain to see that DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law since DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking." Again I say using the e-cigarette is not smoking because it creates vapor.
It’s even unreasonable and unbelievable that DOT considered the use of an e-cigarette to be "smoking for the beginning." Following this reason, a child playing with a toy that created steam would be considered a smoking.
I suppose you are asking why I’m so pro e-cig. The answer: it has worked for several friends and family. The improvement in their health is unbelievable. And it has become obvious that this whole anti thing has been blown out of proportion by many including the FDA, and a matter of the antis being totally unreasonable. It’s so obviously so when the antis play the “Ban it because of the children” which has been so over used for an excuse to control behavior.
Further more using the e-cig is totally better for the children since it leaves no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. The vapor from them will not put enough nicotine in the air to cause anymore harm than a brewing pot of coffee puts enough caffeine in the air to be harmful. Our factories, homes, cars, lawnmowers, boats, etc, present a BIGGER danger to our children and the rest of the public. One plane causes more pollution than every e-cig user on the planet!!!
As far as regulation in an airport or on a plane: The same rules or laws should apply that apply to using other electronic devices.
So, and I know that this is asking a lot these days, let government set reasonable rules or laws and not let, “Oh, my, but it looks like,” be the deciding factor.

Title: Rick Kyle Lonzy
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,

Please realize that I have quite smoking cigarettes. The tobacco variety that burns, has many different chemicals and carcinogens, cancer causing carcinogens.

My mother and father were both smokers. My mother died from COPD which was is caused by smoking tobacco products. My father died of lung cancer.

Please allow us who have chosen to quit traditional smoking of tobacco products to enjoy electronic cigarettes. It is only a heated liquid that is vaporized. So, we get our nicotine without all the cancer causing agents.

A liquid vapor is hardly offensive and quickly dissipates into the atmosphere, doesn't smell and doesn't leave a residual odor in the space the person occupies.

Thank you for your time and efforts.

Title: Richard Scott Brewer
Comment: The proposed regulation to make using an e-cigarette on a plane illegal is a misguided attempt to control something that mimics a prohibited activity.  What surprises me is that the DOT is not also proposing a regulation to make asthma medicine/inhalers illegal to use on airplanes as well.  Asthma inhalers contain the same Propylene Glycol ingredient found in most e-cigarettes.  The vapor that is visible in the output of an e-cigarette is almost identical to these inhalers and my wife has used these inhalers since she was a child on hundreds of flights without a single complaint from passengers or staff.  So why is it that now when e-cigarettes are becoming popular due to their beneficial smoking cessation effect is the DOT seeing this same PG-based vapor as yet another form of smoking.  I was a smoker for over 35 years and could never manage to quit the habit with any of the other conventional methods to stop smoking.  However with this wonderful e-cigarette technology, I was able to give up my 1.5 pack a day habit in just three weeks.  Additionally, I have not had another cigarette since using this technology for just shy of a year.  My asthmatic non-smoking wife could not be happier and I don't even have to go outside to use my therapeutic aide (e-cigarette). My wife is very susceptible to dangerous asthma attacks brought on by even the lightest concentration of cigarette smoke but for the past 11 months she has been completely unaffected by me vaping for several hours a night sitting beside her while watching TV.  Her doctor and mine think this technology is both safe and effective.  My doctor says he wishes he could give a e-cigarette starter kit to all of his cigarette smoking patients  If an airline says they do not want me vaping in the plane then that is their choice since they own the plane but the DOT needs to stop this attempt to vilify the e-cigarette and make it just one more thing that everybody will fear.

Title: Randall G. Fortenberry
Comment:
I am 71 years old and have been using using the e-cig for two years. I can not understand why you are making these strict regulations on something that doesn't affect anyone else. There must be some other motive, a tool of big tobacco, pharmacy industry or just people that like to make laws to be making laws. It is ridiculous whatever your motives are. These vaporizers have saved my life and you are trying to make me a criminal for using something that is keeping me off of an oxygen bottle and early death.
Please research this matter a little better before you act prematurely making an unneccesary law that will affect me and many others!

Title: Jun Song
Comment:
Dear Government. 

As a person who had used two different e-cigarettes for over six month, I agree with the proposal.
