The first e-cigarette I had was a gift from my ex-girlfriend who really hated smoking. There were reasons. First of all, smell; it smells doesn’t matter whether it has lower nicotine or tar. She used to say that the smell can reach half a mile from a smoker. Second, health; she concerned about my health and hers, saying that it is not good for either of us. Third, actually it is the biggest reason, she didn’t want to watch people smoking in front of her. She said watching it made her imagine the smell and all the negative effects of cigarette and she didn’t want to get any near who smokes. 

It was my 7th year as a smoker, but I totally understood what she said. Not good for health, for sure. Even I feel like I am bothered when I smell smoke from others. So I quit as soon as she got me an e-cigarette. But things didn’t go well. It didn’t smell like cigarette, but it smelled weird and reminded her of the real cigarette. 

E-cigarettes are to trick people into believe that they are actually smoking, the smell should be similar even though it says to has different flavor. And it bothered non-smokers just the cigarette could. It is not only about the ex-girlfriend. My sister had tried the same thing – getting me an e-cigarette – and gave up too. If two of people who loved me couldn’t stand it, these e-cigarettes are not working well. 

Furthermore, I had withdrawal symptoms when I used e-cigarette. It would not help people bear better in the aircraft. Not helping smokers, bad for non-smokers, I don’t see why people should be allowed to smoke e-cigarettes in the aircraft.

Comment:

Title: Dargan A. Richards
Comment:
The title of the proposed regulation is an oxymoron.  A person using an electronic cigarette is not "smoking."  There is no combustion and no smoke.

The Department is overstepping its authority to regulate smoking on aircraft by trying to ban these devices.  The airlines can impose and enforce rules on e-cigarettes as they do on other devices and on passenger behavior.

Title: Team 10
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Vanderbilt University Law School - Regulatory State Class
Organization Name: Vanderbilt University Law School - Regulatory State Class
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Trevor
Comment:
It is stated many times throughout your proposal that there is no evidence that the vapor produced by electronic cigarettes is harmful, and to the contrary there is an abundance of anecdotal evidence that it is beneficial. 

Propylene Glycol is present in many items you already serve on board during in flight meals but yet you seek to ban its use because it is being delivered by something that resembles a cigarette? 

Currently air travel can be quite a stressful endeavor, why would you make even more so for someone who is undergoing a commendable life change such as trying to quit smoking?

you mention that the vapor produced can be found to be an irritant, but the percentage of people on who are effected is less then 1/10th that of people who are irritated by common scents in popular perfumes/colognes, but air travel is not designated as a scent free environment.

In addition, there are also many e-cigarette users who do not use any nicotine in their vaporizer. how could this possibly be considered a tobacco product?

I am totally against grouping e-cigarettes as a tobacco product, not only should their use be permitted during air travel, but it should be specifically noted as being allowed for use as other nicotine replacements are.

Title: Keith Edwin Thorne
Comment:
I feel it would be a great pity if smoking of electronic cigarettes were to be banned on aircraft as it would please many customers if they were allowed to use them.
I have been a smoker for fifty years and have recently changed to e-cigarettes, finding them an excellent alternative to normal cigarettes.
No smoke is emitted so there is no problem with secondary smoking, or smell and there is no chance of fire, or any other danger concerned with smoking.
Therefore I do not see what problem is envisaged in allowing people to use electronic cigarettes on board aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I do not believe that there is any evidence to support the idea that E-Cigarettes are harmful in any way.  In addition, they do not leave any smell, ash, or litter behind.  

ALso, under the current Patriot Act laws, if a flight attendant tells a passenger to do something and they do not comply they can be charged.  (I.E. not using your cell phone, IPad or ECig)

The proposed fines do not match the 'crime' in this case, and it seems that while e-cigarettes are not yet FDA approved there is a pretty strong movement to get them approved as a cessation device.  

They worked for me, I no longer smell like smoke, or get any complaints no matter where I am.  If we're going to regulate this because of the possibility that someone MIGHT complain then why don't we propose ruiles banning people from kicking the back of my chair mid flight too.  Or talking too loudly...

Let's see how fast parents stop their kids from kicking the chair when they could get a 2-3 thousand dollar fine...

Title: George Zultanky
Comment: I would appreciate the ability to carry my e-cig aboard aircraft even if I didn't use in flight.  Thank you.

Title: Carolina Cunha Alves de Lima
Comment:
I respectfully request the DOT to withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252 that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ‘‘Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights’’ 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.
It states “An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.”
E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
•	E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients
The U.S. FDA failed to find harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf 
Dr. M. Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor “harmless, inhaled or exhaled.”
Drs. Z. Cohen and M. Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, “a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 
•	E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that their residual exhaled vapor could harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor.  
	They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
	Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.
•	DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Great job! Keep it up!

Title: Ayse Kho
Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. Electronic cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. It is harmless to bystanders and does not linger or have an odor. Vapor is not heavy like smoke from a cigarette and evaporates quickly. E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor “harmless, inhaled or exhaled.” Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Again, I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
Sincerely,
Ayse Kho

Comment:

Title: Anne Marie Griffith
Comment:
The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.
 I have been using an electronic cigarette for a couple of years now. It has no harmful effects whatsoever, and I can use this around family members, including those with health problems with no effects. Thank you for taking the time to read and consider this.

Title: R. Harris
Comment:
This proposed rule is wrong.

The rule itself says "The quantity and toxicity of exhaled vapors have not been studied."..."In light of the unknown health risks with the use of electronic cigarettes"... and much more.

To propose a rule of law based on the unknown is just government excercising more control over a so-called free people's lives.

I suggest you research the "unknown" and come back with "fact" before proposing a rule of law.

Title: James L. Collier
Comment:
Discovering electronic cigarretes a few month ago has changed my life and I'm no longer a slave to tobacco.  Hopefully, before passing such an onerous and unnecessary regulation, you will educate yourselves about these marvelous devices.  To wit: there is NO smoke, only vapor; there is no all-encompassing, slow dissapating smoke at all.  These things are a marvelous way to quit smoking and even the most ardent anti-smoking busy-body has no objection to them...believe me as I know firsthand.

Please direct your regulatory ardor elsewhere, as there is simply no role for the federal government in this issue at all.  Thank-you

Title: Laurel Lee ONeill
Comment:
I am opposed to the banning of electronic cigarettes on aircraft.  There is no evidence to support them being dangerous and we don't need legislation to ban them on aircraft.  Airlines already can make their own rules of what is or is not allowed on planes.  This is a waste of taxpayer dollars and lawmakers time.  The FDA has already put out enough misinformation on electronic cigarettes which keeps being referred to in news outlets.  Please don't keep the smear campaign going against these devices.  My doctor is THRILLED with my switch to electronic cigarettes.  The improvements in my health are quite measurable and I've been smoke free over 2.5 years now thanks to these devices.

I personally would understand people not wanting to see them used airplanes and I would understand if an airline made a rule that disallowed them but I feel making it illegal with large fines is just over the top.  We do not need more nanny legislation.

Title: John George Johnston-Cross
Comment:
Although I appreciate e-cigs look like smoking they are not, to ban something because it looks like something else is puerile.

There is not a shred of evidence that vaporised PG or VG is, in anyway, harmful, in fact, most studies have concluded that it a mild disinfectant.

The vapour doesn't contain any carcinogens, and has no appreciable smell.

If I was being facetious I would expect the banning of boiling kettles but I'm not so I wont!

Title: Louise Pastula
Comment: I feel that e-cigarettes should be allowed on aircrafts.  I currently vape with an e-cigarette (I do not consider this smoking; it is vapor not smoke) sometimes with 0 nicotine.  If you do not allow these "vaporizors" you should not allow "any vaporizors" even for medicinal purposes.  You must identify "exactly" what an e-cigarette is; if it has 0 nicotine, would it even be considered an e-cigarette?  I don't feel the FDA has done their job properly so that you can make an "informed" decision to ban these anywhere.  If you look at the FDA report they tested one e-cigarette marked "High" and "thought", "High" was one with 0 nicotine.  High meant exactly that "High Nicotine".  They the test indicatied 1% nicotine in the bloodstream of the smoker.  It has been 6 months since I have touched a regular cigarette, I have reduced 4000 carcinagins from my body each day.  I started vaping at 36mg of nicotine and now am down to 12.  I try to use the 0 most of the time but still have a nicotine addiction.  Vaping has helped me emensly in trying to rid myself of the addiction.  The FDA is incompetent in their findings., you will see this if you read their reports.  Thank you.

Title: William Jason Russell
Comment:
I oppose this proposed rule for the following reasons.

I switched to using e-cigarettes over a year ago for my mother's health.  She has major lung issues.  Even with me smoking outside, the residual smoke on my clothes would set off her asthma.  Since I have switched to only using e-cigarettes, I have not been responsible for an attack.  I can use my cigarette in her house while visiting, with her sitting right next to me with NO ILL EFFECT!

This ban is ill advised and premature at best.  

There have been NO ill effects found for using an e-cigarette much less for those in the vicinity.

Any airline employee on an aircraft already has the power to ask you to stop using ANYTHING with repercussions for non compliance thanks to the Patriot act.  I personally would ask those around me first if it would bother them before using my e-cigarette.  I know not everyone is a courteous as I am, but there is already proof that non compliance has consequences thanks to the Patriot Act.

It would also be nearly impossible to enforce.  There is no evidence left behind from using an e-cigarette.  No ashes, no butt, not even the smell.

E-cigarette us is NOT smoking.  It is nicotine delivery, it is closest to the nicotine inhalers.  There is no smoke, there is no combustion.  It is fog machine vapor with a small amount of nicotine.  

The fines are also Incredibly excessive!  

When the DOT shows proof that second had vapor is dangerous, I will support a measure to ban e-cigarettes that is more realistic.  This proposed ban however is premature and preposterous.

Thank you for listening,

William Jason Russell

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
It doesn't make sense to me to relegate non-smokers (inhaling vapor) to a smoking section. Every argument about the dangers of smoking has now been thrown out the window. Let's avoid our inherent hesitancy to accept change on this one. E-Cig is a win-win for smokers and non-smokers alike.
Thank You.

Title: Matthew D. Brewer
Comment:
I feel that this is non sense. Pass laws that help with the safety of transportation do not pass laws regulating something that should be left up to the airlines themselves.

I see no reason someone cant use these devices as they are not smoking anything and they do not stink like cigarettes. Usually the people that can use these devices are much more pleasant to deal with if they get that nicotine fix. It is already stressful enough flying now you are gonna try to pass a law to make it more stressful?? that just sounds conterprocuctive to me.

Title: Matthew Thomas Beal
Comment:
Often times the governments cites public safety as the reason to ban cigarettes from public places. The ban of electronic cigarettes on aircraft does the same.  When reviewing some of the facts about what is exhaled form an electronic cigarette, as biochemistry major, the true health hazards are questionable. 
	In a study done by Health New Zealand, the use exhaled vapor form electronic cigarettes are indeed shown to be safe. The study shows that amount of nicotine that is exhaled is up to ten percent less than what is exhaled from a normal cigarette. This lower concentration of nicotine is indeed safe for a third party to inhale. The study also cites that the other major chemical exhaled is propylene glycol, a chemical used for man made smog, which is also safe to inhale. Finally, the study compares the levels of all carcinogens released are in trace amounts, which too are safe to inhale. 
While this report is not a major American journal report, the since no major entity has not been able to prove the inherit risk to a third party from the device, the device should not be banned. The level of government intrusion into private life needs to be rational in it’s approach and banning a device that appears to be safe due to simply a lack of knowledge is wrong. 

Link to Study: 
http://www.healthnz.co.nz/ECigsExhaledSmoke.htm

Title: D. M. Jones
Comment:
Please, do not make the mistake of thinking electronic cigarettes are like burning cigarettes. Nothing burns with an electronic cigarettes. In fact, the only think they have in common with regular cigarettes is the fact they are used to replace them.
Please consider:
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive. The electronic cigarettes are more similar to personal vaporizers used by asthmatics than they are to a regular cigarette. You cannot ban vapor.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking. The very definition of smoke/smoking does NOT describe anything having to do with vaping. 

5. I used to smoke a pack and a half per day. Now, I vape. There is no smoke or nothing burning with an electronic cigarette. My family says the vapor is pleasant and does not smell like or resemble cigarette smoke in any way. 

6. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it, users can also vape without exhaling the vapor because the steam can be held inside the mouth where it totally disappears, unlike the smoke from a burning cigarette.

Title: Thomas Sharrock
Comment: I do not support this regulation.

Title: Charn Premyodhin
Comment:
The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act

As a 18 year smoker, e cigarettes have changed my life.  I have been smoke free for over 1 year.

Title: Dale A. Fluty
Comment:
I am surprised that the DOT would take a stand against e-cigs.  These are items that have been proven to help people stop smoking and the DOT had provided NO evidence that they are harmful to either the user or anyone sitting next to them.

I have recently quit smoking.  This is the first time I have done so and it has actually worked.  Friends and family have not only encouraged me to continue using my e-cig, but I have even had some show interest in starting to use one also if it will keep them from smoking a regular cigarette.

This proposed DOT regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.  The personal vaporizor that I use produces no "smoke".  I am told by friends and coworkes that my vapor produces no odor and I am allowed to use it at work in my cubicle because of that.  I am far more offended (as are my friends and coworkers) by the excessive use of colognes and perfumes.

Please rethink this unfair regulation.

Thank you.

Title: Kimberlee Metz
Comment:
I would just like you to know that I quit smoking cigarettes & started using the e-cig. My family is much happier as there is no smoke or odor associated with it. I've used it in restaurants, Doctor's offices, movie theaters & in my home. No one has ever complained or asked me not to use it. If anything they ask what it is. When I tell them how it helped me quit smoking they were very impressed. I think it would be great if every smoker knew about e-cigs so they could quit harming their bodies with cigarettes. The more they're out there the more people will hear about them. It is a safe alternative to smoking. It has changed my life. I was a smoker for 40 years & the last 3 I tried everything to quit. I was coughing constantly & my husband would get mad because we couldn't watch a t.v. program without me hacking my lungs out. I tried the patch, gum, chantix, hypnosis, & accupuncture to quit & I always started again after a few months. I switched to the e-cig in one day & haven't smoked cigarettes since. That was 6 months ago. For me this is a miracle. I no longer cough & have a lot more energy. I really hope you won't ban the use of e-cigs on your planes. I have used e-cigs on the plane & no one complained. The more acceptable they become the more smokers will hear about them & maybe switch over. Please consider this. Thank You

Sincerely
Kimberlee Metz

Title: Tyler Carson Haskell
Comment:
I support the proposed regulation to specifically ban the smoking of electronic cigarettes on aircraft. It is important to distinguish between traditional cigarettes and e-cigarettes when making a ban, because of the significant differences in the two. 
Having read several e-cigarette sales websites, and the information in the proposed rule, I believe that smoking e-cigarettes on aircraft can and will have a negative effect on the safety and comfort of fellow passengers. In an enclosed space at great altitude where the cabin is pressurized, any smells, smoke, or vapor would easily be extended to a third party on board. E-cigarettes contain glycol, which can cause irritation in certain individuals. Even if irritation does not occur, the discomfort and inability of a flight passenger to escape the smokers vapor range is a violation of that persons space. 
Knowing that this product can have adverse effects on other passengers health and comfort, the no smoking regulation on aircraft should be enforced and include any battery powered or electronic cigarettes. If regular smokers have to wait the duration of a flight to smoke a cigarette, than e-cigarette smokers should be subjected to the same rules.

Title: Roger Boucher
Comment:
When do we cross the line from erring on the side of caution to making rules and laws that make no sense and serve only to further restrict our freedoms?

Please review the following study, which is a meta-analysis across numerous studies that have already been done on electronic cigarettes...

http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf

You will note that nothinig toxic or dangerous has been found in the vapor produced by electronic cigarettes.  The obvious conclusion is that nothing exhaled by the user of an electronic cigarette can possibly be harmful to the user, let alone to any bystanders.

Rules and laws are harder to remove than they are to create, so I suggest waiting until there is an actual reason for such a ban before putting one in place.  Electronic cigarette users are generally a considerate bunch, and I'm sure we aren't planning on going around blasting clouds of vapor into the air, in spite of the fact that even if we did so it would harm no one.

If you really want to do something that will help make flights more enjoyable, please consider banning crying babies and little children that kick the back of my seat.  At least that would have a positive impact and serve a real purpose, as opposed to an imaginary one.

Title: Vanessa Lilith Drakain
Comment:
Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ‘‘Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights’’ 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.
The law states, “An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.”
E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor “harmless, inhaled or exhaled.”
Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, “a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because
Vapor is not smoke
The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.
Please withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Charles Acolatse
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should not be banned on aircrafts. First off, the term "smoking" should not be used in place for electronic cigarettes. An electronic cigarette is simply "vaping." Therefore, electronic cigarettes do not emit harmful carcinogens or any type of smell that can upset the public. These devices are here to help current smokers attempt to quit regular cigarettes. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking, it is simply vaping, NOT smoking.

Title: James R. Rothenberger
Comment:
I request that the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e cigs) on aircraft.  The law ‘‘Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights’’ 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of e ciigs since the only commonality to real cigarettes is the name.  Smoking was banned due to second had smoke and there is no smoke with e cigs, just a vapor.

In 5 years of use by millions there has been no reported harm to the user and certainly no evidence of danger to others.  The benefit to those that have used this alternative to smoking is removing up to 99% of the dangers of smoking and it makes their travel more comfortable.  In the three years I personally have been using an e cig, I have not had a single negative response from anyone around me and I have vaped side by side many avid opponents to smoking.  This proposal is not about health and that is the only issue that should be addressed.

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because vapor is not smoke.  The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.  A fine of any sort for doing a safe, legal activity is certainly excessive.

I respectfully request the DOT to withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Thank you

Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

The law ‘‘Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights’’ 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ‘‘Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights’’ 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

   The U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf

Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.

Title: Brad Preston
Comment:
I am requesting that the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252, which would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft.

The law "Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights" 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of e-cigarettes. The law states, “An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.” E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke, therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

E-cigarette vapor does not contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. FDA’s tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor “harmless, inhaled or exhaled.” Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, “a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be ...comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products." http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf

Commercial artificial smoke generators used in emergency training cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, using a mixture of glycols that are irritating to eyes and airways.  E-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly, and consists of USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.
 
A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted - vapor is not smoke.  The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

Therefore, I request that DOT withdraw the amendment.

Title: Josh Liam McCormack
Comment:
Please remove this new rule as it is based purely on biased and false information. I oppose this rule for several reasons.

1. DOT does not have the authority to write new laws and as this new rule does not fit into the already inacted rule then they cannot make a new one to fit there desires.

2. It has to go before congress to be created.

3. This does not even count as smoking as there is ZERO combustion and should not even be considered.

4. DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

5. The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments. And a $3,000 fine for something that does not even fit specified crime is extreme.

Please reject this proposed rule.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: If you are considering vaporizers to be "tobacco products" as they are described in your proposal, as "any product produced or derived from tobacco" then you have failed to consider those of us who use a vaporizer without nicotine at all. There are thousands of users who have successfully stepped down from a nicotine juice to a flavored vapor simply to fulfill the PHYSICAL habit that most smokers are afflicted with. If you intend to ban all vaporizing devices, then you are banning those that do not use "tobacco products" as well as those that do. Furthermore, the vapor that comes out of a vaper's mouth is the same as the vapor that an asthmatic exhales after using a Proventil inhaler, no more or less harmful, since the drug delivery mechanism is the same right down to the base liquids being vaporized (other than the drug, of course). If you intend to ban vaporizers it should include all vaporizers, inhalers, and breathing treatments. And if your intention is to improve air quality in aircrafts, then you  should also ban perfumes, colognes, scented lotions, hair products and body cleansing products, that produce strong and often uncomfortable scents linked to allergies and migraine headaches. Since, it seems, you would like to be thorough in your violation of my rights, I thought I would point out what you have missed.

Title: Daniel William Joyce
Comment:
E-cigarette vapor is harmless to the public and therefore should never even be considered being banned anywhere. E-cigarettes help smokers stop smoking so they won't die...why would you want to take that right away from people trying to better their lifes? It's wrong and unlawfull and just plain down right dirty thing to do to people trying to live a healthier lifestyle. Who is to tell e-cig users they can't use a product that is saving their lifes? IT'S WRONG on so many levels!

Thanks for your time and understanding.

Title: Nate Harris
Comment:
This is one of the most Obscene travesties of Law I have ever laid eyes on. 

I stopped smoking Tobacco Cigarettes in March of this year solely because of the benefits brought about by the use of Electronic Nicotine Inhalers. You must understand that simply grouping anything that goes into your mouth to be inhaled and then exhaled into the same group as Cigarettes is not only unjust, it is completely unsupported by any evidence of harm to others. Should you push through with this law you will also have to Prohibit the use of Ventolin Albuterol Inhalers solely based on the fact that they are an inhaled device as well. This will ultimately bring the DOT under significant scrutiny by the medical field.

Since beginning to use Electronic Nicotine inhalers my Pulse Oxygen levels have risen from 94% to 99%. My Blood Pressure has dropped from 138 over 92 down to 118 over 70. I have decreased the time it takes me to run a mile and a half from 13 minutes 55 seconds down to 11 minutes 19 seconds.

The above stated medical benefits CANNOT BE Argued as they are documented in my medical record. Therefore I say Leave Electronic Cigarettes useable on Airplanes and other DOT Means of Public Transportation.

Title: Gary
Comment:
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5. Tell your story about how e-cigarettes changed your life, and how your family, friends, and acquaintances have zero problem with being around e-cigarette users.

6. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

7. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

Title: David Wilson
Comment:
Why is it so hard for anyone to understand that vaping is NOT smoking.. And its a safe way for people to get off analog cigarettes, and theres no second hand smoke.. The BIG tobacco companies have allot to do with these kind of rules/laws because they claim their losing millions of dollars..This used to be the home of the FREE and the home of the BRAVE..We the people should be able to decide whether or not we choose to smoke or not, we the people should be able to vape in public without being discriminated against for doing so.. Anytime the government gets involved or takes something away you can bet we will NEVER get it back..


* David A.K.A. eastXrebel *

Title: Michelle Killilea
Comment:
Last year, I had to make two round trip flights in a short period time due to a family emergency. As an asthma user of electronic cigarette products, who's lung capacity has doubled since stopping the use of traditional cigarettes & "vaping" an electronic nicotine device after all other FDA approved methods failed or where too dangerous for my heart condition, tried "vaping" at my doctor's suggestion when I learned that I not only have chronic heart failure & a bad heart valve but an aneurysm in my heart. It has worked tremendously for improving my asthma & my blood pressure.

 When I got on each of those 4 flights, I spoke with a flight attendant to make sure I could use my electronic nicotine delivery device (ironic thing being that there was no nicotine in my device as at that time I had been able to ween myself down to 0 nicotine juice so what I was vaping was simply a flavored/scented liquid that is very similar to what is pumped through hospital & airplane closed air systems to prevent the spread of pathogens & keep the clean). Each flight attendant asked for a demonstration, found it to be as safe (electronically speaking) as the batteries inside the device were Lithiion-ion batteries, very similar to what is used in a camera, and they where unable to smell any offending odors. 

I can tell you right now, with the rising cost of airplane tickets, if this ban is put into effect. I will never fly again. We all know the industry is financially suffering and has been for quite some time, but this will stop over 7,000 US citizens whom use electronic nicotine delivery devices from getting on a flight ever again. I would really hate to see that happen. As Americans, we rely on air flight as a safe and comfortable means of transportation and know that the current spike in cost of tickets will drop. But to not be able to "vape" on a plane and the reasons stated in the document are simply biased and unsubstantiated. 

Please visit casaa.org for more helpful information

Title: Eric M. Ossowski
Comment:
I  agree with ban on electronic cigarettes(EC) on passenger flights for the following reasons:

EC help perpetuate addiction of tobacco
EC use might accidently  allow under age youth to smoke on planes
A terrorist might use a EC for a devious plan(I am not sure how but they would figure it out)
I would not want to sit next to someone using a EC
It is bad for your health


Eric M Ossowski MD
Family Physician

Title: Cori D. Adames
Comment:
To whom it may concern:
I would like to express my extreme distaste of the proposed regulation not already being in affect. I think that this should be a regulation because even though the electronic cigarette doesn’t release the carbon dioxide like a regular cigarette, it still has the vapors in it. There is still an odor with the electronic cigarette. The effects of this “no smoking cigarette” have yet to be determined and with the public bans of smoking inside public facilities already in place, I believe it needs to include the electronic form as well. I understand that they do not hold the tobacco that a regular cigarette does, but it could lead to influencing younger children to start smoking and thinking that it is the “cool” to do because it’s not a real cigarette. It still delivers nicotine into your body and can become as addictive as a regular cigarette. I propose that this regulation be implemented immediately. 
Thank you for your time,
Cori Adames

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Have we really reached the point in our society where the *perception* is given more weight than the *reality*?  Electronic cigarettes are not emitting smoke or any other dangerous chemicals.  There are now very clear studies that show that they are not a danger to the user or the bystander.  Given that reality, why are airlines trying to ban them?  Will they also ban prescription nicotine inhalers and asthma inhalers?  How about perfume and strong body lotions?  Ecigs help smokers stay off of cigarettes.  How is that not a win-win?  I'd rather be seated in an airplane next to someone who uses an ecig and smells normal than someone who smokes and stinks.

Title: Caleb Reniker
Comment:
E-cigarettes have been the only way for me to quit smoking, after being a pack a day smoker for 5 years. I can now have conversations with my mother with having to go outside to smoke, because even though she is allergic to cigarette smoke, she has no problem with the vapor that produced from my e-cig. 

The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive and ost airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act. So why create such unreasonable fines that a ordinary passenger can't afford?

Please do not pass this regulation, as it unnecessary, and unjust.

Title: Tamra Thomas
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes have not been proven to pose any harm or risk to others so please reconsider this law.  I would feel more comfortable if you would focus more on controlling security and actual aircraft operations.
Thank you,
T. Thomas

Title: Brenda Williamson
Comment:
Please ban the use of electronic 
cigarettes on all aircraft in scheduled passenger interstate, 
intrastate and foreign air transportation, also please extend the ban on smoking (including electronic cigarettes) to charter flights of air carriers (i.e. U.S. carriers) and foreign air carriers with aircraft.  These bans should NOT be restricted to only those with more than 19 passengers but to all aircraft.

Title: Tyler Sizemore
Comment: As an individual who has suffered from respiratory problems while flying I believe this proposed rule regarding the banning of electronic cigarettes is by and large a good one. It ensures that people who suffer from respiratory problems can look forward to flying comfortably without fear of their health suffering due to vapors from electronic cigarettes. It will also clear up the confusion over the legality of using e-cigarettes on passenger flights. Though I do support the proposed rule I also have some concerns. Frankly I find the lack of sufficient studies detailing the actual harm that e-cigarettes do to smokers and third parties to be a problem. Of course it is better to be safe than sorry when talking about the health of passengers and crew, but it does seem somewhat premature to ban a new product before its effects on consumers and bystanders can be scientifically determined in the same way that we have conclusively determined the dangers of traditional cigarettes. It could be potentially significant if at a later date consumers of e-cigarettes were found to introduce negligible or no contaminants into their environment. If that were true then the newly amended rule would seem to be inconsistent with and unsupported by the purpose and intent of Part 252 to “improve air quality within the aircraft, reduce the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers, and enhance aviation safety and passenger comfort.” But besides those concerns over the science and consistency with the established rule the proposed rule is a positive step. The amended text explicitly defines smoking as the use of tobacco products or e-cigarettes while specifically excluding beneficial medicines. It seems unlikely that the language in the text could be seen as being so broad as to mistakenly include medically beneficial devices that produce a vapor. All things considered I believe the proposed rule should result in more tolerable air travel.

Title: Travis Burkett
Comment:
In regards to the proposed rule by the Department of Transportation to amend its existing airline smoking rule to explicitly ban the use of electronic cigarettes, through careful study of the proposed rule and the enabling legislation, I find myself in favor of the legislation. Sufficient reason has been given in the wording of the proposed rule to grant the Department of Transportation due right to amend existing law to include electronic cigarettes.
     In addition to the reasons already given in the proposed rule, mentions should also be given to the negative externality of the decision for a person to smoke in an enclosed space, not only for health concerns but general comfort of the passengers above the aircraft should be given. Surveys consistently affirm the fact that most people do not enjoy smoking around them, and the same can certainly be said for the exhaling of vapors and mist. Aircraft passengers who exhale any form of tobacco product, and or chemical agent, into the air meant for breaking by other passengers, show little or no regard for the people around them. If electronic cigarettes truly had no bi-product that would result in the second hand experience of other passengers, a case could be made for the approval of e-cigarettes on aircraft. This, however, is not the case. Further studies should be conducted on the bi-products of electronic cigarettes before my health should be put in the hands of a passenger who happens to board the same aircraft.

Title: Samuel Swenson Schimmel
Comment:
Rather than banning e-cigarettes aboard commercial aircraft, the DoT should place a moratorium on them until their safety can be evaluated by a government-sponsored study, and until e-cigarettes are held to stricter quality control standards. The NPRM demonstrates that insufficient evidence exists to conclude that e-cigarettes do not negatively impact air quality within aircraft. It also cites a study observing that their cartridges leak, thus exposing third parties to nicotine. Given the confined environments of aircraft, nicotine exposure in any amount is a threat to third parties and e-cigarettes must be prohibited on commercial aircraft until cartridge leakage is no longer an issue.
	In the meantime, it is necessary to clarify the smoking ban so as to explicitly include e-cigarettes. This will reduce incidents of passengers attempting to use e-cigarettes, and will provide crew members with a specific regulation to cite in enforcing the rule. It will also put at ease passengers unfamiliar with e-cigarettes who would be alarmed by seeing their neighbor appear to “light up” (perhaps by the time this moratorium were lifted, e-cigarettes will have existed long enough so as to become commonplace). Placing a moratorium on e-cigarette usage on aircraft will not cause users significant inconvenience because alternatives exist that do not pose a health risk to third parties, such as nicotine gum and patches.
	I propose a moratorium rather than a permanent ban because I believe that to ban a product because we don't understand it is an example of policymaking based on fear. To approach scientific progress with caution by enacting a moratorium is reasonable; to condemn it with a ban is regressive. Once the moratorium is in place, the federal government should commission a scientific study of e-cigarettes and the health risks they pose to third parties. It is essential that the study be sponsored by the federal government so as to ensure the unbiased nature of its results.

Title: Jimmie Louise Traylor
Comment:
I request that DOT withdraw the proposed amendment 14CFRPart 252.

U.S.FDA tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. Dr.Cohen and Dr.Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of ecigarette liquid and vapor and concluded"a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be mcuh safer than combustible tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement therapy. With that in mind,should DOT ban pharma nicotine gum, patches,and nictotine vaporizers on planes? After all,people using the pharma products would exhale the same type of product as ecigs. To ban ecigs on planes would be just as silly as banning pharma product use on the plane.

Vapor is not smoke

Title: Nicole Alice Murray
Comment:
With regards to the proposed rule to ban the smoking of electronic cigarettes on airplanes, I must raise a few concerns. Long flights in cramped places can be very uncomfortable as well as stressful, especially to individuals who are addicted to nicotine. I think given the intent of part 252, which is stated in the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking section as “improv[ing] air quality within the aircraft, reduce the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers, and enhance aviation safety and passenger comfort,” the definition of “smoking” needs to be slightly altered. As the Department of Transportation as well as the FDA are currently unaware of sufficient studies on the possible health impacts on third parties who come in contact with these vapors as well as the effects on air quality within a confined space such as an aircraft, the ban of electronic cigarettes should be passed. However, if valid studies should emerge that show there are no adverse effects of these vapors to third parties or to the air quality then e-cigarettes should be allowed. 
Therefore, I think the wording should be changed to include “harmful vapor,” instead of just vapor. With regards to the word “harmful,” the e-cigarette should be proven to be NON-toxic before it can be used, as opposed to having to prove that it is in fact harmful before it is banned. If there is no danger to the welfare of passengers by the use of electronic cigarettes they should not be banned simply because they supply nicotine to the users. However, since the effects of the vapor is not known, the wording of the definition of “smoking” should allow room for change if the vapor is found to be non-harmful to third parties who may come in contact with the second-hand vapor.

Title: Elizabeth Masters
Comment: What will we ban next, nicotine patches?.. who does electronic cigarettes harm?  I think they're a remarkable breakthrough. Don't ban innovation!! Can we still chew gum in air travel, or will it offend a dentist? Can we still bite our nails in public, or will it offend a doctor of communicable diseases?  STOP THE MADNESS!!!

Title: Robert Brown
Comment:
I Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."    E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes. There is no flame, burning or combustion used or created while using an e-cigarette.

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients

    The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
    Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
    Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. 

E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders

Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. 
They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. 

DOT has failed to produce any evidence to support this change.
I Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

Title: Lindsay Carlston
Comment: This is ridiculous. A fine for inhaling vapor?? There is no first or second hand smoke from an electronic cigarette. There is no flame. No tar or ash. Smoking an electronic cigarette could not possibly harm ANYONE. A lot of people are nervous while flying and being able to use an electronic cigarette in the plane would more than likely relax them which could be actually be helpful and useful. Giving someone a fine for inhaling vapor that will dissipate in a few seconds leaving no residue or chemicals to harm others is just unreasonable.

Title: Daniel J. Bateman
Comment:
Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use is not an issue within DOT purview.
The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking. Since there is no fire or smoke, the use of an e-cigarette is not the equivalent of smoking & should not be treated as such; and is on par with an inhaler.
Further research on the part of DOT, along with valid analysis of same, would seem to be in order prior to taking any action regarding this issue.
In this case, the law passed by Congress is 49 USC Section 41706. It states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.” Full text of law: 49 U.S.C. § 41706 : US Code - Section 41706: Prohibitions against smoking on scheduled flights
DOT created regulations to enforce this law. These are stored in the Code of Federal Regulations: 14 CFR Part 252. Text: PART 252; SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: PART 252--SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: CHAPTER II--OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY, DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (AVIATION PROCEEDINGS) :: Title 14 - Aeronautics and Space :: Code of Federal Regulations :: Regulations 

Currently, the regulations in Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. The DOT cannot redefine what "smoking" means, they need to go back to Congress to have the law changed, and then they can enforce this ridiculous rule.
Until such time, any change that is attempted to be enforced is a violation of government law and I will exercise my right as a US citizen to seek court ruling in this matter.

Title: Charlene K. Haste
Comment: I believe the only reason anyone would consider a ban on vaping on planes is because it LOOKS like smoking.  Unlike the FDA, many organizations and other health bodies have done testing to show that there are no effects from the secondhand vapour.  If airlines feel the need to ban vaping I think they had better ban drinking.  Reports have shown some passengers become irritable and unreasonable the more they drink.  I am sure you won't have those instances with vapours!  I am amazed how people frown on someone sociably vaping, and don't consider having a sociable drink a bad thing.  Point being the smell coming from someone DRINKING is horrible.  I hate sitting next to drinkers on airplanes!

Title: Tracey D. Gatchell
Comment:
Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
    The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

        Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 
    E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders
