            They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
            Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegeta

Title: Shannon Beauford
Comment:
Banning e-cigarettes on planes is ridiculous! we are being treated  the same as smokers and that's not right! vapor is not smoke.
there is no first, second, or third hand smoke. there is no combustion. no carcinagens. we should not be treated like second class citizens!

Title: Rebecca Leigh Luckey
Comment:
Please reconsider the proposed rule banning personal vaporizers on aircraft.  PVs or eCigarettes are a safe alternative to the millions (not the "small fraction") of travelers addicted to nicotine.

I don't understand how my country can impose this rule under these pretenses.  Vaporizing is not smoking.  

Vaporizing is a young industry.  Please allow researchers to prove or disprove the harm in the exhaled eCigarette vapor before banning them.  

Thank you for your consideration.

Rebecca Luckey
Memphis, Tennessee

Title: American Thoracic Society
Comment: Please see attached comments.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: A personal vaporizer is not "smoking", there is no combustion or burning of a tobacco product.  Use of a law that is specifically aimed towards the act of smoking, which creates known toxic compounds as well as the risk of fire onboard the aircraft, as a pretext for banning a non-combustion device such as the personal vaporizer, is an unconscionable stretch.

Title: Samuel Crawford
Comment: As a frequent traveler, I agree with the proposed rule that would explicitly ban the use of electronic cigarettes on all aircraft in scheduled passenger interstate, intrastate and foreign air transportation. Even though the rule should be implemented, the Department of Transportation needs to conduct and gather more research on the effects electronic cigarettes have on individuals who are in close proximity to the “smoker.” As of right now, there is not nearly enough scientific research in favor of allowing individuals to use a potentially harmful product in such a close proximity to others. Not only is it unknown whether or not there are health risks associated with the “second hand smoke” emitted from electronic cigarettes, there is also little consensus on the negative effects it has on the user. A recent sampling done by the FDA illustrates the possible danger of this product. Low levels of carcinogens were found in the electronic cigarettes and in one case, diethylene glycol (a poisonous toxicant) was found in an electronic cigarette (Westenberger, 2009). Since there isn’t convincing evidence that the exhaled vapor from electronic cigarettes are not harmful to people’s health, it is completely reasonable to amend part 252 to include the use of electronic “smoking” devices. However, if further research is conducted and all of the evidence points towards electronic cigarettes having no adverse effects due to the exhalation of nicotine vapors, then the proposed rule should be repealed and individuals should have the ability to use them.

Title: Sarah Woolls Tenney
Comment:
I object to the proposed amendment to 14CFR Part 252 that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. The current law 49 U.S.C. 41706 states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft." However, e-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. Also, e-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. (see http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf ) 

More important, e-cigarettes do not harm bystanders. Your agency’s comparison of the liquids used in commercial smoke generators to e-cigarettes is purposely misleading. While commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin. DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed.

Your agency’s proposal of a fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted. It is also open to appeal, given that the 8th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments. Since e-cigarettes do not cause harm to bystanders, they should not be subject to government regulation at all.

Title: Richard Matthes
Comment: This is ridiculous. There is no issue of second hand smoke.  What country is this again?

Title: Pietro Moraldo
Comment: I personally oppose this change in the law and/or regulation electronic cigarettes do not produce toxic fumes like a regular cigarette nor do they pose any safety or fire threat as do regular cigarettes so they should not be banned on aircraft

Title: Dan Milovanovic
Comment:
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf

As such I request for DOT to withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Kerri Marlene Justis
Comment:
Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. 
The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. 
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft." 
E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. 
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients 
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. 
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders 
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders. 
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor.  
DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes. 
A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because 
Vapor is not smoke 
The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

Title: Peter J. Barber
Comment: I would like to express my agreement with the overall aim of the rule as further study is needed before the safety of these products can be determined and there are potential dangers to public health in the interim.   In addition I would like to add that aside from the typical nicotine extract and propylene glycol dispersant often used in these e-cigarettes, there are far more dangerous applications of them that are very difficult to detect and which potentially pose an even greater hazard to public health in the enclosed space of a pressurized cabin.  For instance, the research chemical JWH-018 created to serve as a synthetic form of marijuana (originally marketed under the name “Marinol”amongst many other names and amongst various similarly constructed analogue compounds of JWH-018 used to get around regulatory bans) can be and often is extracted into liquid form and can actually replace the nicotine cartridge in an e-cigarette.   Because of the vaporized form of ingestion through the atomizer in the e-cigarette, there is no (or very little) telltale smell to determine that someone is vaporizing a synthetic cannibinoid rather than a nicotine extract.  Passengers in the pressurized environment of an aircraft cabin may be secondhand exposed to a product known to cause psychosis, panic attacks, heart palpitations, and who knows what else because these extracts are often made overseas in designer drug labs which go completely unregulated and unstudied.  There is also nothing stopping drug manufacturers from synthetically deriving liquid extracts of other dangerous drugs for use in these e-cigarette devices, such as amphetamines, which can then also be vaporized and consumed in a way that is difficult to detect.  The potential to expose these chemicals to an unwilling audience in an aircraft through an e-cigarette or other vaporizer is very real as their popularity in street use continues to grow and so prompt action from the department is warranted in this instance.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: While I understand the need to maintain a consistent rule set on airplanes, I feel that the proposed amendment of 14 CFR 252, to explicitly ban the smoking of electronic cigarettes on planes, is premature. Electronic cigarettes are designed so that the vapor that is released when a user exhales contains no toxins and thus will not be harmful to bystanders. While they may have been designed this way, I know that they may not always work this way, which is why I feel it is important that more research is done on the effects of electronic cigarettes on both users and second parties. This would ensure that the rule is not unequally affecting the freedom of choice for some users, which can result in contention. It has been noted that the health affects and safety of electronic cigarettes have not been verified; therefore the banning of electronic cigarettes would be based on an assumption rather than fact. Instead, an interim period in which e-cigarettes may be banned while research is done seems more appropriate. The health of all passengers is the number one priority here and you can never be too cautious in how you go about protecting it, yet freedom of choice is also an important value in the U.S. Taking away the right to use electronic cigarettes that are in fact safe to other passengers, would be akin to banning the use of IPods on planes because a second party does not want to hear their neighbors music. This is clearly an important issue that deserves more research and attention so that a final decision is reached that is uncontestable.

Title: Nick Mark Girling
Comment: Use of electronic cigarettes should be treated no differently than a conventional cigarette this is on account of the limited amount of knowledge that researchers and the public have on E-cigarettes in general. Although they are advertised to be a healthier alternative to traditional cigarettes there has been little to no research conducted to justify manufacturer claims to prove their validity. The FDA has conducted a preliminary analysis on samples from the two leading E-cigarette brands; although the findings were through the DPA the analysis was and is not exuberant enough to draw conclusions from. With that being said some DPA findings do stir up some concern, discovering certain tobacco-specific nitrosamines (which are human carcinogens) have been detected in half of the samples tested. E-cigarettes may contain many ingredients that are unsafe and harmful to humans, but since no clinical studies have been submitted to the FDA about the safety and efficiency of E-cigarettes consumers have no way of knowing whether these products are safe, what concentration levels or types of potentially hazardous chemicals are in these products and how much nicotine is being delivered when users are inhaling the vapor. After reading an article titled “Electronic Cigarettes: Are They Safe?” from CBS’ website they interviewed Dr. Jonathan Whiteson from NYU's Cardiac and Pulmonary Wellness and Rehabilitation Program, during his interview he emphasized greatly that lack of regulation on E-cigarettes gives buyers no knowledge whether or not the product is safe. Due to the unknown of E-cigarettes one can only further agree that it would be untimely to allow passengers on air planes to use this form of nicotine consumption. Reason being that E-cigarettes are not backed by the FDA and non-using passengers would unwillingly be exposed to potentially harmful chemicals in an enclosed space but alternative forms of nicotine are available that are FDA approved and noninvasive to others.

Title: Ariel Diltz
Comment:
Due to the lack of sufficient studies on if or how vapors produced by electronic cigarettes affect those other than the user, I agree with the Department of Transportation that use of electronic cigarettes should not, at this time, be admitted on aircraft. The Department’s note that electronic cigarettes do expel chemicals into the air that are unknown or the effects of which are unstudied and that there are issues with quality control that could lead to unsafe situations for other passengers provides particularly strong grounds for the argument that it would be unwise to presently permit them. However, the fact that the main reason provided for banning these fake cigarettes is the lack of information about their impact on health leads me to think the Department should refrain from banning them as well. I think a temporary non-admittance of electronic cigarettes until further studies have been conducted is the most logical action to take in these circumstances. In addition to this general opinion on the proposed rule, I would like to share a few comments addressing the comments requested by the Department on whether the definition of ‘smoking’ in the proposed rule is too broad and on concerns over the proposal to clarify the prohibition in Part 252 to explicitly cover cigarettes. 
According to the language of 49 U.S.C. 41706, it does not seem apparent that electronic cigarettes are already banned. The use of the term “smoking” is ambiguous. As used here, the term ‘smoking’ seems to have the built-in notion of the significant known negative consequences of typical, non-electronic types of smoking, such as harmful second-hand smoke released into the air. In addition, built into it is the idea of how the mechanics of smoking works, such as what is inhaled, exhaled and released, and how. If these notions were not built into the term, the reason for the prohibition in aircraft would be completely unclear.  With specifications like these, it seems inaccurate to claim a ne

Title: Scott Stugelmeyer
Comment:
I, Scott Stugelmeyer, respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.  The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."  E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf.  Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."  Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders.  Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.  Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
Once again, I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraftj.  Thank you, Scott Stugelmeyer

Title: Karen Jackson
Comment: Electronic Cigarettes smoking should be allowed on airplanes however the owner must have proof of purchase, the original casing bought from an approved store in the airport itself whose products are technically already checked by the DOJ employees. The owner must show proof to the airline staffer upon itroduction of id and or ticket pruchase.

Title: Michael Howell
Comment: Amending DOT regulations to equate the use of a vaporizer with lighting a cigarette of fire is upsetting to many ex-smokers who use them as a smoking cessation device.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.
 
3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.
 
4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.
 
5. Tell your story about how e-cigarettes changed your life, and how your family, friends, and acquaintances have zero problem with being around e-cigarette users.
 
6. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.
 
7. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act."

Title: M. R. Coleman-Dion
Comment:
It is unreasonable for the DOT to impose a ban on those who have made a huge effort to quit smoking only to be told they also cannot vape. There are no studies pointing to harm from use of a pv or ecig neither to users or bystanders. The FDA's own "study" showed no nicotine or carcinogenic particulates in the vapor itself.
Why ban a product which has done so much good in that it has helped 500,000 smokers to quit and causes no harm to those using the product or those around the user?
It is cruel to not allow those who still may smoke to not have access to a device that is saving their very lives.
If it causes no harm there should not be a ban simply because the uninformed think it may "resemble" like smoke.
C.B.

Title: R. Reeves
Comment:
Going as far as banning the use of an electronic cigarette on-board a scheduled flight, and the on top of it fining those who use them is a bit extreme.
Before even considering matters such as this you must first preform tests to see if there is in fact any harm that might come to those around, and what that harm might in fact be. 
As a licensed nurse, I have used these around patients, and convinced many to quit smoking by example. As a frequent flyer across the nation, I have used my device discreetly though out many airports, and many flights. Never once has anyone complained, or said anything besides simply asking questions about it, and wanting information so they can get one for themselves, or for a relative.
By allowing the use of an electronic cigarette to be used on flights it makes flying much more pleasant for everyone. The person in need of the device is not stressed out, and in turn is much better company to be around.
I have personally used this equipment since April of 2009. I have not touched a single cigarette since, my health has improved, and my life over-all has improved.
Please do not consider this change in rules just because it "look" like a cigarette. Many lives have been changed by this amazing technology... Including my own. Please do not condemn myself, my patients, or those whom have decided to quit using this method to a life of pain, and death.

Thank you for your time in reading this. I hope sincerely that you take these few words to heart, and mind.

LPN R. Reeves

Title: Nicole Perry
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes do not emit smoke, therefore should not fall under any smoking bans.  They pose no danger or health hazard to bystanders.  To place such an excessive fine on those who do use them is unreasonable.  Electronic cigarettes have changed my life for the better and has potentially saved thousands of people from smoking-related disease and death.  To place these devices in the same category as cigarettes is illogical and causes more harm than good.  If anything, they need to fall under the "electronic device" category and monitored as such.  

Thank you.

Title: Christianne Elizabeth Strang
Comment:
I would like to urge that  you not specifically ban e-cigs on airplanes.  I have been smoke free since December 2009. While I do not use e-cigs on planes when I travel, I think that the proposed ban serves no real purpose. 

All of the research to date suggests that e-cigs are orders of magnitude safer than combustible cigarettes.   The harm associated with smoking is due to the smoke from combustion. There is no firsthand or second hand smoke from PVs because there is no combustion. The vapor from PVs is comparable to fog from a fog machine. There is no side stream smoke and no evidence that the vapor is any more dangerous to bystanders than that caused by people wearing too much perfume.  

In fact, all evidence to date shows that the low health risks associated with electronic cigarettes are comparable to other smokeless nicotine products and experts have reported that there should be no significant risk to bystanders. This is supported by research done by Dr. Siegel of Boston University, Dr. Eissenberg of Virginia Commonwealth and Dr. Laugesen of Health New Zealand and by the fact that testing by the  FDA, press releases notwithstanding, failed to find harmful levels of carcinogens or toxic levels of any chemical in the vapor from e-cigs.

Vansickel et al, 2010. A clinical laboratory model for evaluating the acute effects of electronic “cigarettes”: nicotine delivery profile and cardiovascular and subjective effects. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev; 19(8) August 2010. doi: 10.1158/1055-9965.
www.aacrjournals.org 

Bullen et al, 2010. Effect of an electronic nicotine delivery device(e cigarette) on desire to smoke and withdrawal, user preferences and nicotine delivery: randomised cross-over trial. Tob Control 2010 19: 98-103. doi: 10.1136/tc.2009.031567

White paper from the American Association of Public Health Physicians (AAPHP)
http://www.aaphp.org/special/joelstobac/ecigcontext.pdf

Title: Debbie Murphy
Comment: Smoking of any kind should be banned on aircraft, and in ALL public places. Others smoking takes away my freedom NOT to smoke and to protect my health. Everyone should care about their health and easy-to-do prevention methods, such as not smoking. Second hand smoke causes bladder cancer, heart and lung disease, and cancer. Get rid of it!

Title: D. R. Jones
Comment:
Please do not ban e-cigarettes from airplanes. My wife uses and e-cigarette and frankly I don't even see why they are named "cigarette" anything. They are in no way similar to the burning cigarettes she used to smoke. 

They have not been found to be harmful and in no way should be included in a ban of smoking. The smell of the vapor is non-existent to very slight, like someone chewing a piece of gum. 

I feel it is unfair to link these to smoking in any way. I feel it is unfair to ban them unless you plan to ban all cologne, gum, breath mints and candy from use on planes. Did you know that she can puff her electronic cigarette device with emitting any vapor at all? Because it is vapor and not smoke.....!!!!!!!!!

Thank you for your time. I believe it is possible that everyone has gotten so used to being allowed to pick-on smokers that anything similar is considered fair game. Well the fact is, the electronic cigarettes are not simillar to real burning cigarettes.

Title: Tanya Jackisch
Comment:
I find such a proposed ban to be a bit silly considering the DOT only has the legal right to make regulations on smoking while this is not smoking. There simply is no smoke, no combustion whatsoever. There is no evidence it even harms bystanders at all. This seems to be a proposal based on ignorance and fear for lack of understanding what electronic cigarettes are. There is an assumption that is made to anything that resembles a cigarette. The word itself "cigarette" makes most people's mind's rush to the worst connotations possible. I find it very unreasonable the DOT is rushing to ban something that has yet to even be researched. Should after extensive research from different laboratories(not just the FDA) be made without a bias that an electronic cigarette is harmful then I and others could understand. Should evidence come to that conclusion it would be one thing but right now this ban is very sadly being proposed out of sheer ignorance and that shows what an unfortunate  state of mind we are in. Please make proposals based on evidence, research, science facts, and not paranoia associated with assumptions tied to tobacco. An electronic cigarette is not tobacco and should not be treated as such. 
Just the other night people around me said " Oh wow that smells so good!" as I vaped(I don't call it smoking because its not smoking after-all) my electronic cigarette device. I never ever heard someone say that when I smoked cigarettes once upon a time.  Non smokers around me never complain,  tell me how much better my voice sounds and notice how I no longer cough. This invention has truly helped my life and now is helping my family around me feel better and quit smoking too.

Title: Edward Malinksy
Comment:
The general tendency to liken electronic cigarettes to conventional smoking is erroneous, flawed and sneaky. The greatest similarity they have is appearance. The similarities end there.

If one uses a nicotine inhaler everyone applauds them for trying to quit.  Just because users of personal vaporizers (e-cigarette) exhale water vapor, it is likened to cigarettes and therefore an easy target.

There are many other pollutants around us that we are not "guided" to react negatively to.  The foods we eat and are served on the airplanes come to mind. I am certain they contain chemicals only a scientist can pronounce. 

Frequent long trips (10+hours) are the primary reason I began looking for alternatives to smoking a few years back.  I discovered the electronic cigarette and have since quit smoking entirely.

The countless flights I have been on all these years (well over 300), all departed and arrived safely and I do not remember even the slightest incident or complaints from other passengers.

Title: Dawn S.
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes should not be banned.  The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.  Water vapor is not harmful to bystanders.
Banning shows ignorance on the part of those who are banning as to what electronic cigarettes actually are.  
Many people have been able to give up cancer causing real cigs and breathe much better due to the use of them.
Please don't ban them.

Title: Peter Auvil
Comment:
Please withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would ban use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigs for this comment) on aircraft. The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban e-cigs.
* The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."
* E-cigs produce vapor, not smoke.
* Section 41706 does not apply e-cigs.
# E-cigss do not contain harmful ingredients
* The FDA's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
* Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
* Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigs liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products." http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 
# E-cigs do not harm bystanders
* Since those who inhale the vapor directly report their health has improved greatly, it defies logic that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
* Liquids used in commercial smoke generators (used in training) include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigs use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.
http://www.bullexsafety.com /smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
# DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigs or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply.
# A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cig is excessive and unwarranted because
* Vapor is not smoke.
* The 8th Amendment prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.
Please withdraw the proposed amendment.

Thank you.

Title: David D. Embrey
Comment:
I find such a proposed ban to be a bit silly considering the DOT only has the legal right to make regulations on smoking while this is not smoking. There simply is no smoke, no combustion whatsoever. There is no evidence it even harms bystanders at all. This seems to be a proposal based on ignorance and fear for lack of understanding what electronic cigarettes are. There is an assumption that is made to anything that resembles a cigarette. The word itself "cigarette" makes most people's mind's rush to the worst connotations possible. I find it very unreasonable the DOT is rushing to ban something that has yet to even be researched. Should after extensive research from different laboratories(not just the FDA) be made without a bias that an electronic cigarette is harmful then I and others could understand. Should evidence come to that conclusion it would be one thing but right now this ban is very sadly being proposed out of sheer ignorance and that shows what an unfortunate state of mind we are in. Please make proposals based on evidence, research, science facts, and not paranoia associated with assumptions tied to tobacco. An electronic cigarette is not tobacco and should not be treated as such. 
Just the other night people around me said " Oh wow that smells so good!" as I vaped(I don't call it smoking because its not smoking after-all) my electronic cigarette device. I never ever heard someone say that when I smoked cigarettes once upon a time. This invention has truly helped my life and now is helping my family around me feel better and quit smoking too.

Title: Patricia Wittrock
Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to 14CFR Part 252 that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft. The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."  E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke, so Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes. The DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; so 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply. 

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients, The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. A 2008 study by Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled." Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel from Harvard reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products.  

My health has improved dramatically since quitting smoking. This is the same propylene glycol used in asthma medications. Liquids used in commercial smoke generators by aviation include a mixture of glycols that produces a continuous dense fog that may be irritating to eyes and airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade pg and/or vg in a vapor that is thin and dissipates quickly.

A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because vapor is not smoke.  
The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, fines, or cruel and unusual punishments.

Again, I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw this proposed amendment.

Title: Joshua Roy Cash
Comment:
Using an e-cigarette is not the same thing as smoking a standard cigarette, e-cigs produce vapor and regular cigarettes produce smoke from being lit on fire.  For the Department of transportation to amend this regulation to change the "definition" of smoking is absolutely unacceptable. They are most obviously two separate things and to define them as the same is cheating in the way that you are bypassing another regulation that would otherwise have to be passed separately.  Also, what we are talking about is vapor, it evaporates within seconds and it does not affect others the way that a com-busting cigarette does, actually it does not affect them at all unless they happen to smell a slight aroma.  Please do the right thing and do not allow this regulation to be amended.  Thanks for the opportunity to comment.
J

Title: Catherine Bixler
Comment: This proposed ban on e-cigs on airplanes makes no sense.  E-cigs do not burn anything, therefore do not produce smoke.  There is no proof of them harming anyone (directly or indirectly) although they have been used worldwide for years.  Judge Leon noted when he ruled against the government in NJOY vs. FDA that the government did not show any evidence of harm to anyone from electronic cigarettes.  I strongly recommend you not go forward with this proposed ban.

Title: Ginger Marlene Longden
Comment: Do not continue to take away our rights.  Nothing about an electronic cigarrette is harmful in any way to anyone.  Not to the people vaping them, and not to the people around them.  There are no lighters and no heat to burn.  Why must you regulate everything regarding everybody?  There is too much interferance in the average persons life these days.  Befor you ban something, you might try to educate yourself about it first.  There is more education information regarding ecigarrettes out there then most school text books have on WW1.  Do not continue to operate in ingnorace.  EDUCATE yourself.  Stop acting like the people who sue others because the are not smart enough to put hot coffee in a cup holder in their cars!!!!!

Title: Stowers
Comment: Those are severe fines for such a minimum offense. Since when has vaping been shown to be harmful to bystanders? DOT is stepping outside its jurisdiction here.

Title: Jacki Y. Brown
Comment: I do not think that smoking e-cigs on planes should be banned. They are odorless and the vapor is harmless to people around you. And beside's people use snuff on plane's all the time and personally I would rather see someone smoking an odorless harmless e-cig, than someone spitting into a bottle or cup.

Title: Lori L. Switala
Comment:
To my understanding, the Airlines are capable of making their own rules.  Most of them have already addresses electronic cigarettes and made their own rules on them.  All responsible 'vapers' will follow those rules, as they do not want to hurt the entire industry with bad behavior.  However, part of your proposed rule sort of hit me as rather foolish:

Smoking means the smoking of tobacco products or use of electronic 
cigarettes and similar products designed to deliver nicotine or other 
substances to a user in the form of a vapor. It does not include the 
use of a device such as a nebulizer that delivers a medically 
beneficial substance to a user in the form of a vapor.

Do you really not see the wording?  What you are saying is that 'a nebulizer is an electronic cigarette IF it has nicotine in it, because an electronic cigarette IS a nebulizer whose technology we borrowed to make an e-cig!!      How are you going to know if someone's nebulizer has nicotine in it or not?

This is pathetic.  We are, once again, getting too much government in our lives.  Let the Airlines rule themselves!  Honestly?!

Title: J. Winter-Costine
Comment: banning electronic cigarettes on airplanes is ridiculous there is no health threat posed to other individuals around anyone using a vaporized electric cigarette. this is a violation of our rights until proven that there is a health risk posed it makes no sense to ban them. are you trying to make this rule because a cigarette looks like an electronic cigarette? Do our law makers not have more important things to make laws about? I believe this it is ignorance leading to the rule. someone needs to do some real research.

Title: Smokin' Vapor LLC
Comment:
Electronic Cigarettes do not burn any 'matter'. They use water, FDA food flavorings, nicotine (when chosen, but not always), and the main ingredient of Propylene Glycol.  So, what's propylene glycol?  Well, first it's the pharmaceudical grade, not like the kind used by the airlines to de-ice planes.  It's cleaner, purer and deemed safe for human consumption by the FDA.  It may be brought before the courts if the airlines ban them because of safety issues.  Water is not unsafe, food flavoring is not unsafe, propylene glycol is not unsafe, and nicotine (should the user want it) is in most of the vegetables and some of the fruits we eat everyday!  What's left?  Lithium batteries?  Well, lithium batteries are used in our cell phones brought on board and also our iPads and laptops.

As has been shown since the study published in 1942 by the University of Chicago's Billings Hospital, the main ingredient in an electronic cigarette, propylene glycol may prevent pneumonia, influenza, and other respiratory diseases.  CABIN CREW SHOULD not only be HAPPY when someone is using an electronic cigarette in the cabin, as it is sterilizing the very air the vapor touches, but worrying about any toxicity is not necessary.  Science has shown that Propylene glycol is used professionally by manufacturers of consumer and industrial products, but it is not available to consumers as pure substance. Under normal conditions it is therefore impossible to ingest propylene glycol in large amounts.

If you research the past few years of comments on the Electronic Cigarette Forum, the largest Forum of any kind, on line (which can not be corrected or deleted without a noticeable changing of dates),  you can see that there have been many users of electronic cigarettes that have noticed the fact that they have not been sick during normal cold and flu seasons... some -for years now!

Let's not ban something that science has shown is not bad after all.

Title: Kari Matheson
Comment:
E-cigarettes should most defiantly be included in the  ban on all public aircraft.  They are horrible and do have an odor, even thought they claim to be odorless and just water vapor.  They have not been tested enough to be declared a safe product and individuals should not be subjected to their vapor and smell.  Especially on an airplane where there is no where to go to get away from the horrible smell!
They need to be banned on all flights!

Title: Tudor Bogdan Drancea
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

I feel this ban is completely arbitrary and lacking a proper foundation or argument justifying it. If anything, premature as there has yet been no indication that the use of E-Cigs are in any way detrimental to third parties. I would say that there are private interests driving this push against this new product, however speculation is not sufficient.

My greatest concern is what this move represents in the grander scheme of things. Here we have a product which is an excellent replacement for actual cigarettes. I myself have been a smoker for a substantial period of time, quitting never worked for me. Perhaps this was due to the potency of the product or personal faults. Regardless, thanks to E Cigarettes I do not even think about real cigarettes.. Since stopping, I have lost weight, began running, saved money, and overall improved my level of wellness. 

Of course, this last paragraph begs the question of relevance, what will a ban of flights detract from the benefits I currently derive. The answer is that it is one more action in a litany of legislation seeking to ban the use of this product. It set precedent and strengthens the force of any other moves to ban E Cigarettes.

This product is harmless to the public, we have not proven otherwise. Until than there is no reasonable justification for the actions that are being taken. Whatever the motivation may be for such legislation the final product will, at least for me result in me returning to a less healthy state in all probability. This in however is likely to increase costs and harm to the public, as my poor health may end up costing the public. 

This is not a fair action, or a logical one. Whatever the issue may be I urge you to reconsider as this product has been of great help to my family, many friends, and myself.

Title: Abbie Vianes
Comment:
We know that the e-cigarettes hold more nicotine than a regular cigarette. We haven't studied the effects of the nicotine laden mist that is supposedly inhaled - most likely some escapes.
 We do know the dangers of second-hand and even third-hand smoke now and most likely either could apply to the e-cigarette.
  I am sure it would make airline passengers and personnel un comfortable.

Title: Jami L. D'Stasio
Comment:
E-Cigarette use is not smoking. It emits a mist of vaporized liquid which is harmless to other passengers. About the only side effect of e-cigarette use would possibly be a sweet smell in a very localized area. In a crowded airplane cabin, I think I'd welcome that.

The DOT cannot regulate e- cigarettes, as the use of them is not "smoking". There is no flame & no smoke.

If e-cigarette use on an aircraft bothers a passenger I'm sure a member of the flight crew could simply ask that the device not be used. It should be treated do different than a loud movie or a video game in use.

Title: Renee Simonds
Comment:
As an ex-smoker I would like to take this opportunity to point out some flaws in legislative proposals to ban e-cigarette use in public. 

Since the vapor from e-cigarettes does not produce harmful chemicals the way cigarettes do they cannot be compared in any meaningful manner. The burning of tobacco leaves produce over 4000 chemicals whereas vaporizing glycerin or propylene glycol has shown to produce absolutely no chemicals whatsoever. 

There are also some sticky legal issues with your proposal as well, to wit:

1..The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders..There exists, however, plenty of evidence that e-cigarette vapor produces no toxic substances whatsoever.

2..The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking". E-cigarette use is not smoking.

3..The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught “vaping” are unreasonable and excessive.

4..The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5..Millions of anecdotal stories, including mine, support the scientific evidence that e-cigarette usage is not only a safe alternative to tobacco use, it helps smokers quit as well, unlike the ineffective methods promoted by the pharmaceutical industry.

Please be sure to check the science as well as all the stories of healthier ex-smokers whose lives have been saved by e-cigarettes. Ask doctors who are overjoyed that their patients have stopped their use of tobacco. Make a sensible and informed decision. Once you have seen the science and the results in actual human lives, you can only conclude that e-cigarette use poses no threat public health or safety and in fact will improve health and safety for ex-smokers and the general public as well.

Title: Teresa L. Theurer
Comment: I am in support of the bill to ban electronic cigarettes on all commercial airlines.

Title: Chris I.
Comment: Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use is not an issue within DOT purview. The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking. Since there is no fire or smoke, the use of an e-cigarette is not the equivalent of smoking & should not be treated as such; and is on par with an inhaler. Further research on the part of DOT, along with valid analysis of same, would seem to be in order prior to taking any action regarding this issue. In this case, the law passed by Congress is 49 USC Section 41706. It states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.” Full text of law: 49 U.S.C. § 41706 : US Code - Section 41706: Prohibitions against smoking on scheduled flights DOT created regulations to enforce this law. These are stored in the Code of Federal Regulations: 14 CFR Part 252. Text: PART 252; SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: PART 252--SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: CHAPTER II--OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY, DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (AVIATION PROCEEDINGS) :: Title 14 - Aeronautics and Space :: Code of Federal Regulations :: Regulations Currently, the regulations in Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. The DOT cannot redefine what "smoking" means, they need to go back to Congress to have the law changed, and then they can enforce this ridiculous rule. Until such time, any change that is attempted to be enforced is a violation of government law and I will exercise my right as a US citizen to seek court ruling in this matter.

Title: Chris I.
Comment: Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use is not an issue within DOT purview. The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking. Title: Peg Staley
Comment: regulation of e-cigarettes on air planes is just absolutely ludicrous! there is NO smoke emitted from e-cigs, only water vapor - how can you even begin to believe that you can regulate machines that emit water vapor? what about the new portable oxygen tanks that operate on the same premise? are you going to regulate no oxygen tanks on planes now too? You are getting carried away by a small mind mentality that harms many and helps just a few....really now....get over it!

Title: Karlee Adams
Comment: I support the banning of electronic cigarettes on all domestic and foreign flights. While all of the health effects of electronic cigarettes are still unknown they can be a serious irritant for people with asthma and a nuisance to those sitting in close proximity to the user. There are other regulated products that can be used, such as gums and patches, for those who need help making it through a flight without smoking. Again, I support your decision and urge you to ban electronic cigarettes on all domestic and foreign flights.

Title: Jamie Lee Hickman
Comment: This is crazy the e cigg give off no second hand smoke and trust me we will fight this to the supreme court one day and they will favor us so for you all to do this is crazy good luck but you know you have already lost.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The use of electronic cigarettes in an aircraft should not pose any health problems for other passengers since there is no odor, no smoke generated from these cigs.. it is only vapor.  What about kids yelling and screaming in an aircraft, that causes more passenger comfort concerns than smoking a harmless electronic cigarette.

Title: Amanda Marie Lynn
Comment: electronic cigarettes do not smell are nonharmful to those around you. They should be smoked everywhere legaly.

Title: David K. VanBuskirk
Comment: It looks to me you are grasping at straw as the proposal states that there is not enough data the e cigarettes people are using is to help them quite and there is no way there is enough nicotine in them. The smoke as it states is a water vapor. There could not be enough carcinogens  in that vapor. There is twice the amount of carcinogens in the air if you smell gas or the fuel for the planes which I have smelled on several Flights, heck even then plastic on the plane gives off carcinogens. sounds to me this is a witch hunt, and we want to make sure the smokers never smoke anything. Smokers are paying a lot more taxes then non smokers and are treated as unwanted children. Before you pass this law there should be absolute study to say the carcinogens  levels are to high

Title: Ken M. Swanson
Comment:
Dear Big Brother,  

The reason for this ban is noted as: "because of the increased promotion of electronic cigarettes and the potential health and passenger comfort concerns that they pose in an aircraft."

No examples, no details, no backup data?

No public transparancy, no hearings, no nothing?

Just come out and say you don't like the product, or would that be too easy for all to understand?

I expect a reply to my comment.  I also expect the name of the person proposing the ban.  It's important to get the details correct when I write my editorials to various newspapers.

Remember, you work for me, not the other way around.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I have found a worse health and safety risk than the imaginary claim that the vapor from an E-Cigarette presents a major health risk to others....FLATULENCE! Here are the facts:
...................................................................................

Nitrogen: 20–90%
Hydrogen: 0–50%
Carbon dioxide: 10–30%
Oxygen: 0–10%
Methane: 0–10%

Because the methane, hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen present are flammable, igniting the resulting gases can result in burns or explosions as well as the desired flame. Clothing, hair or skin may catch fire and sensitive tissues can be damaged.

....................................................................................

There is as much chance of E-cigarette vapor harming someone as there is flatulence causing a fire, or the resultant chemicals having adverse affects on anyone coming in contact with it. So where are the regulations??? Come on, we need the fart police to start riding our airways!!!

Your regulations has nothing to do with health issues, but is instead rooted in power and need to regulate every aspect of our lives...to justify your existence.

I have quit smoking cigarettes...a smoker of 45 years who has tried EVERYTHING to quit, and 6 months ago found e-cigs and have not touched a cigarette since. My doctor is amazed at the results I have reached, with blood pressure going down to normal, my lungs have cleared completely, and all other aspects of my general health have improved dramatically! But that doesn't matter, does it, no...anything the L O O K S !!!!!!
LIKE A CIGARETTE is the equivelant to me carrying a gun on board a plane....YOU IDIOTS. Don't worry, we are voting you clou

Title: Robert M. Philmon
Comment:
Gentlemen/Ladies

I would hope that you reconsider this ban proposal.  I was a heavy smoker of 42 years and after having open heart surgey and trying ever available method to stop smoking (none successful) I finally was directed to e cigarette by my heart surgeon.  I have now been smoke free for over 8 months.  The e cigarette that I use allows me to ween myself off of nicotine slowly.  I know that most of the smoking is habit and it allowed me to replace a very bad nasty habit with one that my family, friends and co workers find as not bother to them.  I have used my e cigarette on two flights with permission of attendants and found that no one around me found it offensive, in fact several people asked if it worked and after hearing my story several took cards with a place to order the kit for either them or a family member.  No I am not part of the company just a very satisfied customer and my doctor says I am doing very good, infact I have been able to stop some of the medications that I had to take.  Please don't make it hard for other people o get the same success that I have had.

Thank you for your time..    Robert Philmon

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This proposed rule is absurd and again acts to prohibit the rights, not only of the individuals using the electronic cigarettes, but of the airlines rights to determine what can be allowed on the aircraft they own and maintain.

To ban something that is not known to cause any adverse effects to those around them is simply a means of denying pleasure for no reason other than that you can. Even second hand smoke has been shown definitively to be harmless; yet the lie that it is harmful has been repeated ad nauseum. Title: Sioen Roux
Comment:
I am an electronic cigarette user, and I am concerned by this proposed rule.

The DOT has not provided any evidence that bystanders are in any way affected by people using an electronic cigarette. In fact, a person can use an electronic cigarette with no external evidence of its use other than the LED light turning on -- i.e., no vapor released into the air, no smell, nothing.

I am also concerned that the DOT is overstepping its authority, as it has the right to regulate "smoking," but the use of an electronic cigarette is NOT smoking, as there is no flame or burning involved.

Finally, there is the problem of enforcement. I often like to put my electronic cigarette in my mouth as a soothing habit, even when I am not using it. Further, there is no "evidence of use" -- that is, no ash or cigarette butt left behind. Claims of use could turn into silly he-said, she-said situations for no reason, given that nothing is being released and no bystander is being affected. This could lead to great uncertainty and confusion, which is the last thing we need on airplanes.

Thanks for your consideration,
Sioen Roux

Title: Thomas G. Parks
Comment:
Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

    The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."
    E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.
    Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients

    The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
    Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
    Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 

E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders

    Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
    Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. 
        They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
        Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.

Title: Lynn Ryan-Loeb
Comment:
There is absolutely no health basis for banning electronic cigarettes on airplanes.   First of all, the statement that "many of these are tobacco products" is false.   The cartridges that are used in these electronic cigarettes are largely lab-produced, the nicotine coming from vegetable products such as squash, pumpkins, etc., where it appears naturally.   The vapor that is exhaled is odorless and harmless, and dissipates immediately.   Most cartridges contain only nicotine, propylene glycol, sugar alcohol, and artificial flavoring.    They have been found to be virtually harmless to the person who inhales them, and completely harmless to those around him or her.   Please see http://www.tveca.com/ppg.php for the science and facts concerning electronic cigarettes.

What's more, if there is any "confusion", the e-cigarette can quickly and easily be unscrewed to prove to anyone who is blind enough to confuse it with a tobacco cigarette, that this is something different.  

There is no basis for this law in any kind of medical fact, and it is just one more way to demonize people.   What's next?   Banning asthma inhalers on airplanes?   It's the same principle, after all:  people surrounding the user might be worried about the ingredients that are exhaled!

Title: Timothy Leonard Bailey
Comment:
Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use is not an issue within DOT purview.

The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking. Since there is no fire or smoke, the use of an e-cigarette is not the equivalent of smoking & should not be treated as such; it is on par with an inhaler.

Further research on the part of DOT, along with valid analysis of same, would seem to be in order prior to taking any action regarding this issue.

In this case, the law passed by Congress is 49 USC Section 41706. It states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.” Full text of law: 49 U.S.C. § 41706 : US Code - Section 41706: Prohibitions against smoking on scheduled flights

DOT created regulations to enforce this law. These are stored in the Code of Federal Regulations: 14 CFR Part 252. Text: PART 252; SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: PART 252--SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: CHAPTER II--OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY, DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (AVIATION PROCEEDINGS) :: Title 14 - Aeronautics and Space :: Code of Federal Regulations :: Regulations 

Currently, the regulations in Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. The DOT cannot redefine what "smoking" means, they need to go back to Congress to have the law changed, and then they can enforce this ridiculous rule.
Until such time, any change that is attempted to be enforced is a violation of government law and I will exercise my right as a US citizen to seek court ruling in this matter.

Title: Michael J. Morgan
Comment:
I would like to strongly urge the DOT to withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not in any way authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

The aforementioned law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft." and it is important to note that E-Cigarettes do not produce smoke of any kind. The output of an E-Cigarette is vapor, which is quite similar to the steam which is produced when boiling water for tea. By virtue of the fact that E-Cigarettes do not produce smoke by combustion,  Section 41706 does not, and most certainly should not, apply to using E-Cigarettes. 

Further, E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has performed exhaustive tests on these products and failed to find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf

A few helpful definitions: 

Definition of Smoke: A visible suspension of carbon or other particles in air, typically one emitted from a burning substance.

Definition of Steam: The vapor into which water is converted when heated, forming a white mist of minute water droplets in the air. 

Definition of Smoking: Inhale and exhale the smoke of tobacco. 

In light of these facts, which hopefully help to clarify that Smoke and Steam Vapor are not the same substance, and that the intent of 49 U.S.C. 41706 is to prevent Smoking, or the combustion of Cigarettes aboard Scheduled Flights, I once again request that DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Thank you for your consideration and the opportunity to voice my request.
