Title: A. J. Morning
Comment:
Tobacco cigarettes have been banned in almost every public place throughout the US and abroad primarily for two reasons: 

First, the evidence, proven scientifically, that tobacco smoke is harmful to people. We have enough data to confirm this, so the numerous public bans - regardless of their actual effect on public health - are not without reason. 

Second is the fact that many non-smokers simply object to being within sight of anyone smoking a cigarette. It is deemed unhealthy and "bad," and even if the smoke is nowhere near the non-smoker, it's still considered a problem. Non-smokers, with the help of the pharmaceutical industry (which reaps billions of dollars every year selling "stop smoking" drugs in pill and patch and gum forms), have made smoking a social taboo. 

As it applies to electronic cigarettes, the first concern at hand - that being public health - has not been evaluated by any legitimate public health agency. The FDA has conducted studies on e-cigarette vapor since 2003, and so far has yet to find anything more harmful than wearing a nicotine transdermal patch. We have no reason to think exhaled vapor from e-cigarettes is harmful to anyone, so... we're banning it anyway? 

Which brings us back to point number two: Few non-smokers have any idea what e-cigarettes are, what is inside them (though many vendors list all ingredients on their websites), and automatically think "oh, it's a cigarette, so that person is doing something bad and needs to be banned." 

This appears to be more of a problem involving public perception than actual public health, and it would seem irresponsible of the government to ban a product which serves as a much less harmful replacement for tobacco cigarettes. 

A far more prudent move would be to stay any decisions involving e-cigarette bans, until the FDA provides a clearer indication of any actual impact of the exhaled vapor on public health.

Title: Lisa F. Middleton
Comment:
Perhaps you can help me understand why this is such a big deal as to take up all this valuable time to plan the demise of one industry that poses NO HARM to the public.  I am not a drinker, but my favorite place to dance is a bar.  Until the smoking ban went through, I hated coming home smelling like an ashtray from all the smoke in the place.  My eyes would burn, I would get a cough that took days to go away, but no more!  I recently saw a man smoking an E-cig in the place and thought it was GREAT!  
I just don't understand why you feel you must impose such horrific fines and regulations on this healthy alternative to smoking, especially since these fines were never imposed on smokers to this degree.  How do you feel it is within your jurisdiction to oversee this issue?  This is definitely NOT SMOKING, and POSES NO THREAT TO BYSTANDERS.  
Leads people to believe you have a shared agenda with the tobacco industry, and maybe with the healthcare industry as well, since there is big money to be made in the pharmaceutical business, which treats cancer, successfully or not....

Title: Brad A. Brugger
Comment: I will mention that I do not smoke, and I also do not like the smell of secondhand smoke. The rule seeks to prohibit something that is, arguably, a manifest goal of anti-smoking groups, presuming that goal is to eliminate tobacco smoking. If the reasoning behind a ban on smoking tobacco products on a plane is to prevent secondhand smoke injuries & complaints, and also to prevent creating an uncomfortable environment for fellow passengers, this rule does not achieve those ends. However, electronic cigarettes were designed to assist smokers in smoking cessation, and also to allow smokers who do not wish to quit to have the ability to facilitate a personal choice without disturbing those in their vicinity. The byproduct of electronic cigarettes is water vapor, which is literally no worse than the combined exhalations of a full passenger jet. Further, this rule seeks to prohibit one harmless byproduct, with no consideration of any other, actually harmful byproduct; an individual with a minor upper respiratory tract infection, who spends the flight coughing, is sending vast quantities of particulates into the air, possibly infecting and sickening others - yet there is no rule against flying when sick. An individual with a child who refuses to quiet down, and cries incessantly throughout the flight could be damaging to fellow passengers ears and mental health - but there is no rule against flying with children under age 6. Similarly, this rule does not actually serve any purpose, and only serves to appease those individuals who would ignorantly claim that it bothers them. It is justifiable only when rules are implemented that regulate personal hygiene, parenting behaviors, and like. Meanwhile, it deprives those individuals who did the homework, and made the switch to electronic cigarettes, knowing that there are ZERO effects to persons not consuming the electronic cigarette.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Ecigs have large powerful batteries that are a fire hazard and the nicotine liquid inside is a lethal toxin if ingested. Please ban old ladies that drench themselves with perfume while you're at it they are worse than ecigs.

Title: Jason Lee Shiffer
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation (DOT) withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252 that would prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.  The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."; E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke, therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

The preponderance of evidence suggests that E-cigarettes do not contain nor produce harmful ingredients/byproducts.

Also a fine of $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted; vapor is not smoke.  There is no combustion nor production of any harmful byproducts.  

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.  The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

In closing I again respectfully request that the Department of Transportation (DOT) withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Bill
Comment: Electronic cigarettes are in no way shape or form a danger to flights. Electronic cigarettes help tens of thousands of people quit smoking. This is just another ploy by the big tobacco companies to try and get rid of electronic cigarettes because they are losing so much money.

Title: Jim Swift
Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
Since the law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'', 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.  The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."  E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
Thereby, I request for DOT to withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Gary Lee
Comment:
It is impossible to "SMOKE" an electronic cigarette. There is no combustion and you cannot have smoke without combustion, so the entire concept of the DOT's proposed regulation is uninformed and seriously flawed from the beginning.

The plan that the DOT has to make the use of electronic cigarettes illegal on flights is ridiculous. There has been no evidence that electronic cigarettes pose any threat to public health and they are not "smoking" devices so I don't see that the DOT even has the authority to regulate them in the first place.

I personally use electronic cigarettes in lieu of smoking tobacco and it has made a huge difference in my life. After over a year of trying to quit with gum and patches, I tried an electronic cigarette and have not had a single cigarette since the first day. I am now 8 months smoke-free.

Please drop this proposed regulation as it will only add to an unnecessarily negative perception of electronic cigarettes in the public mind. There are too many cigarette smoker's lives at risk to continue this negative attack on electronic cigarettes. This is a device that is ultimately for the public good and will save lives.

Title: Jessie Jay Rakestraw
Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. 

Unless & until DOT can cite harm or threat to those with casual contact to e-cigarette vapor, legality of use is not an issue within DOT purview.

The amount of the proposed fine(s) is extremely excessive, indicating a complete lack of understanding of the devices, and makes an offense on par with cigarette smoking. Since there is no fire or smoke, the use of an e-cigarette is not the equivalent of smoking & should not be treated as such; it is on par with an inhaler.

Further research on the part of DOT, along with valid analysis of same, would seem to be in order prior to taking any action regarding this issue.

In this case, the law passed by Congress is 49 USC Section 41706. It states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.” Full text of law: 49 U.S.C. § 41706 : US Code - Section 41706: Prohibitions against smoking on scheduled flights

DOT created regulations to enforce this law. These are stored in the Code of Federal Regulations: 14 CFR Part 252. Text: PART 252; SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: PART 252--SMOKING ABOARD AIRCRAFT :: CHAPTER II--OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY, DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (AVIATION PROCEEDINGS) :: Title 14 - Aeronautics and Space :: Code of Federal Regulations :: Regulations 

Currently, the regulations in Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. The DOT cannot redefine what "smoking" means, they need to go back to Congress to have the law changed.

I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. 

Thank you,
Jessie Rakestraw

Title: James
Comment:
The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.  The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.
 
The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.  The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

Title: Alex Wenzel
Comment:
I am a frequent-flying non-smoker. It is my view and experience that second-hand smoke is detrimental and unpleasant. However, since electronic cigarettes emit water vapor, and it allows smokers to take a step toward quitting, I believe they should be allowed on commercial flights. 

The original impetus behind prohibiting cigarettes on airplanes being in large part being the prevention of health problems related to second-hand smoke, the prohibition should have no effect on electronic cigarettes, whether or not they emit water vapor.

Were the prohibition to be extended to electronic cigarettes, the only government justification for it would be to discourage smoking of actual cigarettes in contexts other than on airplanes. This is not a legitimate government interest in a free society. 

In conclusion, absent a showing that emitted water vapor from electronic cigarettes negatively effects the interior of airplanes, such cigarettes should be allowed on airplanes because the justifications for outlawing regular cigarettes do not support a prohibition on electronic cigarettes.

Sincerely,

Alex Wenzel
alexwenzel@me.com

Title: Gregory J. Conley
Comment: Mr. Maxwell has provided the DOT with incorrect information about electronic cigarettes.  First, electronic cigarettes represent no more of a fire hazard than a laptop battery.  Second, nicotine e-liquid is not flammable at any degree of heat that is applied by an e-cigarette battery.  Third, despite "fatal doses" of e-cigarette liquid being sold on the worldwide market for 5+ years, not a single death or significant injury has ever been attributed to e-cigarette usage.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients.The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin. 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.Currently, the regulations in Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. 
The DOT cannot redefine what "smoking" means, they need to go back to Congress to have the law changed, and then they can enforce this rule.

Title: Barbara Lauman
Comment:
I understand why smoking is no longer allowed on planes, but I don't understand why e-cigs should be banned also.  The vapor that is exhaled is not smoke, it is a water vapor.  It doesn't smell or stay in the air for long.  It is not harmful to others.  It doesn't continue to emit vapor when not being used.

Please reconsider any decisions on banning e-cigs on planes.

Title: Nancy
Comment:
In response to the Proposed Rule “Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft,” Docket number DOT-OST-2011-0044, I think, based on the current state of the science for these devices, it is reasonable to amend the current smoking policies of aircrafts to include banning electronic cigarettes. Thus far, the scientific literature has not demonstrated that electronic cigarettes are risk-free. The FDA evaluated the devices in 2009 and found them to contain nicotine, propylene glycol, and diethylene glycol. The battery-powered heater vaporizes these chemicals to be inhaled by the user. While these products are marketed to consumers as an alternative to smoking that can satisfy cravings without the health risk, these claims have not been substantiated. The fact that tobacco specific nitrosamines, tobacco specific impurities, and diethylene glycol were found in these devices raises concerns about the health effects they may pose. Even products advertised as nicotine-free were found to have nicotine. While there was a study that didn’t find a measurable amount of nicotine or carbon monoxide in blood plasma when two brands of electronic cigarettes were tested, long-term consequences to the user and health effects of those in close proximity are still unknown. While these devices may really be a better alternative than tobacco cigarettes, the science does not yet warrant its use in confined spaces where exposure may present health concerns.

Eissenberg (2010). Electronic nicotine delivery devices: ineffective nicotine delivery and craving suppression after acute administration. Tobacco Control, 19, 87-88.

U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Evaluation of e-cigarettes. FDA. (2009, May).  Available from: http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf.

Vansickel, Cobb, Weaver, et al. (2010). A clinical laboratory model for evaluating the acute effects of electronic ''cigarettes'': Nicotine delivery profile and cardiovascular and subjective effects.

Title: Arther L. Murphy
Comment:
Hello. My name is Arther L Murphy. It is my understanding that the Department of Transportation has proposed an amendment to 14CFR Part 252 that would prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

I would like to respectfully request the the DOT CANCEL the affore mentioned amendment based on the following:

First, the law "Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights" 49 U.S.C. 41706 does NOT authorize the DOT to ban the use of electronic cigarettes because e-cigarettes do
NOT produce smoke; they produce vapor.

Secondly, e-cigarettes do NOT contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. Food and Drug Administrations own tests did not find ANY harmful chemicals in the vapor.

In 2008, Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled OR exhaled."

Further, after reviewing 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid AND vapor, Drs. Zachary Cohen and Michael Siegel concluded "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be MUCH safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products."

Lastly, considering that those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting IMPROVED health, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.

Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce CANNOT be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. THEY produce a continuous, thick, dense SMOKE. However, e-cigarette VAPOR is thin and dissipates quickly.

I believe that a fine of up to $3,300 is excessive and unwarranted because VAPOR is not SMOKE. The DOT has failed to produce ANY evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed. The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

Therefore, I request that the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Margie Lynn Loeser
Comment:
I oppose the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Electronic cigarettes do not burn and do not emit smoke.  There are NO studies which indicate that there is a risk to another person from their use.  In fact, all studies to date on the ingredients of electronic cigarette vapor indicate beneficial, rather than harmful effect.  Without any harm or threat to others, the legality of electronic cigarettes is outside of the DOT powers.

49 USC Section 41706 states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft.”

Current regulations in 14 CFR Part 252 do not exceed what is authorized by law. The DOT cannot redefine "smoking", to include something that does not burn or produce smoke without committing an ultra vires act.  To ban and provide fines for using vaporizers requires a change of law by Congress, and cannot be accomplished by regulation.

Therefore, I respectfully request that the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252 banning electronic cigarettes.

Title: Amber Dawn Dyson
Comment: I fly regularly and request that you withdraw this proposed amendment to 14CFR Part 252 that would prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes on planes. In my opinion, the law banning cigarettes on flights (USC41706) doesn't authorize the DOT to ban e-cigarettes, because using these vaporizers is NOT smoking (only vapor, no smoke). Further, the FDA didn't find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. Many additional studies have concluded the vapor is harmless (no secondhand effect). There is simply no evidence that would support a ban. For these reasons, I request the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14CFR Part 252.

Title: Andrea Daines
Comment: Electronic cigarettes are non-combustible. They are similar to an asthma rescue inhaler. If you ban electronic personal vaporizers, then you will also need to ban asthma rescue inhalers to maintain consistency.

Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft for the following reasons:

1) The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.

Title: Kimberly A.
Comment: I am confused about this proposed rule. Electronic cigarette vapor (not smoke) is 90% composed of the same chemical used to clean the recirculated air in an airplane - propylene glycol. I know this because I make my own electronic cigarette liquid. Only trace amounts of nicotine are released upon exhale, because only trace amounts of nicotine are in the original solution. There are no studies suggesting negative health effects of first or second hand vaporizing. If there were, people would not be allowed the use of a prescription nicotine inhaler on a plane either.. which contains the same solution as what is being proposed to be banned. I believe the issue is that personal nicotine vaporizers are associated with cigarette smoking far more than gums, patches and nicotine inhalers because it looks like smoking. This is very superficial reasoning to move forward with this ban.. my two cents. Please do your research.

Title: Utah Tobacco Prevention & Control Program
Comment:
Electronic cigarettes have not been properly scientifically evaluated for safety or effectiveness as a cessation aid.  There are no studies available that disclose what inhaling water vapor, propylene glycol, pure nicotine (and any other undisclosed substance contained in the vapor) will do to human lungs, heart or cardiovascular system. It is unclear exactly what every by-product is in the vapor that is emitted from the e-cigarette, and therefore the safety of the smoke/vapor should be called into question.

Persons with breathing disabilities may especially have their lung functioning compromised due to exposure to e-cigarette by-products. A public place that permits the usage of e-cigarettes may be subject to a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

The explicit ban of electronic cigarettes on all aircraft protects public health.

Title: Sharon Barbour
Comment:
Please see attached comment. 

Summary: I submit this comment in support of banning the use of electronic cigarettes on airplanes.  A ban on electronic cigarettes falls within the spirit of the statutory scheme set forth by 49 U.S.C. 41706, 49 U.S.C. 41702, and 14 CFR part 252.  The purpose of these statutes is to provide passengers with safe and adequate airplane travel, to improve air quality within the aircraft, and to “reduce the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers. Banning the use of electronic cigarettes on airplanes furthers these legislative goals because of the dangers posed by nicotine vapors.

Title: Yousaf Haroon Khalid
Comment:
The Department of Transportation (“DOT”) is basing its decision to ban the smoking of electronic cigarettes on data that is either inconclusive or irrelevant to the safety of others aboard aircraft.  At one point, the NPRM notes, “We are unaware of sufficient studies on the health impact on third parties from these vapors to conclude that they would not negatively impact the air quality within the aircraft and/or increase the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers.”  Based on this language, the DOT is simply assuming that electronic cigarettes are unsafe because there have not been studies suggesting that they are safe.  
	The DOT is exceeding its jurisdiction by challenging the underlying safety of electronic cigarettes themselves.  In doing so, the DOT is aggrandizing itself into the jurisdiction of other agencies, such as the Food and Drug Administration.  The DOT cites one paper that admits the “safety of inhaling propylene glycol has not been studied in humans,” and then goes on to state that because electronic cigarette cartridges can leak, they should be removed from the market.  The DOT is charged with protecting the air quality of aircrafts’ cabins and the safety of those aboard the aircraft, not with regulating the sale of consumer products.  
	The DOT admits that electronic cigarettes have become increasingly prevalent in recent years and are largely marketed as capable of being used in places where traditional cigarettes are banned.  The sale of electronic cigarettes represents almost a $100 million industry in the United States.  In proposing to ban electronic cigarettes, the DOT is not sufficiently considering the needs of nicotine-addicted individuals in the US as well as the impact on an industry that may depend on the legal use of its product aboard aircraft. 
	The American Association of Public Health Physicians supports electronic cigarettes.  According to the Association, "A cigarette smoker can reduce his or her risk of fut

45 yr smoker saved by E-cigs !

George Stilwell

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The proposed in-flight regulation, band and fines for vaping are unreasonable and excessive because e-cigarette use is not smoking, merely a healthy alternative to it. 
E-cigarettes leave neither ash nor butts behind, and former tobacco smokers hold e-cigarettes by mouth while inactivated, remaining smoke-free.  Those around e-cigarette users are not at risk, and most fail to notice it's use.  
 I respect and support the DOT’s authority to regulate smoking.  
In opposition, the DOT’s regulation of vaping is contrary to federal law.

Title: Patrick Walsh
Comment:
Nicotine vaporizing is not smoking. Nothing is lit and no smoke is created for anyone else to inhale. They only emit a small amount of vaporized water that immediately dissipates and poses no health risk to others.

They are called electronic cigarettes solely for marketing purposes. 

Barring their use on aircraft is another major step towards a total ban for a product that has been proven incredibly effective in having smokers dramatically reduce their cigarette consumption and, often, allowing them to eliminate cigarettes entirely. 

There have been no studies that even hint that vaporizing is harmful to others.

I would like to refer you to the article: "A Tool to Quit Smoking Has Some Unlikely Critics" by John Tierney that was published in the New York Times on November 7, 2011. In the article many prominent doctors and anti-smoking activists praise vaporizing as a positive alternative to smoking.

"...the American Association of Public Health Physicians and the American Council on Science and Health, sees no reason to prevent adults from using e-cigarettes. In Britain, the Royal College of Physicians has denounced “irrational and immoral” regulations inhibiting the introduction of safer nicotine-delivery devices."

and

"“E-cigarettes could replace much or most of cigarette consumption in the U.S. in the next decade,” said William T. Godshall, the executive director of Smokefree Pennsylvania. His group has previously campaigned for higher cigarette taxes, smoke-free public places and graphic warnings on cigarette packs, but he now finds himself at odds with many of his former allies over the question of e-cigarettes.

“There is no evidence that e-cigarettes have ever harmed anyone, or that youths or nonsmokers have begun using the product,” Mr. Godshall said. On a scale of harm from 1 to 100, where nicotine gums and lozenges are 1 and cigarettes are 100, he estimated that e-cigarettes are no higher than 2. "

Please consider the facts.

Thank you,
P. Walsh

Title: Audrey Rae Peters
Comment:
Please do not ban electronic cigarettes on aircraft. They do not produce harmful secondhand smoke as evidenced in the austrailian study and the FDA has found nothing harmful in the expelled vapor.
Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin and produce a very short puff of vapor that dissipates vary quickly as it is only water vapor.

Electronic cigarettes while dispending nicotine to the individual do not produce harmful emissions.

Please do not ban them on aircraft.

Sincerely,

Audrey R Peters

Title: Yuanjing Chen
Organization Name: New York University School of Law
Comment:
Although in general I support the proposed rulemaking of the Department of Transportation (“the Department”), as a law student and a frequent flyer, I fear that the Department's broad definition of electronic cigarettes may affect the proposed rule's validity.

The nature of the Department's proposed rulemaking is an interpretation of the statutory language of 49 U.S.C. 41706.  In the proposal, the Department views its current regulatory ban on smoking of tobacco products to be sufficiently broad to include the use of e-cigarettes.  Viewing the proposal as an agency interpreting its own rule, the Department may invoke the benefit of the Auer deference and there is little doubt that its interpretation is controlling since it is not plainly erroneous or inconsistent with the regulation.  However, in amending the regulation, the Department proposes to supplement the original phrase "smoking of tobacco products" with "use of electronic cigarettes that are designed to deliver nicotine or other substances to a user in the form of a vapor," which seems to state that e-cigarettes do not fall into tobacco products.  In addition, in the proposal the Department mentions that "we view the statutory ban on smoking in section 41706 to cover electronic cigarettes as the statutory authority for this NPRM," which indicates that this proposal is more of a reinterpretation of the statutory language.  Therefore, the proposal would be subject to the Chevron-Mead deference.  According to the statutory language of 49 U.S.C. 41706, it is clear that Congress intends to delegate to the Department the authority to make rules that carry the force of law and has not explicitly defined "smoking".  So the only potential attack to the Department's position is that it may be an impermissible construction of the statutory language.

The Department's new definition of "smoking" is very broad and may go beyond the permissive construction of 49 U.S.C. 41706.  The Department proposes to prohibit use

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Department of Transportation 
DOT-OST-2011-0044

If subject to judicial review, the Department of Transportation’s proposed rulemaking regarding the explicit ban on use of electronic cigarettes contains some issues under Chevron.  

I)	Definition of “Smoking” 

DOT may fail under the first Chevron inquiry regarding its definition of “smoking.” (Initially I note that Chevron applies to DOT’s rulemaking. See United States v. Mead, 533 U.S. 218, 226-277 (2001) (asking first whether Congress intended to delegate legislative rulemaking authority). 
Has Congress has spoken clearly as to whether the use of e-cigarettes constitutes smoking? The plain language of the statute does not define smoking in specific terms. The Merriam-Webster dictionary defines “smoke” as, “the gaseous products of burning materials… made visible by … small particles of carbon.” SMOKE, http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/smoke (last visited Oct. 30 2011). This definition implies that smoking requires visible smoke, and therefore, not e-cigarette vapor. However, the third definition of smoke includes “fume or vapor...” Id. (emphasis added).  Thus, a reasonable interpretation of smoke might include or exclude e-cigarette vapor. The plain language is ambiguous.  
Turning to the statutory purpose, Congress clearly intended DOT to promulgate rules to prohibit smoking and provide a safe environment. See 49 U.S.C. § 41706 (2000); 49 U.S.C. § 41702 (1994). Moreover, prior to the statute’s enactment, Congress (and DOT) rejected numerous bills to regulate smoking on aircrafts and other scientific studies due to a “lack of evidence” regarding secondhand smoke indoors. A.L. Holm, R. M. Davis, Clearing the airways: advocacy and regulation for smoke free airlines, 33, http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/
13/suppl_1/ i30.full.pdf. Considering the overall statutory purpose, and the lengthy legislative history of the smoking ban, Congress probably intended to limit smoke to mean harmful smoke from cigarette

Title: Victoria Lynn Loeffler
Comment:
I Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.
The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."
E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. E-cigs have saved my life! Again, please do not ban e-cigs on aircraft, I believe it to be no more harmful than nicotine gum/patch. Thank you kindly for your time & consideration!

Title: Don Joe Dameron
Comment:
I am respectfully requesting that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor.

Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."
Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products.

Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor.

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

Therefore, I am respectfully requesting that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

Thanks,

Don Dameron

Cigarettes are burned and create smoke and have known to have chemicals released that are harmful. Title: Brett Markham
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,

I do not believe the DOT should make a rule regarding electronic cigarettes on aircraft. This should be left up to the discretion of each airline, because your proposal cites no evidence of e-cigarettes posing any safety hazard at all either to bystanders or the plane.

An e-cigarette makes vapor, not smoke. There is no combustion. It does not emit carcinogens and it does not pose an ignition risk. It isn't any different, in terms of safety, than a cup of coffee except that it poses less risk than a cup of coffee in terms of accidental burns. 

Electronic cigarettes are a very useful tool for overall tobacco harm reduction; and I believe their use should be encouraged rather than discouraged. Many physicians and physician groups agree.

Since use of an e-cigarette is NOT smoking, since it poses no risk of harm to the user, bystanders or the safety of the aircraft, and since it is a useful tool for tobacco harm reduction, I believe that rules such as what you are proposing would be overall detrimental.

The point of banning smoking is to protect the safety and wellbeing of passengers. Banning e-cigarettes would add nothing to their safety. 

Thank you for considering my comments.

Very truly,

Brett Markham

Title: Tracey Lynn Richey
Comment: The past two years of my life have been smoke free thanks to an e-cig.  I quit smoking cigarettes the very day I got it.   We’ve been demonized for decades for smoking cigarettes.  We’ve struggled for years or decades trying to quit.   We have conquered our struggle with traditional cigarettes.  We are hundreds of thousands of people who won the fight with an e-cig.  Your real concern should be for the people who are still chained to smoking regular cigarettes.   Not  a group of people inhaling vapor with a little nicotine in it.   Seriously, it’s time to get your priorities in order.

Title: James E. Champer, Jr.
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

As you know many are distressed about this issue of late. I felt compelled to write of my experiences and opinions in hopes that the debate will take a turn for the intellectually honest.

I believe the reason for legislation such as this stems from an unfortunate misinterpretation of terms. Equating cigarettes and electronic vapor producing products is disingenuous at best. Dictionary.com defines cigarettes as "a cylindrical roll of finely cut tobacco cured for smoking, .. and usually wrapped in thin white paper". Electronic vapor devices are nothing of the kind. They contain no tobacco, use no fire as a catalyst and carry none of the carcinogens normally associated with smoking. They merely vaporize liquid and no report, to my knowledge, link them to any real health hazards for either users or those in close proximity to persons utilizing them unlike their unhealthy organic "cousins".

As an electronic vapor producing product user for over a year, I should report that because of my use of these products, I have been able to eliminate a 30+ year habit of smoking regular cigarettes. My health has improved immeasurably. My physician has reported that my lung capacity is now that of a 55 year old (I'm 48) having only a year ago reported that of a 67yo. To say nothing of the increased sense of smell, taste and energy level. I should point out that not once has anyone exposed to my use of these products complained of my use of them. Anecdotal to be sure, but I assure you there is near consensus among my peers.

In summary, I believe that it is the governments duty to accurately frame debates. And, here, as a represented citizen, I am formally asking that you do just that.

I ask that my government reject such incorrect comparisons, sponsor tests on products that are in question, and write appropriate rules and regulations that do not inhibit freedoms, but rather, protect the rights of the individuals you have been entrusted to govern. Thank You.

Title: Matthew Brian Williams
Comment: The electronic cigarette is the only device on the market that has been proven, through both study and anecdotal evidence, to be a safe and effective nicotine alternative to smoking and a means to stop smoking long-term.  There is plenty of evidence to support this.  It contains the same (or less) trace amounts of nitrosamines as other FDA-approved nicotine products, proven by the FDA's own testing measurements, and this shows the risks of cancer in using the device to be at or lower than those using patches, gums, lozanges, or nicotine inhalers.  Furthermore, since the device operates similarly to nebulizers or nicotine inhalers, banning the e-cigarette shows bias towards the user and flies in the face of scientiific reasoning and common sense.  There is no practical or rational reason for banning this product from use.

Title: Amber Rose MacArthur
Comment:
I am an e-cigarette user. I quit smoking and switched to electronic cigarettes two years ago. I have ero desire to return to "regular" smoking.

My mother is highly allergic to cigarette smoke. It is a relief to her that there is not smoking allowed in indoor spaces. However I can use my ecig near her without her having an allergy attack. In fact she is very glad that I use this device now. My father switched to vaping indoors around her after I switched. He still uses cigarettes occasionally, but he "vapes"  the e-cig in his off ice now instead of having his pipe or a cigarette, with the window open the way he used to. 

This has been a great relief to my mother.

The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. And based on the evidence I have of using this device around non smokers and smokers alike it has NO effect on them. The smell of the vapor is usually very pleasant and it does not linger the way that cigarette smoke. It is NOT smoke in that no carcinogens are being burnt to produce it, so it is not a fire hazard. 

The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive. I personally, have never used my e-cig ina public place. But were I to this fee is even higher then seems reasonable.

This ruling also seems unnecessary as Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

I fear that more laws against e-cagarrete use will make it seem as harmful or more so then Tobacco cigarettes and that i simply not the case. E-cigarettes produce less litter, have LESS harmful health risks, and additives then regular cigarettes. 

Thank you for your time.

Title: Cynthia Hallett
Comment:
Americans for Nonsmokers’ Rights (ANR) believes that electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) should be prohibited in all places where smoking of tobacco products is prohibited, including airplanes.

The first & most important reason is that components in e-cigarettes raise significant health concerns.  The FDA issued a warning in 2009 that “laboratory analysis of electronic cigarette samples has found that they contain carcinogens and toxic chemicals such as diethylene glycol, an ingredient used in antifreeze.”  The World Health Organization has stated there is “no scientific evidence to confirm the product's safety & efficacy.”

Our second concern involves enforcement of the current Federal rules prohibiting smoking on aircraft.   E-cigarettes can undermine & cause confusion over compliance with smokefree rules when used on smokefree airplanes. Several airlines have prohibited their use, citing enforcement as an issue.
  
It is a common trend to prohibit the use of e-cigarettes in smokefree places.  There are at least 25 municipalities that define “smoking” to include the use of e-cigarettes, & prohibit their use in workplaces & public places.  

There is also strong public support for prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes.  A 2010 study by the C.S. Mott Children's Hospital found 69% support prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes in indoor places and workplaces. 

Without more data from recognized health authorities to prove these products are harmless to bystanders, ANR’s urges the DOT to err on the side of public health & prohibit their use on all aircraft.  

Please see attachment for more information.

Title: Peter K. Hanauer
Comment: I fully support the DOT's proposed rule to prohibit use of electronic cigarettes on airplanes. Not only do these cigarettes pose possible health hazards and discomfort to the passengers and crew, but their use would cause confusion as to whether passengers might also be permitted to smoke tobacco products. The no-smoking rule on airplanes that has existed for more than 20 years has saved countless lives and made air travel significantly more enjoyable for millions of passengers and crew members. Title: Elizabeth Lozen
Comment:
November 11, 2011

Department of Transportation
Office of the Secretary
Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0044

To Whom it May Concern:

I am writing to express my support for the proposed amendment to 49 U.S.C. 41706, “Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights.” This amendment intends to specify that the smoking of electronic cigarettes on airplanes is prohibited along with the smoking of traditional cigarettes.

The main reason for my support of this amendment is the potential negative effects that electronic cigarettes may have on the health of “second-hand smokers” through the vapors they release. As stated in the explanation of this proposed amendment, the purpose of the prohibition of cigarettes on aircraft is to protect passengers and crew by providing clean breathing air. Any passenger or crew action that may threaten air quality on aircraft should be prohibited.

Electronic cigarettes are different than traditional cigarettes in that they release a vapor rather than smoke. I therefore suggest that the inclusion of electronic cigarettes in the smoking ban on aircraft be reviewed if significant evidence is compiled which states that electronic cigarettes do not pose a threat in the form of “second-hand smoke.” Until this sort of evidence can be compiled, I support the proposed amendment to specifically prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft.

Thank you,

Elizabeth Lozen
MSW Candidate
Wayne State University

Title: Jacqueline E. Stallings
Organization Name: The Consumer Advocates for Smoke-free Alternatives Association
Comment:
To respond to, "The Department is taking 
this action because of the increased promotion of electronic cigarettes and the potential health and passenger comfort concerns that they pose in an aircraft." ...

1. I am unclear why the promotion of electronic cigarettes to get smokers off of the carcinogenic tobacco cigarettes would be an issue to the DOT.

2. The public needs to be informed that there are no reported potential health issues with electronic cigarettes. There is no second=hand smoke, no burning, no combustibles, and virtually no odor.  It is completely harmless to any other passengers.

Please educate yourself before condeming electronic vaping. The term "cigarettes" is not accurate. These are not what the public associates with the word "cigarette". I have been a non-smoker since Oct 8, 2011. I only vape.

Title: Melissa Faye Hughes
Comment: You guys, vaping and smoking are two intirely different things. I have quit smoking in the past 2 months, and now I am vaping. It is nothing like smoking. It is nat harmful it does not smell. You should be happy that people are not smoking. Please do not infringe on our right to vape.

Title: Patrick Larkin
Comment:
As a natural born patriotic United States citizen, I am writing to request you NOT ban so-called "electronic cigarettes" or "e-cigarettes".  These are actually personal vaporizers in that no combustion of any substance takes place.  The device merely vaporizes a fluid, creating mostly water vapor with (sometimes) a bit of flavoring and a very small amount of nicotine.  Because of this, use of so called "electronic cigarettes" is not "smoking".  

The DOT has only been granted the authority to regulate "smoking".  Therefore this proposal is contrary to federal law. 
  
Even if the regulation were adopted, it is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

And finally, the DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose any threat to bystanders or aircraft equipment.

For these reasons, and many more, this proposed regulation to ban the use of so-called "electronic cigarettes" should NOT be enacted.

Title: Ericka Warren
Comment:
Docket Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., Room W12-140
Washington, DC 20590-0001

To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing regarding the proposed changes to DOT-OST-2011-0044 -- RIN 2105-AE06-Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft


1)Section 252.4 Smoking ban: air carriers, clearly articulates that “Air carriers shall prohibit smoking on all scheduled passenger flights.

	I strongly agree with this ban and suggest that it be upheld for the protection of the passengers and crewmembers and overall air quality. According to the research of G. Wieslander, D. Norbaumlck, and T. Lindgren, entitled ``Experimental exposure to propylene glycol mist in aviation emergency training: Acute ocular and respiratory effects,'' it has been shown that non-asthmatic people have who have been exposed to propylene glycol mist from artificial smoke generators may cause acute ocular and upper airway irritation and in a few cases people people reacted with cough and slight airway obstruction. Additionally, since there are design flaws in electronic cigarettes and high concerns over quality control and health related issues due to the lack of knowing impact of the ingredients on cabin air quality, the ban of electronic cigarette devices should enforced. The use of electronic cigarettes should only be approved if it can be proven to be beneficial and vital for medical reasons of an individual. 

Thank you very much for taking my recommendation into consideration.

Sincerely,

Ericka Warren, BSW

Title: Stanton Arnold Glantz
Comment:
We support the prohibition of using electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. E-cigarettes are unregulated nicotine delivery devices that emit an unknown mixture of chemicals into the air. Use on an aircraft would increase the level or air pollution inside the aircraft cabin and subject passengers and flight crew to the toxic chemicals in the exhaled “vapor.”

The e-cigarette companies claim that the complex mixture of chemicals emitted is “water vapor.” Blu, an e-cigarette company, claims on their website that the white “smoke” e-cigarette smokers depicted in an aircraft cabin emit contains, “No second hand smoke only water vapor.”  (See image from the www.bluecigs.com home page, accessed November 10, 2011.) Another retailer, The Safe Cig, claims, “Our vapor is so clean that you can exhale directly into a tissue or paper towel and not see or smell a thing!” (www.thesafecig.com).

There has been no independent scientific validation of these claims.

In contrast, studies by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration scientists found that there are substances other than water contained in the vapor (FDA, 2009; Trehy et al., 2011). In a summary report of e-cigarette analyses released by FDA on their website, the products contained tobacco specific nitrosamines (NNN, NNK, NAT, NAB) that are carcinogenic, diethylene glycol, and propylene glycol.  Though few studies exist on the effects of inhaling propylene glycol, it is at minimum a mild irritant to the human respiratory tract (Sciencelab, Inc., 2010). Nicotine and related compounds, such as B-nicotyrine, anabasine, and myosmine are also present in the products (FDA, 2009; Flouris and Oikonomou, 2010; Trehy et al., 2011).  Nicotine is a neurotoxin (Abreu-Villaca et al., 2003) used as an insecticide (American Lung Association, nd).

There is no evidence that all these toxins are absorbed by the smoker.  ...

(Comment continued in attached letter, which also includes image and supporting citations.)

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While riding a train in the UK I became aware of an excruciating burning in my chest--the kind I experience when I am exposed to heavy doses of secondhand tobacco smoke.  I began looking around the train car to see if anyone had indeed lit a cigarette.  Several rows back on the other side of the train car, a woman was puffing on one of these so-called "smokefree" e-cigarettes.  

It is absolutely unacceptable for a person to use such a device in a smokefree area.  The device clearly emitted toxic substances that acted on my body as tobacco smoke does.  I was not aware the device was being used until I experienced the extreme pain and began looking for the cause of that pain.  I had to leave the train at the nearest stop--well before my destination--and wait for a train on which no one had been smoking.  Yes, the woman using the e-cigarette was smoking.  

Do not let such devices back into nonsmoking areas.  These devices are not safe, they are not non-toxic, they are not non-smoker-friendly.  Non-smokers deserve protection from the toxic air contaminants emitted by cigarettes of all kinds, including e-cigarettes.

Title: Kathleen Jeacoma
Comment:
Greetings!

An electronic cigarette harms no one but existing tobacco companies.
There is no second-hand smoke, no flame, no odor and according to many in the medical field, significant health reduction.
So what, exactly, is the issue?

Title: Matt
Comment: It appears that both critics and manufacturers of e-cigarettes alike agree that a vapor is emitted.  Given that an airplane is an air-recirculating environment, the components of the vapor should be understood well, and the effects of accumulation of this vapor in a closed environment on other people should be evaluated before allowing this vapor to accumulate in commercial aircraft cabins.  If it poses a risk to the health or comfort of the other passengers, it should not be allowed.

Title: Richard Paul Sargent
Comment:
I support the prohibition of using electronic cigarettes  e-cigarettes) on aircraft. 

The e-cigarette companies claim that the complex mixture of chemicals emitted is “water vapor.”  There has been no independent scientific validation of these claims.

In studies by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration scientists found that there are substances other than water contained in the vapor (FDA, 2009; Trehy et al., 2011). In a summary report of e-cigarette analyses released by FDA on their website, the products contained tobacco specific nitrosamines (NNN, NNK, NAT, NAB) that are carcinogenic, diethylene glycol, and propylene glycol. 

There is no evidence that all these toxins are absorbed by the smoker.  In considering whether or not to allow this pollution source in the confined airspace of an airline cabin, the DOT should assume that at least some of these toxic chemicals will be emitted into the cabin airspace. 

When smokers go outdoors to feed their addiction we can measure nicotine in the blood stream of their children.  The damaging chemicals are adsorbed on the smoker's clothes, hair and skin.  Use of e-cigarettes on an airliner means the seats and cabin walls will be contaminated with the carcinogens reported by the FDA in 2009.  So we can all enjoy wallowing in toxic waste smeared all over our seats.

No one is going to die if people cannot use e-cigarettes on an airliner.  The onus should be on proving that the devices do not emit unhealthful chemicals into the air shared by all of the passengers.   And if they do emit unhealthful chemicals they should not be allowed.

Title: Rob Crane
Comment:
With no evidence to suggest that the vapors emitted by so called Electronic Cigarettes are safe for passengers including children in close proximity to the user, it seems unreasonable to subject other passengers and aircraft staff to this product.  

In addition this product does include an ignition source used to heat the tobacco product, thus creating a possible safety or security hazard.

There are a half dozen other nicotine substitutes that are both discrete and non-noxious to passengers proximate to their use.

Perhaps most importantly there is a strong societal and public health message in keeping public transportation free of a highly addictive drug, nicotine.  

Please prohibit e-cigarette usage on aircraft.

Rob Crane, MD
Clinical Associate Professor
Department of Family Medicine
Ohio State University
Columbus, Ohio 43201

Title: Robert N. Proctor
Comment:
E-cigarettes should not be allowed on aircraft.  E-cigarettes often contain untested, and often undisclosed, mixtures of toxic chemicals, some of which--notably nicotine--are known to be highly poisonous.   E-cigarettes are nicotine delivery devices,  posing unclear risks to passengers inhaling aerosols released through "vaping" such devices.    E-cigarettes would likely degrade the air quality on public transportation, and should not be permitted on aircraft.  

Air travel has been made quite safe in recent decades, thanks to decades of responsible regulation.  In-flight air quality has also improved over what it was only two or three decades ago, thanks to the prohibition of cigarettes.  We should not reverse the progress that has been made in protecting passengers.  E-cigarettes should not be permitted aboard aircraft.     

Robert N. Proctor
Professor of the History of Science
Stanford University

Title: Kelsey Gmeinder
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Frank Rocha
Comment:
As a natural born patriotic United States citizen, I am writing to request you NOT ban so-called "electronic cigarettes" or "e-cigarettes". These are actually personal vaporizers in that no combustion of any substance takes place. The device merely vaporizes a fluid, creating mostly water vapor with (sometimes) a bit of flavoring and a very small amount of nicotine. Because of this, use of so called "electronic cigarettes" is not "smoking". 

The DOT has only been granted the authority to regulate "smoking". Therefore this proposal is contrary to federal law. 

Even if the regulation were adopted, it is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

And finally, the DOT and FDA have failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose any threat to bystanders or aircraft equipment.

I smoked for 22 years and this is the only device that has worked.  I have tried quitting methods including transdermal patches, Nicotine chewing gum, Chantrix, and a nicotine inhaler.  

For these reasons, and many more, this proposed regulation to ban the use of so-called "electronic cigarettes" should NOT be enacted.

Title: Jennifer A. Majewski
Comment:
I think that this proposed rule making using an ecigarette illegal is unfair and discriminatory.  After more than 25 years of heavy smoking and countless attempts to quit, the ecig saved my life.  There is nothing harmful emitted, it leaves no unpleasant odor and is not dangerous.

Please do not pass this proposed rule.  The devices that we use are as harmless as an inhaler and do not impose on other passenger's rights.

Comment:
I have smoked for over 40 years thanks to my parents and the good old days of drinking and driving was acceptable. The wearing of seatbelts was non existent, child car seats wasn't even thought of. All of these things have matured and laws changed and have saved so many lives.
To those of you who bitch about someone's "vapor" from an e-cig that you have absolutely no proof that it harms you should thank those elder people in law for taking their sweet time in allowing this transition of the e-cig to take place. You should applaud those of us that have chosen the path of the e-cig to rid ourselves of that nasty habit that kills so many. Those who are writing the laws are the ones who brought upon the cigarrettes and mad a fortune selling them in the years past as the same goes for alcohol. Please don't condem the e-cig person unless they are throwing it in your face just because the can. We who smoke e-cig are trying are best. Give us a chance, look at history and don't be so smug. We love life as you. I'd be more worried about the disease the person sitting next to you is exhailing than the vapor, or the invisible germs on their clothes or a hand shake. Please give it some time for us to overcome what was bread into us and our culture. Maybe the airlines can sell their own acceptable brand of e-cig for the flight as we all know, its all about that all mighty dollar.

Title: Fred James LaCroix
Comment: I feel that this will be a great injustice to an industry that will help to stop the profiteering by big tobacco and their people in power, and those that are trying to quit smoking. Ignition of a electronic cigarette creates heated vapor that deliveres a small amount of nicotine that is absorbed into the lungs and then expels nothing more than vapor. If you ask me they should provide disposable electronic cigarettes to all smokers when boarding

Title: Sera
Comment:
Before allowing the use of e-cigarettes in public places, especially in enclosed spaces such as aircraft, they must pass appropriate testing for safety.

History has already shown the irresponsibility of legalizing a dangerous product and then waiting for decades to see whether the suffering it causes is really a direct result of that product. People have needlessly suffered for over a century while fighting tobacco industry propaganda. Decision-makers have only begun to understand that the harm caused by secondhand smoke warrants smoking bans.

Do we really need to repeat this lesson yet again?

The public does not owe it to e-cigarette proponents to act as lab rats once again for yet another questionable tobacco product simply so that users may be spared the inconvenience of respectful behaviour toward others.

The only acceptable safety standard for a non-essential recreational drug with potential to harm bystanders is conclusive proof by independent research that passive exposure to e-cigarette vapour is “as safe as or safer than not being exposed to it at all.”

Lawmakers owe it to us to ban public e-cigarette use until proponents have met this standard of proof.

Title: Matthew T. Reid
Comment: Before making a rash an inappropriate decision regarding these devices, I would advise you to further investigate their actual outputs of harmful pollutants and see whether they fall under OSHA levels.  Also, If the problem lies in the poisonous nicotine in the E-Cigarette fluid, sealed approved devices could be made available for in flight use.

Title: Anonymous

 1) High concentrations of nicotine, if absorbed through skin can cause toxicological effects or even death, since nicotine readily passes into the bloodstream following dermal contact"

5) Other non-smokers have a right to be on a smokeless flight. The vapor from the e-cigarette will not dissipate quickly for all brands/models smoked, and that may make the flight uncomfortable for nearby non smokers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Department of Transportation,  Please do not allow use of electronic cigarettes on airplanes. Evidence has not shown electronic cigarettes to be completely safe to their users or those around them. Nicotine addiction can be managed with products now readily available on the the market--patches, gum, lozenges. These are safe for the user and have no impact upon those near the user.  Addicts who would like to spend their money on another unregulated, potentially dangerous product, are welcome to do so. Please do not allow them to take the rest of us down in the process.
Thank you,
Anonymous

Title: Jeff Geer
Comment:
1. The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders.

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and e-cigarette use is not smoking.

3. The proposed fines of $2,300 and $3,200 for being caught vaping are unreasonable and excessive.

4. The DOT claims that it has always considered e-cigarette use to be "smoking," but despite there likely having been tens of thousands of people using e-cigarettes on planes in the past half-decade, not a single e-cigarette user has been charged with smoking.

5.  Vaping changed my life, I can breath easier and don't get winded, I feel it will extend my life and help me stay around for many years to enjoy my grandchildren.

6. The regulation is unenforceable because e-cigarette users leave behind no evidence (ash, cigarette butt, etc.) of their use. Moreover, e-cigarette users can have an e-cigarette in their mouth without using it.

7. Most airliners already ban the use of electronic cigarettes, and passengers who knowingly disobey an order from a flight attendant to stop using a device (whether an e-cigarette, an iPad, or a cell phone) can be charged for not obeying a lawful order under the Patriot Act.

Comment:

Dear Sir or Madam,
I am submitting a comment in favor of banning the use of electronic cigarettes on aircrafts.  I have an interest in this proposed regulation since I fly for work alot and I wouldn’t want to sit next to someone smoking an electronic cigarette on an airplane.  The seating on airplanes are very close together that you wouldn’t want to be able to smell the vapor from someone smoking an electronic cigarette even though it may be barely noticeable.  They say with electronic cigarettes that second hand smoke is not an issue but there has not been enough research found stating that it does not cause absolutely any health issues for someone sitting next to someone smoking an electronic cigarette.  If there is even a chance that it could affect the health and safety of others then it would be a valid reason to pass this proposed rule.  The discomfort of having to smell an unusual odor even if it was a flavored odor from someone sitting right next to you during a 2 -6 hour flight would not be enjoyable. Smoking of cigarettes, cigars and pipes are already banned from being smoked on aircrafts, trains, etc.  So I agree why would the use of electronic cigarettes be allowed?   The popularity of the electronic cigarettes has been increasingly growing and the airlines are concerned about any safety, health and discomfort that may be imposed by their passengers, crew members or anyone else that may be on the aircraft.  There is not enough valid research that there are no health risks involved with the electronic cigarettes and there would be discomfort involved with the vapors from the product therefore I believe smoking of electronic cigarettes should be banned from aircrafts both domestic and international.  
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this proposed ru

Title: Heather Robertson
Comment:
This nation has come so far in protecting the health of its citizens through the growing number of smoke-free and tobacco-free policies that allow everyone to breathe clean air. Please continue protecting our health by making sure that e-cigarettes are not allowed on aircraft. Formaldehyde is present as are a number of other chemicals in addition to nicotine. There are other means of allowing people addicted to nicotine to remain comfortable during flight, such as gum or patches that don't affect those around them. 

Years ago on the first day of Public Policy 101 class, my professor said, "If you remember nothing else about public policy, remember this: Your rights end where the next person's begins." As travelers, my children and I deserve the right to breathe clean air. Breathing is necessary to survival. If someone wants to use items with chemicals that are known cancer-causing agents, I would ask my government to assure policies are in place so that they are using those items on their own time in a manner that does not affect me and my children.

Thank you for your time.

Title: Julia Tillman Woessner
Comment:
I respectfully submit that the DOT does not have authority to include e-cigarettes in a smoking ban because, simply stated, e-cigarettes don’t involve combustion and don’t create smoke.   As such, it is beyond the DOT’s scope of authority to prohibit their use as part of a ban on “smoking.”  

There is absolutely no evidence that e-cigarettes pose any danger to bystanders.  A careful reading of the FDA report (as opposed to the FDA’s press release) shows that no dangerous levels of any chemicals were found in the e-cigarette vapor.  The DOT should not be prohibiting the use of lawful products on airplanes without scientific proof of harm.  

I have used an e-cigarette instead of smoking for nearly 3 years now.  During that time, I have used my e-cigarette on planes on many occasions with absolutely no problems.  I do not hide the fact that I am using an e-cigarette, but by simply holding the vapor in my mouth for a few extra seconds, there is absolutely no visible vapor upon exhale.

If the DOT won’t ban peanuts on airplanes when there is a demonstrable and proven risk to people with severe peanut allergies, why in the world would the DOT try to ban e-cigarettes when there is absolutely no proven risk to anyone?  

The proposed regulation represents an abuse of discretion and and unwarranted over-reaching of authority on the part of the DOT.  And, as a taxpayer, I object to the abuse of authority as well as to the additional money that the DOT has expended in this particular endeavor.

Title: Mark Howard Weiss
Comment:
I oppose the proposed ban of smoking of electronic cigarettes on Aircraf and respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to 14CFR Part 252 that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."  E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.  Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients 
he U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor.  http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf 
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled." 
Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf  E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders. 
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor.  They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes. DOT should withdraw the amendment

Title: Karen Carey
Comment:
My name is Karen Carey, I am a resident of Wilbraham, Massachusetts.

I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.  The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.  The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."  E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.  Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients.  Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."  Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products.

E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders, unlike traditional tobacco cigarettes.  Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.  DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because vapor is not smoke.  The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

I urge the DOT to examine the facts.  The evidence shows that vapor from an e-cigarette does not cause harm to either user or bystander.  The only sensible choice is to withdraw this  proposed amendment.  Thank you.

Title: Woody Cornish
Comment:
I oppose the proposed rule, and ask that it be withdrawn from consideration. I am a private citizen, and these comments are my personal opinions. I have no direct interest in the rulemaking process.

E-cigarettes are not, by definition, tobacco products. As a result, the FAA does not have statuatory legitimacy to regulate their use on airplanes. From the proposed rule: "14 CFR part 252, titled Smoking Aboard Aircraft, to implement section 41706. See 65 FR 36772. As a result, part 252 today bans the smoking of tobacco products on all scheduled passenger flights of air carriers." 

The law, itself, says: "Smoking prohibition in intrastate and interstate air transportation.--An individual may not smoke in an aircraft in scheduled passenger interstate air transportation or scheduled passenger intrastate air transportation."
To claim that e-cigarettes are "smoked" is to fundamentally misunderstand the definition of smoking. To smoke, smoke itself must be produced. E-cigarettes, which are vaporizers, cannot be smoked because they do not produce smoke. 

As the FAA says, there have been few instances of e-cigarettes being smoked aboard aircraft. Individual airlines, along with their flight crews, are perfectly capable of deciding their own rules on the usage of e-cigarettes. At this time, it does not appear as if an FAA rule is necessary--and this particular rule is not within the limits of the FAA's statuatory authority. Because the health risks of e-cigarettes are minimal, compared to cigarettes, this rule is unlikely to make a material impact in fighting cancers related to second-hand smoke. In the event that e-cigarettes gain popularity aboard aircraft, it may be necessary for the FAA to seek legal authority to regulate them. Until then, this rule must be withdrawn; the FAA should clarify that e-cigarettes ARE NOT tobacco products and that there is no legal ban on their usage aboard aircraft.

Woody Cornish
Concerned Citizen
