Comment: Attached are comments of the Air Line Pilots Association, International in support of the proposed rule to prohibit electronic cigarettes.

Title: Joanna Kirsten Watt
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should not be banned on aircraft.  They should not be banned ANYWHERE.  Un-corrupted science has more than proved that the electronic cigarette is a useful tool for society.  Smokers feel as if their rights are being restored and non-smokers care less because there is NO smell from the ecig at all.  I am positive the pilots I know love their ecigs.  Customers should be able to as well.  Thank you.

Title: Spike Babaian
Comment:
Our organization, National Vapers Club, has already submitted written comment and has offered to share with DOT our results of an indoor air quality study on e-cigarette vapor. E-cigarettes do not produce smoke and therefore do not create the byproducts of combustion. Banning e-cigarette use on planes is akin to banning the use of Nicotrol inhaler. The e-cigarette has not been shown to cause any harm to bystanders and until there is a reason to ban their use on planes, the ban is unfounded. It is the responsibility of airlines to explain the product to people who are uncomfortable with their use to alleviate concerns of those who are not educated and don't know what it is. We are happy to provide informational pamphlets for seat pockets to explain what they are and prevent panic due to use of an unknown product... but to ban use to alleviate fear is unconstitutional. 

Spike Babaian 
National Vapers club
www.Vapersclub.com
516 695 7007

Title: Steve L. Heilig
Comment:
We very much agree that e-cigarettes should be regulated as regular cigarettes, and thus not allowed to be used on aircraft.  The research increasingly supports such restrictions.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Consumer Advocates for Smoke-Free Alternatives Association and the Competitive Enterprise Institute
Organization Name: Consumer Advocates for Smoke-Free Alternatives Association and the Competitive Enterprise Institute
Comment: See attached comments and attachments in opposition to DOT's proposal.

Title: Audrey Darville
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Elaine Keller and Kurt Fritzinger
Comment:
See uploaded files:

COMMENTS on DOT-OST-2011-0044 ...
Ten Attachments

Title: Tina M. McLerran
Comment: Please see attached comments.

Title: Angela Jones
Organization Name: American Cancer Society, American Heart Association, American Lung Association, Campaign For Tobacco Free Kids, Legacy
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Patricia Kay Clewell
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Mareike Karen Petruzel
Comment:
I strongly oppose the DOT proposal for the following reasons: 
- DOT falsely claims that vaporization of smokefree e-cigarettes is the same as smoking tobacco, 
- in contrast to DOT claims, the law banning smoking on airplanes does NOT authorize DOT to ban e-cigarette use, 
- there is no evidence that e-cigarettes have ever harmed any users or any nonusers, 
- DOT's proposal deceives the public to believe that e-cigarettes pose significant health or safety risks to nonusers, 
- DOT's proposal to ban e-cigarette use hypocritically would allow use of nearly identical FDA approved nicotine inhalers, 
- DOT's proposal is unenforceable as e-cigarette consumers can use products discreetly with nobody anyone else knowing, 
- DOT's proposed penalties for violations are outrageously harsh and punitive.

Title: Jan E. Johnson
Comment:
I respectfully request that The Department Of Transportation remove withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes on an aircraft.

Since the law about smoking on an aircraft is based upon a combustible item (ie a lit cigarette,cigar ) and since an electronic cigarette is not lit it is battery powered and uses propylene glycol to produce something akin to fog that fog machines make it simply makes no sense.

Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."

Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products.

http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because vapor is not smoke

The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

I respectfully request that the Department Of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252.

Thank you for your time,
Jan Johnson

Title: Chizimuzo Okoli
Comment: Given that e-cigarettes have compounds (including propylene glycol, volatile organic compounds, formaldehyde, and diethylene glycol) which may be harmful to health, the burden of proof lies on the e-cigarette manufacturers to ensure that the (secondhand) smoke from these products cannot harm none-users. With the current state of evidence (or rather, the lack there of) and the fact that e-cigarettes are not a bona fide therapy for smoking cessation, I would recommend a need for the application of the 'precautionary principle' and NOT recommend the smoking (or vaping) of electronic cigarettes on aircrafts.

Title: Jennifer Tillman
Comment:
Respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. 
The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. 
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft." 
E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke. 
Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.
E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients 
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf 
Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled." 
Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 
E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders 
Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders. 
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor.  
They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q 
Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.
DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes

Comment:

            Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigarettes use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetab

Title: Kathie A. Conway
Comment:
E-cigarettes are not smoking. I am sick and tired of the intrusion into personal lives and choices. E-cigarettes have been proven to NOT be harmful to others or in anyway interfere with those around the user.

Please see the following article:
http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/08/science/e-cigarettes-help-smokers-quit-but-they-have-some-unlikely-critics.html

Thank you.

Title: Sue Casanova
Comment:
There are many reasons why electronic cigarettes should not be allowed on aircraft.  They are untested and unregulated, and the public does not need to be treated as lab rats to find out what the actual harm will be.  It will be confusing to the staff who monitor passenger behavior, and will have them running around needlessly and getting frustrated.  It is frightening in this post 9-11 era to see someone using an electronic devise in cramped quarters where people are on heightened state of fear, and can add to panic and upset.

Smokers can refrain for the duration of a flight, or use gum, lozenges or the patch.

Title: Kristin Noll-Marsh
Organization Name: Consumer Advocates for Smoke-Free Alternatives Association
Comment:
Please withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

My husband and I have used e-cigarettes to avoid smoking since July 2009. Our health has improved and we have suffered no ill-effects. The vapor is virtually odorless, what slight scent there may be is unoffensive to non-smokers and the vapor does not linger in the air like smoke. They cannot be mistaken for cigarette smoking in any way and would cause no discomfort for others.

The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes. The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft." E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke, therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor: http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf 

Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."

Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products: http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf 

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes. A fine of up to $3,300 for using an e-cigarette is excessive and unwarranted because vapor is not smoke.

The 8th Amendment to the U.S. Government prohibits the government from imposing excessive bail, excessive fines, or cruel or unusual punishments.

Again, please withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: E-cigarettes do not pose any additional health or comfort concerns for passengers so I believe this proposed rule is unfounded.  Vapor is not smoke.  The health risks are not present as they are with a cigarettes so tacking it into the same category doesn't make sense.  It is a nicotine product not a tobacco product and there is no 2nd hand risk to other passengers.  Secondly, to address passenger comfort.  I don't really appreciate when someone next to me is eating a smelly greasy meatball sub, or has bad breath, or is drinking and smells like alcohol.  How would an e-cigarette be any different than these other passenger discomforts?  The "discomfort" would truly only be seeing the vapor for a short moment and smelling whatever e-juice they are using for a brief moment.  Most people don't seem to mind smelling blueberries or chocolate or any other flavors from e-cigarette vapor.  Unlike cigarettes, it is a pleasant smell to  most.  For these reasons, I am not in support of this proposed rule.

Title: Penny T. Zeilman
Comment:
I oppose the DOT proposal for the following reasons:
- DOT falsely claims that vaporization of smokefree e-cigarettes is the same as smoking tobacco, 
- in contrast to DOT claims, the law banning smoking on airplanes does NOT authorize DOT to ban e-cigarette use,
- there is no evidence that e-cigarettes have ever harmed any users or any nonusers,
- DOT's proposal deceives the public to believe that e-cigarettes pose significant health or safety risks to nonusers,
- DOT's proposal to ban e-cigarette use hypocritically would allow use of nearly identical FDA approved nicotine inhalers,
- DOT's proposal is unenforceable as e-cigarette consumers can use products discreetly with nobody anyone else knowing,
- DOT's proposed penalties for violations are outrageously harsh and punitive.

I travel extensively and I have found that it is very stressful and the use of e-cigarettes have saved my life.  Don't murder me by forcing me in to one of the smoke filled rooms in the airport that is awful with no ventilation, because I do not smoke...I vape with an personal nicotine vaporizer that has saved my life.  this is harmless to those around me and makes travelling more bearable.

Title: April Chillari
Organization Name: Consumer Advocates for Smoke-Free Alternatives Association
Comment:
I respectfully request that the DOT withdraw the proposed amendment to 14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft. The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does NOT authorize DOT to ban use of ecigs.
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."
E-cigs produce vapor, NOT smoke. Therefore Section 41706 does NOT apply to using e-cigs. E-cigs do not contain harmful ingredients. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf. Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled." Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf. E-cigs do not harm bystanders. Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.
Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cig vapor. They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cig vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q
Liquids used in commercial smoke generators include a mixture of glycols that may be irritating to eyes airways, while e-cigs use USP grade propylene glycol and/or vegetable glycerin.
DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigs or bystanders have been harmed therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigs. Withdraw the amendment, please!

Title: Stephen Andrew Helfer
Comment: E-cigarettes pose no danger and should not be banned on airplanes

Title: Charlene Haste
Comment:
How can it be a problem?  I guess all the teapots and kettles or steam from any of the food/drinks SHOULD be banned as well?  If you are going to ban e-cigs maybe you should consider banning alcoholic beverages as well?

Electronic cigarettes are NOT cigarettes and should not be held in the same regard.  

This is more about what a e-cig represents than the actual device itself.  I am against this ban.  I think it is absurd.  

What is the reasoning behind such a ban?  A Cigarette lighter or match is more dangerous then any e-cig. 

I believe people don't have a true understanding of what an electronic cigarette is.  

Before banning them, I think you may want to do some reading and look at some testing done on what they emit.  

Thank you,
Charlene

Title: Nan Jiang
Comment: I greatly support the prohibition of using electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft. E-cigarettes are unregulated nicotine delivery devices that emit an unknown mixture of chemicals into the air. Use on an aircraft would increase the level or air pollution inside the aircraft cabin and subject passengers and flight crew to the toxic chemicals in the exhaled “vapor.”

Title: Public Health – Seattle & King County
Submitter Representative: David Fleming, Director and Health Officer
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: William Theodore Godshall
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Jimmy M. McGuiness
Comment:
I am opposed to the DOT banning electronic cigarettes on aircraft 
There is no proof the electronic cigarettes harm the user or those around them, in fact all research on the ingredients shows that the vapor produced by electronic cigarettes is perfectly safe
I have been using these devices for 3yrs, I have my lungs tested yearly for respirator use since I am a firemen, 3yrs ago my lung capacity was at 76%, I just had another lung physical and am happy to report that my lung capacity is now at 98%
After 3yrs of use I have no negative effects to report, but many positives
The vapor produced by these devices has hardly any smell and dissipates very rapidly
The original ban on smoking was because of health concerns, since there is no proof that the vapor produced is harmful, I see absolutely no reason for banning these devices
Commercial fog machines used in concerts and clubs use food grade glycol, the general public and health organizations show no fear or concern for such devices 
Electronic cigarettes use lab grade usp glycol, the same substance found in inhalers and nebulizers used to treat pulmonary disease such as asthma and bronchitis 
As an electronic cigarette user I am sickened by the fear mongering, these devices could help save millions of lives, they should be embraced not shunned, all evidence that I have seen points to the fact that the vapor produced by these devices is not harmful in any way, glycol is used in skin lotions and cosmetics, it’s used as a base in injectible pharmaceuticals, it’s used in food goods, and it’s used in medical inhalers and commercial fog machines

Title: Independent Pilots Association
Submitter Representative: Michael Moody, Jr., IPA At-Large Representative
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Dominick David Grant
Comment:
Until it is illegal to enjoy a steamy beverage like tea or coffee that contains an addictive substance that doesn't affect anyone but the user, prohibiting the use of e-cigarette devices is improbable.
This is merely pandering to Lobbyists pushing to ban a device that could and has helped people moderate or limit their nicotine intake that they don't own or profit directly from. (Big Tobacco, and Big Pharma)

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please reconsider the manner in which you are accomplishing the desired goals of keeping the environment in a commercial aircraft comfortable.  As an e-cigarette user I realize that my use of the device in a closed aircraft might cause others some discomfort. 

However, redefining the term 'smoking' in your rules to include e-cigarettes, or personal vaporizers as many users prefer to call them, unfairly categorizes a reduced harm tobacco product that could save the lives of many smokers.

Our language, laws, and regulations are muddied enough with misconceptions.  Vaping is not smoking.  Nothing combusts.  There is no smoke produced.  Fog is not smoke.  Liquid vapor is not smoke.  Please do not further muddy the water by categorizing use of e-cigarettes as smoking.

Do not pass this regulation as-is.  Many years of studies, anecdotal evidence, and scientific proof were required before cigarette smoking was banned on aircraft.  Please require that the matter of e-cigarettes be more exhaustively researched before taking action.

Thank You,
Matt Metzinger
Oklahoma City, OK

Title: Steve Chase
Comment:
A ban on anything is a very serious matter particularly when it infringes upon our personal liberty. In my opinion the DOT has not proven its case regarding a potential ban on electronic cigarettes. The concern with such a personal matter should be focused on whether or not it is causing harm to others. If not the use of this device is a matter of personal preference.

Using an Electronic Cigarette is not smoking. It is an extremely effective device that is helping millions of people to quit smoking. The vapor that is being produced by an electronic cigarette is being drawn directly into the human body. The only potential harm to others is limited to the exhaled breath of the user after the vapor has been filtered through the human body. It seems to me that before any sort of ban is contemplated, proof is needed that harm is in fact being done to non-users. Conduct a test to analyze the exhaled breath of people that smoke, or use nicotine gum, or e-cigarettes, or patches or nicotine inhalers. When you compare the results I suspect you will find that the electronic cigarette falls in line with your approved products like nicotine gum and if so a ban would not be justified.

Title: Patricia Young
Comment: As a former flight attendant for American Airlines who worked for decades to remove smoking from the airplanes, I oppose the allowance of the use of ecigarettes on airaft. Nicotine is a known neurotoxin which will be emitted from the vapor expelled by the user. The innocent by standstander will once again suffer from the impact of the nicotine released from the vapor. Compelling scientific evidence is imperative. In addition the delivery system is an additional terrorist threat because security has no way to monitor the contents in the vials. It is unconscionable to subject flight attendants and passengers to this exposure and subsequent harm.

Title: Riccardo Polosa
Comment:
There is accumulating evidence in the medical literature clearly showing that Electronic cigarettes are much safer and much less toxic than a lit cigarette.
 The vapour they generate will not harm bystanders, so there is virtually no second hand exposure risk associated with the use of these products.
Legislation is required however for their use in public places in order to avoid the problem of being confused with traditional cigarettes that are rightly banned. A simple solution is a legislation enforcing that all marketd electronic cigarette should display a green or blue light instead of a red one that may generate confusion.
As far as their use in the airplane is concerned, their use could be restricted to long haul flights (more than 4 hrs duration for example) only.
These are simple and pragmatic suggestions and should be considered. I am against a generalized ban of these  products.

Prof. Riccardo Polosa

Title: Richard G. Harris, M.D.
Comment: I do not believe that the electronic cigarettes should be allowed on aircraft.  The vapor exhaled into the cabin air contains viruses, bacteria, and other potential pathogens which could be spread to others.  Since aircraft air is only 50% fresh, the number of recycle episodes for a pathogen released in the vapor could be sufficiently high so as to markedly increase the risk of infection in other passengers.  We only have one airplane (Boeing 787 Dreamliner) which has an active pathogen filtration and neutralization system incorporated into the air handling system.  It does not seem reasonable to increase the probability of obtaining an infection while traveling on a plane simply to coddle a nervous smoker.  Let us keep the air in aircraft cabins as free of pathogens as possible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The DOT has failed to cite any evidence that e-cigarettes pose a threat to bystanders. 

2. The DOT's regulation is contrary to federal law. The DOT only has the authority to regulate "smoking," and as we all know, e-cigarette use is not smoking.

Title: Margaret Stadick Olds
Comment:
I oppose the DOT proposal for the following reasons:
- DOT falsely claims that vaporization of smokefree e-cigarettes is the same as smoking tobacco,
- in contrast to DOT claims, the law banning smoking on airplanes does NOT authorize DOT to ban e-cigarette use,
- there is no evidence that e-cigarettes have ever harmed any users or any nonusers,
- DOT's proposal deceives the public to believe that e-cigarettes pose significant health or safety risks to nonusers,
- DOT's proposal to ban e-cigarette use hypocritically would allow use of nearly identical FDA approved nicotine inhalers,
- DOT's proposal is unenforceable as e-cigarette consumers can use products discreetly with nobody anyone else knowing,
- DOT's proposed penalties for violations are outrageously harsh and punitive.

Title: Randall David Fabiano
Comment: A ban on e ciggerettes is the most idiotic thing our government has ever done. It might as well ban caffiene since in as far as stimulants its about the same thing. We are talking about vapor here. No more harmful to others than a steam bath. The fact that it has the form of a ciggerette is irrelevant. If such a ban is passed it once again intrudes on the rights of people. This is a more healthy alternative to smoking and now we want to ban it? Really! Truly idiotic

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I completely agree with your proposal to prohibit electronic cigarettes on flights, including charter flights. 
Hal Edwards
halndallas@earthlink.net

Title: Timothy T. Frank
Comment: Regarding using electronic cigarettes on aircraft. I don't see them as a safety hazard, and other devices using batteries are allowed on aircraft (e.g. laptop computers). They are benign and harmless generally. I don't see a compelling reason to ban them during flight or on the aircraft. It seems to me that the use of electronic cigarettes could be handled sufficiently well by the airline itself, and left to the airline itself. It's no more, or less, a nuisance than alcoholic beverages, coffee (hot), or children, in my opinion.

Title: Stephanie Kozel
Comment:
Regarding docket number: DOT-OST-2011-0044, RIN 2105-AE06, Smoking of Electronic Cigarettes on Aircraft, I do not think that electronic cigarettes should be allowed on aircraft of any sort.  Even though electronic cigarettes do not emanate the smoke that regular cigarettes do, making them legal on aircraft would cause more harm than good.  Wouldn’t it promote others smoking on board?  How would the airlines and their personnel regulate it?  I agree with the banning of all “tobacco” related products on board is a wise choice. It will alleviate all questions about any and all types of tobacco products.  Even though only vapors are emitted in the air and not smoke, there have not been efficient studies on the health impact of third parties.  Also, the propylene glycol that is an ingredient in the electronic cigarette’s vapors can cause respiratory effects on people. Not all ingredients have been disclosed; therefore it is not possible to know what other reactions third parties may have to the vapors. Other uses of public transportation, such as Amtrak, do not allow the use of electronic cigarettes on their trains. With the air quality being an issue in aircraft, adding something to it that could be an issue to passengers is something best avoided.  
Another avenue that needs to be addressed is the use of battery operated machinery in flight. Would there be any interference with controls of the communication and navigation system? 
Thank you for allowing me to voice my concerns about this issue.  I appreciate our attention to this matter.
Sincerely, 
Stephanie Kozel

Title: Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, II
Comment:
E-cigarettes use water vapor and are not harmful to anyone.

The Attorney General of Virginia ruled they were a safe product to use.  His ruling is attached.

There is no reason e-cigarettes should not be allowed on the airlines.

Title: Christina Dawn Thompson
Comment:
First let me say I am indebted to everyone who has put forth effort to ban, or the examine the case for use, of e-cigarettes on planes. I am not necessarily attached to the ban, I am an asthmatic and am attached to clean air which would not hinder my breathing.

In reading the proposed ban of novelty e-cigarettes I am wondering if the rule could cast a broader net. For example, instead of pointing out the electronic nature of the cigarette and the specific anatomy of the "e-cigarette" that the nature of  the device being "an alternative to cigarettes that allow the user to experience nicotine through the use of mutual air". In that the right of those who are experiencing this mutual air are allowed to be safe.

For example, the Tobacco Control Act states: "any product made or derived from tobacco".

Perhaps the act could be amended to state "any product that delivers tobacco through the use of mutual air supply (which is to be considered 50 feet of another citizen."


My reasoning is that although the ban of these cigarettes is a huge amount of work, and undoubtedly this multimillion dollar industry will find another way to provide tobacco to it's users despite the bans put in place.

Title: Michelle
Comment: I am against this proposal.  Electronic Cigarettes do not pose any health risk to any other passengers.  It looks and feels like a cigaratte but doe not burn smoke whatsoever.  There is no fire involved either.  However, for smokers nervous of flying or just nervous in general, it calms them down, thus keeping them from being irritable.  This can only be a good thing for othe passengers and crew.

Title: Stephanie Lynn Estabrook
Comment: Using a electronic cigarette is not smoking. There is no smoke involved, its vapor. So to ban vapor is like telling someone you can't use oxygen either. Freedom is getting taken away. If people are trying to do something better for their health why no let them. I ask people around me out of courtesy is my "vaping" is bothering them. If it does I won't do it but to ban it is extreme! I think this is simply because the is no way for the government to make extra money off being healthier. Next they will be not curing diseases because that will mean a loss of money for medication. Allowing this to go through would only create more of these types of regulations. Before you know it, dangerous stuff will be legal and no one will be going out of their way to stand up for a healthier lifestyle. Please reconsider this and do not ban what has been the only way for some people to kick the cigarettes that cause cancer!

Title: Benjamin Flicker
Comment: I believe this proposed rule is pre-mature.  There is not enough research to claim e-cigarettes are harmful to the user or third parties.  All of the negative attention is simply reactionary to beliefs of nicotine use.  This is a different type of technology that has not been studied fully.  All comments about negative effects seem to be speculative.  It is unfair to the manufacturers and users of the device to ban e-cigarettes based on pure speculation.  It would be fair to assume that after more research is done, if the vapor from e-cigarettes are found to produce no negative side effects to third parties, the Department of Transportation will not rescind this rule.  I do not believe in the restriction of rights based on reactionary speculation.  The Department seems to be reactionary without fully investigating the science and effects of e-cigarettes.  I do not believe it is right to preemptively regulate this product until there is a clearer picture of any possible effects.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should be banned from aircraft

Title: Scott P. Cargill
Comment:
I would like to take this moment to remind the department that there are many u.s. citizens that have elected to smoke a legal act. E-cigs are arguably a safer delivery system than traditional cig's.

Title: Chase
Comment: The Department of Transportation is right in the amendment of 14 CFR Part 252 to include the prohibition of smoking electronic cigarettes on public flights. This amendment aims to define smoking as, “… the smoking of tobacco products or use of electronic cigarettes that are designed to deliver nicotine or other substances to a user in the form of a vapor” (Docket, 2011). The smoking of electronic cigarettes creates a discomfort for many non-smoking passengers, and it is unfair to jeopardize the comfort of an equal paying customer. The purpose of the smoking ban in part 252 is, “…to improve air quality within the aircraft, reduce the risk of adverse health effects on passengers and crewmembers, and enhance aviation safety and passenger comfort” (Docket, 2011). It is later stated in the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) that insufficient research has been conducted that can conclude that electronic cigarettes do not present a health risk for other passengers in an enclosed area, such as an aircraft. Until substantial evidence can be provided that shows no health risk to others by the use of electronic cigarettes, the amendment to 14 CFR 252 should proceed to include the prohibition of this additional device.

Title: Chase
Comment: Similar devices exist for the consumption of illegal substances such as marijuana. The marijuana is made in tablet form, with no scent or visual difference from the tobacco tablets used in electronic cigarettes. The marijuana can then be consumed in vapor form, emitting no smell and nearly impossible to detect. The allowance of electronic cigarettes on public flights presents the possibility for passengers to use illegal mind altering drugs while in flight. Until the research can be conducted and verified on the exclusion of health risks, and a method of differentiation can be established to separate legal and illegal electronic paraphernalia, the amendment should proceed in banning the use of electronic cigarettes on public flights.

Comment:
It appears, on the surface that you believe you have covered all of the issue, however, the samples which were tested, were cheap versions made in China, I believe.

You mention the use of PG, and while it is true, there are many products that use PG, there are also ones which use Vegetable Glycol, (VG), and some that use a blend of the two.

The exhaled water vapor is no more harmful than the body odor, and purfumes many passengers are often subjected to when the planes environmental systems are sealed...  

A heavy smoker can actually burp smoke from his lungs, several hours after he has smoked...  The smoke detectors could detect smoke, but cool water vapor???

It just seems difficult to enforce.  Also, there are perscription inhailers, which look very similar to some of the PV's being used.

Title: Adam Reed
Comment:
I respectfully request that the Department of Transportation withdraw the proposed amendment to  14 CFR Part 252  that would prohibit use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on aircraft.

The law ''Prohibitions Against Smoking on Scheduled Flights'' 49 U.S.C. 41706 does not authorize DOT to ban use of electronic cigarettes.
The law states, "An individual may not smoke in an aircraft."

E-cigarettes produce vapor, not smoke.

Therefore Section 41706 does not apply to using e-cigarettes.

E-cigarettes do not contain harmful ingredients
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's tests did not find any harmful chemicals in the vapor. 

http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/ScienceResearch/UCM173250.pdf

Dr. Murray Laugesen of Health New Zealand conducted studies in 2008 and declared the vapor "harmless, inhaled or exhaled."

Drs. Zachary Cohn and Michael Siegel reviewed 16 toxicology studies of e-cigarette liquid and vapor and concluded, "a preponderance of the available evidence shows them to be much safer than tobacco cigarettes and comparable in toxicity to conventional nicotine replacement products. 

http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/centers-institutes/population-development/files/article.jphp.pdf

E-cigarettes do not harm bystanders

Since those who inhale the vapor directly are reporting their health has improved, it defies belief that the residual vapor they exhale could possibly harm bystanders.

Commercial artificial smoke generators used in aviation emergency training produce cannot be compared to exhaled e-cigarette vapor. 

They produce a continuous, thick, dense smoke, but e-cigarette vapor is thin and dissipates quickly. 

http://www.bullexsafety.com/smoke_generator.aspx?gclid=CNiayLrFhKwCFYSK4AodKlMl9Q

DOT has failed to produce any evidence that users of e-cigarettes or bystanders have been harmed; therefore 49 U.S.C. 41702 does not apply to the use of e-cigarettes.

Title: Gary Leonard Talbot
Comment:
14 CFR Part 382

[Docket No. DOT–OST–2011–0098]

RIN 2105–AD87

Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel; Accessibility of Aircraft and Stowage of Wheelchairs

My name is Gary Talbot and I have been a fulltime wheelchair user for over 30 years and have logged over 1 million miles of airline travel in the past 30 years.  I currently sit on the U.S. Access Board although my comments are my personal opinions and not the opinions of the Access Boards.  A well signed, designated space in the main cabin is all we need to ensure people with disabilities are able to fly and travel independently without fear of our chairs left behind, damage to the unit or other passengers hating us because they just got bumped off the flight due to seat strapping of our device.  The issue of main cabin stowage of folded wheelchairs is critical for people with disabilities and the seat strapping solution is one of the most degrading experiences I have had in any of my flights and experiences that span over a million flight miles.  My thoughts are listed in bold below to the questions asked in the NPRM:

Gary Talbot
126 beach Street 
Foxboro, MA 02035
Talbotgt1@aol.com


Seat strapping
(1)	Is an awkward way of transporting a wheelchair in the cabin; 
a.	This is absolutely correct.  Seat strapping folded wheelchairs takes time and can be very difficult for the employees.  Flight attendants may see 100 different type folding chairs (or more) and each one could require slightly different strapping techniques.  These complexities alone will require additional time to strap the folded chair and could delay flights and bring additional negative attention on the wheeled mobility user.  When the aircraft has a designated storage area/closet the folded wheelchair is simply placed inside the space or closet requiring no special skill or training by the airline employees.  The sequence to simply fold and stow the folded wheelchair in the designated space is extremely

Title: Christopher Hart
Comment:
My name is Christopher Hart and I have been a fulltime wheelchair user for over 25 years. I am concerned that US DOT seeks to further weaken aircraft access by removing the obligation to stow folding wheelchairs in the cabin closet. For many of us who use either power assist or manual chairs, a well signed, designated space in the main cabin is all we need to ensure people with disabilities are able to fly independently; without fear of our chairs left behind, damage to the unit or adding further frustration to other passengers because they just got bumped off a flight due so their seats can be used for seat strapping of our chairs. It also adds a potential for damage to the chair, complexity for and potential injury to cabin crew.  It simply makes little sense.  Further, it amplifies the spectacle and stigmatization that I and so many others must endure to board an aircraft with the help of untrained and ignorant ground staff who transfer us to straight backs, (which are often left exposed to the elements at medium and smaller airports including DCA) then strap us down as if we need to be restrained.
US DOT should be strengthening the Air Carriers Access Act by ensuring every aircraft including commuter jets serving small airports such as Wichita KS, Tuscaloosa AL, Burlington VT and the DC/BAL/PHY/NYC/BOS corridor provide a designated space onboard that holds a folded manual wheelchair and does not require seat strapping.  The space could be a closet or located at the tail directly behind the rear seats.  On two aisle aircraft, it would be reasonable to assume capacity to stow two or more chairs on board and possibly more depending on the fare classes provided by the aircraft.  USDOT should also ensure signage at aircraft entries and at the stowage location identifies the right of passengers to stow their manual chairs onboard.  Finally, the department must prohibit U.S. and foreign carriers from removing existing closets or priority spaces used for stowing chairs.

Title: Steve Demos
Comment:
I am Steve Demos 78yrs old and have on occasion flown particularly to the Caribbean or Japan with a cane, walker or wheelchair as I age. I cannot understand why US DOT is removing the obligation to store folding walkers/wheelchairs in the cabin closet. This ensures my equipment arrives in one piece and allows people with disabilities such as myself to fly independently. Strapping a wheelchair or walker to a seat can damage device.  It also turns a now seamless event (stow object in closet) into a spectacle for no obvious benefit. 

Similar to improving passenger rights, US DOT should strengthen the Air Carriers Access Act, not weaken it. ACAA should cover every 40+ seat aircraft including commuter jets serving small airports to provide a designated space onboard that holds a folded manual wheelchair and does not require seat strapping.  The space should be a closet and signage should be provided that identifies passengers rights to stow their manual chairs and walkers onboard.  US DOT ought to ban the removal of closets that could be used for stowage of personal mobility aids. Thank you.

Title: Sheri Shaw Kyras
Comment: Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this great program.  It has provided significant benefits to the nation; however, one change would allow its benefits to penetrate throughout more of America by modifying the "rural" and "urban" definitions.  Small urban communities find it difficult to compete due to the minimum $10 million dollar threshold and many good projects that could bring regional and metropolitan benefits to their area are left without an avenue for funding.  The suggestion is to divide the "urban" category into "small urban and urban" instead allowing "small urban" communities between 50,000 and 100,000, based on the 2010 census, to have projects for a minimum of $5 million dollars and "urban" areas (over 100,000 popluation) to compete at the $10 million dollar level.  In reviewing the awards made to these "small urban" areas under the TIGER I and TIGER II programs, this level of minimum funding more closely matches the awards provided to these smaller communities.

Dear Ms. Reither:

The following comments on the Department of Transportation’s proposed amendments to the Code of Federal Regulations concerning enforcement of the Air Carrier Access Act of 1986 (ACAA), 49 U.S.C. § 41705, are submitted by Disability Rights New Jersey (DRNJ), the designated protection and advocacy system for individuals with disabilities in New Jersey, pursuant to the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000, 42 U.S.C. §§ 5041 to 15045; the Protection and Advocacy for Mentally Ill Individuals Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 10801 to 10807; the Client Assistance Program of the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 732; the Protection and Advocacy for Individual Rights Program of the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794e; and the Technology Related Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities, 29 U.S.C. § 3004.

DRNJ welcomes the Department’s decision to include accessibility to airline and travel agency websites and self-service kiosks as a component to ACAA enforcement. However, DRNJ has significant concerns regarding how the Department intends to enforce these standards. Without a robust system of enforcement, even the most carefully thought-out standards may not result in accessibility for air travelers with disabilities.

DRNJ suggests that the Department require all carriers to report on the actual costs associated with compliance with these new regulations.  The Department is properly concerned that the actual costs incurred by carriers may substantially exceed the estimated costs in the 2004 NPRM.  It is likely, as the Department suggests, that the use of more sophisticated web authoring tools and services will result in lower costs for ca

Title: Rosemary L. Hendon
Comment: I'm in favor of the Proposed SNPRM -New Rule  of the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA), which addresses  Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel: Accessibility of Web Sites and Automated Kiosks at U.S. Airports.   I request  to have the public input  period extended  since currently the submission link  on the government regulations website  is not directly  accessible  to individuals who use screen reading devices,  precluding input from the disability community.  I request the  Accomodation  of Time on behalf of the entire disability community.  I also ask that  any time limits on  filling out the submission form be removed.

Title: William V. Luneburg
Comment: This is a test. My students at the University of Pittsburgh will be submitting comments on this regulation in the next two weeks.

Title: Sandy L. Popp
Comment:
I am in favor of the Proposed SNPRM -New Rule  of the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA), which addresses  Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel: Accessibility of Web Sites and Automated Kiosks at U.S. Airports. The current ACAA law fails to meet a vast number of critical needs for individuals with disability. The new ruling will go a long way in addressing these shortcomings.  In addition, on behalf of the entire disabled community I would like to request  to have the public input  period extended  since currently the submission link  on the government regulations website  is not directly accessible  to individuals who use screen reading devices.  

Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments on this important ruling.

Title: Mark Romoser
Comment:
Silicon Valley Independent Living Center (SVILC) is a nonprofit organization run by and for people with all types of disabilities, of all ages, throughout Santa Clara County, California. 

SVILC is in favor of the Proposed SNPRM -New Rule of the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA), which addresses  Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel: Accessibility of Web Sites and Automated Kiosks at U.S. Airports.   

We also request to have the public input period extended  since currently the submission link on the government regulations website is not directly accessible to individuals who use screen reading devices, precluding input from the disability community, and the Accomodation of Time on behalf of the entire disability community. Any time limits on  filling out the submission form should be removed.

Title: Justyn Field
Comment:
I am writing to support the Proposed SNPRM –New Rule of the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA).  Reducing discrimination to travelers regardless of disability status should be a national goal that we continue to strive towards.

However, I think that you should extend the public input period for this important issue.  The submission link on your website is not accessible to all people, which is the exact issue that your legislation hopes to counteract.  Also, I believe that you should remove the submission time-limit on your submission form, as it prevents some people from submitting comments.

Thank you,

Justyn Field
Missoula, MT

Title: Cara Jean Wherley
Comment: I am writing to support the Proposed SNPRM- new rule of the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA). It should be required that airport kiosks and websites be accessible to all persons with disabilities. People who are visually impaired can not read the kiosks or website to buy their tickets. This act would require there to be a screen reader. All persons with a disability should be able to fly from the U.S. to a foreign country.

Title: San Francisco International Airport
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Melanie Jannery
Comment:
I use a service animal and was very happy when providing service animal relief areas was brought onto the table.  What I anticipated this to be like and the reality of what came to be was completely different.  Although service animal relief areas are required, they are all outside of the airports, so, spite this consideration to provide something for us to access with our dogs to relieve them, there are barriers.  Currently, in order for me to relieve my service animal, I have to go outside of the secure area of the terminal, find the potty area, relieve my dog and then go back through the entire screening process again. 

This IS an unreasonable process to go through especially when rules are designed to help individuals with disabilities.  Since many airports are large and packed, flights can be missed easily!  Airports can be intimidating and stressful to start.  The first time I flew since having the service animal relief areas implemented I was very disappointed, after asking about 13 airport personnel where the designated area was, I was mislead by many who simply did not know, to finally realize it was outside passed security.  I no longer had time to relieve my dog, nor did I have a moment to sit and catch my breath, where if proper set up was placed, I would have been able to relieve my service dog, not have become stressed and would have been able to sit as the rest of the travelers get to experience.  My challenges are invisible, but I cannot imagine how person with mobility or vision challenges would have navigated their way through successfully since I could not spite my efforts. 

It is only reasonable to place relief areas within the terminals inside the security area somehow.  The space needs to me minimal, perhaps taking guidance and care as they are able to provide areas on cruises to accommodate.  When delayed overnight, I certainly was disgusted with the relief area in place in Detroit. Dirty, dark, isolated, unsafe and inconvenient...not cool!

Title: Deborah L. Birch
Comment:
I hope that relief stations for service dogs will be provided within the Security areas of airports.  As a person with a disability, my travel is severely hamper at present due to the restrictions placed on having to exit many airports to simply relieve my service dogs.  

Many times I am forced to exit the secured area and actually leave the airport to simply allow my dog a much needed break.  This is not only troublesome, but is not within the spirit and intent of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

We have come so far as a minority group, please level the playing field a little more so we can relax between our flights like other travelers who are not disabled.

Thank you

Title: Phillis Fay Peppard
Comment:
I currently do not fly because the needs of my Service Dog are not met. It is impossible for me to go long distances to allow my Service Dog to relieve herself.

I appreciate that this issue is on the table. It is important that TSA and the Airlines meet the needs of all travelers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The sixty-day deadline is an effective start date for ordering an accessible kiosk assuming the rule will take effect thirty days after publication. It is essentially a ninety-day period where airports and plane companies can look into their proposed orders and make the necessary adjustments. This will be enough time for airports to find a new kiosk provider if needed and to adjust for the difference in cost. The ninety-day period is also a sufficient amount of time for carriers to enter into agreements with airports to implement shared-use accessible kiosks.

The reason for which such a large-scale implementation can be effectively executed is because the necessary foundational technology is already in existence. Typically, in system wide overhauls, a majority of the time is spent in the research and development phase, however this would not have to be the case. As specified within the proposal, the process will be guided by section 707 of the DOJ’s 2010 ADA standards that documents the applicable standards for which accessible ATM’s are to adhere too. Because a federally approved method of performing a similar function already exists, it would only make sense that the technology used to make the ATM’s accessible could be easily adapted to perform the functions of an airport kiosk.

Another useful technology already being used is an ipad that is made accessible to blind people by combining touch and sound. Similar versions of this touch screen can easily be retrofitted to replace the screens currently used in automatic kiosks. Also, the proposal mentions the existence of kiosks that already have the hardware necessary to aid in accessibility. All that would need to be installed is the right software. Again, similar software to that which is being used in the ATM’s should be easy to apply to these kiosks.

This is not to say the entire system could or should be completely transformed within this time-frame, however it affirms the potential that airlines will be able

Title: Debbie Brown
Comment:
I buy airline tickets several times a year for myself, and occasionally I buy a group of tickets for 10-20 people.  I have tried several times to use airline web sites, but I have given up, despite the fact that airlines charge a fee for phone service, and despite the fact that I am usually put on hold for awhile.  

I am not supposed to pay the above-mentioned phone fee because of airlines' web site issues, but I have never had an airline tell me about the fee waiver.  
 
I once asked a sighted friend to help me buy tickets on the web, but it took her 3 hours.  Clearly not only blind people have problems using airline web sites.
 
Airline web sites should be made accessible just as public facilities are made accessible to wheelchair users.  Accessible websites would be used by all people, and people would marvel at how simple the business of ticket buying had become.  
 
Please require airline web sites to be made accessible to the blind.

Title: Jane Lansaw

Title: Graham Mehl
Comment:
Re: Supplemental Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, Non-Discrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel: Accessibility of Web Sites and Automated Kiosks at U.S. Airports (Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0177)

Dear Mr. Podberesky:

I have been visually impaired my entire life and will be completely blind in the near future. 
I enjoy traveling and have been to 25 states and 3 countries. Unfortunately every time I try to fly my experience gets increasingly more difficult due to my vision worsening - from finding the best priced tickets online to waiting in long lines to purchse my ickets just because I cannot read kiosks.

Regarding Web sites, although I am happy with the technical standards DOT plans to apply to airline Web sites, there is no performance standard to ensure that the Web site will actually be usable by blind people.  Many Web sites conform to accessibility guidelines but are still only partially accessible or difficult to use with my screen access software.  Because I want to be able to use the Web site with substantially equivalent ease of use as sighted people, I ask DOT to include a performance standard in addition to the technical standards. 

Regarding kiosks, DOT is requiring all newly purchased kiosks to meet the proposed accessibility guidelines.  What if some airlines take several years to purchase new kiosks?  I do not want to wait several years before I am finally able to use a kiosk to check in or print my boarding pass, especially considering that this discrimination has gone on for far too long already.  I ask DOT to require airlines to retrofit a portion of their current kiosks for accessibility to ensure that blind people do not have to wait several years and so that airlines will not try to avoid following the new rule by delaying the purchase of new kiosks.  

In conclusion all Web sites and kiosks must be fully accessible to the blind.

Sincerely,

Graham Mehl

Title: Bangor International Airport
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: V. G. Capata
Comment: I travel with an assistance dog (service dog under the ADA) for my disabilities. I would like to have the relief stations for these animals accessible without having to go outside of the security area. When I am traveling across the country, it is difficult enough to get to my connecting flights without having to rush outside of the secured area to relieve my service dog and then rush back in. Due to the lack of feasible accommodations, I have limited my travel to emergency situations only, rather than more business and pleasure trips. It is unreasonable to expect disabled individuals to run to an isolated relieve station in order to accommodate their service dogs and then go back through security in a reasonable amount of time.

Title: Tonya K. Tiry
Comment: i have a service dog and love the idea of relief areas for them.   i have not had the chance to fly with him yet but that would be a huge concern of my and now i dont have to worry as much thanks you. tonya

Title: K. C. M.
Comment:
I fly for work between Canada and the US a few times a year and I travel with a Boxer service dog. I would find it very difficult if there was only one relief area. Pearson International Airport in Toronto has several relief areas in secured and non secured areas. For the safety and well beings of the passengers I would suggest making more areas readily available for your furry flyers. 

Thank you.

Title: Matthew Larsen
Comment:
I'm a disabled veteran with a medical alert service dog. Having a service dog relief area before and after security would be a significant benefit for us. My mobility isn't significantly impaired, yet I still have difficulty getting to the relief area in several airports and making my connecting flight, I have missed connecting flights because the animal relief area was so far away, outside of security, and the ground material (concrete) wasn't conducive to an animal relieving themselves. A more limited person would have far more difficulty than I do.

The service animal relief areas should have some sort of natural ground, not concrete. Many animals will simply refuse to use a hard surface. A natural surface, as simple as dirt or gravel but preferably grass or some other type of natural ground cover, would make it faster for many dogs to finish, which would make catching our connecting flight easier.

Title: Kim J. Samco
Organization Name: Guide Dogs for the Blind, Inc
Comment:
I am commenting on teh availability of dog relief areas in airports.

I travel with a guide dog.  Ideally there would be a relief area both inside and outside of the secured area.  If I had to choose just 1 it would be inside the secured area.

Title: Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Outreach
Organization Name: Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Outreach

Title: Deborah Allen
Comment:
Thank you for this opportunity to comment on access to airport relief areas for service animals. I am a blind person who has flown with a service animal both before and after the enhanced security measures were implemented a decade ago. My comments are informed by the ease of travel I experienced before those changes--and the significant problems I have experienced since then.

Please find a way to reinstate escorted access to non-designated outdoor areas within sterile zones. This was the practice before the security changes. Using escorted access will eliminate the need to construct relief areas and will provide timely access to many relief areas.

Relieving on the pavement next to the plane was never a problem for my guide dogs. I carry my own pick-up bags and would not expect these to be provided for me.

No matter what approach is taken, I strongly urge access to outdoor relief areas within the sterile zone. Within recent years, I have been in airports that have specially constructed relief areas for service animals within the sterile zone, but I do not use these facilities for my service animal because the relief areas are indoors.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Dorris Lynn Brueggeman
Organization Name: Guide Dog Users of Washington State
Comment: It is vital to have relief accomodation for service animals, particularly in secure areas of Airline Terminals.  I have missed connections and once prepared to relieve my dog in a public place before someone finally assisted me in finding a relief area in a timely manner.  As a past Guide Dog user, this is a vital need that really needs to be addressed.  I would relieve my dog in as out of the way spot as I could find in order to prevent discomfort, accidents, or illness while on a flight.  Thank you for making practical decisions for Accommodations.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a traveler with a guide dog, I am asking for the reasonable accomodation of a relief area for service dogs inside the secured area.  It is not usually possible to get outside the secured area, relieve the dog and then back through security to meet a connecting flight.  I have been told to allow my dog to urinate on the floor in the ladies room.  This really isn't making an accomodation, and is not the best for the dog or the handler in this situation.  Certainlly a secured grassy area can be placed where a handler may relieve her dog either with a security guard in attendance or in a fenced in area.
Thank you

Title: Donna K. York
Comment: Please ensure that service dogs are given an area to relieve themselves in the sterile areas of airports.  Trips through the airports are long for humans, and their service guide dogs need to be remembered.

Title: Becky Barnes
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
Office of the Secretary
49 CFR Part 27

RIN 2105-AD91
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0182]

RE: Service Animal Relief areas in secured areas in airports
Guide Dog Users, Inc. (GDUI) is an international organization of nearly 1000 members dedicated to advocacy, peer support, public education and all aspects of training, working and living with dogs specially-trained to guide individuals who are blind and visually impaired. GDUI does not train or place guide dogs, but acts as an independent resource network, providing information, support and advice concerning guide dogs, guide dog training and access laws to its members, the media and the public at large. GDUI strives to promote civil rights and enhance the quality of life for working guide dog teams. Drawing on the experiences and varied knowledge of its members, GDUI provides peer support, advocacy and information to guide dog users everywhere. In addition, GDUI works with public entities, private businesses and individuals to ensure that guide dog users enjoy the same rights to travel, employment, housing, and participation in all aspects of life that people without disabilities enjoy. GDUI is a special interest affiliate of the American Council of the Blind.

Guide Dog Users, Inc. supports the Department of Transportation’s proposal “to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports.”  Adoption of such rules will constitute a crucial reasonable accommodation for air-travelers with disabilities who travel with the assistance of a trained service dog. We further support these relief areas being located inside the sterile area of each terminal.

Currently, blind travelers who are guided by a trained service dog experience extreme hardship due to a widespread lack of relief areas for

Title: Albert Joseph Rizzi
Comment:
Albert J. Rizzi 
78 Country Club Road
Bellport, New York 11713
631.286.8055
albert@myblindspot.org


November 11, 2011


RE:	docket number DOT-OST-2011-0182


To Whom It May Concern:

As a guide dog handler and as a member of the Board of Directors of the Guide Dog Users, Inc., I would like to voice my support for  the Department of Transportation's proposal "to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports."  Adoption of such rules will constitute a crucial reasonable accommodation for air-travelers with disabilities who travel with the assistance of a trained service dog. I further support these relief areas being located inside the sterile area of each terminal.

Currently, blind travelers who are guided by a trained service dog experience extreme hardship due to a widespread lack of relief areas for service dogs within the sterile area of airport terminals. It is not practical for a blind handler of a guide dog to leave the sterile area to seek a designated relief area in response to his or her guide dog's relief needs, and then undergo re-screening, and ultimately succeed in making a connecting flight. In fact, the time and distance required of connecting passengers means that relieving the service dog is only possible at the very beginning and the very end of an itinerary, which often requires that the service dog must be denied relief for an unreasonable amount of time, causing true hardship for the working dog and unnecessary stress for the blind handler. 

In order for disabled travelers, who are assisted by service dogs, to have reasonable access to air travel, as non-disabled travelers do, the needs of their service dogs must be reasonably accommodated. 
The Department of Homeland Security's Transportation Security Administration has is

Title: Carolyn G. Meyer
Comment: I have profound hearing loss. I cannot hear announcements at airports that are for my safety. I want airports to have accommodations so that I can be informed with the same information as those with normal hearing. I want to see TVs with captions and visual displays at all departure gates. I cannot hear announcements onboard aircraft as well and hope that those announcements will be captioned in the future for my safety.

Title: Laurie Mehta
Comment:
See attached file(s)

RIN 2105-AD91
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0182]

Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance (U.S. Airports)
AGENCY: Office of the Secretary, Department of Transportation (DOT).

ACTION: Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM).
49 CFR Part 27

I am a blind American who travels independently guided by a trained service dog (a guide dog). I appreciate and support the Department of Transportation’s proposal “to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports.” 

There is currently a serious need for such a reasonable accommodation for those of us whose disabilities are somewhat mitigated by the assistance of a trained service dog. Currently, we experience extreme hardship, due to the lack of practical provisions for the relief of our service dogs at U.S. airports. 

The realities of air-travel have changed significantly over the past decade. Travelers are offered limited options, in terms of both direct and connecting flights, and all travelers must now participate in security screening procedures. The time needed for air travel (from the time required for entering the departure airport to the time when a traveler exits the airport at the arrival destination) has increased significantly, and there are limited options available for making flight connections. 

It is not reasonable to require that a blind handler of a guide dog leave the sterile area to seek a designated relief area in response to his or her guide dog’s relief needs, and then undergo re-screening; all to be accomplished between connecting flights. 

Because of the current widespread lack of practical service animal relief areas at airports, the time and distance required of connecting passengers means that it is only possible

Title: Diana Bender
Comment: I support the use of visual captioning so that people who have a hearing disability can understand announcements in gate areas, as well as throughout the airport.  I have a hearing loss and dread having to use the airport if I am unaccompanied by a person who can hear.  Most people who have a hearing loss and use hearing aids are unable to understand the PA systems in use at airports.  In addition, I support the DOT requiring the installation of hearing loops at ticket counters and gate areas in airports.  Hearing loops enable people using hearing aids to understand announcements coming from a PA system or a microphone at a ticket counter.  Loops are common in European airports as an accommodation for those with hearing disabilities and have been installed throughout the Gerald Ford airport in Grand Rapids, MI.

Title: Gyan Mehta
Comment:
See attached file(s) For formatted view:


My wife uses a guide dog. 
I support the Department of Transportation’s proposal “to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports.” 
Such relief areas are most needed within the sterile area of an airport terminal. 

The Transportation Security Administration has said that a relief area can safely be constructed inside of the sterile area, and that it is also appropriate for badged personnel to provide escort to a disabled traveler to access restricted areas where a disabled person’s service dog might be offered relief within the sterile area. This clarification acknowledges the legitimate need for reasonable accommodation of disabled travelers who are assisted by a service dog. 
Please require these reasonable accommodations for service animal relief within the sterile area of airports. 

It is not reasonable to require that a disabled handler of a service dog leave the sterile area to seek a designated relief area in response to his or her service dog’s relief needs, and then undergo re-screening; all to be accomplished between connecting flights. 

Because of the current widespread lack of practical service animal relief areas at airports, the time and distance required of connecting passengers means that it is only possible for a disabled person to reliev his or her service dog at the very beginning and the very end of a trip. Practically speaking, this means that that service dog must be denied any opportunity to relieve for an extreme amount of time, causing genuine hardship and stress for both service dog and disabled handler. 

<Please see the attached word coc>

Title: Tamara Jessup
Comment: As a person with a disability married to a person with a disability, I support the creation of relief areas for service dogs in airports. While I doubt I will fly with my service dog because my husband has medical issues that prevent him from flying, I know it would be very convenient.

Title: Leo Joseph Meyer
Comment: My wife has profound hearing loss. When we travel she cannot hear any announcements in the airports. For her safety, I advocate that all departure gate areas and other areas where information is announced have a looped system. Also, I would like to see visual announcements such as on LED screens with important information as well. This is a safety factor for all traveling with hearing loss. All airport TVs should feature captioning.

Title: Javier Robles
Comment: There should be rest areas where service animals can relieve themselves at airports.  It is very difficult for people with disabilities to find a green area for their dogs. I would suggest building green islands at passenger drop off and pick up spots.

Title: Michael Wayne Evers
Comment:
The department should adopt the following provisions in the design of dog relief areas: 
The dimensions of a dog relief area should be rectangular in shape, at a minimum of 8 FT in width X 16 FT in length.  It should also contain a fence that a dog cannot escape from E.G. chain link or a type of PVC panel style fence, minimum height of 6 to 8 feet, minimum width of 8 feet wide X 16 feet long with a gate 6 feet high X 5 Ft wide (enough width to accommodate a person in a wheel chair using a service animal).  A slab of concrete or any environmentally friendly material that is neither harmful to the service animal, human being or the environment.  
	Dog relief area needs to have trash receptacle and waste bag dispensers on site for properly disposing of animal waste.  A water hose and a drain in the middle of a dog relief area must be included in the design of a dog relief area in order to keep the area clean, unless alternative materials and methods are implemented eliminating the need for water hoses and drains in dog relief areas.  
	DOT should establish a performance requirement for all passengers with service animals in order to determine the number of dog relief areas needed for each concourse in each airport.  It should take a passenger with a service animal no more than 15 minutes to reach a service animal relief area within a sterile and or non-sterile area of an airport.  Also all airports must have a minimum of one service relief area in both non-sterile and sterile areas.  This will help the disabled passengers with service animals make their flights and or other connections by eliminating barriers that would be cause by having a passenger go through the TSA screening process again.  
	Airports should provide at minimum the location of each dog relief area via the airport’s website, diagram/map or information desk, etc.  The airport should also provide information as to whether or not each designated dog relief area is in a sterile and or non-sterile area o

Title: Yolanda E. Phelan
Comment:
RE Service Animal Realief area at Airports

Dot-0st-20011

Please accomadate realief areas inside the airport.

Reason: Inside once you get through security  check there is a risk of missing connecting flights when you have to go out side and back in through security.

Which made me miss my connecting flight which ended up  causeing me to take 5 different flights to get home, from DC to Minnasota to Alabama, to San Francisco to LA the next day then home to Hawaii. each stop I had to get assistence to go outside then back through security and escorted to my Gate. I am Blind it was really a nightmare experence and 
stressful for my Guide dog.

So you see the unexpected can occure there is a serious need for releif areas inside of the check points and the staff needs to be awear wear the releaif areas are located.

Title: Allan J. Brenner
Organization Name: Earle Baum Center of the Blind
Comment:
Allan Brenner, CEO, 
Earle Baum Center of the Blind 
Docket Number: DOT-OST-2011-0182

My name is Allan Brenner. I am a guide dog handler and have been such for about 15 years. I am the CEO of Earle Baum Center of the Blind, Immediate past Chair of VisionServe Alliance and Past President of California State Board of Guide Dogs for the Blind, a Governor appointed position.

I frequently travel by air throughout the United States and infrequently, outside. One of the biggest obstacles for safe and comfortable travel with my guide dog is the lack of access to relieving areas when in the airport. Currently, with few exceptions, one must exit the airport security areas in order to find a relieving area which is often both difficult to find and unsafe. At times, the only option is the busy street.

Since most flights require stopover or change of planes, unless one has enough time to exit the airport and return through security, the guide dog suffers. Arriving at the airport at least one hour in advance of the flight, taking into consideration the flight time, stopovers, additional flights, delays and time to exit the final destination, many hours can pass without having the opportunity to relieve my guide dog. It feels cruel and stressful to both of us as a team. 

I have been asking for service dog relieve areas within the sterile zone of airports for years to no avail. As most people recognize, air travel is challenging for everyone but the additional challenges traveling with a guide dog significantly make air travel undesirable. 

I would like to see relief areas located in each terminal no further than a 5 to 7 minute walk from any gate so that one can relieve a guide dog with a 30 minute stopover. The surface can range from grass, dirt or gravel. The key is the ease of access and availability to help make air travel with a service dog team more in line with the experience of the general public.

Title: Jordan Griffin Gallacher
Comment: The number of relief areas should be determined by the size of the airport and the size of the terminals.  Also, I will say that along with one being outside of the sterile area there must be at least one inside the sterile area depending on what I previously said.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please make it possible for Guide Dogs to have a relief break without going out and back in security.

Title: Jan Bondi Robitscher
Comment:
I travel to many places in the US and Canada with a guide dog, but am most familiar with the ATL and SFO airports. In both cases, the dog relieving area is outside of the "sterile area" and quite a distance from the gates, but nearer to the Baggage Claim area, with little signage and, really, not much space. Upkeep of the area is also a concern. 

As airports expand and pave over more "green" areas, such relieving areas are becoming harder to find, if they exist at all. In an unfamiliar airport this can be very difficult and even scary if there are delays. 

I am also wondering what happens if a plane is stuck on the tarmac and my dog can't get out to relieve.  What happens then? 

Flying is hard enough as it is and I hope this rule change will make it easier to travel with my guide dog.

Title: Gyan Mehta
Comment:
I am a member of Guide Dog Users Inc and  spouse of a guide dog handler. As we travel a lot,we experienced the hardship caued by the lack of relief areas inside the sterile zone. 

I fully support this comment submited by the President of GDUI.

Title: Louie Pierre Nalda
Comment: Please provide relief areas  like the one at ABIA in Austin, TX.

Title: Joseph K. Landau
Comment:
Here are my comments based on practical experience at US airports with my guide Dog.

Relief areas are required within a 15 minute window of boarding or exit from the aircraft.  This may fall within secured areas at larger airports. ( I have actually been told at Denver to use the family bathroom to relieve my guide which is totally unacceptable.)

The area should be outside,  a minimum of 10x15 feet and   have a lidded trash can and supply of doggy cleanup bags.   Fencing is not necessarily required as guide dogs are under control of their users at all times and remain on leash.  (Pets on the other hand are another story).  The area should be cleaned daily and clearly labled as a relieivng area.  Signage is critical as well as notations on AP maps and websites.
