Training should be provided to all AP and carrier  staff so that they are familiar with the areas locations and can direct users to the location.  I  don't feel it is necessary to provide escorts to the area unless security is an issue.

I have found smaller regional airports to be a non issue as one can typically get out of the airport within a resonable time frame and back due to short distances.  Releiving areas are not really necessary.

Compliance should be within 90 days.

Would this legislation apply to cruise terminals?

Title: Gerald Richmond
Comment:
I'm a guide dog user, and I appreciate the improvement of adding an outside relieving area in the airport.  However, it is not easy as a blind person to go out, find the area, and get back in through security.  Usually there is not enough time between planes to even do this.  If a service dog relief area could be provided inside the sterile or secure area, service animal handlers could attend to the dog's needs and still have time to make their connection.  This could be done with an area similar to a human restroom, using floors covered in an absorable media such as wood shavings, a floor drain, and available pickup bags.
With more blind people flying, either for work or pleasure, anything that would make travel easier and more accessible would be welcome.

Title: Chelsie Anne Bowden
Comment: I would love all airports to have service animal relief areas past security checkpoints.  Dirt or sand might be good material for a relief area and not hard to maintain.  The area wouldn't have to be large at all, maybe 4ft x 4ft.  Garbage cans with bags should be located beside the relief areas to dispose of waste.

Title: Katherine S. Schneider
Comment: I support based on my experience of 38 years traveling witha guide dog a relief area within ten minutes walk of any gatepreferably in the "sterile" area and one near baggage claim in every airport.

Title: Alexander William Schneider
Comment:
I wish to add my support to amendemts to provide accessible, safe areas for persons with disabilities who use service animals to allow said service animals to relieve themselves. Such areas should be within a five minute walk (approximately 1000 feet, measured by paths accessible to a person with disabilites) of any gate, waiting area, or lounge open to the general public, including membership clubs and the like, and should not require passing into or out of a "sterile" area through security screening. Any less generous provision unacceptably increases the risk of the peron with disabilities being unable to return in time to board his/her flight.

To the extent possible, such areas in aggregate should be adequate to provide at least 100 square feet per user, and should permit at least 0.01% of the daily users of the airport to simultaneously use the area. 

These comments are based on experienced with my sister, who frequently travels by air to and from Chicago, the nearest airport to my home.

Also to the extent possible such areas should be shielded with visual and acoustical barriers to shield the animals view from moving aircraft, to allow them to relax and urinate or defecate quickly.

Title: Catherine Cecilia Varidel
Comment: I would like to urge the DOT to require a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal located inside the sterile area to significantly reduce the time and distance for disabled passengers whose assistance dogs need to make use of the service animal relief area.  In very large terminals with more than one concourse where gates may be well over a quarter mile apart, we hope the DOT will require a centrally located relief area inside the sterile area or if that is not possible for logistical reasons, the airport could build two service animal relief areas inside the sterile area, one at either end of the terminal to ensure time and distance do not pose barriers for disabled passengers traveling with canine assistants.  These relief areas need to be located outdoors on the sterile side of the airport since service dogs are trained not to eliminate indoors and doing so would cause stress and confusion.

Title: Cin Moyni
Comment: A working canine is an invaluable asset to those in need.  It is hard for others to understand at times. But should you find yourself in need of a working canine, you would want to ensure the canine could be with you whenever possible.  The canines are well trained to be in public settings without drawing attention or doing any inappropriate action.  They do, however, need to "toilet" if in an airport or traveling for an extended period of time.  Toileting is limited to the front of airport areas, past security.  This can prove difficult for travelers with working canines.  We have noticed there are often designated outside areas to smoke after the security check point.  It would be most helpful to have a designated spot or portion of the smoking area for working canines to toilet.  It would need to be outside, as working canines are trained to never toilet indoors. Those with working canines are aware of clean up procedures and would work to ensure the area remained clean.  This might prove difficult at some airports and it may need to be more on a case by case basis.  We do not wish to ask for more than what would appear "logical" to help those in need. But if one has ever traveled with a working dog, they understand the dynamics of how hard it is and the complexity of going through security, ensuring the dog is taken care of and not put too much demand on any one person, airport or working dog.  Consideration in helping those in need would be invaluable.  Especially today...with everyone is saying go..go..go and those with working canines can only "go" so fast and do so much to adapt to the world of those who do not or are not in need of an assistant dog. Thank you in advance for consideration of thoughts and ideas to find a reasonable solution.

Title: Jenine Stanley
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Susan Taniguchi
Comment: It's hard enough travelling as a disabled person without having to go long distances to find an area for one's service animal to relieve themselves. I support this regulation.

Title: Tonja Peterson-Wendt
Comment:
I would encourage you to pass this bill and require that there are at least one accessible spot for assistance dogs to relieve themselves at per terminal within the secure areas.  

I would also encourage you to have assistance available for those who may be pressed for time in these situations.  

Myself, I am able to make it to most places, however some days I would be faster doing this than others.  There are varied reasons one would utilize the services of an assistance dog.  Please keep this in mind when making legislation/rules that would govern the time frames that they are allowed.

By your support of additional relief areas this will allow more of us to live more productive lives and contribute to our society in better and useful ways.

Thank you for your consideration.  
Sincerely,
Tonja Peterson-Wendt 
Assistance Dog Luka
Assistance Dog in Training Hazel

Title: American Council of the Blind
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Mary Jane Ellis
Comment: guide dogs should not be treated insiuch a manner that they atre at airports they are with the owner at all times

Title: Debra Losey Peterson
Comment:
Re:  SERVICE ANIMAL RELIEF AREAS AT AIRPORTS IN THE U.S.: Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0182 Department of Transportation 

Marty is my brother-in-law. Juanita is my brother-in-law's eyes.  Service dogs are as essential to the people needing them as your own body parts is essential to you.  I am appalled that Airport security has put an unfair burden on those traveling with service dogs for something as essential as a usable bathroom area for a person's service animal. 


I am requesting that the following be incorporated into the new DOT rule change:

1. Require at least one relieving area INSIDE the "sterile" TSA security area of each terminal.

2. A minimum of 20 square feet per relieving area

3. The relieving area should be OPEN-AIR (outside of the terminal building) since service dogs are trained NOT to relieve indoors.

Title: Nancy Joan Tucker
Comment:
As an individual with disabilities who frequently air-travels with my service dog, I fully support the proposed change. It is stressful for a dog to not be able to relieve him/herself when needed, as sometimes happens in the case of delayed flights, tight connections, etc. I try to plan my trips to allow plenty of time to try to find a place to potty my dog, which involves having to sometimes go quite a long distance. There are some airports which have no place but concrete. Then there is the time factor of having to go back through security. 

Thank you for this proposed change.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Re: docket number DOT-OST-2011-0182

SubJect: Service Animal relieving areas at airports

I am requesting that the following be incorporated into the new DOT rule change:

1. Require at least one relieving area INSIDE the "sterile" TSA security area of each terminal.

2. A minimum of 20 square feet per relieving area

3. The relieving area should be OPEN-AIR (outside of the terminal building) since service dogs are trained NOT to relieve indoors.

Title: Daniel Mahaney Donlan
Comment: I travel frequently with my Guide Dog and am nearly always presented with the choice of taking the dog outside security to relieve him and possibly missing my next flight or allowing the dog to be uncomfortable during the flight.  A relieving area inside secure area would allow me to relieve the dog without the fear of missing my flight.

Title: Rebecca Jo Kragnes
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-
2011-0182 The current system of having service animal relief areas outside the "sterile area" or TSA screening checkpoint is impractical for people who have mobility or visual impairments. 
Traveling with an adult familly member with autism who uses a service dog and has a gait impairment was a very frustrating and difficult experience, as the relief areas were over a mile from the gate and required travel by train in order to access them. Signage was poor. Other service dog users have advised purchasing a newspaper and training the animal to use the paper in the airport restroom as an alternative. If the air carriers will not provide a relief area, it seems that service dog users may have to creatively provide their own. Cruise liners solve the problem by providing kiddie pools with shredded newspaper or mulch. Such an arrangement would solve many problems for disabled travelers.

Title: Sheri Richardson
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this NPRM. I am totally blind and have traveled with a dog guide multiple times over 30 years. There have been a few occasions when my dog was not able to reach an appropriate relief area in time to prevent an accident in the airport. Designated animal relief areas will be extremely helpful.

Relief areas should be accessible from both outside and within sterile areas to accomodate arriving, departing and transfering passengers.  Also, these areas should be accessed quickly and with as little walking as possible. All airport staff should be able to assist a passenger to the relief area. Signage should also be made available for those persons who can see and read them.

Title: Cheryl Ann Roshka
Comment: I would appreciate having a relief area set aside for guide dogs and other service animals in the sterile areas of all U.S. airports.  They would greatly reduce the stress of finding an area to relieve my guide dog and for other handlers who use service animals to relieve their partner prior to entering the airport.  Traveling with a service animal and having relief areas in the sterile areas of the airport will provide greater independence for the handler who otherwise would need to have an airline agent assist them and/or go through the TSA screening process again.

Title: David C. Emery
Comment: I would like to respond to the issue of Assistance Animals and Service Dogs in Airports. As an individual who must be accompanied by his Service Dog, It greatly concerns me that I can often find no 'relief area' (potty spot) for my dog. I would like Airports to be REQUIRED to provide these places Within the 'sterile' or Secure areas, because it is a hardship for me to go through security to find a place for the dog to potty. Each time I go through security, any medical equipment I carry much be inspected and scanned, along with all the Service Dog's gear. This is difficult, and I often run the risk of missing connecting flights while trying to find a relief area at all, much less navigating security multiple times. I also would like the Airports to be REQUIRED to post signs which point the way to those relief areas, within the 'sterile' secure zone, so that we can find them. Thank you very much for allowing us to add input to this issue.

Title: Heather Elizabeth Murlin
Comment:
My views are in line with the recommendations of the IAADP With he exception that I would like to see IN ADDITION to the one relief area per terminal optional relief areas in restrooms made of AstroTurf at least 3x4 feet with a rinsing nozzle similar to the ones in convalescent homes where when the nozzle is tilted toward the floor it turns on.    Keeping in min accessibility.

Though I agree that most dogs will not eliminate indoors. Many service dog handlers that travel extensively have trained their dogs to eliminate indoors on cue either on papers they carry with them or an item called a "chuck" that has AstroTurf on the top of the pan.  

When I have traveled with my service dog. I have had to leave the TSA checkpoint to let my dog eliminate outdoors forcing me to walk long distances and miss flights limping up to the terminal too late to catch the assigned flight. Airlines try to accommodate but when I miss the flight they cannot seat me in the optimal area for service dogs in flight and I end up separated from my party and luggage.

Title: Cecilia Amber McKinsey
Comment:
I recently acquired a service dog and I have been worried about what to do for his "potty" needs if we were to travel by plane. I think it would be a very good idea to place service dog relief areas in the sterile areas of airports where disabled people will not have to go through the security access points in order for their service dog to relieve themself. As many disabled people have problems with mobility, making them leave the secured area to relieve their service dog and then go through the security check again, could cause the person to miss their flight. Please make airports more accessible for people with disablilities who require the use of a service dog.

Thank you for your time,
Cecilia McKinsey

Title: Ben R. Ezzell
Comment: Rest areas for Service Dogs within the "secure" areas at all airports should be an absolute requirement.  Most individuals - if not all - traveling with SDs are already facing problems not experienced by normal travelers and adding the time-consuming and tedious necessity to reenter though security -- complete with even carry-on luggage -- in order to provide their companions with the proper facilities is simply an unfair and unnecessary burden.

Title: Orbie Sue Davis
Comment:
Having a relief station after security and before planing would be very helpful for those traveling with assistance dogs.  Handlers are always aware of sanitation issues and clean up after their animals.  

Now, we must go out of the airport, find a designated area, which are not always easy to find and then go back through security.  This method is both time consuming and difficult.

Title: Melanie Lynn Sinclair
Comment:
I totally support IAADP, I would very much like to see the DOT require a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile area of each terminal so that time and distance do not impose a hardship on disabled passengers traveling with assistance dogs.

My foster father is alive and well today due to the valuable companion service dog that goes everywhere with him and alerts when needed. Please allow him and people like him to travel with peace of mind and to move freely and live better. 

Signage for this Service Animal Relief Area should also be required and implemented. 

Thank you for your time and attention.

Title: Orbie Sue Davis
Comment: What a wonderful deal this would be.  As is we must go out of the airport try to find the designated area (not always clearly marked or nonexistent) and then go back through security.  In Honolulu I have never found the area and must find a place away from the people then go back through security and then on to the international airport.  At some airports they must be in carriers and boy do they feel heavy after a while.  Tried the carrier on wheels but did not work well as we well know when a dog lays down they lay against the side which causes the carries to fall over and I am then dragging it.  Not fun, easier to just carry them.

Title: Helene Elisabeth Wheeling
Comment:
Please make it easier for people who travel with service dogs to find relief areas.  Making teams go through security twice is grueliing, as is travel for most disabled people (not to mention able bodied people).

This will take a huge stress off dog owners and airport personnel.

Your help in this matter would be greatly appreciated.

Regards,
HE Wheeling

Title: Ernest John Richardson
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Lynn M. Duplessis
Comment:
I support the Department of Transportation's proposal "to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports."  Adoption of such rules will constitute a crucial reasonable accommodation for air-travelers with disabilities who travel with the assistance of a trained service dog. We further support these relief areas being located inside the sterile area of each terminal.

 Relief areas inside of the sterile area (inside of security) are desperately needed because connecting passengers cannot offer their guide dog relief as things are now because of a lack of opportunity to do so inside of the secured zone. 

The TSA suggested that airports offer authorized staff to escort a service dog handler outside of restricted areas to relieve their dog .  This could be a low-cost answer that could take effect immediately. 

I also wish to affirm the efforts that TSA has made in clarifying that there is no security problem with service animal relief areas inside of the secured zone. 

Appreciation to the DOT for its efforts to help improve airport travel experiences for service dog handlers.

Title: Kevin Lee Frankeberger, Ph.D.
Comment:
As a person who is blind and travels frequently with my guide dog, I implore you to implement the rule that relief areas for service dogs be within the "sterile" area of the airport.  With ever increasing lines at security check points, crowded airports and planes, it is now impossible to take my dog out of the "sterile" area for relief and still make any connection within an hour having to again, endure the security lines and needs of TSA.  I have noted that TSA also has no issues with service dog relief areas being within the "sterile" area of the airport.

Personnel must be trained and available to assist myself and my guide dog to and from the relief area.  My dog is not and can not be "route trained" within all the airports we might find ourselves.

Title: Scotti D. Clair
Comment:
i almost missed my connecting flight because of the long distance i had to go to take my service dog to relieve himself. the big airports are impossible and then having to wait in line again is so rude and disheartening. Please have a place where dogs can go where we don't have to miss or almost miss our flights. I was in 1st class so my wait wasn't as bad as if i was in regular steerage! Then i surely would have missed my flight!
Thank you~
Ms Scotti d Clair

Title: Clark Nevin Johnson, Jr.
Comment: As the owner of a IAADP Registered Service Dog, I wholly support the placing of a Service Dog Relief Area accessible inside the TSA Secure Area within EACH airport terminal/Gates Area.

Title: Jo-Anne A. Plunske
Comment: To make "relief areas" is an aboslute necessity.  Disabled have enough fal de ral to go through without being sent out of the terminal or to the other end of the world to find an appropriate location. Time schedules do not permit long periods of time to "wander around" looking for such a place.

Title: Anne Patrick Lowry
Comment: The MUST be places for service dogs to relieve themselves at airports.  I had a horrible time in Atlanta when my flight was delayed 6 hours and my dog needed to go out.  The airlines got a boy who took us on a 15 minute (at least) walk/ride to an outdoors spot.  He ran over the dog's foot 4 times and did not listen to me to slow down while pushing my wheelchair.  While the dog was urinating on a patch of grass, I saw the boy looking into a side pocket in my computer case.  When he took me back to the line to get cleared again, he was told 3 times by security workers to put me and the dog in a certain area, yet he ignored them and pushed me right through the whole system.  Had he broken the foot of a dog that cost $25,000 to train, I would have been furious.  It still took many times to get the dog who had not previously been afraid of eevators to get into one, as the boy ran over his foot twice, shoving us in.

Title: Linda S. Berry
Comment: One relief area per terminal, located inside the sterlile area is the best resolution to this issue.

Title: Kathie Ward
Comment: Please listen to the people involved - the grass roots - so to say.  I travel often and to have a relief spot both inside and outside of each terminal would be perfect.    I and I am sure many more have, in the past, missed connecting flights not just within the USA but to overseas because of the problem to let my Asssitance Dog use a suitable place.

Title: Kathryn L. Bales
Comment:
I am a disabled person who travels with a service dog. Last year I flew to NY, and was in severe pain for the duration of my trip, and for over a week afterward, because of the distance I needed to walk to allow my dog to relieve herself.

Each trip required a trip through security and, since I must wear a back brace, a strip search. Had my connections been closer, I would have missed my connecting flights.

A service dog relief area inside the sterile area of each terminal is sadly needed. Since my condition is progressive, I will not be able to fly again until such facilities are available. 

Please consider adding this much needed amenity to the terminal areas.

Thank you.

Title: Ann Elisabeth Manning
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

It is imparative that service dog relief areas be positioned in the sterile area of every terminal.  It is very stressful trying to make connections while taking care of our personal needs and that of our service dogs.  In a time crunch I have been fortunate that the pilot offered to take my service dog out on the tarmack for relief, but that circumstance has not happened since.  It's also distressing to entrust my best friend, who can't talk, to a total stranger who happens to be a member of airport personnel to take my dog for relief if time does not allow for me to go back through security.  We want to take care of our own animals so please consider what I have to say.  Sincerely,  Ann Manning

Title: Dan Marquardt
Comment:
THE NEED TO HAVE A SERVICE ANIMAL RELIEVE THEMSELVES WITHIN THE STERILE AREA IS NOT JUST OBVIOUS BUT TOTALLY NECESSARY. EACH TERMINAL SHOULD BE CAPABLE OF ACCOMMODATING SERVICE ANIMALS WHO, WILL MOST LIKELY BE UNABLE TO RELIEVE THEMSELVES FOR HOURS, WHILE IN TRANSIT.

 THE STENCH CREATED WHILE ABOARD A FLIGHT BY ONE SUCH ANIMAL WAS REVOLTING. THE POOR ANIMAL SHOULD NEVER BE ALLOWED TO AFFECT A FARE PAYING PUBLIC IN SUCH A DISGUSTING MANNER. THERE ARE BETTER OPTIONS THAT SHOULD BE PURSUED, PROVIDING AN AREA OF RESPITE WOULD GO A LONG WAY IN MAINTAINING SANITARY CONDITIONS IN AN HERMETICALLY ENCLOSED AREA SUCH AS AN AIRSHIP.

Title: Nicholas A. Giudice
Comment: I travel frequently with a dog guide and often have had the situation after a long flight that my dog needs to releave himself but there is insufficient time to get to a relief area outside of the security zone. If an authorized area were designated within the sterile zone, it would make travel much easier, my dog much happier and this issue far  less of a problem. As the time between flight legs is  decreasing and the time to clear security increasing, this is a major problem and the notion of creating a relief area for service animals within the sterile zone of each terminal would be an important and much appreciated solution.

Title: Kathleen Mary Miller
Comment:
I think it is very necessary to have the service animal relief area  located inside the sterile area or outside the sterile area, to ensure time and distance are not barriers for disabled passengers.     I have Multiple Sclerosis and if I had to take my Service Dog Gus who is my mobility dog outside to potty at any great distance and then had to go through Security again I would more than likely miss my flight.  I am an American Red Cross Disaster Volunteer and member of the K9 Comfort Team for the Military and I fly frequently.  Please put the Service Dog relief area inside the 'sterile area'.
Thank you,

Title: Sue Matthews
Comment:
I am a person with disabilities who has been partnered with mobility assistance dogs for more than twelve years. I have flown numerous times with my assistance dog and a primary concern has always been my dog's welfare because toileting has almost always been impossible to accomplish.

On a few occasions, when flying regional carriers, I've been able to toilet my dog outdoors in an out of the way place on the tarmac. On only one occasion when I had a 3 hour layover was I able to make my way to the outdoor dog area at the Atlanta Airport so my dog could eliminate between flights. That area in my mind is nearly useless. It is so small and located adjacent to a very busy roadway which is very dangerous for dogs.

Whenever I've flown, I've tried to be proactive and find out where dog relief areas are at the airports I will be traveling through, but the simple fact is that they are always located outside of the secure areas, are generally located at a great distance from the arrival gates, and it's not possible for me to get to and from that area before my connection leaves, both because of the distances involved and the time it would take to get through security again.

Any other times I've flown in the last 12+ years, my dog has either needed to "hold it" or I have resorted to having him eliminate on a CHUX pad placed on the floor in the ladies' restroom, which I've then bagged and disposed of in the trash can. This really is not an acceptable solution to me, but it's the only one available at this time. There have been times when I've been stuck in a gate area for hours due to weather or maintenance issues, but could not leave because the flight could be called at any minute. This jeopardizes my dog's health.

It's vital that airports provide accessible areas for assistance dog relief within the secure areas. If there is more than one terminal, it would be best if each one had a dog relief area, or at least be centrally located so that distances could be minimized.

Title: Gary W. Johnson
Comment:
I am concerned that time and distance to a relief area located outside the sterile area could result in assistance dog teams missing their flight.  Any of us could experience this problem, as any assistance dog can suddenly have a digestive upset.  Many like my own service dog may become stressed by severe air turbulence or a thunderstorm during the flight and upon landing, urgently need a trip to a relief area so as to prevent "an accident" and to alleviate cramps.  Young dogs, elderly assistance dogs and those on their first flight will need to eliminate more often than assistance dogs in their prime who are seasoned travelers. 
        I believe the vast majority of assistance dog teams who are on the way to the gate or connecting with another plane or after landing at their destination before they get their luggage would be best served by a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal.

Title: Cheryl L. Tipton
Comment:
As someone who trains service dogs AND is in the process of getting a service dog I think this is an issue that is long overdue being addressed.  It's extremely stressful to both those traveling with a service dog as well as other airline passengers for these dogs to have an accident.  Additionally it's hard on the dog and can affect their ability to work to the best of their ability.
Please take these concerns seriously - you owe it to the disabled who already have to overcome many obstacles to travel.
Thank you.

Title: Laura
Comment: This is a very real issue for the disabled community. Especially considering that the screening process for an individual in a wheelchair is more complicated than that of a non wheelchair user, service dog relief areas should be standard inside all terminals. Please consider this.

Title: Kizzen N. Laki
Comment:
I support the
INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF ASSISTANCE
DOG PARTNERS statement and comments.  I travel with a hearing dog.  It is a real hardship to have to leave a terminal and then come back in, especially when having short times on connecting flights.  People have been kind to let me go to the head of a security line, but we still had to go through the search again.  While transferring in Denver one time, I almost missed my connecting flight.  My service dog will NOT defecate indoors.  She would never use that indoor facility as she has been trained not to go indoors.  Please have at least one outdoor area per terminal for service dogs.  Their service is invaluable to us owners.  With appreciation.
Kizzen N. Laki & Peggy Sue

Title: Clenric Guy Hancock
Comment:
In support of the International Association of Assistance Dog Partners, I agree that a dog relief area should be required at each terminal and within the secure zone so that passengers do not have to travel far, or be re-screened by security after using the dog relief area.

C. Guy Hancock, DVM, MEd

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I just returned from a round trip flight from San Jose, CA to Tampa, Fl.  Long flight with a stop and change planes in Denver. There was not enough time to take me dog out of the airport and there was no relief area.  An airline attendant offered to take Carter out on the tarmac but it is not that easy to get him to follow someone elses commands.  I needed to take him but was not allowed.  It is stressful for all traveling as well as the dog when there is limited time and have carryon luggage to deal with.  I guess I was under the impression this had already passed but have since found that not the case.  Also important is a realistic relief area.  Dogs prefer lawn and most times will Not go on cement.  It is not healthy to hold things back and can cause many other problems which ultimately can effect a handler.  Please genuinely help get this passed as anyone with a disabliity already suffers  and can use the help of making things easier and better for the dog as well.  THANK YOU!

Title: Tandy C. Thompson
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: Just as relief stations (aka bathrooms) are provided for humans, human health care assistants sometimes known as canines need to have an opportunity to relieve themselves in appropriate locations.  Please consider this to be a need for those of us who require an this relatively inexpensive medical assistant.  As my mobility is limited traveling great distance to facilitate my service dog's needs challenges my ability to travel.  Currently, I travel more by car because of this very reason.

Title: Debbie Cripps
Submitter Representative: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners and Paws With a Cause
Comment:
I believe that there should be in smaller airports one potty area for service dogs for every two terminals. Larger airports should have one for every terminal. I think the area should be in the secure area between the security area and the area where we get on the planes. 

Thank You for taking up such an important issue.

Title: Carol Presunka
Comment: Please consider having a canine rest area inside the sterile areas of the airport, inside security.  Our assistance dog is for our son who is both physically and developmentally disabled.  Boarding and deplaning are stressful enough without having to worry about how long it will take us to toilet our service dog and catch a connecting flight.  Having it within the scure area of the airport would make it so much easier on us.

Title: Anne Curran
Comment:
I have been traveling with service dogs for over 191/2 years. My dog is a medical response canine who also braces. Although my dogs are well trained and have traveled well from coast to coast, because of my disability I become exhausted having to leave the terminal to take care of the dogs needs. I often have to make a trip an overnight because I cannot have too many stops where I have to take my dog out..... the distance is too great and the time going through security is awful. Please designate a number of areas within the terminal and within the secured areas for use. It would make an incredible difference in my being able to travel out of Montana and to see my daughter in Ga. and family in Boston.

I am a member of IAADP and my dogs have always been certified.
Thank you 
Anne Curran

Title: Charles G. Parkin
Comment:
As a 100% service-disabled veteran and former FAM I can see both sides of the issue.

In the interest of airport security I can definitely understand TSA's desire to allow the service dog team to exit the sterile area via an access door and would prefer they exit the secure area of the airport all together…but this does pose a problem when there is limited time between connecting flights or the handler is confined to a chair.

Here is a though!  Cruise ships routinely accommodate service dogs by providing wooden boxes filled with sand, artificial grass that drains urine, litter, etc.  For flights it would be the responsibility of the service dog team to train their dogs to use these boxes, and for the airport to provide a small ventilate room for the service dogs to do their business in.  I have seen many “SMOKING” areas within the sterile areas to accommodate an addiction…why not mandate a room for service dogs to relieve themselves in under the ADA?  

This way the sterile area can be kept intact and the service dog teams are accommodated.  Just like a human with a full bladder, a service dog with a full bladder is not at 100% which could impact the safety of the team.

Title: Irma G. Schwartz
Comment:
I have flown with my service dog 3 times so far this year, each of which required a layover between flights.  Coupled with the additional time required to get through security, this is a long time for a dog to not be able to relieve itself.  Although I was told I could take the dog out past security to the front of the terminal, it meant my navigating an unfamiliar airport through heavy pedestrian traffic, finding my way back & going through security again.  I was so fearful of not getting back in time through security, we opted not to struggle to do so.  It would be so helpful to have a designated area of some sort as a relief area, and
personnel who knew where it was as well.  Most of the airport personnel I asked didn't know where outside of security to send me.

Title: Holly S. Koester
Comment: As a Service Dog Owner, it would really be much easier and less worrisome to take my SD with me when I fly if I knew I would be able to poddie my Service Dog with out having to go outside security.  Thank you for your kind concideration.

Title: Lynn Wheaton Overtree
Comment:
I have a hearing dog. I appreciate your efforts to provide relief areas for him within the sterile zone of the airport. To have to leave and come back through security between flights can be cause to miss a connection. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Lynn Overtree

Title: Carin Smith
Comment:
The following are my comments regarding the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) about Service Animal Relief Areas at Airports.
Disabled passengers could miss connecting flights due to the time and distance involved if a service animal relief area is located outside the sterile area of the terminal.  
Time and distance to a relief area located outside the sterile area could result in assistance dog teams missing their flight.
The vast majority of assistance dog teams who are on the way to the gate or connecting with another plane or after landing at their destination before they get their luggage would be best served by a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal. The DOT should require airports to install a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal.
Sincerely,

Dr. Carin Smith
Smith Veterinary Consulting

Title: Mari Bull
Comment: I think it is very important to have a service animal relief area within EACH terminal in the sterile area.  I also think it is quite important to have a service animal relief area outside the sterile area.  A disabled person might have to travel some distance/time by public transportation to reach the airport and need to let the animal relieve itself before attending to tickets and  going through security.  It is not uncommon to arrive a couple of hours early for long flights nowadays, so it is reasonable to assume the animal might have to relieve itself again after being at the airport a couple of hours and before being on the plane for several more hours.

Title: Ann M. Hamachek
Comment:
I have had to take my dog  outside to toilet more than a few times in different airports-this is a huge deal.  First you need to find the area and wheel out there as fast as you can bercause not only do you have to go far away from the building( and it is a strange place, so the dog takes time finding just the right spot).  Than you must wait in line again to get physically checked and try and make the flight.  Whew!!
And God help you if your flighjt is delayed and you only have minutes between weather fronts for the plane to get out.

Title: Dennis Michael Chinnock
Comment:
I am a disabled veteran with a service dog that assists me with hearing, vision and mobility. My dog is a large Standard Poodle. I will be traveling by air in June 2012 with my dog for the first time. The trip is Boston, MA to Denver, CO to Sacramento, CA. The change of planes in Denver is 45 minutes. I am greatly concerned that my service dog will need relief in Denver and that a location within the 'Sterile' area will not be available. I worry because the Sacramento airport has its pet relief are in an 'Unsterile' area. I do not move very fast and need the assistance of the service animal. I hope a requirement is introduced for airports and train stations. I will be taking AmTrack Sacramento, CA to Boston, MA and am concerned that the train will not wait for my dog to relieve himself at unmanned stations along the route. I risk being left behind.

Please give these needs some serious thought. I am not trying to be difficult, merely seeking equitable access to places I use to travel prior to my disabilities.

Title: Walter Preston Black
Comment:
As a frequent traveler with service dogs, it is extremely difficult if there is no adequate animal relief area inside the "sterile area", for it is not possible to go outside, find a relief area and then return thru security again.  That would take an hour at the best of times, but often 90 minutes or more, plus the difficulty wheelchair examinations.

It is also critical to have relief areas clearly marked outside the secure area where an animal can get the relief it needs.

Title: Dr. Nancie Spector
Comment: I am writing in regard to relief areas for service dogs at airports. I strongly urge all airports to contain relief areas within the security areas so that animals and their disabled handlers can quickly locate a relief area while traveling. There should be a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal so that security does not be to be cleared again. Thank you.

Title: Elsebeth S.
Comment:
Please change the law to require a disabled service animal area in the "sterile" area of airports; especially large ones.  It can be very difficult, if not impossible, to change planes in airports with multiple terminals.  I have almost missed connections more than once due to having to exit the airport complex and then go through the TSA screening again.  In Atlanta (where the area is the sidewalk!), it took me almost two hours once.

Truly, the lack of a place where our service dogs can relieve themselves in the sterile area of multiple terminal airports is TANTAMOUNT TO HAVING NO DISABLED SERVICE ANIMAL AREA AT ALL!

Thank you very much for continuing your efforts for accessibility on our behalf.  You are a lifesaver and I am very grateful to each and every time I travel anywhere (mostly to out of town doctors).

Sincerely, Elsebeth S Stryker and Hearing DOg "Tigger"

Title: Joseph Rocco Marchi
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) issued new guidelines in May 2011 that clarify the TSA has no objection to airports installing a service animal relief area outdoors, in the sterile area, for the benefit of passengers with disabilities who travel with assistance dogs.
  Among all the people who are disabled and a having a service dog.We need a sterile area for our dogs,ASAP.They provide a great service, and to fly you can't expect them to hold themselves  because your not providing them an area to do there business.
     Please provide this for the sake of the dogs so they can do there job by focusing on there owner.
                                                 Thank You.
                                                 Joe R Marchi

Title: Mark Ruefenacht
Comment:
The need for service animal relieving areas within the sterile area for each terminal is imperative.  As a frequent (weekly) traveler I am continually faced with the challenge of relieving my service dog between connecting flights or after entering a sterile area and then encountering a significantly delayed departure.  Presently, in both cases, I must not only leave the sterile area but typically traverse a significant distance to find an appropriate relieving area.

Visually impaired persons not only have the challenge of being re-screened to enter a sterile area, after relieving, but are significantly challenged to even find an appropriate relieving area.

Airline, airport, and TSA personnel are rarely willing to assist me in finding an appropriate relieving area or in expediting my screening after leaving a sterile area and then reentering.  It is virtually impossible to leave a sterile area, find an appropriate relieving area, and be re-screened between connecting flights.

Coast-to-coast trips, with a connection, currently require my service dog to "hold" their relieving for 12+ hours due to screening times, being to the gate an hour before boarding, connections, and disembarking an aircraft.

Thank you for your consideration.

Mark Ruefenacht
President & Service Dog User
Dogs4Diabetics, Inc.

Title: Marianne Leclerc
Comment:
I am a Deaf person using a Hearing Assistance /Service Dog and I wanted to comment on the need for relief areas for service dogs at Airports.  I have flown with my hearing dog several times.   When changing planes, it's extremely important that there be a relief area for my service dog, in a location that is outside, well maintained by an employee, and within a close distance of where fliers will be changing planes; it is best this area be within the secure area.  From my own experience, I have noticed I have barely time to make it a relief area and back before time for my plane to leave.  In that time, sometimes I need to also find food for myself to eat and take a restroom break. I have problems with my feet and ankles also so it needs to be a distance that isn't too far. 

My dog and other service dogs are well trained to not potty inside a building.  If they did, it could cause problems with them going in public places.  So it is very important the dog potty in an outside area, preferabble an area which has grass or wood chips as the dogs are usually trained to go in the grass or on a mulched area.  

The place needs to have been kept clean. I am aware that sometimes is hard for individuals who are blind or individuals who have other disabilities to adequately clean up after their dogs.  So the area needs to be checked a few times per day.  

Also important is that airline employees all know where the area is and can help the indivual find the area quickly as time is a factor in not missing a plane.  I also wanted to mention that employees should be trained the proper way to work with individuals accompanied by a service dog (don't send them through the xray machine, don't require the dog to be in a crate etc.)  From my own experience, I noticed many employees were unaware of the laws.

Thank you very much for your time and for letting us give input based on our experience

Title: Melissa R. Simonin
Comment: As a disabled person with a service dog, I urge the DOT to require that airports install a minimum of one service dog relief area per terminal, inside the sterile area.  Going through security is a lengthy and exhausting process.  There are many circumstances in which traveling outside of the sterile area to find a relief area would result in a missed flight.  When you consider the many disabilities which hinder ease of movement and thus require a service dog, you can understand why it is so important to provide easy and timely access to relief areas from every point inside the sterile area.  Not everyone requires a service dog, but for those of us who do, this is vital.

Title: Cheryl Lynn Porter-Avino
Comment:
It is not often that I travel with my assistance dog but I can tell you that it causes great stress.  While traveling between Newark Airport and Dallas/Fort Worth, I was unable to locate a pet relief area in either airport.  I did quite a bit of research before traveling and knew the locations of the pet relief areas but was unable to locate them once in the airport.  Much to my dismay, and my dogs, there was no relief area within the sterile area of the airport.  It is difficult enough to travel with a service dog and without a pet relief area within the sterile area it just makes traveling that much harder.  Please consider making it a prerequisite that all airports must have a pet relief area in a more accessible area, which would be inside the security area.  

Thank you.

Title: Linda M. Uriadko
Comment: I fly out of Chicago/Midway airport or O'Hare airport.  Their service areas are outside the terminal area.  I am disabled and in a scooter.  When I have to take my service animal out to relieve himself, it is usually after I go through the security checkpoints.  I almost missed my last flight because having to go through the security checkpoints again.  This is not satisfactory.  You do need to make the relief areas inside the checkpoints, so we can go out there without worrying about missing the flight.

Title: Frank T. Delorenzo
Comment: As I was flying to Texas last year for the first time with my service dog I had a 2 hour lay over and after a 4 hour flight I had to take my service dog outside for a break. After doing so I had to go through security a few times in the time frame. This stressed myself and my service dog. I think that a area in a secure area to provide relief for my service dog. This would help disabled people with service dogs

Title: Shelley Smith
Comment:
I have a service dog and travel 8 - 12 times a year.  A sterile area in the terminal would be really helpful for my dog to have the opportunity for a potty brake.  Especially if one is changing planes or if the flight is delayed.

Thank you for your strong consideration in this matter.

Shelley

Title: Peggy Ann Snyder
Comment:
Personally, I think the rare use of such areas as noted in the article, the dogs should be allowed to relieve themselves at the gate with a screen being provided and a disposable mat.
I have been around these wonderful companions more than once and they are better behaved than 99% of the human passengers.  I'll glady welcome and help anyone with this need at such time.  I am going to guess that most of the gate agents would probably be okay with that too.  And if the gate agent isn't.... get a job that doesn't require such a duty.
Make that word:  gladly, not glady.  Thanks.

Title: Randy Alan Zeyen
Comment: I propose that the DOT require airports to locate a minimum of one (1) Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area. This could be for legally registered service animals only. Traveling is hard enough for this of us with physical limitations, and our trained animals aid us in our travel. A relief area nearby our gate area would help immensily.  Thank you!

Title: Diane Korona
Comment: Please ensure that service animal relief areas are required to be located in the sterile areas of each and every airport terminal.  If passengers with service animals must leave and re-enter security, they are likely to miss connecting flights.

Title: Edward Daniel Afanador
Comment:
Hello,

I ask that you please consider placing service dog relief areas within the sterile area at airports. I recently traveled through Phoenix and had to to leave the sterile area and go back through TSA after my service dog needed to relieve himself. This was very difficult for me and I almost missed my connecting flight to Flagstaff, AZ.

Please contact me if you need any additional information or clarification.

Regards,

Ed Afanador

Title: Daun Lorraine Flynn
Comment:
Service Dog reief areas inside the secure area are necessary OR other arrangements so that we do not miss out connectiing flights.  Just imagine if the Men's and Ladies rooms were outisde
the secure area .. this is NO different.

Thank you,

Daun L. Flynn

Title: Jennifer Moon
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: Please establish regulations that every airport have a service dog relief area INSIDE the sterile area.     Please remember that the reason for service / guide dogs is that their persons are ill and/or injured and/or disabled.    Flying is a huge undertaking for the disabled --- we just don't have the energy of regular folks.    A relief area as close as possible inside the sterile area is so important.    We don't have the stamina to stand in a screening line a second time.    Meanwhile, our dogs may  have been "holding it" for 6 or 7 hours and they've got to get outside ASAP.

Title: Richard L. Heath
Comment:
As a mobility impaired person with a service animal who must remain with me 24/7, it is imperitive that my dog and I have a safe, secure and easy to reach area for us to get to so that she may relieve herself before boarding planes or trains.  Please, in light of the law passed in May 2011, pass this on to airlines, airports and train satations and anyone who may help so that the disabled with service animals will have one less concern and worry removed from our travel angst.

Thank you

Title: Kay
Comment:
Please continue to consider the requirement for an animal relief area in a sterile or secure zone of airport terminals. I am a person with a disability, and this issue has limited my freedom to travel. 
 On our last flight, it was a stressful trip anyway, and my dog was very anxious to get to an area where he could relieve himself safely. We didn't have a connecting flight, but the distance we had to travel would have made it impossible to catch a connection. Thank you for your consideration of this request. Kay Konz

Title: Cheryl Anita Knapp
Comment:
It would be so much appreciated if the relief area was as close as possible and not so difficult to get to or from.  Avoiding going thru security repeatedly with a service animal would be a real time saver of all concerned.

Thank you,

Cheryl A Knapp

Title: Belle Bundy
Comment:
Please prescribe that airlines and/or airports should have a "relief" area for Service Dogs, INSIDE the secure area at airports.  My Service Dog and I have had to go out to the "animal walk" area at several airports.  The area is almost always way outside the airport building, many yards from the building.   We have had to go through security as many as six times during long layovers, then go back through security.  Not only has this been an issue for me, but it has taken up valuable resources, in the way of security personnel.  
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a service dog owner I am urging you to provide service animal relief areas inside the sterile areas of airports accessible from the gate areas of the terminal. On two occasions I have had to exit the secure area in order to allow my dog to toilet and then be re-screened to get back into the gate area of the airport. 

Thank you.

Title: Dennis Michael Cannon
Comment:
As a wheelchair user with a service dog I highly concur wiuth a requirement to provide relief areas within the sterile area of an airport.  One area for each terminal will NOT suffice for many airports.  Some terminals have multiple concourse that require travel through a connecting area.  The minimum number of relief areas should be determined by a maximum travel time from any gate, such as 10 minutes.  For some of us who normally use power wheelchairs, but must rely on manual wheelchairs in the airport, it is often necessary to wait for airport or airline personnel.  This greatly increases the time. The Department should also provide minimum design standards.

I also applaud the Department for referencing the new ADA Guidelines issued by the Access Board.

Title: Kelly
Comment: My service dog has had diarrhea twice inside the airport because he had been asked to hold it so long. On one occasion we were at the gates to the bus transport for terminal changes at Philadelphia Airport.  The attendant would not allow us to slip just outside for my dog to go outside.  It smelled very bad, I was embarrasses needlessly and all the other travelers were inconvenienced as well.

Title: Mem Hughes Seaman
Submitter Representative: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
How delightful to anticipate "A Service Dog Relief Area" within the  sterile area of the specific terminal.
The prospect of having to go outside the security area and be forced to take one's service dog back through the entire security check, facing long queues and indeterminate periods of time is sufficient to curtail my travel.
Missing a flight is commonplace as a consequence of some of the outdated and inconvenient locations of relief areas.
It would truly be a great comfort to reduce the anxiety of travel by introducing relief areas for working dogs that are located close to departure gates.
Thank you for considering this humane approach.  Kind to the disabled and the service dogs.
Sincerely,
Dr. Memory Hughes Seaman

Title: Natalie J. Hunter
Comment:
I respectfully ask that relief areas for service dogs be located in the "sterile" area such that a disabled traveler accompanied by such an animal has sufficient time to utilize the space between connecting flights. 

It is very difficult to exit the "sterile" area, walk the service dog outside the terminal, and return through TSA security when connections are very tight and terminals at major hubs are huge. 

I have traveled with two service dogs under such conditions and find it virtually impossible to leave the "sterile" area for fear of missing my connecting flight.

Thank you for your consideration.

Natalie j Hunter

Title: Carolyn Jean Edwards
Comment:
Please make a place within the secure area where a service
dog can relieve itself.  It would be impossible for me to get my
service dog through to outside and then come through security
in time to catch a connecting flight.  I appreciate your consideration.

Title: Heide Catherina Coppotelli
Comment:
It may be difficult for someone without a disability and service dog to mitigate its effects to understand how huge the problem of not having reasonable access to service animal relief areas can be...  

The distance and time involved in moving between check-in and gates or between gates/terminals while changing flights is already a challenge for me.  My German Shepherd Service Dog, Teddy, makes it possible for me to fly independently.  She handles herself like the pro that she is, and the two of us can handle our challenges with effort and with grace.  

However, not having reasonable access to relief areas within the sterile areas of flight terminals can impose a huge burden on us  in the way of distance and time that make travel even tougher.  In some instances, it can make it impossible to make connections.  

Please, when you next walk through terminals, try to imagine how defeating it would be to have to detour to more distant areas for relief outsize the sterile zones and how further demoralizing it would be to miss connections in the process.

Teddy can't use the restrooms like you can.  And it is horrible to put her through situations in which she can barely hold her urine after doing her job for me faithfully and for long hours. 

It isn't a good deal we're asking for, just simple assistance in making our own way fairly and with dignity.

Thank you.

Title: April B. Havey
Comment: A relief area should be within the check in area. It is ridiculous to expect a handler to navigate out to the area which takes 30 minutes. Checking through the security takes a longer time because of the dog's equipment and, therefore, adds more time to the equation. Lay overs are usually only a half hour long anyhow, giving you enough time to locate the gate and use the restroom yourself. Why should the dog have to suffer? To avoid unnecessary clean ups, there should be 1 relief area within the security zone. I have had to become very creative in having my dog just relieve in the human bathroom just because I want to avoid the public's response to an embarrassing accident or there wasn't enough time to leave and come back in. The relief area outside the check point is ok for pets and things once they have been picked up, they would have to go, but there wouldn't be as much walking since they would be outside the check point. I will be traveling through the Dover airport in February but will not be able to use the relief area because my flight connects too quickly. A relief area within the safe zone should be allowed to assist those with service animals.

Title: Rick
Comment:
I am a disabled veteran with a service dog who would be very grateful if airports had a canine relief area in the sterile zone. I've been very lucky so far; the only time my dog "Raskin" had to "get busy" on her first cross country flight was at Salt Lake City Airport where a relief area is provided. I would like to thank the DOT (and any others involved), for making this service a possibility in the future...
In Kindness,
Rick Adair

Title: Joan
Comment:
I strongly advocate that at least one relief area be provided for passengers traveling with service dogs WITHIN the sterile area of every airport terminal.  With the size and complexity of many airports it is extremely difficult for disabled folks to get outside of the sterile area to let their dogs relieve themselves without missing connections.  Abled bodied people have enough trouble making connections and navigating today's airports, much less someone with a disability.
These dogs are WORKING dogs and their health and comfort is vital to their disabled owners.  PLEASE.....outdoor relief areas within the sterile area of every airport!  Thank you.

Title: Pamela G. Thompson
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Parners
Comment: See attached file(s)   I have serious concerns  about having relief areas for our service dogs only available outside of sterile areas at airports.  When traveling with a service dog who maybe inexperienced or when needed to connect to another flight having to travel such a long distance to a relief area will cause us to miss our connecting flight.  Service dogs although well trained are still dogs, who need certain considerations especially when owned by a disabled person who is already challenged in being able to connect to flights. I have a difficult time being able to travel since it takes som much extra time in getting wheelchairs and finding out where everything is located.  Please don't add to our difficulty by further stressing our k9 parenters who are in need of relief by placeing the relief ar such distnaces. Please read my attached document for greater detail.

Title: Betty E. Birt
Comment: HAVE RECENTLY TRAVELLED WITH MY SERVICE DOG FROM HALIFAX-TORONTO TO TAMPA...IT WAS VERY INCONVENIANT  TRYING TO RELIEVE MY DOG....MY HUSBAND HAD TO TAKE HIM OUTSIDE FOR ME BECAUSE THE WALK WAS JUST TOO FAR FOR A DISABLED PERSON....THE RELIEF AREA SHOULD BE IN THE SECURE AREA SO NOT AS MUCH WALKING IS NEEDED.....I COULD NOT HAVE DONE THIS WITHOUT MY HUSBANDS HELP...PLEASE CONSIDER THAT  SERVICE DOGS ARE OWNED BY DISABLED PEOPLE SO AN AREA SHOULD BE AVAILABLE CLOSER TO THE CONNECTING FLIGHT AREAS

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

As a person who travels frequently with an Assistance Dog, it is terribly important that an appropriate area, within the "sterile" zone at airports, be available for my dog to relieve himself. Please consider the incredible extra time and effort that it takes for us to travel outside the airport, between connections, in order to accomplish this, and then to have to return and make our way through security. 

My dog is very well behaved, and he is well trained, but for his comfort and the health of all persons traveling within airports, a designated area is required for pet relief.

Thank you so much for your time and consideration!

Title: James D. Birt
Comment: THERE SHOULD BE RELIEF AREAS FOR SERVICE ANIMALS AT EVERY TERMINAL AND THEY SHOULD BE LOCATED INSIDE THE STERILE AREAS..IF NECESSARY  AN AIRPORT STAFF PERSON SHOULD BE AVAILABLE TO HELP THE PAIR TO THE RELIEF AREA..THIS SHOULD BE CONSIDERED STANDARD PROCEDURES AT ALL AIRPORTS

Title: Teresa Kofski
Comment: As a disabled person with a assistance dog, I fully support the IAADP,  and ask the DOT to require a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile area of each terminal so that time and distance do not impose a hardship on disabled passengers traveling with assistance dogs. I also ask that the DOT post signs to direct disabled passengers to these areas and mark these areas clearly on maps. This issue seriously impacts assistance dog teams, as dogs are trained NOT to toliet inside, and when traveling their is often not enough time to take them all the way out of the sterile area, and so we are forced to try and get our dogs to toliet inside, which goes against all their training. This completely stresses both them and us, and is usually useless anyways; most well-trained dogs refuse.

Title: Arnie Thomas Pike
Comment: I find it dificalt to take my service dog outside to relive her selh so inside would be easier.

Title: Dina Coster Kaplan
Comment:
I am the parent of a disabled teen with a service dog.  We support having a "relief area" at all terminals inside the sterile area.
I have trouble toileting my son on an airplane because of the size of the restrooms and often have to race to a bathroom on the ground for him and then race a great distance to take the dog outside the terminal so she can relieve herself.  This has made me very nervous on several occasions that the dog might not be able to hold it until we get outside.  Also, there have been times when our flight was delayed several hours and we had to be escorted to a place in the sterile area but outside where the dog could relieve herself.  That was a big problem with security! It would be so much better if there were designated relief areas that were accessible inside the sterile area in each terminal.  Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
It has come to my attention that the Department of Transportation is taking comments regarding the installation of dog relief areas within airports to help the disabled who travel with an assistance dog.

This is something that is going to be extremely helpful to the disabled that are traveling with their assistance dog.

As a frequent airline traveler I have found it extremely difficult to travel with my assistance dog as a result of not having adequate relief areas at the airport for my assistance dog.

This difficulty of traveling occurs both before and after a long flight when traveling with my assistance dog and also when attempting to get to a connecting flight which is almost impossible to do.

It is imperative that appropriate dog relief areas be placed inside the "sterile area" within each airline terminal to allow disabled travelers the access we need.  These installations are long overdue.

Thank-you for considering my comments and hopefully ensuring that the disabled have appropriate access to travel just like the rest of the population.

Title: Mark
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
Please provide relief areas for Service Dogs in Airports
 I am a Service Dog Team Member who flys frequently.

Often I have to exit security to enable my dog to potty.
Sometimes at airports it is necessary to run across a busy street that is not crossed by pedestrians to enable the dog to find a spot of ground to potty.  
    Please help.    I support the IAADP position on portty areas in airport terminals

  Thank you   Mark Glasser

Title: Leah Kathryn Brooks
Comment:
I have a black lab service dog and we fly several times a year. I think that having a place for service dogs to relieve themselves that is inside the sterile area at an airport would be optimal. We often fly out early in the morning...earlier than she would normally be asked to eliminate...and consequently we have to arrive extra extra early so that we have sufficient time to coax her to 'go'. It would save time if there was a place inside the sterile area to do this. 

Also, I rarely take connecting flights and often pay more for non-connecting flights because taking my dog back through security in order to 'go' is too difficult for me.

Thanks for taking the time to listen!

Title: Dana D. Handbury
Comment:
I am a member of IAADP (International Association of Assistance Dog Partners)

I am also the facilitator of a Skilled Companion Team utilizing an assistance dog for my son, and we travel/fly frequently.

I want to express my opinion that the DOT should require airports to install a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal and that it should be located inside the sterile area.  This is vital on connecting flights where time is of a minimum for our service dog to relieve herself.  This occurs each time we connect because of the extra time it already takes to transport my son, get him to an accessible bathroom, and make our connection.

Thank you.
Dana Handbury

Title: Kari Ann Owen
Comment:
I have been a service dog partner since 1998.

My pain is almost as acute as then, when it was excruciating.

Please allow common sense to prevail; we are all mammals.

May you be blessed with all your needs,
Sincerely,
Kari Ann Owen

Title: Stephanie Kovach Fama
Comment: I just want to voice my opinion that I think it is very important for animal relief areas to be inside the sterile zone.  Trekking through security is hard enough for individuals without disabilities, and a dog, so it can only be seen as a hinderance if you don't put a relief area in each terminal, within the sterile zone.  Please don't make life any more difficult for those with disabilities.

Title: Christina Hyosun Kimm
Comment: I travel quite frequently using air transportation to present at various seminars and training workshops. I always hurry and wheel around to find a place where my assistance dog can be released, which is not very easy to do. Many airport do not have any lawn area neither the pet relief area. One time when the plane was delayed due to the weather, I had to go out twice and went through hard security checks every time. I travel alone with my assistance dog, going through the security is not easy although many TSA people are trying to be helpful. If the assistance dog relief area is inside of the secure area, it would be great and helpful to relief my anxiety from my travel. Thanks for the consideration, Christina

Title: Dennis Y. Okada
Comment: Yes, relief areas for service dogs are a must!

Title: Ellen Tutsch-Gregos
Comment: My husband is in a wheelchair due to a back injury and can not walk, and his service dog helps immensely to help pull him through airports when we travel.  The security check points always take much longer for him and his service dog and when we are in the secure area, it is always a struggle to make it to the plane on time.  When we have connecting flights, we stay in the secure area so as not to have to endure the long process of going outside and back through another time consuming security check.  But my husbands service dog needs an opportunity to do her business....and often we are put into a dilemna of where and how we can have her do her business.  Having a relief area for service dogs is a must at airports, especially in the secure areas....and I hope that you will push this effort forward, these amazing dogs who help the disabled, blind and deaf are in need of this when helping their partners travel! Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Ruth Elaine Lake
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule change.  I am a full time wheelchair user who also uses the services of a mobility assistance dog to help mitigate my disability.

When traveling by air, it is always difficult to make my connecting flights as I have to wait until the entire plane has disembarked before they get someone to bring me an aislechair and escort me off the plane to my wheelchair which hopefully someone has brought up from the cargo hold.  My service dog has been trained to hold his eliminations when we are traveling but sometimes a trip across the country takes us 12 hours or longer and my service dog needs to eliminate before we reach our destination and get to a place where he can do his buisiness.  Having a relief area that is located within the sterile area of an airport is of great importance to those of us who travel with a service dog.

If our service dogs need to use the relief area and it is not located within the sterile area, it can add almost 90 minutes to the amount of time it would take to get to and use the relief area and go back through the security area to get to our connecting flight.  Most of the time we do not have an extra 90 minutes to spend going outside of the airport, let our dogs relieve themselves, go back through the security line and get to the gate to board our flight.  It is super important that all airports have at least one SD relife area located within that sterile area so that we have the time to let our dogs potty and still get to our connecting flight, especially when you stop to remember that for most of us, we have to wait close to an hour after our plane lands just so we can use a restroom.  I have skipped using a restroom myself just so I have enough time to potty my SD and I can't use the restroom onboard a plane so for me it is either I wait or my SD waits if there is no relief area for him within that sterile area.

Thank you for allowing me to comment on this.

Title: Laura Meyers
Comment:
While I am encouraged by the DOT efforts, the effects have so far been less than helpful.  I have been with a service dog for nine years, and fly often for business.  I find I must choose between booking direct flights that may be prohibitively expensive or do not exist and booking a layover of more than two hours so I have time to allow my dog to relieve herself and then re-enter the sterile area.  Such a lengthening of my trip comes at a great physical burden.

For the legislation to be effective:
1)	Relief areas must be outdoors, within sterile areas.  The physical strain as well as the time shortage of an extra trip through security exacerbates the difficulties of travel.  Most service dogs are trained to never relieve themselves indoors, and to contradict that training by an indoor relief area is counterproductive.

2)	Relief areas should be a minimum of one per terminal, reachable by wheelchair within a maximum of 10 minutes from each gate, 5 being preferable.  Disabled persons may be unable to cover distances with any speed, and may have to wait for other passengers to disembark or airport assistance personnel to arrive before deplaning.  I have been to airports that have a service animal relief area within a sterile area of the airport, but it is in another terminal requiring me to travel for 20+ minutes by several methods to reach it or requires that I exit security to change terminals.  At my final destination, I have been forced to choose between claiming my baggage or tending to my dog, only to find that my baggage has been removed by the time I arrive.

3)	The DOT should provide minimum guidelines for design and maintenance, but allow for flexibility to accommodate climate, material innovations, etc.

4)	Such areas should be adequately marked, identified on the airport website, and well publicized to staff.  Allowing a disabled person to feel empowered with their travel plans is a great asset and removes much of the stress that traveling produces.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
See attached file for the full comment from a frequent domestic and international traveller with disabilities who uses a mobility service dog.

Summary of Comment:

1. Service dog relief areas need to be placed within the sterile areas of airports.  Relief areas outside the sterile area are practically useless to travellers, especially those with connections.

2. Relief areas in the sterile area should not be more distant than a 10-15 minute walk from all gates.

3. The relief area does not need to be huge, but it must be protected from adverse weather and temperature conditions.  It could be grass, faux grass, or mulch.

4. If pets are allowed to use the same area, special considerations need to be taken, such as giving priority use to service dogs (a front-of-the-line pass), a time limit on how long a dog can be using the area, and a prohibition against playtime taking place in the area.  Pet or service dog, only one dog must be allowed at a time for safety's sake.

5. The service dog relief areas should be clearly marked on maps, Web sites, and have some signage (including Braille signage) in the airports.

6. The relief areas could be paid for (construction and/or maintanence) by sponsor corporations/businesses in a deal worked out with each individual airport.

7. When the new rule is implemented, there needs to be oversight to ensure the relief areas are constructed and finished on time, unlike what happened with the previous rule about airports having a relief area anywhere on site.

Title: Jennifer
Fraser Sime
Comment:
I am submitting a comment on the proposal regarding "relief areas" for service animals in airports.  

Please consider locating a relief area inside the "sterile area" of the terminals, since it is very difficult to get outside of that area, visit the relief area with my dog, and then have to go back through the whole security screening process again.  It's tough enough going through all that hassle to begin with.  There is seldom time between flights to accommodate this process, since I need assistance with wheelchair, etc..

Thank you for considering my comment - I urge you to try to "walk a mile in my shoes" and try to understand my concerns.

Title: Jerriann Skinner
Comment:
It is imperative that the relief area for service animals be located INSIDE the TSA screening area and as close to the boarding area as possible.  
Flights often have short lay overs that are made even shorter due to delays because of mechanical and weather issues.  Service animals and their users need to be able to get their dogs out, let them relieve themselves and reboard without the hassle and time necessary to go through the TSA screening process again. 
 I have a physical disability and if the relief area is outside the TSA "sterile area" I would probably miss my flight and this would produce an undue hardship on myself and others similiarly situated who are already on reduced or fixed incomes. 
Please make sure the releaf areas are convenient to our service animals and not an undue hardship on us.  Thank you.  
Jerriann Skinner

Title: Dennis Lawrence Robertson
Comment:
I would like to see at least one service animal relief area at each airport terminal within the sterile area and at a distance of no more than twenty minutes from a loading gate. For security an escort or guard should accompany the disabled user and dog to the area and back to the gate area. 120 days to implement this facility after approval is quick but a workable time frame I beliieve. This ruling should apply to all airports both local and foreign, especially the more popular destinations such as Canada. 
Thank you

Title: Trina Denise Aurin
Comment: I have a 7 year old son who has a service dog. I know a close sterile environment for our dog to use to relieve himself in the terminal would be much easier then leaving the terminal to find a spot of ground so he can go - having a child with special needs who probably has to go and use the bathroom himself, then our service dog also has to go andthen we have to leave the terminal and being nervous about missing the flight is stressful. An area for the service dog that is INSIDE the terminal would be easier for a parent with a child and a dog to handle.

Title: Barbara Eves
Comment: Please locate at least one service animal relief area within sterile area of each terminal.  Centrally located so that a person traveling with an assistance dog could make it to the area within 10 minutes would be best.  Relief areas should be located outdoors.

Title: M. Kathryn Miller
Comment: This note is to let you know how important it is to me to have a Service Dog Relief Area within the sterile area of airports.  After a horrible experience of forcing my Service Dog to wait over 20 hours before he had the opportunity to relieve himself, I have stopped flying anywhere.  It is just too much to ask of my Service Dog.  Having to change flights within a limited time period made it impossible for me to take him to the designated areas which were near the parking lots -- far from the sterile area.
