Title: Michelle Lynn Dunlop
Comment: I feel that a service dog relief area should be standard in all airports inside the starile area as people with disabilities do not have the energy to walk great distances and if worried about security than a staff member should be abailable to help the pair go to the relief area.

Title: Martha Holley Noyes
Comment:
re: assistance dog relief area in airport

It is good that there are assistance dog relief areas, but it is difficult to get to them and back through the security check both because of the time it takes and because of the difficulty of physically managing the trek to the relief area and back.

It would be extremely helpful if there were a relief area for assistance dogs within the "sterile area."

Title: Elizabeth Ann Paolero
Organization Name: Canine Companions for Independence, service dog owner
Comment: Having traveled by plane several times with my service dog, I have found first hand that not having a service animal relief area inside the security checkpoints makes it very difficult for my dog and I. It takes so long and wears me out to go all the way through the checkpoints and back in again, that I actually dread it. I know the relief areas are only for a few of us with  pet passengers, but they are  SO APPRECIATED! Thank you.

Title: Richard Welsh
Comment: It would be very helpful to have a last minute place for my dog to relieve himself if needed. Not only for his confort and health but for the calmness of the animal while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This is in regards to the proposed regulations for service animal relief areas in airports. I am a service dog handler, and I highly urge you to require a minimum of one outdoor service animal relief area per terminal in the sterile area between security checkpoints and gates. 

Due to time constraints and also physical limitations, forcing service dog handlers to take their dogs outside the secure area to relieve themselves creates many difficulties - missed flights, added stress, and often added difficulty or increased symptoms relating to the handler's disability. It is for this reason I am requesting a minimum standard of one relief area per terminal within the sterile area.

Also, I urge you to require that these areas be outdoors in a secure, fenced area, or on another suitable surface, such as cedar chips. Our dogs are trained to relieve themselves on command, but also to never relieve themselves indoors. With the added stress on both dog and handler that traveling provides, asking a service dog to relieve itself indoors on a typical floor surface is difficult at best, impossible at worst.

We rely on our service animals to keep us safe and enable us to travel independently. Please help them help us by providing nearby, appropriate areas for the animal's necessary relief. Thank you.

Title: Eileen Fisher
Comment:
I agree that service dogs need an area inside security to relieve themselves.  Getting through security with a wheelchair is a long process, and having to do it multiple times in a single trip is unreasonable, and could be impossible on a short layover.  SeaTac had an area inside security, but was more or less a cat litter box, and not sufficient for an 80 pound lab.  Cruise ships have a 4x4 box that is sufficient for any size dog.  Even if it was an escorted trip outside to a 4x4 box on the tarmac, it would be a good relief option for both the dog and the handler.
I recently travelled with my husband and his dog, and I took the dog out in Dallas, but it was outside security and outside the airport.  My husband would not have been able to do it on his own, and then get back through security with the dog to get to the next flight.
Please consider a viable option inside security, and inside each terminal for the large airports.
Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This is in regards to the proposed regulations for service animal relief areas in airports. I am a service dog handler, and I highly urge you to require a minimum of one outdoor service animal relief area per terminal in the sterile area between security checkpoints and gates. 

Due to time constraints and also physical limitations, forcing service dog handlers to take their dogs outside the secure area to relieve themselves creates many difficulties - missed flights, added stress, and often added difficulty or increased symptoms relating to the handler's disability. It is for this reason I am requesting a minimum standard of one relief area per terminal within the sterile area.

Also, I urge you to require that these areas be outdoors in a secure, fenced area, or on another suitable surface, such as cedar chips. Our dogs are trained to relieve themselves on command, but also to never relieve themselves indoors. With the added stress on both dog and handler that traveling provides, asking a service dog to relieve itself indoors on a typical floor surface is difficult at best, impossible at worst.

We rely on our service animals to keep us safe and enable us to travel independently. Please help them help us by providing nearby, appropriate areas for the animal's necessary relief. Thank you.

Title: Jill Exposito
Comment: Please see comment in Word document.  Thank you.

Title: Marty Reynolds
Comment:
Please require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.  Service dogs have to hold their urine a lot longer than people do on a airline flight. Think about it, usually the first thing one wants to do after leaving a plane is to go to the bathroom.  Well, our dogs have to be able to eliminate so that they do not get ill.  It is complicated enough to go through necessary, but needed airport check systems.  But to have to try to rush outside of a sterile area for a dog to relieve itself presents a hardship on the disablility team.  If at the end of a trip, a disabled team has to get to a relief area as soon as possible.  If waiting for a plane and there is a delay or long wait, the team could miss their plane if a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal is outside the steril area.  We need your help to consider our needs on this necessary legislation.
  Also, many dogs won't go unless grass is provided or some dirt with bushes. Please help us.

Title: Dianne Strasser
Comment: I strongly urge the DOT to require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.

Title: James Reynolds
Comment:
Please provide a minimum of one relief area in each "sterile area" of  each airport terminal.  Everyone knows the long lines that occur when going into a "sterile area."  A disabled person with their service dog has a hard time even initially waiting in these lines.  Once, inside a sterile area, a dog might get an upset stomach and need to go into a relief area quickly.  Grass should be grown if possible in these relief areas.  Or even artificial turf.
After patiently waiting during a long trip, a dog, just like people, need to be able to get to a relief area quickly so they don't get cramps.  They can't go during the flight like people can. Please don't make our disabled teams suffer or their wonderful service dogs.  Please provide a minimum of one relief area in each "sterile area" of each airport terminal. Thank you, Jim

Title: Jeremiah Arbogast
Comment:
location of service animal relief areas an airport should be within the "safe zone" of not having to go out the security zone to provide relief of your service animal. 

I personally have almost missed flights, could not provide relief for my service dog because of the transfer times being so close and not being able to get out of secure zone and then going back into it and then trying to get to gate.

With all this said it makes it more difficult when your also in a wheelchair. I ask you give sincere consideration into this matter to ease the individuals with disabilities who require service animals a lot easier for their travel.

Title: Linda Zelson
Comment:
Our community cares about this issue...
Please require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.
        I am concerned that a number of disabled passengers could miss connecting flights due to the time and distance involved if a service animal relief area is located outside the sterile area of the terminal.  After a long trip to a relief area, the disabled passenger would have to go through a screening at the TSA security checkpoint before he or she is allowed to return to the gate area with a guide, hearing or service dog. 
        The service animal relief area should be located nearby to ensure time and distance are not barriers for disabled passengers. This could also result in assistance dog teams missing their flight. An assistance dog can suddenly have a digestive upset and/or become stressed by severe air turbulence or a thunderstorm during the flight and upon landing, urgently need a trip to a relief area so as to prevent "an accident" and to alleviate cramps.  Young or elderly assistance dogs and those on their first flight will need to eliminate more often than assistance dogs in their prime who are seasoned travelers. 
       The majority of assistance dog teams who are on the way to the gate or connecting with another plane or after landing at their destination before they get their luggage would be best served by a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal.
        We ask airports that only have one service animal relief area for two or more terminals, believing there is no need for more since that one is rarely used, to take a second look at this problematic situation for disabled passengers. 
        Thank you for your atttention to this matter.
Sincerely,
Linda Zelson

Title: James Anthony Selner
Comment: I am a 100% disabled Vietnam Vet with a service animal who recently flew from CA to MD with my service animal.  We flew from Oakland Intl. Airport, which has fairly accessible relief areas for service animals.  However, in the past we've flown through airports like Mpls/St. Paul where a plane change was necessary and it was impossible for my service animal to get to a relief station, reclear TSA and make the connecting flight.  That day my service animal went 12 hours without relieving herself, and frankly I don't know how she did it.  There seem to be more and more disabled passengers with service animals flying every year, and it simply isn't possible to provide relief for these animals if it's necessary to go back outside the TSA clearance area to do so.  Supporting the establishment of standard relief stations within the TSA clearance area would do so much to insure the continued use of air travel for those of us with service animals.

Title: Marissa Culp
Comment:
A few months ago I had to travel from Portland, OR with a six hour layover in Seattle, WA. At the Portland Airport we could not find the animal relief center even with a map. My dog went outside before we entered the security check, around 9:30 in the morning. When we got to Seattle there was only one relief area and it was indoors, tiled, and smelled of disinfectant. (It looks exactly like the one in your photos.) My dog looked up at me as if saying, "There's no dirt, no grass. What do you want me to do here?" He's been trained not to go indoors, and he wouldn't. He ended up "holding it" until we got to Honolulu. This means he did not pee for about 13 hours. 

Animals need a place where they are comfortable relieving themselves and as their people, we need to have access to those places. In Seattle, for example, there is one relief area for (I believe) five terminals. If you have to take the tram to get to your terminal, once you do your animal has no place to relieve himself.

Title: Steven Chapin Sterry
Comment:
As an ordained Episcopal Church deacon and a volunteer for several service organizations, I travel extensively with my hearing dog, Montera.  Invariably, I am forced to go outside the airport during stopovers in order to find a place for her to go to the bathroom.

When you consider both the weather factor in the Winter and the TSA screening process, it is imperative that all airports be required to provide relief areas for assistance dogs inside TSA sterile areas.  Assistance dog users are currently placed at risk for missing connecting flights because now they must be re-screened as they are required to leave the sterile areas to toilet their dogs at most airports.  Additionally, mobility and sight disabilities put not only the dog at risk but also the disabled person, since most airports where I have landed don't have adequate toilet areas that are even accessible.  

Under the current situation, airports are putting themselves at risk, because their lack of facilities create situations in which there are accidents just waiting to happen.

Title: Abhijit Mehta
Comment:
I support DOT’s proposal to require service dog relief areas.  My mother is blind and travels independently, guided by a service dog, and service dog relief areas are needed inside the sterile area, because otherwise it is impossible for travelers like her to relieve their dogs without missing connecting flights.  TSA has stated that there are no security impediments to providing these reasonable accommodations, and the need for these requirements is dire!  

Disabled travelers should not be forced to leave the sterile area to seek a relief area in response to their service dog’s relief needs.  The basic relief needs of service dogs must be reasonably accommodated for disabled travelers to have reasonable access to air travel just as non-disabled travelers do. 
Please require all airport terminals to have a service animal relief area within the sterile area, as well as outside of the terminal’s sterile area as a reasonable accommodation for connecting travelers with disabilities. 

There is a particular need for this in the world of post- 9/11 security.  Prior to 9/11, airline personnel would routinely escort a guide dog handler outside close to the gates to relieve their dog during layovers. 

Thanks for addressing this serious need. These reasonable accommodation requirements are needed as soon as possible!

Title: Wade R. Kammin
Comment: Regarding the subject of the location of service dog relief areas, I would strongly encourage that they be located in the "sterile" area (beyond the security checkpoints) so as to avoid having to re-screen between connecting flights or, with direct flights, for giving the service animal an additional chance to toilet before deprature in the event of delays. Having traveled this summer with a connection in Chicago/Ohare airport, I had a two and a half hour layover, yet used literally all but three minutes of it locating the distant relief area, then waiting through an incredibly long security line. My canine partner and I made it back to our gate just as they were calling our boarding number.

Title: Assistenthunden Thorman
Comment:
Hi,
 I just want to tell you to place a helping service dog in a noisy terminal or dissociate the owner and the dog gives a devastating impact. To train a service dog is an investment and the disabled person is totally disabled, but the dog's help. A dog that is exposed to stress can become damaged, both mentally and physically and then you can not use the dog for the purpose of educating the dog. A lifeline to the community and a safety for both the owner and the environment. The dogs Help us with handicapped to live like everyone else.
 The individuals who blame the pet allergy is not adequately briefed the asthmatics who may have problems and given that they have asthma who are in public places since they usually are sensitive to such as perfume, deodorant, detergent, and much more for the particles are airborne. And sensitization to dog is allergic to so do not touch the dog or let the dog's saliva to touch you if you have allergies. This has been scientifically researched and the dog saves lives but only if it is not subjected to unnecessary stress.
 Greetings Association of Assistenthunden & Rehabhunden in Sweden.

Title: Desiree Michaels
Comment: Speaking as someone with a physical disability who uses a service dog, yes, the distance between gates and the service animal relief area really does need to be considered.  I can still remember almost missing a flight at Phoenix Airport because I was expected to more or less run to the center of where the X shape of the terminal wings met, make a left, go almost all the way to the end, outside and around a few odds and ends to access what wasn't much more than a small sand box - and then go all the way back - and back through security.  If this is "acceptable", then some sort of arrangement really should be made to make it easier for those of us with mobility issues.  Escorts?  Carrier provided wheelchairs or other transportation?  I'm not sure what would be best, but some sort of faster way to get there and back, along with some sort of priority to get back through the added security trip.

Title: Valerie Marjorie Petta
Comment: I am an amputee and have difficulty with mobility.  I travel with a CCI service dog.  Having an area near to the gate for my dog to relieve itself would be a great help and would greatly reduce the stress of travelling.

Title: Joyce Van Horn
Comment:
I have hearing dog, tained by NEADS.  We travel a lot.  It is very hard to get a change for him to “go” before and after flights.  If I have a long layover I can go out of the TSA screening and let him get relief but then I have to check back in.  Sometimes I do not have time for all that.  Please either get relief areas or allow TSA to take us outside.
My dog is also covered under my care through the Veteran’s Administration.  I am 75 percent disabled.
Thank you

Title: Pauline M. Lamontagne
Comment:
Pine Tree Guide Dog Users (PTGDU) is an organization in the State of Maine representing guide dog handlers, puppy raisers, and others in our efforts to promote civil rights and enhance the quality of life for working guide dog teams.

 

PTGDU supports the Department of Transportation's proposal "to amend (49 CFR) part 27 by inserting a provision that would require airport operators to work with carriers to establish relief areas for service animals that accompany passengers with disabilities departing, connecting, or arriving at U.S. airports."  Adoption of such rules will constitute a crucial reasonable accommodation for air-travelers with disabilities who travel with the assistance of a trained service dog. We further support these relief areas being located inside the sterile area of each terminal.

 

 Relief areas inside of the sterile area (inside of security) are desperately needed because connecting passengers cannot offer their guide dog relief as things are now because of a lack of opportunity to do so inside of the secured zone. 

 

The TSA suggested that airports offer authorized staff to escort a service dog handler outside of restricted areas to relieve their dog .  This could be a low-cost answer that could take effect immediately. 

 

PTGDU also wishes to affirm the efforts that TSA has made in clarifying that there is no security problem with service animal relief areas inside of the secured zone. 

 

PTGDU thanks the DOT for its efforts to help improve airport travel experiences for service dog handlers.

Title: Deborah Ann Wagner
Comment:
Please require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.

The primary reason for this request is that a number of disabled passengers could miss connecting flights due to the time and distance involved if a service animal relief area is located outside the sterile area of the terminal.  After a long trip to a relief area, the disabled passenger would have to go through a screening at the TSA security checkpoint before he or she is allowed to return to the gate area with a guide, hearing or service dog.  

Secondly, young dogs, elderly assistance dogs and those on their first flight will need to eliminate more often than assistance dogs in their prime who are seasoned travelers.  

The vast majority of assistance dog teams who are on the way to the gate or connecting with another plane or after landing at their destination before they get their luggage would be best served by a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal.

Title: Linda Marler
Organization Name: Baylor Health Care System Servce Dog Academy
Comment: Please make it mandatory for each airport in each teminal have a relief aera for Service Dogs in the sterile area. This could make a great deal of difference not only in the disabled person's lfe but in the life of their wonderful Service Dog by allowing the person to toilet them and not have t rush to get back to their plane. Thank you for allowing me to comment.

Title: Patricia Thayer
Comment:
It would be very benificial for airports to have service dog relief areas, that are past security, not outside the front doors.  It is the reason that I no longer fly.  It is way too time comsuming to take my SD back out of the airport to relieve herself and get back to my gate. Its alot of walking for both of us.

It only makes sense to have them. I wouldn't want anyone's SD to have an "accident" when a flight is delayed or they are on a plane too long, due to weather or air traffic and the SD team just doesn't have enough time to make it back out of the airport once they can land.  Delays happen. People with SD's plan and schedule around their and the dog's needs.   

As an example, we are going on a cruise in January.  Instead of going to a major airport (DTW) and flying, getting there in a few hours, we will have to drive.  I cant sit for too long because of my back.  It will take me three days to drive, and cost more money, rather than a few hour flight.

Thank you kindly,
Patricia Thayer

Title: Mark Hartley
Comment: DOT should require airports to install a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal, and where it should be located, inside the sterile area. this is imparative when traveling with a service dog. with my Handicapp. I move to slowly with my wheelchair to go all the way outside the safe zone, and then return, thru all the safty checks. A very slow process for handy capable people!

Title: Kurt E. Potter
Comment: When traveling with my guide dog, I have found that for me to be able to successfully make connecting flights that a relieving area needs to be provided inside the sterile area.  For large airports one area per terminal would be ideal.

Title: Edward Maxwell Hull
Comment:
I travel often with my service dog, Toffee.  One of the major obstacles of the existing Boston Logan Airport service animal relief station is that it is located outside the baggage claim next to a very busy road.  This presents a very uncomfortable area for myself and my service dog.
 
When we travel to other airports, we are often required to leave the sterile area to get outside, then stand in a long lines at security to go through screening again.  For someone with disabilities, this is quite difficult.  

I ask that the DOT should require ALL airports to install a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal and it should be located, inside the sterile area.  

Thank you for allowing my comments on this very important matter.

Title: Jan Feltham
Comment: we need something close to security   as when i last traveled to atlanta delta airlines could not have been more helpful, but it did take three people before i got the correct one and then we had to go down through the bowels of the airport and then by pick up to the side of the runway...i did havesixty minutes but this took 45!

Title: Leigh Anne Novak
Comment:
I urge you to include these provisions for the owners/handlers of service dogs.  I have been in this situation with a service dog in training and had to beg an airport employee to take my dog out a service door - without me - for relieving, as we were delaying due to weather.  This was very unsettling, uncomfortable and not within guidelines at all
Please make these relief areas a requirement in airports! 
Thank you!

Title: Thomas E. Rich
Organization Name: National Education for Assistance Dog Services
Comment:
As a traveler with a Service Dog a special area in a steril secure
area where I can have my dog relieve themselves would be extremely helpful without having to go thru security & screening again - would not want to miss my connections. 

Please give this some thoughtful consideration for disabled travelrrs like myself.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Hello,
As a retired, disabled vet with a service dog, it is extremely important to have relief areas available!  Everyone is aware disabled persons require additional time for flying.  Requiring relief areas in the secure area of airports would not only help ensure the comfort of our service animals, but would keep them perfoming at their best!  Please consider this wonderful idea and opportunity to help the disabled.  
Sincerely,
Steve Grant

Title: Mary Elaine Iliff-Gauck
Comment: As a Owner of a 2 Service Dog Family I have been put in somewhat of the same situation people need to accept our Dogs as Medical equipment and certain things need to be done for our equipment as they do with people that are in wheel chairs, oxygen, tensing units, diabities units,canes,walking sticks, canes for the blind. Our Service Dogs are just as important as the other Medical Equipment. Yes we love our Service Dogs but they save our lives and help us function and go on with our lives as much as we will half to for the rest of our lives. Our health issues is why we have these. Please Help us with our equipment. Thank You Mary E. Iliff-Gauck

Title: John Cieslinski
Organization Name: Top Dog and International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
Airports that only have one service animal relief area for two or more terminals, believing there is no need for more since that one is rarely used, to take a second look at this problematic situation for disabled passengers.   

I have MS and suffer from among other things fatigue 

A close in dog rest area would be necessary for my situation

Thank you for accepting my comments

Title: Ross Evans
Comment:
Hi Folks
you know we all need the rest room an any journey so why not have some area thay our doggy friends can relive themselves
now take a guide dog --he/she is responsible for his charge would it nice to give them a leg up so to speak in the correct area?

Title: Debbie Jean Johnson
Comment: The relief areas for service dogs would be greatly improved by being inside the secure areas. It is very difficult o get in and out of the secure areas in time to catch a flight. Also the bigger airports need to have more than one also due to the distance to get to one. Haveing them well marked ad/or making sure emplyees know where they are wouuld be a great help too.

Title: Constance B. Clark
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Laura Anne Curtis
Comment: To Whom it May Concern:  I have traveled many times by airplane with my service dog, and whenever I have a connecting flight, I know it is going to be an adventure getting Flynn releif.  Because of the time it takes to get through the boarding process plus the length of the flight leading to the layover, skipping a relief period for Flynn is not an option.  Each time since I received Flynn as a service dog, I have called ahead to the airline and announced that I was bringing a service dog well ahead of time, and I have called to confirm within 24 hours of my flight, as well.  Still, my family has time to get everyone through the bathrooms, have a snack/meal, and are standing by ready to board the next flight by the time I can get back to them after finding Flynn relief.  At that time I have neither voided nor eaten myself, and I am exhausted.  Once the airport security brought me out to an unused landing strip for Flynn to find a patch of grass to use.  Other times, we had to go out to the bushes and back through security.  The airline representative even stated to me that she felt like this was a waste of time, she would rather just have Flynn void on the floor at the terminal (I found this distasteful, but even if that were the plan, Flynn never relieves himself inside of his own volition).  Airports should have relief areas for service dogs easily accessible to the terminals (by elevator or non-metal mesh steps for both the sake of the disabled person and the health of the dog's paws).  Please improve this situation, as I have begun to limit the length of air trips because of the issues with finding Flynn relief - and that means I do not have the same access to air flight as an abled person.  Thank you.

Title: Pamela E. Kuttruff
Comment: Having service dog relief areas at the airports sounded like such a good thing.  Unfortunately, for me anyway, it hasn't worked out that well.  Trying to flag someone down to take me and my guide dog to the area is difficult and nobody seems to ask if you need to get there.  If I do find someone to help me and my dog to the service area we have to go out and come back through security again.  Since I have the dog and have a knee replacement we have to be patted down and this takes a while so I have come very close to missing my flight.  Since most service animals are curb trained a grass area outside isn't necessary.  Just a nice place at a curb on concrete works well.  If going out with a chaperone I think that once you have been through security once and someone was watching you all the time that TSA should bend their rule a little.  Its not like the blind lady and her dog met up with a terrorist or someone while outside under the scrutiny of someone leading them in and out.  I ferquently fly long distances and my poor dog has to go without water as she isn't able to get to the area designated and still be able to make the flights.

Title: Dr. Thomas Gaetano Philip Luparello
Organization Name: Redwood Empire Council for the Blind, Greater Bakersfield Council for the Blind, California Council for the Blind
Comment:
As a member of the Redwood Empire Council for the Blind, Greater Bakersfield Council for the Blind and the California Council for the Blind, whose wife is Visually Impaired and relies upon the support of a trained Guide Dog from Guide Dogs for the Blind, I am in complete support of the "DOT" providing a relief area for service dogs at airports in the "sterile" area. That this has not been done before now has created a situation where individuals who rely on these wonderful service animals are hugely inconvenienced and disruption to not only their lives and schedules, but also that of airport personnel including TSA staff. This proposal to so provide a relief area for these trained and certified partners of disabled persons is absolutely needed and I, as a member of the above noted groups whose existence is to raise awareness of the public at large and our elected officials of the needs of disabled persons and effect appropriate accommodations, strongly support this legally required accommodation. To do so would alleviate a great deal of problems, real and potential, for all involved and bring into complaince with the in place laws, including the American's with Disabilities Act (ADA), these service providers to the public in keeping with all security requirements of public transportation and national security concerns. Thank you for your intervention into this overdue situation and if there is/are any further needs or if I may be of any assistance in this matter, please do not hesitate to contact me. I stand ready to assist in any way that I can.

Sincerely,

Dr. Thomas G.P. Luparello, D.C. (Retired)

Title: Denis Richard Lane
Comment: As a veterinarian with 50 years experience of assistance dogs in Uk and from international air travel I can not emphasise enough the importance of th eprovision of suitable 'relief areas' for dogs at airports.

Title: Marianna Davis
Comment: I am writing to request you seriously consider making the assistance dog relief areas in airport terminals inside the "sterile zones".  As a person who travels frequently with my service dog, many times I have almost missed flights b/c of spending too much time trying to locate and get to and back from a relief area.  Other times I have put my dog in undue stress b/c I was unable to get to a relief area in time and still make my connection. It is vital to have these relief areas, they don't have to be large, within the sterile area to enable travelers with disabilities and service dogs the time to relieve their dogs and still make their connections.  Often times passengers with disabilities take longer through tsa screening, forcing them to go out of the sterile area and then go through screening again to take care of a fundamental need for their service animal simply is not right.  Thank you for your time considering this request.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am a mother of a disabled teenager who has a wonderful 
service dog.  We travel several times a year by plane and find it very difficult to bring his dog due to the issues of toileting and the time it takes to get to and from the toileting area.

It would be greatly appreciated if you could address this issue and help make it more easily and efficiently accessible to toilet our service dogs.  Placing the toileting area in the "sterile area" where we don't have undue delays would be most helpful!

Thank you,


Cindy

Title: Monique RoseEllen Morgan
Comment:
Please locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.

I have traveled with my service dog who has desperately needed to relieve himself after a flight.  Time is of the essence.

Thank you.

Monique Morgan (and Jake, service dog)

Title: Kay Joanna Crickmore
Comment: Please do not changethe relief areas for our service dogs. I myself was at the dulles airport a very large airport and had to take my dog out to elief outside and come back through security in my wheel chair and it was longer for me and my service dog to get through that we missed our connecting flight and had to wait 6 more hrs in the airport. This is a very important area to be used for thouse of us with service dogs

Title: Amena Reess
Comment:
I travel with a very small service dog.  She travels well.  I have difficulty walking far and she has very short legs.  We both would greatly appreciate having an area in which she could relieve herself that is close to where we would be boarding the planes. 

When we traveled through the Altanta, GA airport last year (between connecting flights) we were directed to a patch of grass used by the airport security dogs.  This was about 1 mile away from our gate.   

Even with taking the tram it was very taxing for me and the timing was quite stressful, let alone having to drag my self, my luggage, and GiGi through screening all over again.  

Quite an ordeal.  Anything that could alleviate this happening to myself and others would greatly be wonderful!

Thank you for your time.

Title: Laura Luker
Comment: My daughter, her service dog and I have just flown from Lubbock, TX to Boston.  We only had one connecting flight.  There was no way for us to take Laith outside the check in area, and then get back through check-in for our service animal to go to the bathroom.  It usually takes us an extra long time just to get through security as it is, being she is in a wheel chair.  Being that the case, her dog could not have anything to drink since the evening before the flight.  If it had been a longer flight, or more stops, it would have been abusive not to allow him a drink of water.  I appreciate this matter being taken care of.  Unless you are in that situation, you would never understand the impact of this.  Plus, as a side note, most airports are located in the city...When we finally did get to our destination, there was only cement areas, and I know this stressed our dog out, being he does not "go" in areas like that.  Thank you.

Title: Karen
Comment: We are going to be seeing more and more service dogs traveling and the handlers should not have to go all the way outside to give their dog relief. Serivce dogs are a prominent part of our society now, and deserve access just as convenient as their handlers have.

Title: Danielle L. Tate
Comment: I have a form of dysautonomia called postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome or POTS for short. It affects all systems of my body. I have a service/alert dog to help me. We just recently flew to fl from oh. During our layover we bearly had time to make it to our gate for boarding, let alone walk across the whole airport, exit it, toilet my service/alert dog, go back through security, and walk across the airport to our gate. It's unreasonable and impractical and unfair to the disabled and their service dogs. Many of our health conditions cause us to move slower and exhausts us. My poor service/alert dog had to wait 8 hours to toilet. She seemed miserable. I fully support providing relief areas within the sterile zone of the airport to accommodate us and our canines. Thank you.

Title: Bobbi Rae Wethern
Comment:
This proposed rule Document ID DOT OST 2011 0182 0001 is an essential change that would allow our partnership with our service dogs to help alleviate some of the stress of air traveling that is so negatively impacted by uncontrollable variables, such as inclement weather, late departures and arrivals, unexpected plane changes, etc. Our incredibly well trained dogs are simply not ok with relieving themselves in an indoor setting, causing them incredible and unnecessary stress, painful cramping or distressing and humiliating accidents. Please help us and our dogs, be the best passengers we can be, by providing relief stations in every terminal that gives our wonderful dog partners the dignity they deserve.
Sincerely, 
Bobbi Wethern

Title: Curtis Lee Mettler
Comment: I hope you will support installing animal relief areas in the sterile part of the airport for service dogs.  I travel with my hearing dog through airports and would really appreciate having a relief area that won't make me go out the gates and through security again.  thank you

Title: Kathy A. Taylor
Comment: As a frequet business traveler with a service dog. Airports really need to address the issue of having accessible relief areas in sterile areas. I have missed flights due to having to be re-screen during connecting flights. Many airports will not allow us to move to the front of the line in order to make flights. Statement I was told. "You should have got here sooner." They have no idea how hard it really is.

Title: Jason L. Guthrie
Comment:
I am a diabetic that travels for a living.  Eli is my hypoglycemia alert dog.  All he does is save my life.  About every 3rd week we are at the Sacramento Airport traveling to a city in 1 of 11 states in the west and 4 times a year to St Pete or Ft Lauderdale Florida.  

Inevitably there is a time Eli needs to be relieved.  My life would be made so much easier if there was even a 6 foot square area after security we could use.  

When the need arises there is always a long security check line.... 

Please help, I dont have a pretend companion dog, I have no patience for those people.  I have a dog that is my life-saver.

for more info www.earlyalertcanines.org 

Sincerely
Jason Guthrie

Title: Charles Bourke Motsett
Comment:
I am a 100% Total and Permanently Disabled Veteran  who must use a wheelchair at all times.  I use a Service Dog for a variety of support functions I'm unable to do from my wheelchair.

I am requesting you mandate animal relief sections in the "sterile area" between the gates and TSA Security area in each terminal to allow our animals the opportunity to relieve themselves immediately after landing, especially after long flights. 

Additionally, I request you mandate a relief area as close as possible to the TSA Security Point on the "Non-Sterile" side so animals can relieve themselves before boarding. ideally these would be near the ticketing area(s).

These relief stations will not only reduce the number of accidents inside the building but are also the only humane way to treat these animals.

Thank you.

Title: Stephanie Schatz
Comment: Please set up a Service Dog 'relief area' INSIDE of the sterile zone so that my husband doesn't have to take my service dog and RUN out of the airport between flights and make his way back through the TSA before we miss our next connection.   This would be greatly appreciated by us and my service dog.

Title: James Clark
Comment: The issue of "service dog relief area's" is something that I have had some experience with since getting my service dog.  Most of the area's are outside the "sterile" area and it certainly would mean a great deal to most of us if if were inside the "sterile" area so that we could cut down on the time between "use of the relief area" and boarding the aircraft.  Many of these area's are a great distance and difficult to find (even with directions).  I thank-you for your consideration of a new rule.

Title: Nicole Wiley
Comment: I was in the Denver Airport when I was told that there was a place for my service dog to go in between flights and when I arrived at the relief area, it was closed off. Then when I approached someone about it, the airport staff told me to just have my dog "do his business" on the concrete of the parking lot next to where the relief are would have been. I was horrified! That went against everything my dog was taught. He was taught NOT  to relieve himself anywhere but on grass or mulch (occasionally on gray stone). This is not acceptable.

Title: Cynthia A. Christie
Comment: I have a disability and have a Service Dog.  When I travel I depend on the Service dog relief stations that are in the airport.  I require assistance to get through the check station to get to my gate and if I had to go back out of the "sterile environment' to potty my dog, I would be unable to do so.  Please keep the potty stations in the sterile area and would also encourage them in each wing of the airport.  Thank you, Cindy Christie

Title: Dr. Jane Diamond
Comment: It would be a tremendous "relief" to have a sterile relief area for my service dog at the airports when traveling. In the past it has been so far I couldn't make it to an outside area and back without the possibility of missing my connection. PLEASE HELP WITH PLACING THESE AREAS IN THE STERILE AREAS SO AT LEAST I DON'T HAVE TO GO BACK THROUGH TSA STATIONS A SECOND TIME. IT WILL SAVE EVERYONE TIME AND MONEY AS WELL ON THE TSA END, I PRESUME. THANK YOU

Title: Abigayil
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: Please make dog relief areas close to the areas that you need to go through to board planes. When one has a connecting flight there usually is so little time to make it to the designated relief areas and be back in time to board the plane. It is very difficult to fly cross country with a connection and not be able to let one's dog get available relief.

Title: Lisa L. LaMunyon
Comment: As someone with disabilities it is criticle that my service animal have a location inside the terminal between TSA and the gate. The distance I have to travel from the gate area is very hard for me and I must have time to get through the checkpoint. Please consider this very important.

Title: Carol F. King
Comment:
I really want to see this in full force, at every airport.  It has been years since the directive was first out and now it includes all airports.

It is very needed.

Title: Marianne Jackson
Comment: I feel that seevice animal relief areas should be set inside each airport terminal so the disabled person and their animal do not risk missing their flight.  This is very important for connecting flights.

Title: Bernadette Walsh
Comment: I am in favor of having a sterile area in the terminal for the service cannines.  Frequently, when traveling with my service animal there is a long wait to board and it would be good for the animal to have one more relief time before boarding. It is not convenient to go back through security and outside to the designated area, which frequently is at the far end of the terminals.  I would encourage this act to be passed for all of the people who travel with service dogs.  We owe it to them.  Thank you for your consideration in this matter.Sister Bernadette Walsh

Title: Brennan Consulting Inc.
Comment:
Service Dog Relief Areas in (Sterile Areas) Airports
11/23/2011
Submitted by, Michael Brennan, President, Brennan Consulting Inc., Federal Court Approved Adaexpert Witness.  Miami Beach, Florida, 305-864-7070, Adaexpert@Gmail.com
( 1 )     The issue for we service dog owners in the Notice of Proposed Rule Making is the question posed by the DOT on where to locate service animal relief areas.  The DOT is seeking input on whether service animal relief areas should be located inside or outside “the sterile area.”   The sterile area is understood to be the secure area between the TSA screening checkpoints and the gate area where passengers board or deplane the aircraft.
            
         We service dog owners thank DOT for this proposal seeking input for relief areas located outside the sterile area that in essence creates barriers for disabled passengers.
 Service dog owners urge DOT to require a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal located INSIDE the sterile area to significantly reduce the time and distance for disabled passengers whose assistance dogs need to use the service animal relief areas.  Many times gates are over a quarter mile apart. We implore the DOT to require a centrally located relief area INSIDE the sterile area. If not possible, the airport could build two service animal relief areas inside the sterile area, one at either end of the terminal to ensure time and distance do not pose barriers for disabled passengers traveling with canine assistants.  These relief areas need to be located outdoors to the extent feasible, on the sterile side of the airport, something the TSA discussed in its Guidelines issued in May 2011.
        Owners believe service animal relief areas located inside the sterile area best serve the needs of the majority of disabled passengers with assistance dogs when on the way to the gate, changing planes or during a stopover and immediately after arriving at their destination before passengers have to collect

Title: D. Baker
Comment:
As a person with a disability accompanied by a service dog, I support the proposal to provide service animal relief areas within the sterile area of the airport, to have them clearly signposted, to ensure that only service animals can use this area (to minimise exposing service animals to pathogens that may be carried by pets, compromising the high standard of health service animals must be maintained at) and that the relief areas are marked on the airport's website.

As a person with limited mobility, walking any distance over 50 metres is painful and the effects can last for days, further impacting on quality of life. If the airport can only provide one relief area, can consideration be given to a passenger transport service (ie wheelchair carrying airport golf buggy) that can be utilised at short notice to transport the person and their service animal to the sterile relief area? This will ensure that distance does not become a limiting factor and that persons who are not ambulatory or can only move at a slower speed than a normal walking pace will not miss their flight.

Title: Richard Burhl Faubion
Comment:
I have a guide dog and travel quite a bit for my company, the Foundation Fighting Blindness. I have learned that each airport supposedly has a place for guide dogs to be relieved. I have found these sometimes challenging to find and trying to find someone who knows where they are is sometimes challenging. 
At Denver Intl. Airport (DEN), about 4 years ago, no one could direct me to one of these relieving areas, maybe they did not exist then? Anyway, I tried to find a place, but my dog just would not go. Long story short, we flew to Jacksonville and it was a LONG time before he found a place to go.
I have not experiencded any problems with TSA agents checking my dog when I go through security. They do seem to check my dog inconsistently which is surpising, but of course there is nothing to be concerend with.

Title: Barbara Catherine Gosse
Comment:
I travel with a hearing dog - Darla II.  It would be a tremendous relief to be able to toilet my dog in the sterile area at terminals because it is a real worry when flights are late and you have connections to make.  To make a long story short, a deaf person's nightmare is having to stay over in a strange city and find a hotel who will accept a dog when you can't understand what anyone is telling you especially now that so many people you deal with have foreign accents.

A relief area for dogs to avoid going through Security twice would be wonderful.

Many thanks for your consideration, Barbara Gosse

Title: J. Phillips
Comment:
Airports MUST have more than one service dog relief point inside the airport (i.e. no security check to exit and then re-enter the airport)
MSP has a relief area outside the baggage claim exit. To get there, I must use moving sidewalks and a monorail from the concourse. THERE ARE no maps or signs indicating how often the monorails travel or when they are due to arrive. I'm deaf, and I get panic attacks just trying to get my dog to the relief area AT MSP. I've had to beg airport personnel to SHOW ME instead of telling me where to go, because I can't understand them, and I can't remember where to go.
I've had to ask TSA to shortcut me through the security check just so I can get back in time to catch my flight.  It takes me 40 minutes to just get in and out of MSP for service dog relief, and a late flight can cut 2 hours' layover to nothing.MSP's relief area is very tiny and often foul.  MSP should have at least two to three relief spots on the main concourses inside the security zone. It's a major hub and it's HUGE. 
O'Hare: To get to the relief area, I must travel a long way,  exit the baggage claim, cross a wide road with many buses to get to a large field. It's hazardous even with a traffic-trained hearing guide dog, and there are distracting rabbits.
REROUTES: Once I was bumped up to an earlier flight and rerouted the long way, through Denver, which I didn't know.
When we disembarked I had to go find the baggage claim and then beg a hospitality volunteer to show me where the relief area was, immediately, because my dog was bursting and there was no time to waste.  It took 10 minutes for him to take me to a hill next to the parking garage.  This field was cluttered with dead pigeons.
It's so bad I've tried to train my dog to urinate down drains in handicap bathrooms instead; he won't.
I have never even found the relief areas at Dulles, LAX, or BWI, so I can't speak for these, but these airports also should have at least three service dog relief areas.

Title: Carol-Lynn Katherine Gigandet
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners and Delta Society
Comment:
I travel with my service dog frequently. As a disabled senior, it is difficult, if not impossible to find relief areas throughout the airports for my dog to relieve himself.  We are forced to take long layovers due tot he fact that we must  go out of the airport and try to find any area for this purpose - then we must go back through security all over again to get back to our next flight. Travelers are rude and there is no help for your disabled passengers, making this an unpleasant experience.

Being disabled is challenging enough, without the airports making it more difficult for us.  Please support having "potty" areas inside the airport for our working dogs.  

You migh also take into consideration the cleaning of the areas that do exsist.  Most are filthy and not suitable for our animals.  These serviced dogs noses are so sensitive and the smells are distracting.  Areas should be desgined for only the use of the disabled with thier service dogs. 

In this country we are so concerned with being correct in treatment of so many - but the diabled are overlooked and discarded as valuable human beings.

Katherine Giganadet

Title: Nancy Alice Flemming
Comment: We want to encourage the adoption of rules that provide for service animals to have a place to relieve themselves between flights that accommodate the needs of their disabled charges, as far as someone accompanying them and having enough areas available at each airport to accommodate the volume of passengers and animals needing these services.

Title: Alice Duddy
Comment:
Please make a sterile area available in each terminal between the TSA security area and the gate for people with service dogs.

Thank you,  Alice Duddy

Title: Melissa Wallace
Comment:
Both myself and my husband are disabled. I am partnered with a Service Dog, and my husband is partnered with an ESA. We fly at minimum 2-3 times a year, often not together. It is absolutely critical that Service Animal Relief Areas be located within the sterile area. Ideally, there should be one area per teminal. If it is not possible to create multiple areas, this area should be centrally located within the building. For airports that have satellite terminals, each terminal must have its own relief area. The location of the areas are critical because it is often impossible to make it to the relief area and back to your gate, even if it is within the sterile area. For example, when my husband and I traveled together recently, we were waiting for our flight to board. It had been several hours since the dogs had voided, and the next flight was 4.5 hours. We knew that the airport we were flying to did not have a relief area. The relief area (fortunately insude the sterile area) was on the other side of the terminal building, 3 terminals away. There was no way that my husband would make it. So I had to struggle across the airport in pain with 2 dogs. Both dogs were absolutely mortified at being asked to void indoors. I convinced them that it was okay. I got back to the gate, and everyone except my husband had boarded, and they wanted to close the gate. Given the limited flight options at certain locations, missing that flight might have meant not leaving until the next day. It was very stressful and painful.
It would be preferred to have an outdoor option within the sterile area because many dogs would get overly stressed if asked to eliminate on command in an indoor area as this is not a normal behavior for a service dog. This then creates stress for the disabled handler in an already stressful travel situation. It is a difficult situation to train. Preferred materials even for an indoor area include, grass, soil, wood chips, or small gravel to give an outdoor feel.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While traveling with a friend who has a Hearing dog, our itinerary took us through the Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta GA.  As soon as we arrived, she told me she needed to take him to the dog park outside the airport so I went with her.  I was in shock when I realized how far they needed to go to get there. With a layover of 1 hour and 15 minutes I was a little concerned about us making the connection.  And when we came back into the building, we had to go back through security screening!  Fortunately, it was not a heavy travel weekend and were able to get through screening in enough time to make the long trek back to our gate and make our connection.

Service animal relief areas need to be provided on the "sterile" side of gate areas to allow people with service animals to take them between flights.  Air travel these days is stressful enough but to make these dog partner teams walk so far and make them go through TSA screening again is unfair.

Title: Linda Gail Arkow
Comment: I believe it is imperative for there to be places for asssitance dogs to releive themselves

Title: Sarah Kelly Broderick
Comment: Please, please  installing a minimum of one service animal relief area per terminal, making it a convenient location and preferably inside but outside is fine too. Creating a toilet area would mean the difference of me stressing and having anxiety about my beloved dog's comfort or discomfort. Thinking I may miss my flight is also a great concern to me and also causes extreme anxiety. My assistance dog is elderly and needs a quick place to go, especially before and after long flights.  My successor dog is young and new to flying so I want him to have the best possible experience as he starts his new 'job' with me. Thank you for yur consideration.

Title: Elaine G. Maddow
Comment:
I think it's imperative for disabled persons and their service dogs to have a pet relief area available after they have gone through the tsa check, inside the sterile area since there is generally a long wait before boarding and that this should be available in every terminal.
This is the very least to be done for disabled people traveling under already stressful conditions because of their disabilities.

Title: Arleen Marilyn Foster
Comment: I am a 55 y.o. disabled woman, and I visit my daughter in California as often as she can afford to buy me airfare. This is usually once/year. However, I also travel for other reasons and find myself on a plane at least one or two other times. I need to travel with my Service Dog Gryphon, who is now seven+ years old, but he's gone on every plane that I have since 2006. We must deal with as we travel the single-most obnoxious, frightening, and sweat-provoking stressor. Although I do walk with a cane at home, I can only do so for about a short city block [in extraordinary pain]. Therefore, I am in a wheelchair from the minute I enter a terminal. This alone makes traversing the airport something we fear terribly. Even the best-trained working dog has problems there. I have to yell to my dog "Stay in a Heel" to be heard over the noise. Then there are the people who walk into or onto him, talk to or distract him, and then we get to the gate, where he might show the first inkling he needs to toilet. Keep in mind I took him to the grass before entering the terminal. So, I'm really stressed about the time. I'll ask for someone at the gate to take him down to one of the toileting area since it's too far for me and I have to go thru security again, in addition to the pain. Even with some cue words to get him to "do it," he is too scared to go. That means he will sit stiffly and painfully in the bulkhead beside my feet and those of others [some with bulging bags under the seat], all the while having to go numbers 1 & 2. I ask you, how long can you remain in one position on a cold metal floor without having an accident? Could you hold it for a minimum of 2 hours and 45 minutes? I didn't think so. There is such a need to have a sound and emission-free (or close to that) working dog toileting area at no less than every other gate. These dogs are HEROES, just like war veterans, to their "disabled" partners; some are like me, & can't do much on their own. Gryphon deserves more.

Title: Pam
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: We need this service for our companions! It's an important and integral part of our being able to travel with them.

Title: Barbara K. Schwartz
Comment:
Myself and my service dog fly regularly on business and pleasure. It is a nightmare trying to arrange enough time to allow my dog during layovers. For example, the Denver Airport has a relief area which is a patch of dirt at the farthest end of the parking garage. If I am using my crutches, it is impossible for me to get there at all. Other airports such as Albuquerque, Seattle, etc are almost as bad. It would be very easy to install a relief station with secure section just as large dog show do.

Dr. Barbara Schwartz

Title: Anonymous
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
IAADP's Public Comment with photos of Service Animal Relief
Areas cannot be submitted online in its entirety, as the website rejeced the upload due to its length.  We subsequently reduced the file size by eliminating five of the six photos in order to get the website to accept the text.  

Those interested in reviewing the photos can visit http://iaadp.org/comments.html
and scroll to the bottom of our public comment.

IAADP plans to re-submit this comment with all the photos after reviewing other submission options.  It may not get posted till after the Nov 28 deadline.  The photos show a deplorable service animal relief area and two excellent ones, by way of contrast. The one photo retained in this document should be sufficient to illustrate why we support the U.S. Department of Transportation setting standards for the design of service animal relief areas.

Title: Linda K. Mosier
Comment: Please allow service dog relief areas WITHIN the sterile area.  My first service dog had an accident on a plane, during flight, because we didn't have time to get to an area which was a long way outside the sterile area prior to flight time.   It was a very stressful flight & I was mortified by what happened.

Title: Cindi Fleishans
Comment:
I am writing here hoping the DOT will require a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile/secure area of each terminal so that time and distance do not impose a hardship on disabled passengers traveling with assistance dogs. 
  I have had difficulties with that issue in the past myself. Barely made the flight and was worrying the whole time. Also I had difficulty finding the service dog relief area due to lack of directions or sign to guide me there. Was very fortunate to find a security person in airport who guided me there. So signs would be extremely helpful, along with on line map to relief area would be great to help with prior planning.

Thank You,
cindi fleishans

Title: Robert B. Maddow
Comment:
My sister-in-law is deaf.  She is a single woman who lives alone, and she has been able to continue doing so, as the degree of her deafness increased, because she has a hearing dog.  She is one of 8 siblings, 6 of whom live in eastern Canada, whereas she lives in California.  Almost every year, there are family events and gatherings in the east, and until she got her hearing dog she was often unable to participate, because cross-country travel for a deaf person can be exceptionally difficult, especially in the event of flight delays or disruptiions due to weather or mechanical problems. 

But even with the hearing dog, my sister-in-law's travel  difficulties can be compounded if she is in an airport where the pet relief areas are limited or far from the terminal where she has landed or will depart.  This can be especially true when connecting flights are involved.

I understand that one of the purposes of the ADA is to allow our citizens with disabilities to be fully integrated into our fast-moving and complex society.  The regulation now being considered is one easy and relatively simple way to accomplish that end for people like my sister-in-law, but making it easier for them to be able to travel with their service dogs, to do without having to risk missing flights or other connections, and to do so without having to go through TSA screening more than once because of the unfortunate and inconvenient location of a pet relief area.

Thank you for giving consideration to my comment.  I have provided my e-mail address if there are any questions about my comment.

Bob Maddow
Castro Valley, CA 94546

Title: Robin Lesley Emanuel-Smith
Comment: I am a Deaf 56 year old woman who also has severe Meniere's Disease (which affects my mobility). When my hearing dog and I travel by plane, it is imperative that there be a sterile relief area for my dog or I generally will miss my connecting flight. Please make this change happen for service, hearing, and seeing eye dog partners!!!

Title: Paul Louis Hinz
Comment: I know my Girl "Sandy" she'd probably be right grateful for one last chance to relieve er' self. Me... I'd sure be more than grateful considering how badly I walk not to have to be harrassed by the security folk again and again! Maybe the person in charge of this decision should be asked to "hold it" for a couple of extra hours. It's "no big deal" right?

Title: Amy Gooding
Comment: Please consider access to relieving areas within the sterile area of airports for service animals.  This can be a very difficult situation when traveling with my guide dog, especially at night in airports where I have to take my dog outside, often unaccompanied.  For safety of the dog and myself as a guide dog user, please provide one relieving area within the sterile area of each terminal at airports.  Thank you.

Title: Betty Janet Wittels
Comment:
I am disabled and have a service dog and travel frequently by plane. It is too difficult and far for me to go outside the sterile area when she has to go to the bathroom. In Vancouver last year the airport manager kindly took her as she said it was too far away and I would miss the plane. My dog did a bowel movement and if she had not helped me there would have been a mess on the plane. 
Animals, like humans, bodies get off track in travel and she was no exception. Your service areas, besides being ultra small and located in ridiculous places like 3 feet square in the middle of the parking lot on cement instead of grass with a fire hydrant, are not very hospitable for dogs anyway. If I need to take her after going to the gate to go back and then through time-consuming security is impossible.

Title: Roxie D. Mayfield
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: I am an individual with a physical disability and I have been partnered with a service dog to assist me for the past 16 years. I have traveled a number of times via air, and always my service dog accompanied me. I found some airports to have excellent relief areas for my dog, and others did not or they had none at all. The best service animal relief areas are within the "sterile area" of the airport, not far from an exit/entrance door so that it is easily accessible within a timely manner, but also it should be not in the most busy area of the airport. I have seen covered areas with gravel located at one end of the terminal building, out-of-the-way of most passenger traffic, and this works very well. Some airports have a similar area with dirt or grass which also works well. The important thing is it cannot be more than a short distance (10-20 feet) from the terminal building or it will not be practical for most individuals to utilize. Thank you for your attention to this very important matter. All of us with disabilities value our independence, including our ability to travel independently. Our service animals make us more independent and able to be in the mainstream.

Title: Melanie Jannery
Comment:
I use a service animal and was very happy when providing service animal relief areas was brought onto the table.  What I anticipated this to be like and the reality of what came to be was completely different.  Although service animal relief areas are required, they are all outside of the airports, so, spite this consideration to provide something for us to access with our dogs to relieve them, there are barriers.  Currently, in order for me to relieve my service animal, I have to go outside of the secure area of the terminal, find the potty area, relieve my dog and then go back through the entire screening process again. 

This IS an unreasonable process to go through especially when rules are designed to help individuals with disabilities.  Since many airports are large and packed, flights can be missed easily!  Airports can be intimidating and stressful to start.  The first time I flew since having the service animal relief areas implemented I was very disappointed, after asking about 13 airport personnel where the designated area was, I was mislead by many who simply did not know, to finally realize it was outside passed security.  I no longer had time to relieve my dog, nor did I have a moment to sit and catch my breath, where if proper set up was placed, I would have been able to relieve my service dog, not have become stressed and would have been able to sit as the rest of the travelers get to experience.  My challenges are invisible, but I cannot imagine how person with mobility or vision challenges would have navigated their way through successfully since I could not spite my efforts. 

It is only reasonable to place relief areas within the terminals inside the security area somehow.  The space needs to me minimal, perhaps taking guidance and care as they are able to provide areas on cruises to accommodate.  When delayed overnight, I certainly was disgusted with the relief area in place in Detroit. Dirty, dark, isolated, unsafe and inconvenient...not cool!

Title: Adelle Leber
Comment:
I have traveled several times with a disabled person and her service dog. Luckily I was with her. There was no way she could have gone outside and back in time for her connecting flight. 
There was one time the dog and I had to run to get outside in time and then found only cement. There was no place for a female dog to relieve herself. Then we had to go back thru security and the long line. I barely made it in time. Another time I knew there was no way I could get her outside and back in time to she had to hold it from NJ to CA. 
If you do put in more dog spots they need to be easily found.
If someone checks in with a dog give them a map of where the relief area is in the airport where their lay over is. This would be a big help. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Sandy K. Ash
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment:
I think it is important to have Service Dog relief areas in the sterile zone.  I will be traveling with my service dog in March of 2012 and the airlines has asked me to be there three hours before my plane leaves.  It takes me a while to get to the gates and if my service dog needs to relieve himself agaon before we fly I would not have sufficient time to get back to the gate if I have to leave the steriel area and then go through the security check in again.  Please make sure that all concourses and airlines have relief areas for service dogs at all airports.  They need to keep them maintained too and we the users need to help keep them clean so they are not a source of smell or eyesores, so that we can once these relief areas are in placebe able to keep them there.

Thank you for listening to those of us who depend on service dogs to help us remain independent and allow us to use air travel without the worry of not having to miss our planes. We ask you to require that all airports have a place for relief areas for service dogs in the sterile areas on all concourses.

Title: Suzanne Edwards Brean
Comment:
As a person who flies frequently and is accompanied by a Service Animal the idea of not having to exit the airport and hassle with going back through security during a layover makes me ecstatic.  

Currently if I am going to be flying for an extended period of time I have to allow for an extended layover so that I have enough time to leave the secure area, find the pet relieving area and make it back through security before my plane boards.  This often means I have to leave the terminal where I am and travel to the main terminal or parking lot to relieve my service animal. Often the areas where the relieving areas are located are not safe or are poorly lighted.  Many times the airport staff has no idea where the relieving area is located so a lot of time is spent just trying to find an area to relieve my Service Animal, all the time concerned about my next plane boarding and if my Service Animal is going to be able to hold it long enough to find the relieving area. 

If there were Service Animal Relieving areas passed security it would mean I could fly more efficiently and would feel more secure while relieving my Service Animal.

Please approve the rule that would make Service Animal Relieving areas a requirement in airports that receive federal funds. It would make those of us who travel with a Service Animal feel safer while traveling.

Title: Ellen Lenox Smith
Organization Name: American Pain Foundation Advocate; Arthritis Ambassador
Comment:
I have had to travel many times with my service dog due to medical appointments and surgeries. I have found it so frustrating to find a place where my dog can relieve herself at the airlines. In DC, we almost missed our flight when we had to travel a long distance, slip outside, and then go back through security. This is not an easy process in a wheelchair. I have been fortunate to have my husband's help, but can't imgaine how I would do all this by myself.

Please make this safer and closer for us all!!
ellen smith

Title: Michael Wuich
Comment: I love that the airlines let my service dog fly with me but there does need to be a place for him to go to the bathroom outside of gate areas inbetween flights that is not back through secuity.  I know you can get this worked out.  more and more people are in need of service dogs and it will be a problem that will continue to grow if you don't get a head of it now.  Thank you for your time.

Title: Olivia De Hill
Comment: It would be a great blessing to have a relief area at the airport within the sterile area.  I am a facilitator for my granddaughter and her companion dog Brooke.  A couple of years ago, we arrived at the Denver airport and almost made it to the outside when her dog needed a relief area.  He had to relieve himself.  It was a big mess and had there been a relief area nearby we would not have been embarrassed and had a big mess in the airport.  Thank goodness it was late at night and not many people were at that area of the airport.  Please consider putting a relief area for the disabled with service animals.  This would be a very helpful thing to implement.

Title: Beverly J. Galarza
Comment:
Our family appreciates the opportunity to comment to this proposed rule.  It is imperative DOT implement a rule which would require animal relief areas within the sterile/secured areas of airports between TSA and gates, both inside and outside of the United States.

I am attached a lengthy, detailed comment which describes some of our family's layover issues and considerations when traveling alone with my adult son, Steven, with his emotional service animal, Sophie, a Lab, from San Antonio, Texas, to Maui, Hawaii.   I'm also attaching a pic. of Steven and Sophie so DOT knows who I am advocating for.

Thank you for your consideration and with warm Aloha,
Beverly, Steven and Sophie Galarza

Title: Lisa Westerman
Comment: The last 3 times I've flown with my service dog from Alaska to Ohio, the airlines was 2 hours late making my connection.  There was no time to leave the security area to take my dog outside to potty. Please put service dog potty areas inside TSA security screening so my dog doesn't have to hold it 11 hours!

Title: Evan Lee Parmenter
Comment:
Please consider revising the requirements of the locations for the Service Animal Relief Areas.  As a family member and primary caregiver I am urging the DOT to require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate areas.

Those disabled that travel with an assistance animal have special needs.  The needs of a living creature need to be taken into consideration.  The dogs obviously have the biological need to relieve themselves at reasonable intervals.  

 For the disabled who are often unable to walk or travel as quickly as the average traveler, caring for the elimination needs of their animal becomes a very long, drawn-out and many times painful process of exiting the secure area, finding the relief area, then getting back through security and finally making it back to the boarding gate in time for the flight.

My family has had personal experience with this issue.  During a delay between connecting flights in Arizona, my wife nearly missed her flight because of this issue.  It took time to get directions to find the relief area.  When she obtained directions and found the area it was outside of the secure area.  It was a very long walk in order to get the service dog outside, then an extended process to get back through security.  By the time my wife was able to return to the gate area she was within seconds of the gate being closed and being left on the ground.

At one time it was rare to see a baby-changing station in a men’s room.  Now it is the norm.  Having a relief area for service dogs inside the secure areas and close to the various terminal gates would be a kindness to our disabled citizens, to the animals that provide service to them, and would improve the efficiency of passenger movement by reducing traffic through the TSA security checkpoints.

Title: Linda M.
Comment: I have traveled with my service dog on occasion for the past 10 years. It has been my experience that the dog relief areas were not easily available and outside of the security area. As I travel alone on most occasions with my service dog, it means having to go back through security with all my carry on baggage, myself, my power wheelchair, etc. I believe the airports need to have relief areas with better signage and access to the person traveling with a service animal. There should be places inside the security zone in addition to outside this area so our animals can get relief coming and going and also while waiting especially if there are flight delays. We should not be inconvenienced because we have to travel with a service animal.

Title: Eileen Cash
Comment:
I flew on November 1, 2001 from Syracuse NY to Chicago and then from Chicago to San Francisco.  On 11/15/2011, we flew a return trip along the same route.

I traveled with my service dog, Grace.  As for pet relief areas (of course, my service dog is not a pet), we only used the one at O'Hare.  It was a nice area and clean, but quite a ways from the gate area, outside of the airport.  I use a wheelchair for distance walking and I was with another friend with a guide dog.

We had to leave our arrival gate and make our way through the airport.  Thankfully, we had requested the wheelchair and help, so in both directions, we had a great support in place to get to the relief area.  Of course, we were carrying all our carry-on items the whole way.  

Once our dogs had finished relieving themselves, we had to go back througn the airport again, including going through security.  Since we were traveling with our dogs, the always set off the detectors at security because of their gear, which contained metal rings.  Since the dog set off the detector, I had to be patted down again both time we were in O'Hare.
