The bottom line is that although a nice area was provided, it was outside and far from the gates.  Taking time to go through security again, being patted down again, scanning all our carry-on again caused stress and concerns about making our next flight.  By the time we reached the gate for our trip home, they were ready to start pre-boarding.

Title: Amy
Comment: please see attached file. Thank you sooooo much.

Title: Gary Christopher Norman
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Rachel Campbell
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION

Office of the Secretary

49 CFR Part 27

RIN 2105-AD91
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0182]

	I am for this regulation in all its parts, focusing on the service animal relief areas, of this regulation. This service area should be placed with in the sterile area of the airport and not just past security, within reasonable distance from any terminal or within each terminal depending on the size of the airport. With larger airports, it is often difficult for the average passenger to make flights, let alone the traveler with disabilities, when compounding that problem with the necessary care of the service animal many feel that travel is just not in the available options for them. Currently the list of service animal areas in the airports show that a number of large airports only have one or two for the massive area of the whole airport, with the most of them located outside the sterile area, which requires the traveler to go through the screening process at security. During heavy air travel traffic time such as holidays the screening process can take even longer than normal, and is an unnecessary delay for travelers with disabilities, in order to care for their working animals. If the relief area was with in the sterile area it also would be a benefit to other travelers with pets, which would benefit the airport and airlines with more revenue, therefore the cost does not outweigh the benefit to all and there is no reasonable objections.  
	The time line that is imposed on the airports to implement this regulation is reasonable of 120 days. Currently airports offer services that are not as important or vital to a number of travelers as the service of animal relief area with no problem, such as smoking lounges. If they are able to offer non vital services then it should be expected to offer these vital ones in a timely matter, with little delay. A small room with drainage and Astor turf would not take long to implement and set up, and maintaining

Title: Lisa Sanchez
Comment:
I WOULD LIKE TO RECOMMEND THAT RELIEF AREAS FOR SERVICE ANIMALS BE MORE ACCESIBLE AND TO BE LOCATED INSIDE THE STERILE AREAS FOR THOSE OF US THAT USE THE AIRLINES WITH OUR SERVICE ANIMALS.
THANK YOU,
SINCERELY,
LISA SANCHEZ & CANINE COMPANION STEVO

Title: Estelle Gray
Comment: Please please please understand how important it is for service dogs to have a comfortable area to relieve themselves. Just like you and I they need to use a restroom facility after a long flight. Fl ying is stressful enough for them, and they need a large enough area for them to be comfortable, no different than a human's needs. Please consider their needs as these animals are important in the lives of people with disabilities.

Title: Nancy Leverett
Comment: See attached file.

Title: Rosanna Lynn Daniel-Kanetake
Comment: I am a frequent flyer with my male service dog, mainly from Hawaii to the west coast.  I usually have a layover in Seattle WA., SEATAC airport.  There is a releif area inside the terminal but it appears to be an old mechanical area with pee pads that have been used, so the oder is atroshis there is no ventalation and by allowing my male dog to urinate on used pee pads it also teaches my dog it is okay to mark territory indoors over the top of other dogs markings, I refuse to take him in there.  The outdoor area is as stated "outside" the secure area which takes several mins. to get to and then have to go back through security checkpoint and have on several occasions have been so late that the plane has had to wait for me which from the look on other passangers faces, they appear very annoyed.  It would be so helpful if there was a relief station inside that was suitable and ventilated for my service dog to releave himself without us missing our flight or holding up the other passangers.

Title: Melanie Jannery
Comment:
I use a service animal and was very happy when providing service animal relief areas was brought onto the table.  What I anticipated this to be like and the reality of what came to be was completely different.  Although service animal relief areas are required, they are all outside of the airports, so, spite this consideration to provide something for us to access with our dogs to relieve them, there are barriers.  Currently, in order for me to relieve my service animal, I have to go outside of the secure area of the terminal, find the potty area, relieve my dog and then go back through the entire screening process again. 

This IS an unreasonable process to go through especially when rules are designed to help individuals with disabilities.  Since many airports are large and packed, flights can be missed easily!  Airports can be intimidating and stressful to start.  The first time I flew since having the service animal relief areas implemented I was very disappointed, after asking about 13 airport personnel where the designated area was, I was mislead by many who simply did not know, to finally realize it was outside passed security.  I no longer had time to relieve my dog, nor did I have a moment to sit and catch my breath, where if proper set up was placed, I would have been able to relieve my service dog, not have become stressed and would have been able to sit as the rest of the travelers get to experience.  My challenges are invisible, but I cannot imagine how person with mobility or vision challenges would have navigated their way through successfully since I could not spite my efforts. 

It is only reasonable to place relief areas within the terminals inside the security area somehow.  The space needs to me minimal, perhaps taking guidance and care as they are able to provide areas on cruises to accommodate.  When delayed overnight, I certainly was disgusted with the relief area in place in Detroit. Dirty, dark, isolated, unsafe and inconvenient...not cool!

Title: Margaret Baron
Comment:
Department of Transportation
Docket number DOT-OST-2011-0182 

I am requesting that the following be incorporated into the new DOT rule change:
1. Require at least one relieving area INSIDE the "sterile" TSA security area of each terminal for service animals.
2. A minimum of 20 square feet per relieving area
3. The relieving area should be OPEN-AIR (outside of the terminal building) since service animals (dogs) are trained NOT to relieve indoors.

Title: Kathy Kimmel
Comment: I travel with a service dog. I have yet to find an area that is accessible to for me to get to within the gate areas at airports to toilet my dog. Often it it hard to find grassy areas at all in some airports.  Sometimes grassy areas are at another terminal.  After a stressful flight for my canine partner it is important that she be given the opportunity to toilet.  It  is discrimination against physically challenged people to make them go through security twice just because their service animals have to go to the bathroom and they have a connecting flight and that may cause them to miss the connection. All efforts to make travel for disabled people made easier should be made and not give them more obstacles to deal with

Title: Karen Nagle
Comment:
I was in Chicago O'Hare  Airport walking to my connecting flight,  If there was a relief area, no one knew about it.  I had an hour.  Enough time to dash to a relief area but not enough time to take the long walk to security and then re-enter through security.  After asking multiple times to have someone please escort me and my dog to the tarmac so he could relieve, I decided to try to make it outside.  But unfortunately, due to a long flight, my poor dog was unable to make it and relieved in the middle of a busy terminal.  The woman who was escorting me was kind enough to get paper towels to help clean up the mess as well as paige for more assistance.  

It is unfair for service animals who must endure long flights to be denied a convenient place to empty within the confines of security.  When I prepare to fly I must feed my dog enough to settle his stomach but not too much.  He also gets a very minimal amount of water and a few ice cubes on our journey.  He never complains once but I can't begin to imagine the discomfort he endures simply because there is no place for him to empty.  

When I walk through an airport I notice that no one is denied an opportunity to use the restroom within security.  Why shouldn't service animals be given the same respect?

Title: Chantal E. Wilson
Comment:
I am commenting regarding DOCKET - OST - 2011 - 0182

I have just returned from the first flight with my Service Dog.  The lack of RELIEF AREAS at airports and/or the staff's knowledge of their location, severely affects my ability to travel.  

I strongly  support the opinion stated by the International Association of Assistance Dog Partners (IAADP).  This opinion can be found at http://iaadp.org/comments.html.

Title: Gaeyle L. Gerrie-Boss
Comment:
I use a service animal and am so thankful when the issue of providing service animal relief areas is being considered. It seems very outdated and even anti-handicapped.  Current  service animal relief areas are outside security areas making them a very difficult for people with disablilities to access.  If all restrooms were outside of the secured area and required re-examination for re-entry it would be obvious that this would be an untenable situation. 

It is reasonable to have a timely, safe and accessible way to relieve my service dog. Not having reasonable access leaves the handler with the real issue of meeting the service dogs true health and wellness needs, or possibly missing their flight due to distance and disability issues.  It would be the ethical and legally correct thing to create areas safe and accessible for service dog teams. My challenges are invisible, but I cannot imagine how person with mobility or vision challenges navigate throught the current offerings for relieving a service dog at an airport.

It is reasonable and necessary to place relief areas for service dogs within the terminals secured areas.  Service dogs need a minimal space and the means to dispose of waste in a sanitary manner.  People with Disabilities who use Service Dogs should have reasonable accomodation to care for their dogs while traveling. If it can be done on a cruise ship, accommodating this need for people with disabilities who have a service dog in an airport is not only practical, it is the only humane way to go. 

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this issue.
Respectfully yours, 
Proud to be a Handi-Capable Veteran and American

Title: Maria Proschan
Comment: I have had a guide dog for the last 7 years and I have found it to be the most wonderful mobility aid, even though I am an excellent cane  traveler.  Unfortunately, I've experienced the horror of my dog's inability to wait more than 20 minutes for an escort to guide us to a non existing relief area in the parking loat the Dallas airport.  If one existed in the sterile area he would have had a chance, but personnel must be available alone with the relief area.  There is no question that the relief area within the secure section of the terminal is a must to assist the service animal teams.Thank you for your efforts in this regard.Maria

Title: Delores B. Powell
Comment:
Docket Number: # DOT-OST-2011-0182
I support the IAADP in asking the DOT to require a  minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile area of each terminal.  The lack of these relief areas creates a sever handicap on those of us who travel with our Service Animals .  Due to my disability, walking long distances is painful and a time consuming endeavor.  Providing this Relief Area would make travel more accessible to a large part of the population.  

I also believe that signs and maps should be clearly marked with the location of all Service Animal Relief Areas.  Please help those of us who through no fault of our own, rely on our Service Animals for our mobility and the ability to travel.

Title: Melissa Dalland
Comment: I was thinking about flying to Pittsburgh PA for my grandma's funeral. I decided not to on the fact of my service dog and being able to him time to go potty. To stressful for me trying to find him a place to go coming back through security not worth it.I would love for this to happen. I can't believe we have to put foot baths in restrooms for Muslims but cant put relief areas in for service dogs.

Title: Patricia P.
Comment:
I am requesting that the following be incorporated into the new DOT rule change:
1. Require at least one relieving area INSIDE the "sterile" TSA security area of each terminal.
2. A minimum of 20 square feet per relieving area
3. The relieving area should be OPEN-AIR (outside of the terminal building) since service dogs are trained NOT to relieve indoors.
Please consider the above suggestions.  My husband is legally blind and his guide dog Juanita does and incredible job and needs consideration too.
Thank you,
Patricia Moore

Title: Suzan Morris
Comment:
In regard to service animal relief areas, I feel strongly that there should be options within the sterile area and guidelines for design/potty material surfaces of those areas.  

I am disabled and travel with a service dog.  I was thrilled to find a relief area within the sterile area at SeaTac but that turned to dismay once we tried to use it.  All that was provided were small potty pads.  My service dog is a Golden Retriever and doesn't use potty pads.  If she did, I could easily carry them myself and use the ladies room!  It seem like they were catering to people with small pet dogs (and how these areas are being marketed, this one even said "Pet Relief Area"), not working service animals which tend to be the larger breeds.  At that point my dog is looking at me like "you want me to do what, where?" and I didn't know where the nearest relief area outside the sterile area was because we were directed to the one within it.  

I believe that the inside areas should use fake grass.  There are systems out there that have sprinklers and draining capabilities like the Porch Potty which would make maintenance easier.  Dog owners pick up the solid waste and liquid is rinsed through and can be directed through a hose to a floor drain. http://www.porchpotty.com/  

I wonder if relief areas could be a part of the regular people bathrooms with it's own stall or a separate one with a door like the family bathrooms.  Perhaps one or two family bathrooms could be re-purposed.  That would be ideal with a sink for washing your hands (there wasn't one in the SeaTac one) and you wouldn't have to worry about coming in contact with an uncontrolled pet dog in the area itself which is always a worry with a service animal.  I've heard of untrained, stressed out pet dogs and emotional support animals lunging at and attacking a service animal. 

Thank you for allowing people with service dog to comment.

Title: Karen L. Brockett
Comment: As someone with a service animal I would like to see a requirement of a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile area of each terminal so that time and distance do not impose a hardship on those of us who travel with assistance dogs.  Furthermore airports should be required to put up Signs to help disabled passengers find the Service Animal Relief Areas and those location of Service Animal Relief Areas should be shown on website maps of the airport.

Title: Amanda Melville
Comment: My comment is about service dog relief areas in our airports. When I have taken flights there are no clearly marked relief ares for service dogs within the security check ares. When I have connecting flights I am unable to go outside security check points and make it back inside the secured area before my connecting flight leaves. With travel being more and more convenient for the disabled we are flying more. But, with no conveniences for our service dogs being considered we often have to rethink our plans. If you would make it so EVERY airport in the US has a service dog relief area INSIDE check points THAT would be FANTASTIC and would allow us to travel more comfortably. It doesn't have to be a big area, just big enough for a big dog to potty in. Most service dogs are trained to relieve themselves on command so it wouldn't have to be too big. Most of us disabled folks are trained to pick up after our dogs too so it SHOULDN'T require any work on your part other than providing our much needed dogs with a decent place to relieve themselves INSIDE security check. Thank you for reading this. I hope this matter is addressed and is fixed soon. It would really make our travel a LOT easier!

Title: Mark Powell
Comment:
I am submitting in regards to the proposal for service animals for disabled persons to have available a rest facility within the secure area. If there are restrooms for non-disabled persons, and for disabled persons in the secure area, then it only makes sense that for those who rely on service animals to maneuver, a facility for the animals to relieve themselves is necessary and the only solution that makes sense for hygiene. The animals cannot always wait for their slower moving persons to take them outside the airport, and then to ask the disabled person to go back through security is discriminating against them, and making missing their flights so much more likely.
I know that the airlines are claiming it is a financial hardship to accommodate disabled persons, but honestly, are American citizens worth less than a few extra dollars on the airlines bottom lines?

Title: Elizabeth Bossoli
Comment:
Please keep the diverse needs of air travel consumers, including those with disabilities, in mind when considering accessible airport design.  The proposed changes, including;

Adding relief areas for service dogs, in the sterile area of each terminal
Adding signs to indicate where relief areas can be found
Adding relief area locations to airport layout maps

Will improve accessibility for those passengers with disabilities, who travel with service dogs.

Signage should feature raised Braille for visually impaired travelers.

Title: Terry Mykol Christensen
Comment: I fly with my Guide Dog three or four times per year. Although I make certain that he has the opportunity to relieve before we go through security, it may be an hour before we board the plane. Even after we board the plane, we are subject to delays beyond our control. These hold-ups are particulary troublesome when we have to make connections to another flight. For example, a trip from Philadelphia to Portland on Southwest Airlines may well involve two or more connecting flights with layovers that range from 30 minutes to 1 hour and involve moving from moving from one set of gates to another. Even if the layover is one hour, getting outside the security perimeter and back in time to board the flight is problematic at best. Meanwhile my Guide has to go up to 8 hours without a chance to relieve. I don't know of many humans who can "hold it" for eight hours, and it is inhumane to ask our Guides to do so. I STRONGLY support the establishment of relieving areas for Guide Dogs inside the security perimeter.

Title: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners

Title: Agustya Mehta
Comment:
I want to express my strong support for this proposal to require relief areas for service animals past security in airport terminals.

People who require service animals need to be accommodated in the secure areas of our nation's airports. Disabled people have a right to travel independently, and should not be forced to leave and reenter the secure area to relieve their service animals. The way that our airports are set up today needlessly prevents many people with service animals from being able to travel by making connecting flights with short layovers impossible.

My mother is visually impaired, and our family has experienced firsthand how people with disabilities are seriously impacted by the current state of affairs.

The TSA has asserted that there is no negative security impact in providing relief areas past security. I urge you to address this issue, and require that our airports accommodate people with service animals at all terminals.

Thank you for addressing this important issue, and for working to provide reasonable accommodation to all of our nation's travelers, disabled or not.

Title: American Aviation Institute
Comment:
The Department has not conducted basic research to incorporate known compliance cost data from actual airport projects.  It has also not yet demonstrated that a market failure or regulatory gap requires new regulations for airports.  Publicly available information demonstrates that airport compliance costs are material, the proposed regulations are economically significant, and existing regulations already address the accessibility objectives given in this proposal.  Furthermore, the compliance timelines proposed are not reasonable.  

We respectfully request that the Department suspend proposed rulemaking until it presents a clear justification for changing the rules.  The Department should incorporate known information into its analysis, present rigorous estimates of costs and benefits, evaluate alternatives, and justify the burden of its new regulations on airports.  

Any proposed changes to Part 382 airline regulations belong in a separate rulemaking with airline-specific regulatory language, cost and benefit analysis, and evaluation of alternatives.

Title: Barbara Burton
Comment: Service animal relief areas should be located both inside and outside air terminals.  Inside, they should be located within the sterile area no more than 10 minutes from any gate for a person who moves very slowly (consider a person using a walker or crutches). Determine the number or relief areas based on that.  Consult service animal agencies/partners when designing the relief areas. Relief areas should, when possible, have grass. Avoid rocks and other sharp, uncomfortable surfaces. Avoid asphalt as it gets too hot in summer sun & can burn paws. Provide waste disposal cans at relief areas. Consider providing a source of water. Provide relief area location information on all carriers' & airport websites as well as on maps inside airports. Develop a universal symbol for signage indicating relief area locations; consult with CADO, ADI, IAADP & other organizationsto do so. All such regulations should apply to US and foreign carriers. All regulations should be written in person first language.

Title: Judy
Organization Name: International Association of Assistance Dog Partners
Comment: It would be a GREAT help to me & my dog to have a relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal at all airports.

Title: Beverly J. Galarza
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
Our family submitted a comment a few days ago, but over the weekend, I learned something which absolutely impacts persons with disabilities who are traveling with emotional service animals from the mainland to the State of Hawaii, specifically, if you miss a connecting flight from the mainland going into the State of Hawaii.
I am attaching the information I was provided.  Our family almost missed a connecting flight from DFW to Maui, Hawaii this past summer.  We are returing in two weeks and I felt I needed a back-up plan in case we missed a flight in the future. The attachment goes into detail as to what the State of Hawaii's Animal Quarantine officials advised me what could occur in such a circumstance.
I hope information such as this will help reinforce the need for a rule requiring the animal relief areas inside the sterile/secured areas between TSA and gates, in at least every terminal.

Aloha Nui Loa
Beverly, Steven and Sophie Galarza

Title: Katrina L. Jankey
Comment:
Docket Number: # DOT-OST-2011-0182
I support the IAADP in asking the DOT to require a  minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area located inside the sterile area of each terminal.  The lack of these relief areas creates a sever handicap on people  who travel with their Service Animals .  My mother is disabled and  walking long distances is painful and a time consuming endeavor for her.  Providing this Relief Area would make travel more accessible to a large part of the population.  I also believe that signs and maps should be clearly marked with the location of all Service Animal Relief Areas.  Please help the people who rely on our Service Animals for mobility and the ability to travel.

Title: Kathy Odenbach
Comment: I have a friend who has missed a flight because there was no place for her service dog to relieve himself after my friend had checked in and was waiting to board the plane.  It is important for both the owner and the service dog that there is a place for the dog to relieve itself.

Title: Leslie Elaine Weilbacher
Comment:
I urge the DOT to require airports to locate a minimum of one Service Animal Relief Area per terminal inside the "sterile area" between the TSA security checkpoint and the gate area.
 
        The NPRM raises the DOT's concern a number of disabled passengers could miss connecting flights due to the time and distance involved if a service animal relief area is located outside the sterile area of the terminal.  After a long trip to a relief area, the disabled passenger would have to go through a screening at the TSA security checkpoint before he or she is allowed to return to the gate area with a guide, hearing or service dog.  
         
              On the way to the gate or connecting with another plane or after landing at their destination before they get their luggage would be best served by a service animal relief area that can be accessed from inside the sterile area of each terminal.

Title: The Whole Person
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Lydia
Comment:
I strongly support requiring the installation of assistance dog relief areas within each airport sterile zone (terminal). 

As a disabled handler of an assistance dog, and as a relatively frequent consumer of air travel, I can attest to the additional and unique challenges of traveling with a living assistive device.  

Although I make every effort possible to schedule my flights with the extra time required between the two to three legs I travel, I find it increasingly difficult due to the airlines' tighter scheduling. I am often faced with these choices: Withholding food and limit water intake to the possible discomfort of my assistance dog; risk an accident in the airport; pay nearly double fares to get the exact planes necessary to make time;  miss my flight and incur a $75-150 rescheduling fee and huge delays, resulting in further discomfort for both myself and my assistance dog.

Having the same relief that their handlers are provided will help ensure the professional working habits of assistance dogs.  It will alleviate further challenges created by the airlines' increasingly tight schedules.  Requiring relief areas within sterile zones will allow assistance dog teams to travel without additional hardship and will avoid the combined cost to airport, airline, and consumer of flight rescheduling or accidents within the terminal. 

I ardently support the passage of this requirement.

Title: Camille Jassny
Comment:
I am a frequent traveler and fly to many airports.  I have experienced many difficulties when traveling with my service animal.  In particular, going in and out of the sterile area and through security in order to relieve my dog.  It makes reaching connecting flights difficult and stressful.  Providing relieving areas in every terminal would diminish the stress of traveling with my animal.  I understand the need for security and I would be willing to have an escort accompany me in and out out of the sterile area.  Providing an escort is necessary when trying to reach a relieving area quickly.  Along with educating the staff about where to relieve my dog, providing signage for sighted guides would allow me to quickly find the relieving area.  Being able to reach a relieving area from any part of an airport within 10 minutes would be ideal and would save my dog and I a lot of stress.  

Thank you for your consideration

Title: Paralyzed Veterans of America
Comment: These comments are submitted on behalf of the members of the Paralyzed Veterans of America.

Title: Debra Young
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Sandra Jean Maurizio
Comment:
I would like to comment specifically regarding the service dog relief areas located at airports. I have visited a variety of service dog relief areas during my travels, some very good, and some very bad. 

I strongly feel that service dog relief areas need to be available both within and outside of the security area. My dog needs to relieve herself when we arrive at the airport or leave the airport, so having one outside of baggage claim would be helpful.

I like to arrive early for flights so my dog and I can settle in before the gate area becomes very populated. We can't do this if I cannot take her to relieve herself just before a flight. At this point I have a choice--wait outside security until the last minute so I can take her to the relief area outside the secured area, or go through security to the gate, knowing it will be a long time before she has the opportunity to relieve herself. 

I almost missed a flight because she needed to relieve herself. Thankfully, a very nice security agent waited for me and walked me through security when we returned from the relief area. 

Individuals with disabilities need to be assisted in regard to service dogs; not penalized. We would all much rather be in a position in which we were healthy and did not need service dogs.

Title: Open Doors Organization
Comment:
1. Open Doors Organization has spent much time with its consultants in creating a Guideline for SA Relief Areas and recommends the DOT review this guide for this proposal (attached).  
Some additional suggestions are as follows: 

Regarding distance and location: As people walk at different speeds, blind and sight impaired passengers must wait for an escort, and indoor traffic and obstacles such as moving carts vary, using a performance requirement most likely wouldn’t work, and we recommend using a distance requirement of ¼ mile instead.  Being that most animals are trained to relieve themselves inside but handlers do not want to encourage this behavior, we suggest you require locating SARAs outside or inside with outdoor materials (grass) but maintaining this design can be too costly.  Creating an outside area that is closed off yet inside the sterile area is a design we’ve been recommending for a few years, but seems to be harder to implement.   120 days in some cases is perhaps unreasonable, and ODO suggests 6-12 months depending on airport size and budget (however all airports were required to have at least one SARA by May of last year). 

We feel that maintaining these areas to be clean is a must. 

We also feel that all US and foreign carriers should indeed be required to assist the passenger should that be needed, with a maximum wait time of 15 minutes, as well as maps provided in all their literature.  Airports should also provide in-terminal maps.  

We also feel that fences can create barriers for many PWD, and should not be in your requirements. 

Again, our guide for airports is attached. 



2. In regard for Captioning for passengers in terminals: ODO agrees that 30 days is reasonable, and that captioning should be required.  We also support simultaneous transmission of the information through PIDS, and suggest a 2-year 100% implementation for all airports, no matter the size.

Title: Telecommunications for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, Inc. et al.
Organization Name: Telecommunications for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, Inc. et al.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Although the TSA does not have any rules requiring the ramp area to be a secured location that is off limits to passengers, all airports have an airport security plan that is approved by the TSA and almost all of those airport security plans require the entire ramp area to be a secured location.  Furthermore small and medium hub airports are geographically small enough that one service animal relief location should suffice.

Title: Anita Pratto
Comment: Airlines should be required to provide 'toilet' facilities for service animals once they have gone through the security process.  Anything else is asinine.  Would you tell a person who is helping another person that they can't have facilities once they've gone through security?  No.  Then consider this--service animals should be considered part of the 'person' they are helping and should be entitled to the same considerations and accessibility as the person they are helping.  And that should be the same for every person, whether the person needs assistance or not.

Title: Airports Council International - North America
Submitter Representative: James I. Briggs, Jr., Vice President, Legal Affairs
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Denver International Airport
Organization Name: Department of Aviation City and County of Denver
Government Agency: City and County of Denver Colorado
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Holly Ann Fletcher
Comment:
I have spent most of my life in the travel industry. I started out working for a major air carrier and later transitioned into a travel consultant. I am currently operating a travel resource site in which I provide travel information, resources and reviews for my readers. I have just recently begun to travel with a service dog. Immediately I found this to be quite a hassle when people and places are not very accommodating.  This led me to start a new project and website titled "Have Service Dog Will Travel". In my research I came across this rule proposal by the Dept. Of Transportation. I was already studying relief areas for dogs in airports, among other places. My actual proposal to you is that I would like to get personally involved in the process of evaluating the need for service dog relief areas in airports. I would like to do this in a  consultant capacity. I already travel and I have a service dog and I feel I understand the needs that have to be met. I also understand the workings of an airport and an airline both in the public sense and behind the scenes. My immediate reaction is that not all situations in all airports are identical so the new rule or regulation would need more tailoring than one would expect at first thought. I will be forwarding a more formal request to speak with someone in regards to my proposal. Thank  you in advance for your consideration.
Holly Fletcher
"Annie" 
http://www.thesavvytourist.com
http://www.haveservicedogwilltravel.com

Title: Jeanette Carlene Gulbronsen
Comment: Please make the government mandated relief areas convenient for those with disabilities that require assistance and other service dogs.  I have tried to access some areas and they are so inconvenient that my dog has had to wear a belly pad so they could do his business.

Title: Deborah Lynn Davis
Comment:
As. Person who has had to leave sterile areas to provide my service animal relief I have found it difficult both physically and time wise being able to do so with adequate time to catch my connecting flight even when factoring in multiple hour layovers for this purpose.

I not only feel that there should be at least one location within the sterile areas for service animal relief stations but such should be clearly marked on maps along with a map provided at each area where a passenger enters the airport, deplaned or boards. Escort service and even transportation should be available on request.

As it is not a modification that can happen over night there should be a plan in place at each airport to provide escort service to a suitable location in the interim. In addition in such cases where it becomes necessary to leave sterile areas a secure locked area should be provided to leave carry on baggage before leaving the sterile area.

I remember a trip a few years ago when every delay possible seemed to happen. My original flight out of home was delayed for three hours. My connecting flight was set to leave only 10 minutes after we landed and I was lucky to even make that flight. Then due to weather we were in a holding pattern for over an hour and half before being diverted to an other airport. 

When we landed we were advised not to leave the terminal as our departure would be announced at any minute and if we were not there we would need to purchase a new ticket. The piolet was kind enough to offer to take my service animal out on the tarmac for me but she was too concerned for me to be able to relax and relieve herself

Later a foreman did escort me to a suitable location so my service animal might have some relief. It had been nearly 13 hours since she had been able to do so. To get to this location it was necessary for mr to carry my checked luggage down then back up 2 flights of steep stairs despite my mobility difficulties

Title: Joan Froling
Comment: This attached comment addresses Service Animal Relief Areas, in particular with regard to the DOT adopting requirements for the design and maintenance of service animal relief areas, as well as the location of such areas.

Title: Deanna R. Lamb
Comment: I am commenting on the proposal that an area for the relief of service dogs required by the disabled be supplied in the "after checkpoint" area at airports so that if a service animal companion needs to relieve itself before a flight, the disabled person doesn't have to go back through the checkpoint to a distant area and then come back through the checkpoint again to reboard the airplane. I thankfully don't require a service animal and seldom travel by air, BUT this would seem like a no-brainer to me. I never thought about it before, since I don't have or need a service dog...but it could happen to anyone that they DO need one at some point. I am a dog lover and I can say without doubt that most well trained dogs would rather die than mess where its not allowed, but they have physical needs like people and it is just as painful for a dog to hold its business as it is for a person. What could it hurt to provide facilities for the relief of an animal just before they get on the plane? Would you rather they do their business on the plane after takeoff if they could not hold it? As a passenger, I know I WOULD RATHER they have a place near the plane to relieve themselves before they get on! Thank you in advance for having some common sense in this matter.

Title: Air Transport Association of America, Inc.
Organization Name: Air Transport Association of America, Inc.
Comment: ATA Comments.

Title: Michael
Comment: If causing airports to create a new "potty area" for service dogs is going to cost the tax payer one penny, then I disagree.  This is egregious.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Attached is a picture of a guide dog team at Logan Airport outside the security area. This place is outside of the security area and the team still has to go quite a long distance to find any relief area for the dog. 

If one needs to make a connection, relieving the dog is simply impossible as things are now, since one must exit the secure area.

Please require all airport terminals to have a service dog relief area inside and outside of security. 
  
See attached file(s)

Title: Deaf-Blind Young Adults in Action
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Fred I. Fuller
Comment: After a recent  airplain trip iI do think there should be a dog pee station  in the departure area. or at least one on each floors of the airport. Traviling with a service dog is all ready hard enought.

Title: Lawrence Smith
Comment: Having flown with my service dog I have found it is often up to a mile to get to an area for my service dog to releiv herself. Every owner of a service dog I have metcarryed a bag to pick up the dog's dropings. So it should not be much of a prroblem. One time in Orlando we had to get off the plane ,go through customs then catch a train to the outside. If I would have had another flight to catch there would have been no way to have got out and  in on time. Thank you

Title: Corinne Knight
Comment:
Relief areas for service dogs need to be placed within airport sterile zones. Forcing disabled persons to leave to relieve their dogs, then come back through security is inexcusable. Major airports will likely require one in each terminal (LAX, DEN, etc), but smaller airports could likely get by with one or two.

It's hard enough to get through security checkpoints once per trip when you're disabled. To have to do it multiple times for the sake of your dog makes a bad situation worse, and it puts undue hardship on both dog and handler. Additionally, it adds congestion to already understaffed and overcrowded security lines, which isn't fair to anyone involved.

Signage should be a basic requirement and should be no different than posting directional signs for food, bathrooms, or departure gates.

Please, for the sake of dogs and handlers, mandate these changes. It can only have positive effects on the nation's travel and our sense of equality and compassion for others.

Title: Patricia Anne Hidalgo
Comment: My son is disabled and he has a service dog. I would like to see a service dog relief area in each and every airport terminal. These areas should be located inside of the security checkpoint area so that the assistance dog user does not have to go through security again. Air passengers who are disabled often move about more slowly than non-disabled passengers. If they have to go outside of security area for their dogs to relieve themselves, it will cause them to miss their flights.

Title: Jenny Michelle Murley
Comment: Please require Airports to have a dog releif area inside. Currently, it is impossible for many people with handicaps to take their dogs outside for relief. Often there is not even a grassy area in the first place near the outside of many airports. I travel 50% of the year with my 5lb chihuahua. He is an excellent traveller and currently I am taking him into family type bathrooms (where available) to try to get him to use a disposable diaper. He is so well trained he refuses to use anything but grass. This is not healthy for him and as stressful as it is for me (someone not handicapped) as well as it being virtually impossible to take him outside if making a connecting flight, I can't imagine being blind and in an unfamiliar area like an airport trying to take my biggest ally to find a small patch of grass. Get rid of the indoor smoking areas and replace with a dog run. PLEASE!

Title: Robyn Jean Siskoff
Comment: Having recently flown to go on vacation, I was amazed at how large some of the airports are.  It can take a very long time to get from the unsecured area to the sterile area.  People that have service dogs have them because they NEED them for vision problems, mental health issues and physical disabilities, which are just some examples of what service animals are used for.  An area must be provided to them within the sterile areas of the airports in order care for their service animals' needs, not miss their next flight and not to mention the undue stress of trying to get outside and back in again.  Thank you.

Title: Karalyn Peterson
Comment: I think that service animal relief areas should be placed inside the secure area at airports and there should be at least one per terminal.  It does take quiet a bit of time to get through security, especially if the disabled person uses an assistive device.  It is not fair to the person to further discriminate against them by making them late for or miss a connecting flight because their service animal has to go to the bathroom.  Likewise, it is not fair to the animal to have the relief area so far away that he/she is uncomfortable or has an accident.

Title: Todd Allen Rohm
Comment: The ADA has made great strides or many people of disabilities. One thing that is sorely missing is a designated area - inside the secured area - in our nations airports for those of us who travel and are partnered with a service dog. It has been my experience that there has been little or no consideration on this subject. We have wheel chair accessible areas through out the public sector, yet service animals are the forgotten ones. I ask that you correct this problem, by requiring a "sterile area" with in the airports so that those disable persons with service dogs may take their animals to "relieve" themselves. The current situation discriminates against those with service animals, by requiring them to leave the secured area and then go back thru the security check, just to tend to the needs of the service dog. This is like constructing all the wheelchair accessible facilites outside the secured part of our nations airports. This lack of consideration demonstrates that persons with disabilities, partnered with a service dog are not treated fair and equal as those with other disabilities. Please put an end to this discrimination and provide for those with service dogs traveling our nations airways.

Title: Joseph William Diz
Comment:
I have a diisability that requires me to have a service dog. When I traveled to Hawaii my wife had to take the dog outside the secured area to go the bathroom and then go through security again to catch the the connecting flight to get to destination.  This is very inconvienent for my wife and for me if I was traveling alone.  Sometimes time will not allow us all that time to take the dog to the bathroom.  Please help are travel experience better for our assistance dogs and for the people with disabilities.



Thank You

Title: Hans Ake Nilson
Comment:
It is very important that there are releif areas for service dogs in sterile areas at all major airports.
I am going to Sweden every year with my service dog.

Hans

Title: Janet A. Martin
Comment: I, unfortunately, missed my flight due to the difficulties of trying  to reach the dog relief area in a very large airport between  our connecting flights.  I was not given antiquate direction by airport staff not offered assistance.  The relief area was at the opposite end of that airport and down and up various stairways or elevators. I tried running to get to the area in time but was told I had to get back to our gate because I would miss the plane.  In tears I started back and my distressed dog lost his fesses right there on the floor.  Embarrassed and angry I stooped down and picked it up and ran only to have the gate close just as I reached it.  We spent hours trying to arrange another flight (my husband is a very sick person requiring dialysis, which we had to rearrange for also) and we could not get another flight until the next day, which cost us a considerable amount of money we did not plan to spend, even with the discount offered to us by the airline.  We did not have food for our service dog not could we get any and we ended up giving him Cheerios for his meal ( at the cost of $3.00  a bow. In the hotel restaurant..  After literally running from one end of the airport to the other and back again I could not walk comfortably for several days.  I reported the incident to the manager of one airline, and am very pleased to say,  "she made arrangements for a dog relief area at the AirTran terminal".  I do not know if the other airlines did likewise. Trying to get a service dog to a remote relief area creates such a hardship for both the dog and the partner. These dog relief areas are extremely important to service dog teams.  Please take these factors into consideration as you vote on the document ID DOT-OST-2011-0182-0001

Title: B. Skinner Grace-Hansen
Comment: Traveling with a disability is hard enough... please offer these helpers adequate facilities.

Title: Michael Josiah Grantham
Comment:
Please consider requiring a service animal relief area within the sterile area of public airports.

As a manual wheelchair user, having to time the relief of my service dog before and between flights is often quit difficult. Traveling through the security check point often requires more time and inconvenience for me. Being unable to stand, I will always require a physical pat down. In addition, I am usually the first boarded onto an airplane and the last to deplane. Not having a service animal relief area in the sterile area means potentially extra hours of time between bathroom breaks for my dog. For cross country flights, this can mean quite long length of time before between relief breaks.

In addition, having to leave the sterile area for animal relief puts me at risk of missing my connecting flight. The difficulty and amount of time required to go through screening often is longer than airlines schedule for their passengers and since it is already difficult for me to move quickly, this can be prohibitive.

I also think it's worth pointing out that by requiring a service animal relief area within the sterile area, you will be helping TSA security and efficiency.

Each time I travel through the security check-point requires a halt in screening of able bodied passengers, then requires an extra person to perform a lengthy pat down. By reducing the number of times I need to pass through security, you are reducing the same number of wheelchair screenings required of TSA agents. Fewer screenings directly means fewer slow downs and better security.

In addition to making flying accessable for service dog handlers, it will benifit all passengers with better efficiency and safer travel. I believe it to be a win for everyone.

Sincerly,

Michael Grantham

Title: Nancy Lee
Comment: Please support providing an area of relief for service animals inside airports.

Title: Bryan Michael Gearry
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
Office of the Secretary
49 CFR Part 27
RIN 2105-AD91
[Docket No. DOT-OST-2011-0182]

I am a Guide Dog user and frequent many airports in this nation. I live in Alaska and have to travel out of the state on occasion. As you know you must travel a lot to get to the contiguous US.By the time I get to any connecting airport, it already has been up to 6 1/2 hours. That is a long time and that is just the first leg of the flight. HNL has made a great strides in this. They have a very easy place for this. SEA is looking into changing what they currently have, but have not made any improvements at this date. I know have to schedule at least 4-5 hour layovers between connections to relive my Guide Dog. It is so simple to accommodate this situation. At SEA I have given them suggestions to make that is at little or no cost. ATL, ORD, & ANC have not shown any interest in remedying this matter. Please give this some attention. This so easy to remedy. Thank you, Bryan Gearry.

Title: Grace Ann Opolski
Comment: As a disabled person who relies on my service dog of 8 years to walk, balance me, retrieve dropped items and a multitude of physical restrictions he helps me with, I find traveling to be a challenge possible only because of my service dog.  I have had to leave the terminal to toilet my dog and go all thru security again, needlessly.  I believe it is as essential to have a relief area for service dogs in each terminal as much as public toilets are provided, more so because so many of us are so limited, not forgetting the many wounded warriors that return from deployment with not only PTSD, but missing limbs, etc. It is a reality today that airports should and other facilities to travel should be required to accomodate service dog teams. Please try to put yourselves in our place and imagine the difficulties of even small efforts.  Thank you.

Title: Jennifer
Comment: This is the best idea I have heard in a very long time.  I just traveled from CA to CT with my service dog.  Being disabled I have no chance in the 30 minutes I had to get my service dog out through security, to relief area (if there even is one) outside and then back through the security line.  To go through security I have to take off all of his vests, harness, leash act to get through without beeping.  I can barely walk without him and doing this in a 30 minute time crunch is impossible.  Even with a longer lay-over it's just too hard for me to do this.  My dog is well trained and will not go inside but as he gets older I am afraid.  Please please I am begging you to pass this with no objections.  Being disabled is hard enough but to have to worry about where to take him, going through security is just too hard.  I implore you do pass this measure.  I am available to come and speak if necessary

Title: Heidi Ann Eagleton
Comment:
As of Nov. 2010 the only relief area for my dog in the Denver airport was one the airport had and that was IMPOSSIBLE to get to. 
Due to the need to wait for assistance off the plane and to my next flight, not only was there no time to take Hazel for a break but I missed my flights.  Relief areas need to be in ea. airline terminal in the sterile zone.  Hazel ended up 'holding it for 15 hours!!!

Title: Alan E. Safier
Comment: When I am in an airport with my guide dog, it is difficult to park my dog, especially if I need to go through security again.  It would be nice if we could find a grass area without going through security.

Title: Denver International Airport
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: There definitely should NOT be a rule to have only one post-security service dog relief area per terminal, as some terminals are gigantic!  One terminal I frequent has gates that are literally over a half-mile apart from each other, still in the same terminal.  It is a very long walk!  Almost always, my flights leave from the gates that are over a half-mile from security.  If I were to have a connecting flight at this terminal and the gates were near each other but the only service dog relief area was a half-mile from them, that would be very hard to get to.  As it is, I have to use the moving sidewalks just to be able to walk the half-mile-long corridor that runs in between sections of the terminal, otherwise I would arrive at my gate out of breath, breathing from my mouth for the next ten minutes as I sat at the gate (I know because it happened the first time I used this terminal).  (A relief spot cannot be put in that corridor because it is underground, so if there was only one spot, it would be at either end.  Therefore, a terminal like this needs to have two relief spots, one at either end, where it wouldn't take more than fifteen minutes to get to the relief areas from any gates in the same end.)  Thank you!

Title: Jill P.
Comment:
My service dog and I travel by air usually more than 6 times per year. Planning these trips can be difficult. I try not to have a total flight time over 6 hours so that I can "potty" my service dog on the way into the airport and on the way out of the airport. 

This often means I have overnight stays in cities that are not my destination. For example, to fly from the east to west coast, I have to build in a stop in the midwest. This adds travel time and cost.

Delays are horrible - especially when they ask you to stay in the gate area in case they get clearance to load and take off quickly. There are always plenty of human restrooms nearby, but I risk missing my flight if I try to take my dog outside the sterile area to relieve himself.

Having a service dog relief area within a 10 minute walk of every gate would be a huge improvement! Remember that many of those using service dogs are doing so because of difficulty getting around. What would be a 10 minute walk for a regular passenger, might take 20-30 minutes for someone who has to walk slowly due to a disease like MS (multiple sclerosis), COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or severe arthritis.

When I get to a service animal rest area, I want the surface to be non-skid (a safety issue for my dog and those with mobility challenges). I would like it to be easy to clean (maybe a poured surface with a drain in the center). I realize grass is difficult indoors and to keep clean, but maybe some tiny gravel or shavings would work. (I used to clean up at a yearly dog show in the Atlantic City Convention Hall. They would put a 6' x 12' chain link pen and add a layer of shavings. The dogs would relieve themselves on the shavings. It was easy clean up and would be easy to periodically totally replace.)

Thanks for considering my suggestions.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: In reviewing the proposed policy, it appears that more concrete language is needed to specify the protege's ability to withdraw from the program voluntarily.  There is currently only an indirect reference.  Additionally, there does not appear to be any language stating whether a mentor can receive reimbursement for MP program costs; whether it be direct, or through credit against subcontracting goals.  It appears that should be added as well.
